text: <Gene>A Drosophila insulin-like peptide promotes growth during nonfeeding states.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In metazoans, tissue growth relies on the availability of nutrients--stored internally or obtained from the environment--and the resulting activation of insulin/IGF signaling (IIS).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In Drosophila, growth is mediated by seven Drosophila insulin-like peptides (Dilps), acting through a canonical IIS pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>During the larval period, animals feed and Dilps produced by the brain couple nutrient uptake with systemic growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We show here that, during metamorphosis, when feeding stops, a specific DILP (Dilp6) is produced by the fat body and relays the growth signal.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of DILP6 during pupal development is controlled by the steroid hormone ecdysone.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Remarkably, DILP6 expression is also induced upon starvation, and both its developmental and environmental expression require the Drosophila FoxO transcription factor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study reveals a specific class of ILPs induced upon metabolic stress that promotes growth in conditions of nutritional deprivation or following developmentally induced cessation of feeding.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Brat promotes stem cell differentiation via control of a bistable switch that restricts BMP signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Drosophila ovarian germline stem cells (GSCs) are maintained by Dpp signaling and the Pumilio (Pum) and Nanos (Nos) translational repressors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Upon division, Dpp signaling is extinguished, and Nos is downregulated in one daughter cell, causing it to switch to a differentiating cystoblast (CB).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, downstream effectors of Pum-Nos remain unknown, and how CBs lose their responsiveness to Dpp is unclear.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we identify Brain Tumor (Brat) as a potent differentiation factor and target of Pum-Nos regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Brat is excluded from GSCs by Pum-Nos but functions with Pum in CBs to translationally repress distinct targets, including the Mad and dMyc mRNAs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Regulation of both targets simultaneously lowers cellular responsiveness to Dpp signaling, forcing the cell to become refractory to the self-renewal signal.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mathematical modeling elucidates bistability of cell fate in the Brat-mediated system, revealing how autoregulation of GSC number can arise from Brat coupling extracellular Dpp regulation to intracellular interpretation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Contribution of STAT4 gene single-nucleotide polymorphism to systemic lupus erythematosus in the Polish population.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The STAT4 has been found to be a susceptible gene in the development of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) in various populations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>There are evident population differences in the context of clinical manifestations of SLE, therefore we investigated the prevalence of the STAT4 G > C (rs7582694) polymorphism in patients with SLE (n = 253) and controls (n = 521) in a sample of the Polish population.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We found that patients with the STAT4 C/G and CC genotypes exhibited a 1.583-fold increased risk of SLE incidence (95 % CI = 1.168-2.145, p = 0.003), with OR for the C/C versus C/G and G/G genotypes was 1.967 (95 % CI = 1.152-3.358, p = 0.0119).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The OR for the STAT4 C allele frequency showed a 1.539-fold increased risk of SLE (95 % CI = 1.209-1.959, p = 0.0004).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We also observed an increased frequency of STAT4 C/C and C/G genotypes in SLE patients with renal symptoms OR = 2.259 (1.365-3.738, p = 0.0014), (p (corr) = 0.0238) and in SLE patients with neurologic manifestations OR = 2.867 (1.467-5.604, p = 0.0016), (p (corr) = 0.0272).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, we found a contribution of STAT4 C/C and C/G genotypes to the presence of the anti-snRNP Ab OR = 3.237 (1.667-6.288, p = 0.0003), (p (corr) = 0.0051) and the presence of the anti-Scl-70 Ab OR = 2.665 (1.380-5.147, p = 0.0028), (p (corr) = 0.0476).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our studies confirmed an association of the STAT4 C (rs7582694) variant with the development of SLE and occurrence of some clinical manifestations of the disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The hereditary spastic paraplegia protein strumpellin: characterisation in neurons and of the effect of disease mutations on WASH complex assembly and function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in the gene encoding strumpellin cause autosomal dominant hereditary spastic paraplegia (HSP), in which there is degeneration of corticospinal tract axons.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Strumpellin is a component of the WASH complex, an actin-regulating complex that is recruited to endosomes by interactions with the retromer complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The WASH complex and its relationship to retromer have not been fully characterised in neurons, and the molecular pathological mechanism of strumpellin mutation is unclear.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we demonstrate that the WASH complex assembles in the brain, where it interacts with retromer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Members of both complexes co-localise with each other and with endosomes in primary cortical neurons, and are present in somato-dendritic and axonal compartments.</Gene>
<Gene>We show that strumpellin is not required for normal transferrin receptor traffic, but is required for the correct subcellular distribution of the b-2-adrenergic receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, strumpellin disease mutations do not affect its incorporation into the WASH complex or its subcellular localisation, nor do they have a dominant effect on functions of the WASH complex, including regulation of endosomal tubulation, transferrin receptor traffic or b-2-adrenergic receptor localisation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Models of the WASH complex indicate that it contains a single strumpellin molecule, so in patients with strumpellin mutations, complexes containing wild-type and mutant strumpellin should be present in equal numbers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In most cell types this would provide sufficient functional WASH to allow normal cellular physiology.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, owing to the demands on membrane traffic imposed by their exceptionally long axons, we suggest that corticospinal neurons are especially vulnerable to reductions in functional WASH.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The immunoglobulin domain of the sodium channel b3 subunit contains a surface-localized disulfide bond that is required for homophilic binding.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The b subunits of voltage-gated sodium (Na(v)) channels possess an extracellular immunoglobulin (Ig) domain that is related to the L1 family of cell-adhesion molecules (CAMs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that in HEK293 cells, secretion of the free Ig domain of the b3 subunit is reduced significantly when it is coexpressed with the full-length b3 and b1 subunits but not with the b2 subunit.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using immunoprecipitation, we show that the b3 subunit can mediate trans homophilic-binding via its Ig domain and that the b3-Ig domain can associate heterophilically with the b1 subunit.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Evolutionary tracing analysis and structural modeling identified a cluster of surface-localized amino acids fully conserved between the Ig domains of all known b3 and b1 sequences.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A notable feature of this conserved surface cluster is the presence of two adjacent cysteine residues that previously we have suggested may form a disulfide bond.</Gene>

<Gene>We now confirm the presence of the disulfide bond in b3 using mass spectrometry, and we show that its integrity is essential for the association of the full-length, membrane-anchored b3 subunit with itself.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, selective reduction of this surface disulfide bond did not inhibit homophilic binding of the purified b3-Ig domain in free solution.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hence, the disulfide bond itself is unlikely to be part of the homophilic binding site.</Gene>
<Gene>Rather, we suggest that its integrity ensures the Ig domain of the membrane-tethered b3 subunit adopts the correct orientation for productive association to occur in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Scribble is required for normal epithelial cell-cell contacts and lumen morphogenesis in the mammalian lung.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>During lung development, proper epithelial cell arrangements are critical for the formation of an arborized network of tubes.</Gene>
<Gene>Each tube requires a lumen, the diameter of which must be tightly regulated to enable optimal lung function.</Gene>

<Gene>Lung branching and lumen morphogenesis require close epithelial cell-cell contacts that are maintained as a result of adherens junctions, tight junctions and by intact apical-basal (A/B) polarity.</Gene>
<Gene>However, the molecular mechanisms that maintain epithelial cohesion and lumen diameter in the mammalian lung are unknown.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we show that Scribble, a protein implicated in planar cell polarity (PCP) signalling, is necessary for normal lung morphogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lungs of the Scrib mouse mutant Circletail (Crc) are abnormally shaped with fewer airways, and these airways often lack a visible, 'open' lumen.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mechanistically we show that Scrib genetically interacts with the core PCP gene Vangl2 in the developing lung and that the distribution of PCP pathway proteins and Rho mediated cytoskeletal modification is perturbed in Scrib(Crc/Crc) lungs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However A/B polarity, which is disrupted in Drosophila Scrib mutants, is largely unaffected.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Notably, we find that Scrib mediates functions not attributed to other PCP proteins in the lung.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Specifically, Scrib localises to both adherens and tight junctions of lung epithelia and knockdown of Scrib in lung explants and organotypic cultures leads to reduced cohesion of lung epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Live imaging of Scrib knockdown lungs shows that Scrib does not affect bud bifurcation, as previously shown for the PCP protein Celsr1, but is required to maintain epithelial cohesion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To understand the mechanism leading to reduced cell-cell association, we show that Scrib associates with b-catenin in embryonic lung and the sub-cellular distribution of adherens and tight junction proteins is perturbed in mutant lung epithelia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data reveal that Scrib is required for normal lung epithelial organisation and lumen morphogenesis by maintaining cell-cell contacts.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus we reveal novel and important roles for Scrib in lung development operating via the PCP pathway, and in regulating junctional complexes and cell cohesion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>What can naturally occurring mutations tell us about Ca(v)1.x channel function?</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Voltage-gated Ca2+ channels allow for Ca2+-dependent intracellular signaling by directly mediating Ca2+ ion influx, by physical coupling to intracellular</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Ca2+ release channels or functional coupling to other ion channels such as Ca2+ activated potassium channels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>L-type Ca2+ channels that comprise the family of Ca(v)1 channels are expressed in many electrically excitable tissues and are characterized by their unique sensitivity to dihydropyridines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this issue, we summarize genetic defects in L-type Ca2+ channels and analyze their role in human diseases (Ca2+ channelopathies); e.g. mutations in Ca(v)1.2 a1 cause Timothy and Brugada syndrome, mutations in Ca(v)1.3 a1 are linked to sinoatrial node dysfunction and deafness while mutations in</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ca(v)1.4 a1 are associated with X-linked retinal disorders such as an incomplete form of congenital stationary night blindness.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Herein, we also put the mutations underlying the channel's dysfunction into the structural context of the pore-forming a1 subunit.</Gene>

<Gene>This analysis highlights the importance of combining functional data with structural analysis to gain a deeper understanding for the disease pathophysiology as well as for physiological channel function.</Gene>
<Gene>This article is part of a Special Issue entitled: Calcium channels.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Gastric expression of plasminogen activator inhibitor (PAI)-1 is associated with hyperphagia and obesity in mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The adipokine plasminogen activator inhibitor (PAI)-1 is increased in plasma of obese individuals and exhibits increased expression in the stomachs of individuals infected with Helicobacter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To investigate the relevance of gastric PAI-1, we used 1.1 kb of the H(+)/K(+)b subunit promoter to overexpress PAI-1 specifically in mouse gastric parietal cells (PAI-1-H/Kb mice).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We studied the physiological, biochemical, and behavioral characteristics of these and mice null for PAI-1 or a putative receptor, urokinase plasminogen activator receptor (uPAR).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PAI-1-H/Kb mice had increased plasma concentrations of PAI-1 and increased body mass, adiposity, and hyperphagia compared with wild-type mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the latter, food intake was inhibited by cholecystokinin (CCK)8s, but PAI-1-H/Kb mice were insensitive to the satiating effects of CCK8s.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PAI-1-H/Kb mice also had significantly reduced expression of c-fos in the nucleus tractus solitarius in response to CCK8s and refeeding compared with wild-type mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Exogenous PAI-1 reversed the effects of CCK8s on food intake and c-fos levels in the nucleus tractus solitarius of wild-type mice, but not uPAR-null mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Infection of C57BL/6 mice with Helicobacter felis increased gastric abundance of PAI-1 and reduced the satiating effects of CCK8s, whereas the response to CCK8s was maintained in infected PAI-1-null mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In cultured vagal afferent neurons, PAI-1 inhibited stimulation of neuropeptide Y type 2 receptor (Y2R) expression by CCK8s.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, gastric expression of PAI-1 is associated with hyperphagia, moderate obesity, and resistance to the satiating effects of CCK indicating a new role in suppressing signals from the upper gut that inhibit food intake.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The neuropilin 1 cytoplasmic domain is required for VEGF-A-dependent arteriogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Neuropilin 1 (NRP1) plays an important but ill-defined role in VEGF-A signaling and vascular morphogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that mice with a knockin mutation that ablates the NRP1 cytoplasmic tail (Nrp1(cyto)) have normal angiogenesis but impaired developmental and adult arteriogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The arteriogenic defect was traced to the absence of a PDZ-dependent interaction between NRP1 and VEGF receptor 2 (VEGFR2) complex and synectin, which delayed trafficking of endocytosed VEGFR2 from Rab5+ to EAA1+ endosomes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This led to increased PTPN1 (PTP1b)-mediated dephosphorylation of VEGFR2 at Y(1175), the site involved in activating ERK signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Nrp1(cyto) mutation also impaired endothelial tubulogenesis in vitro, which could be rescued by expressing full-length NRP1 or constitutively active ERK.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results demonstrate that the NRP1 cytoplasmic domain promotes VEGFR2 trafficking in a PDZ-dependent manner to regulate arteriogenic ERK signaling and establish a role for NRP1 in VEGF-A signaling during vascular morphogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Telomerase downregulation induces proapoptotic genes expression and initializes breast cancer cells apoptosis followed by DNA fragmentation in a cell type dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The aim of the study was to analyze the consequence of silencing genes coding for the key subunits of the telomerase complex, i.e. TERT, TERC and TP1 in human breast cancer MCF7 and MDA-MB-231cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The transfection was performed using Lipofectamine2000 and pooled siRNAs.</Gene>
<Gene>The cytotoxic and/or antiproliferative effect of siRNA was measured by the SRB assay, the cell cycle was analysed by flow cytometry and DNA fragmentation by TUNEL analysis.</Gene>
<Gene>Telomerase activity was assessed by TRAP, followed by PAGE and ELISA assays.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Telomerase downregulation was also assessed using qPCR in order to estimate the changes in the expression profile of genes engaged in apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It was revealed that treatment of breast cancer cells with different siRNAs (100 nM) resulted in a cell type and time-dependent effects.</Gene>
<Gene>The downregulation of telomerase subunits was followed by reduction of telomerase activity down to almost 60% compared to control cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, a significant effect was only observed when the TERT subunit was downregulated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Its silencing resulted in a significant (p<0.05) increase of apoptosis (over 10% in MCF7 and about 5% in MDA-MB-231 cells, corresponding to the Annexin V assay) and DNA fragmentation (almost 30% in MCF7 and over 25% in MDA-MB-231 cells).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, also several proapoptotic genes were induced after the downregulation of the key telomerase subunit, including Bax, Bik or caspase-1 and caspase-14, as well as NGFR and TNFSF10 which were upregulated twice and more.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Arabidopsis CHROMOSOME TRANSMISSION FIDELITY 7 (AtCTF7/ECO1) is required for DNA repair, mitosis and meiosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The proper transmission of DNA in dividing cells is crucial for the survival of eukaryotic organisms.</Gene>
<Gene>During cell division, faithful segregation of replicated chromosomes requires their tight attachment, known as sister chromatid cohesion, until anaphase.</Gene>
<Gene>Sister chromatid cohesion is established during S-phase in a process requiring an acetyltransferase that in yeast is known as Establishment of cohesion 1 (Eco1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inactivation of Eco1 typically disrupts chromosome segregation and homologous recombination-dependent DNA repair in dividing cells, ultimately resulting in lethality.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report here the isolation and detailed characterization of two homozygous T-DNA insertion mutants for the Arabidopsis thaliana Eco1 homolog, CHROMOSOME TRANSMISSION FIDELITY 7/ESTABLISHMENT OF COHESION 1 (CTF7/ECO1), called ctf7-1 and ctf7-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutants exhibited dwarfism, poor anther development and sterility.</Gene>

<Gene>Analysis of somatic tissues by flow cytometry, scanning electron microscopy and quantitative real-time PCR identified defects in DNA repair and cell division, including an increase in the area of leaf epidermal cells, an increase in DNA content and the upregulation of genes involved in DNA repair including BRCA1 and PARP2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>No significant change was observed in the expression of genes that influence entry into the endocycle.</Gene>
<Gene>Analysis of meiocytes identified changes in chromosome morphology and defective segregation; the abundance of chromosomal-bound cohesion subunits was also reduced.</Gene>
<Gene>Transcript levels for several meiotic genes, including the recombinase genes DMC1 and RAD51C and the S-phase licensing factor CDC45 were elevated in mutant anthers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together our results demonstrate that Arabidopsis CTF7/ECO1 plays important roles in the preservation of genome integrity and meiosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Loss of PPARg expression in mammary secretory epithelial cells creates a pro-breast tumorigenic environment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Breast cancer is the leading cause of new cancer diagnoses among women.</Gene>
<Gene>Using peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (PPAR)g((+/-))</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>mice, we showed normal expression of PPARg was critical to stop 7,12-dimethylbenz[a]anthracene (DMBA)-induced breast tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PPARg is expressed in many breast cell types including mammary secretory epithelial (MSE) cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MSEs proliferate as required during pregnancy, and undergo apoptosis or reversible transdifferentiation during involution once lactation is complete.</Gene>
<Gene>Thus, MSE-specific loss of PPARg was hypothesized to enhance DMBA-mediated breast tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To test this, MSE cell-specific PPARg knockout (PPARg-MSE KO) and control (PPARg-WT) mice were generated, mated and allowed to nurse for three days.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>One week after involution, dams were treated with DMBA to initiate breast tumors, and randomized on week 7 to continue receiving a normal chow diet (DMBA Only: PPARg-WT, n = 15; PPARg-MSE KO, n = 25) or one supplemented with a PPARg activating drug (DMBA + ROSI: PPARg-WT, n = 17; PPARg-MSE KO, n = 24), and monitored for changes in breast tumor outcomes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PPARg-MSE KOs had significantly lower overall survival and decreased mammary tumor latency as compared to PPARg-WT controls.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PPARg activation significantly reduced DMBA-mediated malignant mammary tumor volumes irrespective of genotype.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MSE-specific PPARg loss resulted in decreased mammary gland expression of PTEN and Bax, increased superoxide anion production, and elevated serum eotaxin and RANTES, creating a protumorigenic environment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, PPARg activation in MSEs delayed mammary tumor growth in part by down-regulating Cox-1, Cox-2 and cyclin D1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, these studies highlight a protective role of MSE-specific PPARg during breast tumorigenesis, and support a novel chemotherapeutic role of PPARg activation in breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Common polymorphism (81Val>Ile) and rare mutations (257Arg>Ser and 335Ile>Ser) of the MC3R gene in obese Polish children and adolescents.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The predisposing role to human obesity of the MC3R gene polymorphism is controversial.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this report we present the first study focused on the search for the MC3R polymorphism in the Polish population.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Altogether 257 obese children and adolescents (RBMI>120) and 94 adults, who were never obese or overweight (BMI<25), were studied.</Gene>
<Gene>For all subjects the entire coding sequence was analyzed by direct DNA sequencing.</Gene>
<Gene>One common polymorphism (81Val>Ile) and two rare mutations (257Arg>Ser and 335Ile>Ser) were identified.</Gene>
<Gene>The common polymorphism was widely distributed in the obese and control cohorts, while the mutations were identified in four obese subjects only.</Gene>
<Gene>In case of the 335Ile>Ser substitution a three-generation family, consisting of 20 members, was also analyzed.</Gene>
<Gene>It was found that all carriers of the 335Ser mutation were obese, but among non-carriers obese subjects also were found.</Gene>
<Gene>Our study suggests that the predisposing effect to obesity of the 81Ile polymorphic variant is rather unlikely.</Gene>
<Gene>With regard to the studied rare mutations we suggest that the 335Ser allele may have a small predisposing effect.</Gene>
<Gene>Cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis protects liver sinusoidal endothelial cells in acute liver injured mice.</Gene>

<Gene>Cultured mycelium Cordyceps sinensis (CMCS) was widely used for a variety of diseases including liver injury, the current study aims to investigate the protective effects of CMCS on liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSECs) in acute injury liver and related action mechanisms.</Gene>
<Gene>The mice were injected intraperitoneally with lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and D-galactosamine (D-GalN).</Gene>
<Gene>39 male BABL/c mice were randomly divided into four groups: normal control, model control, CMCS treatment and 1,10-phenanthroline treatment groups.</Gene>
<Gene>The Serum liver function parameters including alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels were assayed with the commercial kit.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The inflammation and scaffold structure in liver were stained with hematoxylin and eosin and silver staining respectively.</Gene>
<Gene>The LSECs and sub-endothelial basement membrane were observed with the scanning and transmission electronic microscope.</Gene>
<Gene>The protein expressions of intercellular adhesion molecule-1 (ICAM-1) and vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1) in liver were analyzed with Western blotting.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of von Willebrand factor (vWF) was investigated with immunofluorescence staining.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The lipid peroxidation indicators including antisuperoxideanion (ASAFR), hydroxyl free radical (.OH), superoxide dismutase (SOD), malondialdehyde and glutathione S-transferase (GST) were determined with kits, and matrix metalloproteinase-2 and 9 (MMP-2/9) activities in liver were analyzed with gelatin zymography and in situ fluorescent zymography respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The model mice had much higher serum levels of ALT and AST than the normal mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Compared to that in the normal control, more severe liver inflammation and hepatocyte apoptosis, worse hepatic lipid peroxidation demonstrated by the increased ASAFR, .OH</Gene>
<Gene>and</Gene>

<Gene>MDA, but decreased SOD and GST, increased MMP-2/9 activities and VCAM-1, ICAM-1 and vWF expressions, which revealed obvious LSEC injury and scaffold structure broken, were shown in the model control.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Compared with the model group, CMCS and 1,10-phenanthroline significantly improved serum ALT/AST, attenuated hepatic inflammation and improved peroxidative injury in liver, decreased MMP-2/9 activities in liver tissue, improved integration of scaffold structure, and decreased protein expression of VCAM-1 and ICAM-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CMCS could protect LSECs from injury and maintain the microvasculature integration in acute injured liver of mice induced by LPS/D-GalN.</Gene>
<Gene>Its action mechanism was associated with the down-regulation of MMP-2/9 activities and inhibition of peroxidation in injured liver.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Loss of Bak enhances lymphocytosis but does not ameliorate thrombocytopaenia in BCL-2 transgenic mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bax and Bak are critical effectors of apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although both are widely expressed and usually functionally redundant, recent studies suggest that Bak has particular importance in certain cell types.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Genetic and biochemical studies indicate that Bak activation is prevented primarily by Mcl-1 and Bcl-xL, whereas Bax is held in check by all pro-survival Bcl-2 homologues, including Bcl-2 itself.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we have investigated whether loss of Bak or elevated Mcl-1 modulates haemopoietic abnormalities provoked by overexpression of Bcl-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Mcl-1 transgene had little impact, probably because the expression level was insufficient to effectively reduce Bak activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, loss of Bak enhanced lymphocytosis in vavP-BCL-2 transgenic mice and increased resistance of their thymocytes to some cytotoxic agents, implying that Bak-specific signals can be triggered in certain lymphoid populations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nevertheless, lack of Bak had no significant impact on thymic abnormalities in vavP-BCL-2tg mice, which kinetic analysis suggested was due to accumulation of self-reactive thymocytes that resist deletion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intriguingly, although Bak(-/-) mice have elevated platelet counts, Bak(-/-)vavP-BCL-2 mice, like vavP-BCL-2 littermates, were thrombocytopaenic.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To clarify why, the vavP-BCL-2 platelet phenotype was scrutinised more closely.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Platelet life span was found to be elevated in vavP-BCL-2 mice, which should have provoked thrombocytosis, as in Bak(-/-) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis of bone marrow chimaeric mice suggested the low platelet phenotype was due principally to extrinsic factors.</Gene>
<Gene>Following splenectomy, blood platelets remained lower in vavP-BCL-2 than wild-type mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, in Rag1(-/-) BCL-2tg mice, platelet levels were normal, implying that elevated lymphocytes are primarily responsible for BCL-2tg-induced thrombocytopaenia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The -930A>G polymorphism of the CYBA gene is associated with premature coronary artery disease. A case-control study and gene-risk factors interactions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are involved in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease (CAD).</Gene>
<Gene>NADPH oxidases are the main source of ROS in the vasculature.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>p22phox is a critical component of vascular NADPH oxidases and is encoded by the CYBA (cytochrome b245 alpha) gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The -930A>G CYBA polymorphism (rs9932581:A>G) modulates the activity of the CYBA promoter, and influences CYBA transcriptional activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The aim of the present study was to analyze a possible association between the -930A>G polymorphism and CAD and to search for gene-traditional risk factors interactions.</Gene>
<Gene>480 subjects were studied: 240 patients with premature CAD, 240 age and sex matched blood donors.</Gene>
<Gene>The -930A>G polymorphism was genotyped using the TaqMan - Pre-designed SNP Genotyping Assay (Applied Biosystems).</Gene>
<Gene>The -930G allele carrier state was a risk factor for CAD (OR 2.03, 95% CI 1.21-3.44, P=0.007).</Gene>
<Gene>A synergistic effect of the -930G allele with overweight/obesity (BMI --25) and cigarette smoking was found.</Gene>

<Gene>The estimated CAD risk for BMI --25 and the -930G allele interaction was about 160% greater than that predicted by assuming additivity of the effects, and about 40% greater for interaction of cigarette smoking and the -930G allele.</Gene>
<Gene>Overweight/obesity was a risk factor for CAD only in the -930G allele carriers (P<10(-10)) but not in the AA homozygotes (P=1.00).</Gene>
<Gene>In conclusion the -930A>G CYBA polymorphism is associated with CAD in the Polish population.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The -930G allele carriers are particularly at risk of consequences of obesity and tobacco smoke exposure.</Gene>
<Gene>Disruption of the temporally regulated cloaca endodermal b-catenin signaling causes anorectal malformations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cloaca is temporally formed and eventually divided by the urorectal septum (URS) during urogenital and anorectal organ development.</Gene>
<Gene>Although congenital malformations, such as anorectal malformations (ARMs), are frequently observed during this process, the underlying pathogenic mechanisms remain unclear.</Gene>
<Gene>b-Catenin is a critical component of canonical Wnt signaling and is essential for the regulation of cell differentiation and morphogenesis during embryogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of b-catenin is observed in endodermal epithelia, including URS epithelia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We modulated the b-catenin gene conditionally in endodermal epithelia by utilizing tamoxifen-inducible Cre driver line (Shh(CreERT2)).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both b-catenin loss- and gain-of-function (LOF and GOF) mutants displayed abnormal clefts in the perineal region and hypoplastic elongation of the URS.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The mutants also displayed reduced cell proliferation in the URS mesenchyme.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, the b-catenin GOF mutants displayed reduced apoptosis and subsequently increased apoptosis in the URS epithelium.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This instability possibly resulted in reduced expression levels of differentiation markers, such as keratin 1 and filaggrin, in the perineal epithelia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of bone morphogenetic protein (Bmp) genes, such as Bmp4 and Bmp7, was also ectopically induced in the epithelia of the URS in the b-catenin GOF mutants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of the Msx2 gene and phosphorylated-Smad1/5/8, possible readouts of Bmp signaling, was also increased in the mutants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, we introduced an additional mutation for a Bmp receptor gene: BmprIA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Shh(CreERT2/+); b-catenin(flox(ex3)/+); BmprIA(flox/-) mutants displayed partial restoration of URS elongation compared with the b-catenin GOF mutants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results indicate that some ARM phenotypes in the b-catenin GOF mutants were caused by abnormal Bmp signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The current analysis revealed the close relation of endodermal b-catenin signaling to the ARM phenotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results are considered to shed light on the pathogenic mechanisms of human ARMs.</Gene>
<Gene>Dysregulation of Wnt inhibitory factor 1 (Wif1) expression resulted in aberrant Wnt-b-catenin signaling and cell death of the cloaca endoderm, and anorectal malformations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In mammalian urorectal development, the urorectal septum (urs) descends from the ventral body wall to the cloaca membrane (cm) to partition the cloaca into urogenital sinus and rectum.</Gene>
<Gene>Defective urs growth results in human congenital anorectal malformations (ARMs), and their pathogenic mechanisms are unclear.</Gene>
<Gene>Recent studies only focused on the importance of urs mesenchyme proliferation, which is induced by endoderm-derived Sonic Hedgehog (Shh).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we showed that the programmed cell death of the apical urs and proximal cm endoderm is particularly crucial for the growth of urs during septation.</Gene>
<Gene>The apoptotic endoderm was closely associated with the tempo-spatial expression of Wnt inhibitory factor 1 (Wif1), which is an inhibitor of Wnt-b-catenin signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In Wif1(lacZ/lacZ) mutant mice and cultured urorectum with exogenous Wif1, cloaca septation was defective with undescended urs and hypospadias-like phenotypes, and such septation defects were also observed in Shh(-/-) mutants and in endodermal b-catenin gain-of-function (GOF) mutants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, Wif1 and Shh were expressed in a complementary manner in the cloaca endoderm, and Wif1 was ectopically expressed in the urs and cm associated with excessive endodermal apoptosis and septation defects in Shh(-/-) mutants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, apoptotic cells were markedly reduced in the endodermal b-catenin GOF mutant embryos, which counteracted the inhibitory effects of Wif1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken altogether, these data suggest that regulated expression of Wif1 is critical for the growth of the urs during cloaca septation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hence, Wif1 governs cell apoptosis of urs endoderm by repressing b-catenin signal, which may facilitate the protrusion of the underlying proliferating mesenchymal cells towards the cm for cloaca septation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Dysregulation of this endodermal Shh-Wif1-b-catenin signaling axis contributes to ARM pathogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Structural mechanisms determining inhibition of the collagen receptor DDR1 by selective and multi-targeted type II kinase inhibitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The discoidin domain receptors (DDRs), DDR1 and DDR2, form a unique subfamily of receptor tyrosine kinases that are activated by the binding of triple-helical collagen.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Excessive signaling by DDR1 and DDR2 has been linked to the progression of various human diseases, including fibrosis, atherosclerosis and cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We report the inhibition of these unusual receptor tyrosine kinases by the multi-targeted cancer drugs imatinib and ponatinib, as well as the selective type II inhibitor DDR1-IN-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ponatinib is identified as the more potent molecule, which inhibits DDR1 and DDR2 with an IC50 of 9nM. Co-crystal structures of human DDR1 reveal a DFG-out conformation (DFG, Asp-Phe-Gly) of the kinase domain that is stabilized by an unusual salt bridge between the activation loop and aD helix.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Differences to Abelson kinase (ABL) are observed in the DDR1 P-loop, where a b-hairpin replaces the cage-like structure of ABL.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>P-loop residues in DDR1 that confer drug resistance in ABL are therefore accommodated outside the ATP pocket.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Whereas imatinib and ponatinib bind potently to both the DDR and ABL kinases, the hydrophobic interactions of the ABL P-loop appear poorly satisfied by DDR1-IN-1 suggesting a structural basis for its DDR1 selectivity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Such inhibitors may have applications in clinical indications of DDR1 and DDR2 overexpression or mutation, including lung cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thyroid hormone receptor a mutation causes a severe and thyroxine-resistant skeletal dysplasia in female mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A new genetic disorder has been identified that results from mutation of THRA, encoding thyroid hormone receptor a1 (TRa1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Affected children have a high serum T3:T4 ratio and variable degrees of intellectual deficit and constipation but exhibit a consistently severe skeletal dysplasia.</Gene>

<Gene>In an attempt to improve developmental delay and alleviate symptoms of hypothyroidism, patients are receiving varying doses and durations of T4 treatment, but responses have been inconsistent so far.</Gene>
<Gene>Thra1(PV/+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>mice express a similar potent dominant-negative mutant TRa1 to affected individuals, and thus represent an excellent disease model.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We hypothesized that Thra1(PV/+) mice could be used to predict the skeletal outcome of human THRA mutations and determine whether prolonged treatment with a supraphysiological dose of T4 ameliorates the skeletal abnormalities.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Adult female Thra1(PV/+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>mice had short stature, grossly abnormal bone morphology but normal bone strength despite high bone mass.</Gene>

<Gene>Although T4 treatment suppressed TSH secretion, it had no effect on skeletal maturation, linear growth, or bone mineralization, thus demonstrating profound tissue resistance to thyroid hormone.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Despite this, prolonged T4 treatment abnormally increased bone stiffness and strength, suggesting the potential for detrimental consequences in the long term.</Gene>

<Gene>Our studies establish that TRa1 has an essential role in the developing and adult skeleton and predict that patients with different THRA mutations will display variable responses to T4 treatment, which depend on the severity of the causative mutation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Functional characterization of obesity-associated variants involving the a and b isoforms of human SH2B1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have previously reported rare variants in sarcoma (Src) homology 2 (SH2) B adaptor protein 1 (SH2B1) in individuals with obesity, insulin resistance, and maladaptive behavior.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we identify 4 additional SH2B1 variants by sequencing 500 individuals with severe early-onset obesity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>SH2B1 has 4 alternatively spliced isoforms.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>One variant (T546A) lies within the N-terminal region common to all isoforms.</Gene>

<Gene>As shown for past variants in this region, T546A impairs SH2B1b enhancement of nerve growth factor-induced neurite outgrowth, and the individual with the T546A variant exhibits mild developmental delay.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The other 3 variants (A663V, V695M, and A723V) lie in the C-terminal tail of SH2B1a.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>SH2B1a variant carriers were hyperinsulinemic but did not exhibit the behavioral phenotype observed in individuals with SH2B1 variants that disrupt all isoforms.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In in vitro assays, SH2B1a, like SH2B1b, enhances insulin- and leptin-induced insulin receptor substrate 2 (IRS2) phosphorylation and GH-induced cell motility.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>None of the variants affect SH2B1a enhancement of insulin- and leptin-induced IRS2 phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, T546A, A663V, and A723V all impair the ability of SH2B1a to enhance GH-induced cell motility.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast to SH2B1b, SH2B1a does not enhance nerve growth factor-induced neurite outgrowth.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These studies suggest that genetic variants that disrupt isoforms other than SH2B1b may be functionally significant.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Further studies are needed to understand the mechanism by which the individual isoforms regulate energy homeostasis and behavior.</Gene>
<Gene>Mesenchymal stromal cells express GARP/LRRC32 on their surface: effects on their biology and immunomodulatory capacity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) represent a promising tool for therapy in regenerative medicine, transplantation, and autoimmune disease due to their trophic and immunomodulatory activities.</Gene>
<Gene>However, we are still far from understanding the mechanisms of action of MSCs in these processes.</Gene>
<Gene>Transforming growth factor (TGF)-b1 is a pleiotropic cytokine involved in MSC migration, differentiation, and immunomodulation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recently, glycoprotein A repetitions predominant (GARP) was shown to bind latency-associated peptide (LAP)/TGF-b1 to the cell surface of activated Foxp3(+) regulatory T cells (Tregs) and megakaryocytes/platelets.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this manuscript, we show that human and mouse MSCs express GARP which presents LAP/TGF-b1 on their cell surface.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Silencing GARP expression in MSCs increased their secretion and activation of TGF-b1 and reduced their proliferative capacity in a TGF-b1-independent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, we showed that GARP expression on MSCs contributed to their ability to inhibit T-cell responses in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In summary, we have found that GARP is an essential molecule for MSC biology, regulating their immunomodulatory and proliferative activities.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We envision GARP as a new target for improving the therapeutic efficacy of MSCs and also as a novel MSC marker.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Ena/VASP proteins cooperate with the WAVE complex to regulate the actin cytoskeleton.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ena/VASP proteins and the WAVE regulatory complex (WRC) regulate cell motility by virtue of their ability to independently promote actin polymerization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We demonstrate that Ena/VASP and the WRC control actin polymerization in a cooperative manner through the interaction of the Ena/VASP EVH1 domain with an extended proline rich motif in Abi.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This interaction increases cell migration and enables VASP to cooperatively enhance WRC stimulation of Arp2/3 complex-mediated actin assembly in vitro in the presence of Rac.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Loss of this interaction in Drosophila macrophages results in defects in lamellipodia formation, cell spreading, and redistribution of Ena to the tips of filopodia-like extensions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Rescue experiments of abi mutants also reveals a physiological requirement for the Abi:Ena interaction in photoreceptor axon targeting and oogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data demonstrate that the activities of Ena/VASP and the WRC are intimately linked to ensure optimal control of actin polymerization during cell migration and development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Impaired musculoskeletal response to age and exercise in PPARb(-/-) diabetic mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Fragility fractures are recognized complication of diabetes, but yet the underlying mechanisms remain poorly understood.</Gene>
<Gene>This is particularly pronounced in type 2 diabetes in which the propensity to fall is increased but bone mass is not necessarily low.</Gene>
<Gene>Thus, whether factors implicated in the development of insulin resistance and diabetes directly impact on the musculoskeletal system remains to be investigated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PPARb(-/-) mice have reduced metabolic activity and are glucose intolerant.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We examined changes in bone and muscle in PPARb(-/-) mice and investigated both the mechanism behind those changes with age as well as their response to exercise.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Compared with their wild type, PPARb(-/-) mice had an accelerated and parallel decline in both muscle and bone strength with age.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These changes were accompanied by increased myostatin expression, low bone formation, and increased resorption.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, mesenchymal cells from PPARb(-/-) had a reduced proliferation capacity and appeared to differentiate into more of an adipogenic phenotype.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Concomitantly we observed an increased expression of PPARg, characteristic of adipocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The anabolic responses of muscle and bone to exercise were also diminished in PPARb(-/-) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The periosteal bone formation response to direct bone compression was, however, maintained, indicating that PPARb controls periosteal bone formation through muscle contraction and/or metabolism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, these data indicate that PPARb deficiency leads to glucose intolerance, decreased muscle function, and reduced bone strength.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>On a molecular level, PPARb appears to regulate myostatin and PPARg expression in muscle and bone, thereby providing potential new targets to reverse bone fragility in patients with metabolic disturbances.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Arabidopsis acyl-CoA-binding protein ACBP3 participates in plant response to hypoxia by modulating very-long-chain fatty acid metabolism.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In Arabidopsis thaliana, acyl-CoA-binding proteins (ACBPs) are encoded by a family of six genes (ACBP1 to ACBP6), and are essential for diverse cellular activities.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recent investigations suggest that the membrane-anchored ACBPs are involved in oxygen sensing by sequestration of group VII ethylene-responsive factors under normoxia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we demonstrate the involvement of Arabidopsis ACBP3 in hypoxic tolerance.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ACBP3 transcription was remarkably induced following submergence under both dark (DS) and light (LS) conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ACBP3-overexpressors (ACBP3-OEs) showed hypersensitivity to DS, LS and ethanolic stresses, with reduced transcription of hypoxia-responsive genes as well as accumulation of hydrogen peroxide in the rosettes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, suppression of ACBP3 in ACBP3-KOs enhanced plant tolerance to DS, LS and ethanol treatments.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By analyses of double combinations of OE-1 with npr1-5, coi1-2, ein3-1 as well as ctr1-1 mutants, we observed that the attenuated hypoxic tolerance in ACBP3-OEs was dependent on NPR1- and CTR1-mediated signaling pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lipid profiling revealed that both the total amounts and very-long-chain species of phosphatidylserine (C42:2- and C42:3-PS) and glucosylinositolphosphorylceramides (C22:0-, C22:1-, C24:0-, C24:1-, and C26:1-GIPC) were significantly lower in ACBP3-OEs but increased in ACBP3-KOs upon LS exposure.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By microscale thermophoresis analysis, the recombinant ACBP3 protein bound VLC acyl-CoA esters with high affinities in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Further, a knockout mutant of MYB30, a master regulator of very-long-chain fatty acid (VLCFA) biosynthesis, exhibited enhanced sensitivities to LS and ethanolic stresses, phenotypes that were ameliorated by ACBP3-RNAi.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, these findings suggest that Arabidopsis ACBP3 participates in plant response to hypoxia by modulating VLCFA metabolism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The Dpp/TGFb-dependent corepressor Schnurri protects epithelial cells from JNK-induced apoptosis in drosophila embryos.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) often mediates apoptosis in response to cellular stress.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, during normal development, JNK signaling controls a variety of live cell behaviors, such as during dorsal closure in Drosophila embryos.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>During this process, the latent proapoptotic activity of JNK becomes apparent following Dpp signaling suppression, which leads to JNK-dependent transcriptional activation of the proapoptotic gene reaper.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Dpp signaling also protects cells from JNK-dependent apoptosis caused by epithelial disruption.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We find that repression of reaper transcription by Dpp is mediated by Schnurri.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, reporter gene analysis shows that a transcriptional regulatory module comprising AP-1 and Schnurri binding sites located upstream of reaper integrate the activities of JNK and Dpp.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This arrangement allows JNK to control a migratory behavior without triggering apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Dpp plays a dual role during dorsal closure.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It cooperates with JNK in stimulating cell migration and also prevents JNK from inducing apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells directly contribute to arteriosclerotic progression via integrin b2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recent studies described the association between hematopoietic stem/progenitor cell (HSPC) expansion in the bone marrow (BM), leukocytosis in the peripheral blood, and accelerated atherosclerosis.</Gene>
<Gene>We hypothesized that circulating HSPC may home to inflamed vessels, where they might contribute to inflammation and neointima formation.</Gene>

<Gene>We demonstrated that Lin(-) Sca-1(+) cKit(+) (LSK cells) in BM and peripheral blood of LDLr(-/-) mice on high fat diet expressed significantly more integrin b2 , which was responsible for LSK cell adhesion and migration toward ICAM-1 in vitro, and homing to injured arteries in vivo, all of which were blocked with an anti-CD18 blocking antibody.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>When homed LSK cells were isolated from ligated artery and injected to irradiated recipients, they resulted in BM reconstitution.</Gene>

<Gene>Injection of CD18(+/+) LSK cells to immunodeficient Balb/C Rag2(-) gC(-/-) recipients resulted in more severe inflammation and reinforced neointima formation in the ligated carotid artery, compared to mice injected with PBS and CD18(-/-) LSK cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hypercholesterolemia stimulated ERK phosphorylation (pERK) in LSK cells of LDLr(-/-)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>mice in vivo.</Gene>
<Gene>Blockade of pERK reduced ARF1 expression, leading to decreased integrin b2 function on HSPC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, integrin b2 function could be regulated via ERK-independent LRP1 pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Integrin b2 expression on HSPC is regulated by hypercholesterolemia, specifically LDL, in pERK-dependent and -independent manners, leading to increased homing and localization of HSPC to injured arteries, which is highly correlated with arteriosclerosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The androgen receptor confers protection against diet-induced atherosclerosis, obesity, and dyslipidemia in female mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Androgens have important cardiometabolic actions in males, but their metabolic role in females is unclear.</Gene>

<Gene>To determine the physiologic androgen receptor (AR)-dependent actions of androgens on atherogenesis in female mice, we generated female AR-knockout (ARKO) mice on an atherosclerosis-prone apolipoprotein E (apoE)-deficient background.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>After 8 weeks on a high-fat diet, but not on a normal chow diet, atherosclerosis in aorta was increased in ARKO females (+59% vs. control apoE-deficient mice with intact AR gene).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>They also displayed increased body weight (+18%), body fat percentage (+62%), and hepatic triglyceride levels, reduced insulin sensitivity, and a marked atherogenic dyslipidemia (serum cholesterol, +52%).</Gene>

<Gene>Differences in atherosclerosis, body weight, and lipid levels between ARKO and control mice were abolished in mice that were ovariectomized before puberty, consistent with a protective action of ovarian androgens mediated via the AR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the AR agonist dihydrotestosterone reduced atherosclerosis (-41%; thoracic aorta), subcutaneous fat mass (-44%), and cholesterol levels (-35%) in ovariectomized mice, reduced hepatocyte lipid accumulation in hepatoma cells in vitro, and regulated mRNA expression of hepatic genes pivotal for lipid homeostasis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, we demonstrate that the AR protects against diet-induced atherosclerosis in female mice and propose that this is mediated by modulation of body composition and lipid metabolism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Adipogenic Differentiation of hMSCs is Mediated by Recruitment of IGF-1r Onto the Primary Cilium Associated With Cilia Elongation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Primary cilia are single non-motile organelles that provide a highly regulated compartment into which specific proteins are trafficked as a critical part of various signaling pathways.</Gene>
<Gene>The absence of primary cilia has been shown to prevent differentiation of human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs).</Gene>
<Gene>Changes in primary cilia length are crucial for regulating signaling events; however it is not known how alterations in cilia structure relate to differentiation.</Gene>
<Gene>This study tested the hypothesis that changes in primary cilia structure are required for stem cell differentiation.</Gene>
<Gene>hMSCs expressed primary cilia that were labeled with acetylated alpha tubulin and visualized by confocal microscopy.</Gene>
<Gene>Chemically induced differentiation resulted in lineage specific changes in cilia length and prevalence which were independent of cell cycle.</Gene>
<Gene>In particular, adipogenic differentiation resulted in cilia elongation associated with the presence of dexamethasone, while insulin had an inhibitory effect on cilia length.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Over a 7-day time course, adipogenic differentiation media resulted in cilia elongation within 2 days followed by increased nuclear PPARg levels; an early marker of adipogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cilia elongation was associated with increased trafficking of insulin-like growth factor-1 receptor b (IGF-1Rb) into the cilium.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This was reversed on inhibition of elongation by IFT-88 siRNA transfection, which also decreased nuclear PPARg.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This is the first study to show that adipogenic differentiation requires primary cilia elongation associated with the recruitment of IGF-1Rb onto the cilium.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study may lead to the development of cilia-targeted therapies for controlling adipogenic differentiation and associated conditions such as obesity.</Gene>
<Gene>The CB -cannabinoid receptor signals striatal neuroprotection via a PI3K/Akt/mTORC1/BDNF pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The CB1 cannabinoid receptor, the main molecular target of endocannabinoids and cannabis active components, is the most abundant G protein-coupled receptor in the mammalian brain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In particular, the CB1 receptor is highly expressed in the basal ganglia, mostly on terminals of medium-sized spiny neurons, where it plays a key neuromodulatory function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The CB1 receptor also confers neuroprotection in various experimental models of striatal damage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, the assessment of the physiological relevance and therapeutic potential of the CB1 receptor in basal ganglia-related diseases is hampered, at least in part, by the lack of knowledge of the precise mechanism of CB1 receptor neuroprotective activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, by using an array of pharmacological, genetic and pharmacogenetic (designer receptor exclusively activated by designer drug) approaches, we show that (1) CB1 receptor engagement protects striatal cells from excitotoxic death via the phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase/Akt/mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 pathway, which, in turn, (2) induces brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) expression through the selective activation of BDNF gene promoter IV, an effect that is mediated by multiple transcription factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To assess the possible functional impact of the CB1/BDNF axis in a neurodegenerative-disease context in vivo, we conducted experiments in the R6/2 mouse, a well-established model of Huntington's disease, in which the CB1 receptor and BDNF are known to be severely downregulated in the dorsolateral striatum.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Adeno-associated viral vector-enforced re-expression of the CB1 receptor in the dorsolateral striatum of R6/2 mice allowed the re-expression of BDNF and the concerted rescue of the neuropathological deficits in these animals.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, these findings unravel a molecular link between CB1 receptor activation and BDNF expression, and support the relevance of the CB1/BDNF axis in promoting striatal neuron survival.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Adipose triglyceride lipase is involved in the mobilization of triglyceride and retinoid stores of hepatic stellate cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) store triglycerides (TGs) and retinyl ester (RE) in cytosolic lipid droplets.</Gene>
<Gene>RE stores are degraded following retinoid starvation or in response to pathogenic stimuli resulting in HSC activation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>At present, the major enzymes catalyzing lipid degradation in HSCs are unknown.</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, we investigated whether adipose triglyceride lipase (ATGL) is involved in RE catabolism of HSCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, we compared the effects of ATGL deficiency and hormone-sensitive lipase (HSL) deficiency, a known RE hydrolase (REH), on RE stores in liver and adipose tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that ATGL degrades RE even in the presence of TGs, implicating that these substrates compete for ATGL binding.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>REH activity was stimulated and inhibited by comparative gene identification-58 and G0/G1 switch gene-2, respectively, the physiological regulators of ATGL activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In cultured primary murine HSCs, pharmacological inhibition of ATGL, but not HSL, increased RE accumulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In mice globally lacking ATGL or HSL, RE contents in white adipose tissue were decreased or increased, respectively, while plasma retinol and liver RE levels remained unchanged.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, our study shows that ATGL acts as REH in HSCs promoting the degradation of RE stores in addition to its established function as TG lipase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HSL is the predominant REH in adipocytes but does not affect lipid mobilization in HSCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>An in vivo screen to identify candidate neurogenic genes in the developing Xenopus visual system.</Gene>
<Gene>Neurogenesis in the brain of Xenopus laevis continues throughout larval stages of development.</Gene>
<Gene>We developed a 2-tier screen to identify candidate genes controlling neurogenesis in Xenopus optic tectum in vivo.</Gene>
<Gene>First, microarray and NanoString analyses were used to identify candidate genes that were differentially expressed in Sox2-expressing neural progenitor cells or their neuronal progeny.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Then an in vivo, time-lapse imaging-based screen was used to test whether morpholinos against 34 candidate genes altered neural progenitor cell proliferation or neuronal differentiation over 3 days in the optic tectum of intact Xenopus tadpoles.</Gene>

<Gene>We co-electroporated antisense morpholino oligonucleotides against each of the candidate genes with a plasmid that drives GFP expression in Sox2-expressing neural progenitor cells and quantified the effects of morpholinos on neurogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Of the 34 morpholinos tested, 24 altered neural progenitor cell proliferation or neuronal differentiation.</Gene>

<Gene>The candidates which were tagged as differentially expressed and validated by the in vivo imaging screen include: actn1, arl9, eif3a, elk4, ephb1, fmr1-a, fxr1-1, fbxw7, fgf2, gstp1, hat1, hspa5, lsm6, mecp2, mmp9, and prkaca.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Several of these candidates, including fgf2 and elk4, have known or proposed neurogenic functions, thereby validating our strategy to identify candidates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genes with no previously demonstrated neurogenic functions, gstp1, hspa5 and lsm6, were identified from the morpholino experiments, suggesting that our screen successfully revealed unknown candidates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genes that are associated with human disease, such as such as mecp2 and fmr1-a, were identified by our screen, providing the groundwork for using Xenopus as an experimental system to probe conserved disease mechanisms.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together the data identify candidate neurogenic regulatory genes and demonstrate that Xenopus is an effective experimental animal to identify and characterize genes that regulate neural progenitor cell proliferation and differentiation in vivo.</Gene>
<Gene>Idh1 protects murine hepatocytes from endotoxin-induced oxidative stress by regulating the intracellular NADP(+)/NADPH ratio.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Isocitrate dehydrogenase-1 (Idh1) is an important metabolic enzyme that produces NADPH by converting isocitrate to a-ketoglutarate.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Idh1 is known to reduce reactive oxygen species (ROS) induced in cells by treatment with lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we used Idh1-deficient knockout (Idh1 KO) mice to investigate the role of Idh1 in antioxidant defense in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Idh1 KO mice showed heightened susceptibility to death induced by LPS and exhibited increased serum levels of inflammatory cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor-a and interleukin-6.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The serum of LPS-injected Idh1 KO mice also contained elevated levels of AST, a marker of inflammatory liver damage.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, after LPS injection, livers of Idh1 KO mice showed histological evidence of elevated oxidative DNA damage compared with livers of wild-type (WT) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Idh1 KO livers showed a faster and more pronounced oxidative stress than WT livers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In line with that, Idh1 KO hepatocytes showed higher ROS levels and an increase in the NADP(+)/NADPH ratio when compared with hepatocytes isolated from WT mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that Idh1 has a physiological function in protecting cells from oxidative stress by regulating the intracellular</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>NADP(+)/NADPH ratio.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings suggest that stimulation of Idh1 activity may be an effective therapeutic strategy for reducing oxidative stress during inflammatory responses, including the early stages of septic shock.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of LDHA suppresses tumor progression in prostate cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A key hallmark of cancer cells is their altered metabolism, known as Warburg effect.</Gene>
<Gene>Lactate dehydrogenase A (LDHA) executes the final step of aerobic glycolysis and has been reported to be involved in the tumor progression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the function of LDHA in prostate cancer has not been studied.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In current study, we observed overexpression of LDHA in the clinical prostate cancer samples compared with benign prostate hyperplasia tissues as demonstrated by immunohistochemistry and real-time qPCR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Attenuated expression of LDHA by siRNA or inhibition of LDHA activities by FX11 inhibited cell proliferation, migration, invasion, and promoted cell apoptosis of PC-3 and DU145 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mechanistically, decreased Warburg effect as demonstrated by reduced glucose consumption and lactate secretion and reduced expression of MMP-9, PLAU, and cathepsin B were found after LDHA knockdown or FX11 treatment in PC-3 and DU145 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, our study revealed the oncogenic role of LDHA in prostate cancer and suggested that LDHA might be a potential therapeutic target.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Leptin activation of mTOR pathway in intestinal epithelial cell triggers lipid droplet formation, cytokine production and increased cell proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Accumulating evidence suggests that obesity and enhanced inflammatory reactions are predisposing conditions for developing colon cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>Obesity is associated with high levels of circulating leptin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Leptin is an adipocytokine that is secreted by adipose tissue and modulates immune response and inflammation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lipid droplets (LD) are organelles involved in lipid metabolism and production of inflammatory mediators, and increased numbers of LD were observed in human colon cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>Leptin induces the formation of LD in macrophages in a PI3K/mTOR pathway-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, the mTOR is a serine/threonine kinase that plays a key role in cellular growth and is frequently altered in tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We therefore investigated the role of leptin in the modulation of mTOR pathway and regulation of lipid metabolism and inflammatory phenotype in intestinal epithelial cells (IEC-6 cells).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that leptin promotes a dose- and time-dependent enhancement of LD formation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The biogenesis of LD was accompanied by enhanced CXCL1/CINC-1, CCL2/MCP-1 and TGF-b production and increased COX-2 expression in these cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We demonstrated that leptin-induced increased phosphorylation of STAT3 and AKT and a dose and time-dependent mTORC activation with enhanced phosphorilation of the downstream protein P70S6K protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Pre-treatment with rapamycin significantly inhibited leptin effects in LD formation, COX-2 and TGF-b production in IEC-6 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, leptin was able to stimulate the proliferation of epithelial cells on a mTOR-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that leptin regulates lipid metabolism, cytokine production and proliferation of intestinal cells through a mechanism largely dependent on activation of the mTOR pathway, thus suggesting that leptin-induced mTOR activation may contribute to the obesity-related enhanced susceptibility to colon carcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Role of stress-activated OCT4A in the cell fate decisions of embryonal carcinoma cells treated with etoposide.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Tumor cellular senescence induced by genotoxic treatments has recently been found to be paradoxically linked to the induction of "stemness."</Gene>
<Gene>This observation is critical as it directly impinges upon the response of tumors to current chemo-radio-therapy treatment regimens.</Gene>

<Gene>Previously, we showed that following etoposide (ETO) treatment embryonal carcinoma PA-1 cells undergo a p53-dependent upregulation of OCT4A and p21Cip1 (governing self-renewal and regulating cell cycle inhibition and senescence, respectively).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we report further detail on the relationship between these and other critical cell-fate regulators.</Gene>
<Gene>PA-1</Gene>
<Gene>cells treated with ETO display highly heterogeneous increases in OCT4A and p21Cip1 indicative of dis-adaptation catastrophe.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Silencing OCT4A suppresses p21Cip1, changes cell cycle regulation and subsequently suppresses terminal senescence; p21Cip1-silencing did not affect OCT4A expression or cellular phenotype.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SOX2 and NANOG expression did not change following ETO treatment suggesting a dissociation of OCT4A from its pluripotency function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Instead, ETO-induced OCT4A was concomitant with activation of AMPK, a key component of metabolic stress and autophagy regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>p16ink4a, the inducer of terminal senescence, underwent autophagic sequestration in the cytoplasm of ETO-treated cells, allowing alternative cell fates.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Accordingly, failure of autophagy was accompanied by an accumulation of p16ink4a, nuclear disintegration, and loss of cell recovery.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Together, these findings imply that OCT4A induction following DNA damage in PA-1 cells, performs a cell stress, rather than self-renewal, function by moderating the expression of p21Cip1, which alongside AMPK helps to then regulate autophagy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, this data indicates that exhaustion of autophagy, through persistent DNA damage, is the cause of terminal cellular senescence.</Gene>
<Gene>Putative Prostate Cancer Risk SNP in an Androgen Receptor-Binding Site of the Melanophilin Gene Illustrates Enrichment of Risk SNPs in Androgen Receptor Target Sites.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genome-wide association studies have identified genomic loci, whose single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) predispose to prostate cancer (PCa).</Gene>
<Gene>However, the mechanisms of most of these variants are largely unknown.</Gene>

<Gene>We integrated chromatin-immunoprecipitation-coupled sequencing and microarray expression profiling in TMPRSS2-ERG gene rearrangement positive DUCaP cells with the GWAS PCa risk SNPs catalog to identify disease susceptibility SNPs localized within functional androgen receptor-binding sites (ARBSs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Among the 48 GWAS index risk SNPs and 3,917 linked SNPs, 80 were found located in ARBSs.</Gene>

<Gene>Of these, rs11891426:T>G in an intron of the melanophilin gene (MLPH) was within a novel putative auxiliary AR-binding motif, which is enriched in the neighborhood of canonical androgen-responsive elements.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T>G exchange attenuated the transcriptional activity of the ARBS in an AR reporter gene assay.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of MLPH in primary prostate tumors was significantly lower in those with the G compared with the T allele and correlated significantly with AR protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Higher melanophilin level in prostate tissue of patients with a favorable PCa risk profile points out a tumor-suppressive effect.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results unravel a hidden link between AR and a functional putative PCa risk SNP, whose allele alteration affects androgen regulation of its host gene MLPH.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conditional knockdown of BCL2A1 reveals rate-limiting roles in BCR-dependent B-cell survival.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bcl2 family proteins control mitochondrial apoptosis and its members exert critical cell type and differentiation stage-specific functions, acting as barriers against autoimmunity or transformation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Anti-apoptotic Bcl2a1/Bfl1/A1 is frequently deregulated in different types of blood cancers in humans but its physiological role is poorly understood as quadruplication of the Bcl2a1 gene locus in mice hampers conventional gene targeting strategies.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transgenic overexpression of A1, deletion of the A1-a paralogue or constitutive knockdown in the hematopoietic compartment of mice by RNAi suggested rate-limiting roles in lymphocyte development, granulopoiesis and mast cell activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we report on the consequences of conditional knockdown of A1 protein expression using a reverse transactivator (rtTA)-driven approach that highlights a critical role for this Bcl2 family member in the maintenance of mature B-cell homeostasis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, we define the A1/Bim (Bcl-2 interacting mediator of cell death) axis as a target of key kinases mediating B-cell receptor (BCR)-dependent survival signals, such as, spleen tyrosine kinase (Syk) and Brutons tyrosine kinase (Btk).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As such, A1 represents a putative target for the treatment of B-cell-related pathologies depending on hyperactivation of BCR-emanating survival signals and loss of A1 expression accounts, in part, for the pro-apoptotic effects of Syk- or Btk inhibitors that rely on the 'BH3-only' protein Bim for cell killing.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Diagnostic Exome Sequencing Identifies a Novel Gene, EMILIN1, Associated with Autosomal-Dominant Hereditary Connective Tissue Disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Heritable connective tissue diseases are a highly heterogeneous family of over 200 disorders that affect the extracellular matrix.</Gene>
<Gene>While the genetic basis of several disorders is established, the etiology has not been discovered for a large portion of patients, likely due to rare yet undiscovered disease genes.</Gene>

<Gene>By performing trio-exome sequencing of a 55-year-old male proband presenting with multiple symptoms indicative of a connective disorder, we identified a heterozygous missense alteration in exon 1 of the Elastin Microfibril Interfacer 1 (EMILIN1) gene, c.64G></Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A (p.A22T).</Gene>
<Gene>The proband presented with ascending and descending aortic aneurysms, bilateral lower leg and foot sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy, arthropathy, and increased skin elasticity.</Gene>
