<Gene>Sanger sequencing confirmed that the EMILIN1 alteration, which maps around the signal peptide cleavage site, segregated with disease in the affected proband, mother, and son.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The impaired secretion of EMILIN-1 in cells transfected with the mutant p.A22T coincided with abnormal protein accumulation within the endoplasmic reticulum.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In skin biopsy of the proband, we detected less EMILIN-1 with disorganized and abnormal coarse fibrils, aggregated deposits underneath the epidermis basal lamina, and dermal cells apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings collectively suggest that EMILIN1 may represent a new disease gene associated with an autosomal-dominant connective tissue disorder.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Apoptosis of Sertoli cells after conditional ablation of murine double minute 2 (Mdm2) gene is p53-dependent and results in male sterility.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Beside its well-documented role in carcinogenesis, the function of p53 family has been more recently revealed in development and female reproduction, but it is still poorly documented in male reproduction.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We specifically tested this possibility by ablating Mdm2, an E3 ligase that regulates p53 protein stability and transactivation function, specifically in Sertoli cells (SCs) using the AMH-Cre line and created the new SC-Mdm2(-/-) line.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Heterozygous SC-Mdm2(-/+) adult males were fertile, but SC-Mdm2(-/-) males were infertile and exhibited: a shorter ano-genital distance, an extra duct along the vas deferens that presents a uterus-like morphology, degenerated testes with no organized seminiferous tubules and a complete loss of differentiated germ cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In adults, testosterone levels as well as StAR, P450c17 (Cyp17a1) and P450scc (Cyp11a1) mRNA levels decreased significantly, and both plasma LH and FSH levels increased.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A detailed investigation of testicular development indicated that the phenotype arose during fetal life, with SC-Mdm2(-/-) testes being much smaller at birth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, Leydig cells remained present until adulthood and fetal germ cells abnormally initiated meiosis.</Gene>
<Gene>Inactivation of Mdm2 in SCs triggered p53 activation and apoptosis as early as 15.5 days post conception with significant increase in apoptotic SCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, testis development occurred normally in SC-Mdm2(-/-) lacking p53 mice (SC-Mdm2(-/-)p53(-/-)) and accordingly, these mice were fertile indicating that the aforementioned phenotypes are entirely p53-dependent.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data not only highlight the importance of keeping p53 in check for proper testicular development and male fertility but also certify the critical role of SCs in the maintenance of meiotic repression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Synovial Regulatory T Cells Occupy a Discrete TCR Niche in Human Arthritis and Require Local Signals To Stabilize FOXP3 Protein Expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although there is great interest in harnessing the immunosuppressive potential of FOXP3(+) regulatory T cells (Tregs) for treating autoimmunity, a sizeable knowledge gap exists regarding Treg fate in human disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) patients, we have previously reported that atypical CD25(+)FOXP3(-) Treg-like cells uniquely populate the inflamed site.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intriguingly, their proportions relative to CD25(+)FOXP3(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tregs associate with arthritis course, suggesting a role in disease.</Gene>
<Gene>The ontogeny of these FOXP3(-) Treg-like cells is, however, unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we interrogated clonal relationships between CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>T cell subsets in JIA, using high-throughput TCR repertoire analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We reveal that FOXP3(+) Tregs possess highly exclusive TCRb usage from conventional T cells, in blood, and also at the inflamed site, where they are clonally expanded.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intriguingly, the repertoires of FOXP3(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Tregs in synovial fluid are highly overlapping with CD25(+)FOXP3(-) Treg-like cells, indicating fluctuations in FOXP3 expression in the inflamed joint.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, cultured synovial Tregs rapidly downregulated FOXP3 protein (but not mRNA), and this process was prevented by addition of synovial fluid from JIA patients, through an IL-6-independent mechanism.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings suggest that most Tregs arise from a separate lineage from conventional T cells, and that this repertoire divergence is largely maintained under chronic inflammatory conditions.</Gene>

<Gene>We propose that subsequent Treg expansions at the inflamed site creates an environment that leads to competition for limited resources within the synovium, resulting in the destabilization of FOXP3 expression in some Tregs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Upregulation of centrosomal protein 55 is associated with unfavorable prognosis and tumor invasion in epithelial ovarian carcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Centrosomal protein 55 (CEP55) is a cell cycle regulator implicated in development of certain cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, characteristics of CEP55 expression and its clinical/prognostic significance are unclear in human epithelial ovarian carcinoma (EOC).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, we investigated the expression and clinicopathological significance of CEP55 in patients with EOC and its role in regulating invasion and metastasis of ovarian cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CEP55 mRNA and protein expression levels were detected by quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR), Western blotting, and immunohistochemistry (IHC).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Potential associations of CEP55 expression scores with clinical parameters and patient survival were evaluated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CEP55 function was investigated further using RNA interference, wound healing assay, transwell assay, immunofluorescence analysis, qRT-PCR, and Western blotting.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CEP55 was significantly upregulated in ovarian cancer cell lines and lesions compared with normal cells and adjacent noncancerous ovarian tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the 213 EOC samples, CEP55 protein levels were positively correlated with clinical stage (P < 0.001), lymph node metastasis (P < 0.001), intraperitoneal metastasis (P < 0.001), tumor recurrence (P < 0.001), differentiation grade (P < 0.001), residual tumor size (P < 0.001), ascites see tumor cells (P = 0.020), and serum CA153 level (P < 0.001).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, patients with aberrant CEP55 protein expression showed tendencies to receive neoadjuvant chemotherapy (P < 0.001) and cytoreductive surgery (P = 0.020).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>By contrast, no significant correlation was detected between the protein levels and patient age, histological type, or serum CA125, CA199, CA724, NSE, CEA, and b-HCG levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Patients with high CEP55 protein expression had shorter overall survival and disease-free survival compared with those with low CEP55 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Multivariate analysis implicated CEP55 as an independent prognostic indicator for EOC patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, downregulation of CEP55 in ovarian cancer cells remarkably inhibited cellular motility and invasion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Aberrant CEP55 expression may predict unfavorable clinical outcomes in EOC patients and play an important role in regulating invasion in ovarian cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, CEP55 may serve as a prognostic marker and therapeutic target for EOC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Effect of junctional adhesion molecule-2 expression on cell growth, invasion and migration in human colorectal cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The junctional adhesion molecule (JAMs) family belongs to the immunoglobulin subfamily involved in the formation of tight junctions (TJ) in both endothelial and epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Aberrant expression of JAM-2 is associated with cancer progression but little work has been carried out in discovering how this affects changes in cell behaviour.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The present study aimed to examine the expression of JAM-2 in human colon cancer specimens and cell lines and its role in the development of colon cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>JAM-2 expression in human colon cancer specimens (normal, n=75; cancer, n=94) and cell lines was analysed using quantitative real-time PCR and conventional RT-PCR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Colon cancer cells were stably transfected with a mammalian expression vector to overexpress JAM-2-Flag.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The effect on growth, adhesion and migration following overexpression of JAM-2 was then investigated using in vitro models.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>TJ function was assessed using a trans-epithelial resistance assay (TER, with an EVOM voltammeter).</Gene>
<Gene>JAM-2 was lowly expressed in colon cancer cells such as RKO, HT115.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>JAM-2 overexpression in RKO cells (RKO-JAM-2) and HT115 cells (HT115-JAM-2) showed retarded adhesion (P<0.05).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>An in vivo tumour model showed that RKO-JAM-2 had significantly reduced growth (P<0.05), invasion (P<0.05) and migration (P<0.05) as well as in HT115-JAM-2, except on proliferation and migration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of JAM-2 resulted in a significant increase in TER and decrease in permeability of polarized monolayers (P<0.05).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Further analysis of JAM-2 transcript levels against clinical aspects demonstrated that the decreasing JAM-2 expression correlated to disease progression, metastasis and poor survival.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, JAM-2 may function as a putative tumour suppressor in the progression and metastasis of colorectal cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein-3 as a marker for distinguishing between cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma and keratoacanthoma.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the histopathological diagnosis of cutaneous tumors, the differential diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) with crateriform architecture and keratoacanthoma (KA) is often difficult so an accurate understanding of the biological features and the identification of reliable markers of SCC and KA are crucial issues.</Gene>

<Gene>Insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein-3 (IGF2BP3, also known as IMP3) is thought of as a bona fide oncofetal protein, which is overexpressed and is involved in cell proliferation, migration, and invasion in several kinds of tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the role of IMP3 in cutaneous SCC and KA has not been well studied.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, we focused on studying the biological functions of IMP3 in SCC and KA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In human skin SCC cell lines, HSC-1 and HSC-5, and the human keratinocyte cell line, HaCaT, IMP3 mRNA levels were significantly higher than that of normal human skin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The knockdown of IMP3 expression reduced the proliferation of HSC-1, and significantly reduced invasion by HSC-1 and HSC-5.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, the knockdown of IMP3 did not significantly affect invasion by HaCaT cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In immunohistochemical studies of SCC and KA tissues, the Ki-67 labeling index (LI) of the suprabasal cell layer was significantly higher in SCC, compared with KA tissues and the tumor-free margin (TFM) adjacent to SCC and KA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Most SCC tissues stained strongly positive for IMP3, but KA tissues and TFM were mostly negative for IMP3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Ki-67 LI of the IMP3-positive group was significantly higher than that of the IMP3-negative group in the suprabasal cell layer of SCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that IMP3 plays an important role in proliferation and, more significantly, in the invasion of SCC, and may be a suitable marker for the histopathological diagnosis of SCC with a crateriform architecture and KA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, IMP3 may potentially be a new therapeutic target for SCC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of haptoglobin peptide as a novel serum biomarker for lung squamous cell carcinoma by serum proteome and peptidome profiling.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To date, a number of potential biomarkers for lung squamous cell cancer (SCC) have been identified; however, sensitive biomarkers are currently lacking to detect early stage SCC due to low sensitivity and specificity.</Gene>

<Gene>In the present study, we compared the 7 serum proteomic profiles of 11 SCC patients, 7 chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients and 7 healthy smokers as controls to identify potential serum biomarkers associated with SCC and COPD.</Gene>

<Gene>Two-dimensional difference gel electrophoresis (2D-DIGE) and mass-spectrometric analysis (MS) using an affinity column revealed two candidate proteins, haptoglobin (HP) and apolipoprotein 4, as biomarkers of SCC, and a-1-antichymotrypsin as a marker of COPD.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The iTRAQ technique was also used to identify SCC-specific peptides.</Gene>
<Gene>HP protein expression was significantly higher in SCC patients than in COPD patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, two HP protein peptides showed significantly higher serum levels in SCC patients than in COPD patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We established novel polyclonal antibodies for the two HP peptides and subsequently a sandwich enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) for the quantification of these specific peptides in patient and control sera.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The sensitivity of detection by ELISA of one HP peptide (HP216) was 70% of SCC patients, 40% of COPDs patients and 13% of healthy controls.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We also measured CYFRA, a cytokeratin fragment clinically used as an SCC tumor marker, in all the 28 cases and found CYFRA was detected in only seven SCC cases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, when the measurement of HP216 was combined with that of CYFRA, 100% (10 of 10 patients) of SCC cases were detected.</Gene>
<Gene>Our proteomic profiling demonstrates that the SCC-specific HP peptide HP216 may potentially be used as a diagnostic biomarker for SCC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Long non-coding RNA AK027294 involves in the process of proliferation, migration, and apoptosis of colorectal cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study is aimed to investigate the differentially expressed long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) in colorectal cancer and its potential biological function.</Gene>
<Gene>Colorectal adenoma is the precancerous lesions of colorectal cancer, so in this study, we used colorectal adenoma as negative control.</Gene>
<Gene>The global lncRNA expression profile in colorectal cancer and adenoma was evaluated by bioinformatics.</Gene>
<Gene>The biological functions and potential mechanism of AK027294 were investigated in HCT116, HCT8, and SW480 colorectal cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A total of 135 lncRNAs were found to be differentially expressed in colorectal cancer and adenoma tissues.</Gene>
<Gene>Among them, 71 lncRNAs were up-regulated and 64 lncRNAs were down-regulated.</Gene>
<Gene>Especially, AK027294 was found to be highly expressed in colorectal cancer tissues compared with colorectal adenoma tissues (fold change is 184.5).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our results indicated that AK027294 down-regulation significantly inhibited colorectal cancer cells proliferation and migration, but promoted cell apoptosis (P < 0.05).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The potential mechanism of AK027294 might be associated with the regulation of caspase-3, caspase-8, Bcl-2, MMP12, MMP9, and TWIST.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The lncRNA expression profile in colorectal cancer suggests lncRNAs may play important roles in the occurrence and progression of colorectal cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>AK027294 is highly expressed in colorectal cancer and closely correlates with colorectal cells proliferation, migration, and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of the dopamine transporter SLC6A3 as a biomarker for patients with renal cell carcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) is among the most common human malignancies.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>In order to provide better understanding of the molecular biology of ccRCC and to identify potential diagnostic/prognostic biomarker and therapeutic targets, we utilized a microarray to profile mRNA expression of corresponding normal and malignant renal tissues.</Gene>
<Gene>Real-time PCR, Western Blot and immunohistochemistry were applied to study the expression of candidate biomarkers.</Gene>
<Gene>ccRCC cell lines were treated with sertraline to inhibit the dopamine transporter SLC6A3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: Differential expression of fourteen mRNAs, yet not studied in ccRCC in depth, was confirmed using qPCR (upregulation: SLC6A3, NPTX2, TNFAIP6, NDUFA4L2, ENPP3, FABP6, SPINK13; downregulation: FXYD4, SLC12A1, KNG1, NPHS2, SLC13A3, GCGR, PLG).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Up-/downregulation was also confirmed for FXYD4, KNG1, NPTX2 and SLC12A1 by Western Blot on the protein level.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast to the mRNA expression, protein expression of the dopamine transporter SLC6A3 was lower in ccRCC compared to normal renal tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Immunohistochemistry indicated that this decrease was due to higher concentrations of SLC6A3 in the proximal tubules.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Immunohistochemical analyses further demonstrated that high SLC6A3 expression in ccRCC tissue was correlated with a shorter period of recurrence-free survival following surgery.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Treatment of ccRCC cells with the SLC6A3 inhibitor sertraline induced dose-dependent cell-death.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>Our study identified several novel biomarkers with diagnostic potential and further investigations on sertraline as therapeutic agent in ccRCC patients are warranted.</Gene>
<Gene>Repression of Wnt/b-catenin response elements by p63 (TP63).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Submitted: TP63 (p63), a member of the tumor suppressor TP53 (p53) gene family, is expressed in keratinocyte stem cells and well-differentiated squamous cell carcinomas to maintain cellular potential for growth and differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Controversially, activation of the Wnt/b-catenin signaling by p63 (Patturajan M. et al., 2002, Cancer Cells) and inhibition of the target gene expression (Drewelus I. et al., 2010, Cell Cycle) have been reported.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Upon p63 RNA-silencing in squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) lines, a few Wnt target gene expression substantially increased, while several target genes moderately decreased.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although DNp63a, the most abundant isoform of p63, appeared to interact with protein phosphatase PP2A, neither GSK-3b phosphorylation nor b-catenin nuclear localization was altered by the loss of p63.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As reported earlier, DNp63a enhanced b-catenin-dependent luc gene expression from pGL3-OT having 3 artificial Wnt response elements (WREs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, this activation was detectable only in HEK293 cells examined so far, and involved a p53 family-related sequence 5' to the WREs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In Wnt3-expressing SAOS-2 cells, DNp63a rather strongly inhibited transcription of pGL3-OT.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, DNp63a repressed WREs isolated from the regulatory regions of MMP7.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DNp63a-TCF4 association occurred in their soluble forms in the nucleus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, p63 and TCF4 coexisted at a WRE of MMP7 on the chromatin, where b-catenin recruitment was attenuated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The combined results indicate that DNp63a serves as a repressor that regulates b-catenin-mediated gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CFI-rs7356506 polymorphisms associated with Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PURPOSE:</Gene>
<Gene>Complement factor I (CFI) plays an important role in complement activation pathways and is known to affect the development of uveitis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The present study was performed to investigate the existence of an association between CFI genetic polymorphisms and Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada (VKH) syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>A total of 100 patients diagnosed with VKH syndrome and 300 healthy controls were recruited for the study.</Gene>
<Gene>Two milliliters of peripheral blood were collected in a sterile anticoagulative tube.</Gene>
<Gene>CFI-rs7356506 polymorphisms were genotyped using Sequenom MassARRAY technology.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Allele and genotype frequencies were compared between patients and controls using a X(2) test.</Gene>
<Gene>The analyses were stratified for recurrent status, complicated cataract status, and steroid-sensitive status.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>No significant association was found between CFI-rs7356506 polymorphisms and VKH syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, patients with recurrent VKH syndrome had lower frequencies of the G allele and GG homozygosity in CFI-rs7356506 when compared to the controls (p=0.016, odds ratio [OR]=0.429, 95% confidence interval [CI]=0.212-0.871; p=0.014, OR=0.364, 95% CI=0.158-0.837, respectively).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, there were significant decreases in the frequencies of the G allele and GG homozygosity in CFI-rs7356506 in patients with VKH syndrome with complicated cataract compared to the controls (p<0.001, OR=0.357, 95% CI=0.197-0.648; p<0.001, OR=0.273, 95% CI=0.135-0.551, respectively).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Nevertheless, no significant association with patients with VKH syndrome in steroid-sensitive statuses was detected for CFI-rs7356506 polymorphisms.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>Our results indicate that CFI polymorphisms are not significantly associated with VKH syndrome; nevertheless, we identified a trend for the association of CFI-7356506 with VKH syndrome that depends on the recurrent status and the complicated cataract status but not on the steroid-sensitive status.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cdc45 is limiting for replication initiation in humans.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cdc45 is an essential protein that together with Mcm2-7 and GINS forms the eukaryotic replicative helicase CMG.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cdc45 seems to be rate limiting for the initial unwinding or firing of replication origins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In line with this view, Cdc45-overexpressing cells fired at least twice as many origins as control cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, these cells displayed an about 2-fold diminished fork elongation rate, a pronounced asymmetry of replication fork extension, and an early S phase arrest.</Gene>
<Gene>This was accompanied by H2AX-phosphorylation and subsequent apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Unexpectedly, we did not observe increased ATR/Chk1 signaling but rather a mild ATM/Chk2 response.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, we detected accumulation of long stretches of single-stranded DNA, a hallmark of replication catastrophe.</Gene>

<Gene>We conclude that increased origin firing by upregulated Cdc45 caused exhaustion of the single-strand binding protein RPA, which in consequence diminished the ATR/Chk1 response; the subsequently occurring fork breaks led to an ATM/Chk2 mediated phosphorylation of H2AX and eventually to apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Multiple Transduction Pathways Mediate Thyrotropin Receptor Signaling in Preosteoblast-Like Cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It has been shown that the TSH receptor (TSHR) couples to a number of different signaling pathways, although the Gs-cAMP pathway has been considered primary.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we measured the effects of TSH on bone marker mRNA and protein expression in preosteoblast-like U2OS cells stably expressing TSHRs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We determined which signaling cascades are involved in the regulation of IL-11, osteopontin (OPN), and alkaline phosphatase (ALPL).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We demonstrated that TSH-induced up-regulation of IL-11 is primarily mediated via the Gs pathway as IL-11 was up-regulated by forskolin (FSK), an adenylyl cyclase activator, and inhibited by protein kinase A inhibitor H-89 and by silencing of Gas by small interfering RNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>OPN levels were not affected by FSK, but its up-regulation was inhibited by TSHR/Gi-uncoupling by pertussis toxin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Pertussis toxin decreased p38 MAPK kinase phosphorylation, and a p38 inhibitor and small interfering RNA knockdown of p38a inhibited OPN induction by TSH.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Up-regulation of ALPL expression required high doses of TSH (EC50 = 395nM), whereas low doses (EC50 = 19nM) were inhibitory.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>FSK-stimulated cAMP production decreased basal ALPL expression, whereas protein kinase A inhibition by H-89 and silencing of Gas increased basal levels of ALPL.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Knockdown of Gaq/11 and a protein kinase C inhibitor decreased TSH-stimulated up-regulation of ALPL, whereas a protein kinase C activator increased ALPL levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A MAPK inhibitor and silencing of ERK1/2 inhibited TSH-stimulated ALPL expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that TSH regulates expression of different bone markers via distinct signaling pathways.</Gene>
<Gene>A Role for Androgens in Epithelial Proliferation and Formation of Glands in the Mouse Uterus.</Gene>
<Gene>The endometrium consists of stromal and epithelial compartments (luminal and glandular) with distinct functions in the regulation of uterine homeostasis.</Gene>

<Gene>Ovarian sex steroids, namely 17b-estradiol and progesterone, play essential roles in modulating uterine cell proliferation, stromal-epithelial cross-talk and differentiation in preparation for pregnancy.</Gene>
<Gene>The effect of androgens on uterine function remains poorly understood.</Gene>
<Gene>The current study investigated the effect of the non-aromatizable androgen dihydrotestosterone (DHT) on mouse endometrial function.</Gene>

<Gene>Ovx female mice were given a single sc injection (short treatment) or 7 daily injections (long treatment) of vehicle alone (5% ethanol, 0.4% methylcellulose) or vehicle with the addition of 0.2 mg DHT (n=8/group) and a single injection of bromodeoxyuridine 2 hours prior to tissue recovery.</Gene>
<Gene>Treatment with DHT increased uterine weight, the area of the endometrial compartment and immunoexpression of the androgen receptor in the luminal and glandular epithelium.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Treatment-dependent proliferation of epithelial cells was identified by immunostaining for MKi67 and bromodeoxyuridine.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Real-time PCR identified significant DHT-dependent changes in the concentrations of mRNAs encoded by genes implicated in the regulation of the cell cycle (Wee1, Ccnd1, Rb1) and stromal-epithelial interactions (Wnt4, Wnt5a, Wnt7a, Cdh1, Vcl, Igf1, Prl8, Prlr) as well as a striking effect on the number of endometrial glands.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study has revealed a novel role for androgens in regulating uterine function with an effect on the glandular compartment of the endometrium.</Gene>
<Gene>This previously unrecognized role for androgens has implications for our understanding of the role of androgens in regulation of endometrial function and fertility in women.</Gene>
<Gene>MOL1 is required for cambium homeostasis in Arabidopsis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Plants maintain pools of pluripotent stem cells which allow them to constantly produce new tissues and organs.</Gene>
<Gene>Stem cell homeostasis in shoot and root tips depends on negative regulation by ligand-receptor pairs of the CLE peptide and leucine-rich repeat receptor-like kinase (LRR-RLK) families.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, regulation of the cambium, the stem cell niche required for lateral growth of shoots and roots, is poorly characterized.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we show that the LRR-RLK MOL1 is necessary for cambium homeostasis in Arabidopsis thaliana.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By employing promoter reporter lines, we reveal that MOL1 is active in a domain that is distinct from the domain of the positively acting CLE41/PXY signaling module.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In particular, we show that MOL1 acts in an opposing manner to the CLE41/PXY module and that changing the domain or level of MOL1 expression both result in disturbed cambium organization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Underlining discrete roles of MOL1 and PXY, both LRR-RLKs are not able to replace each other when their expression domains are interchanged.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, MOL1 but not PXY is able to rescue CLV1 deficiency in the shoot apical meristem.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By identifying genes mis-expressed in mol1 mutants, we demonstrate that MOL1 represses genes associated with stress-related ethylene and jasmonic acid hormone signaling pathways which have known roles in coordinating lateral growth of the Arabidopsis stem.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings provide evidence that common regulatory mechanisms in different plant stem cell niches are adapted to specific niche anatomies and emphasize the importance of a complex spatial organization of intercellular signaling cascades for a strictly bidirectional tissue production.</Gene>
<Gene>Yeast Gdt1 is a Golgi-localized calcium transporter required for stress-induced calcium signaling and protein glycosylation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Calcium signaling depends on a tightly regulated set of pumps, exchangers, and channels that are responsible for controlling calcium fluxes between the different subcellular compartments of the eukaryotic cell.</Gene>

<Gene>We have recently reported that two members of the highly-conserved UPF0016 family, human TMEM165 and budding yeast Gdt1p, are functionally related and might form a new group of Golgi-localized cation/Ca(2+) exchangers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Defects in the human protein TMEM165 are known to cause a subtype of Congenital Disorders of Glycosylation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using an assay based on the heterologous expression of GDT1 in the bacterium Lactococcus lactis, we demonstrated the calcium transport activity of Gdt1p.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We observed a Ca(2+) uptake activity in cells expressing GDT1, which was dependent on the external pH, indicating that Gdt1p may act as a Ca(2+)/H(+) antiporter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In yeast, we found that Gdt1p controls cellular calcium stores and plays a major role in the calcium response induced by osmotic shock when the Golgi calcium pump, Pmr1p, is absent.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, we also discovered that, in the presence of a high concentration of external calcium, Gdt1p is required for glycosylation of carboxypeptidase Y and the glucanosyltransferase Gas1p.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally we showed that glycosylation process is restored by providing more Mn(2+) to the cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Anti-IL-20 monoclonal antibody promotes bone fracture healing through regulating IL-20-mediated osteoblastogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bone loss and skeletal fragility in bone fracture are caused by an imbalance in bone remodeling.</Gene>
<Gene>The current challenge in bone fracture healing is to promote osteoblastogenesis and bone formation.</Gene>
<Gene>We aimed to explore the role of IL-20 in osteoblastogenesis, osteoblast differentiation and bone fracture.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Serum IL-20 was significantly correlated with serum sclerostin in patients with bone fracture.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In a mouse model, anti-IL-20 monoclonal antibody (mAb) 7E increased bone formation during fracture healing.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro, IL-20 inhibited osteoblastogenesis by upregulating sclerostin, and downregulating osterix (OSX), RUNX2, and osteoprotegerin (OPG).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IL-20R1 deficiency attenuated IL-20-mediated inhibition of osteoblast differentiation and maturation and reduced the healing time after a bone fracture.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that IL-20 affects bone formation and downregulates osteoblastogenesis by modulating sclerostin, OSX, RUNX2, and OPG on osteoblasts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results demonstrated that IL-20 is involved in osteoregulation and anti-IL-20 mAb is a potential therapeutic for treating bone fracture or metabolic bone diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Galectin-1 dimers can scaffold Raf-effectors to increase H-ras nanoclustering.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Galectin-1 (Gal-1) dimers crosslink carbohydrates on cell surface receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Carbohydrate-derived inhibitors have been developed for cancer treatment.</Gene>

<Gene>Intracellularly, Gal-1 was suggested to interact with the farnesylated C-terminus of Ras thus specifically stabilizing GTP-H-ras nanoscale signalling hubs in the membrane, termed nanoclusters.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The latter activity may present an alternative mechanism for how overexpressed Gal-1 stimulates tumourigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we revise the current model for the interaction of Gal-1 with H-ras.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that it indirectly forms a complex with GTP-H-ras via a high-affinity interaction with the Ras binding domain (RBD) of Ras effectors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A computationally generated model of the Gal-1/C-Raf-RBD complex is validated by mutational analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both cellular FRET as well as proximity ligation assay experiments confirm interaction of Gal-1 with Raf proteins in mammalian cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consistently, interference with H-rasG12V-effector interactions basically abolishes H-ras nanoclustering.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, an intact dimer interface of Gal-1 is required for it to positively regulate H-rasG12V nanoclustering, but negatively K-rasG12V nanoclustering.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings suggest stacked dimers of H-ras, Raf and Gal-1 as building blocks of GTP-H-ras-nanocluster at high Gal-1 levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Based on our results the Gal-1/effector interface represents a potential drug target site in diseases with aberrant Ras signalling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NLRP3 Localizes to the Tubular Epithelium in Human Kidney and Correlates With Outcome in IgA Nephropathy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nod-like receptor pyrin domain-containing-3 (NLRP3) has been implicated in the pathogenesis of experimental renal injury, yet its characterization in human kidney disease remains largely unexplored.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NLRP3 expression was evaluated in human kidney biopsies, primary renal tubular cells (HPTC) and correlated to disease outcomes in patients with IgA nephropathy (IgAN).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NLRP3 localized to renal tubules in normal human kidney tissue and to mitochondria within HPTC by immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence microscopy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Compared to control kidneys, NLRP3 gene expression was increased in biopsies of patients with IgAN.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>While NLRP3 expression in IgAN was detected in glomeruli, it remained largely confined to the tubular epithelial compartment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro NLRP3 mRNA and protein expression were transiently induced in HPTC by TGF-b1 but subsequently diminished over time as cells lost their epithelial phenotype in a process regulated by transcription and ubiquitin-mediated degradation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consistent with the in vitro data, low NLRP3 mRNA expression in kidney biopsies was associated with a linear trend of higher risk of composite endpoint of doubling serum creatinine and end stage renal disease in patients with IgAN.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, these data show that NLRP3 is primarily a kidney tubule-expressed protein that decreases in abundance in progressive IgAN.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human wild-type full-length tau accumulation disrupts mitochondrial dynamics and the functions via increasing mitofusins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intracellular accumulation of tau protein is hallmark of sporadic Alzheimer's disease (AD), however, the cellular mechanism whereby tau accumulation causes neurodegeneration is poorly understood.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we report that overexpression of human wild-type full-length tau (termed htau) disrupted mitochondrial dynamics by enhancing fusion and induced their perinuclear accumulation in HEK293 cells and rat primary hippocampal neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The htau accumulation at later stage inhibited mitochondrial functions shown by the decreased ATP level, the ratio of ATP/ADP and complex I activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Simultaneously, the cell viability was decreased with retraction of the cellular/neuronal processes.</Gene>
<Gene>Further studies demonstrated that htau accumulation increased fusion proteins, including OPA1 and mitofusins (Mfn1, Mfn2) and reduced the ubiquitination of Mfn2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Downregulation of the mitofusins by shRNA to ~45% or ~52% of the control levels attenuated the htau-enhanced mitochondrial fusion and restored the functions, while downregulation of OPA1 to ~50% of the control level did not show rescue effects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, abnormal mitochondrial accumulation and dysfunction were also observed in the brains of htau transgenic mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, our data demonstrate that htau accumulation decreases cell viability and causes degeneration via enhancing mitofusin-associated mitochondrial fusion, which provides new insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying tauopathies.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>On the pivotal role of PPARa in adaptation of the heart to hypoxia and why fat in the diet increases hypoxic injury.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The role of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor a (PPARa)-mediated metabolic remodeling in cardiac adaptation to hypoxia has yet to be defined.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, mice were housed in hypoxia for 3 wk before in vivo contractile function was measured using cine MRI.</Gene>
<Gene>In isolated, perfused hearts, energetics were measured using (31)P magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS), and glycolysis and fatty acid oxidation were measured using [(3)H] labeling.</Gene>

<Gene>Compared with a normoxic, chow-fed control mouse heart, hypoxia decreased PPARa expression, fatty acid oxidation, and mitochondrial uncoupling protein 3 (UCP3) levels, while increasing glycolysis, all of which served to maintain normal ATP concentrations ([ATP]) and thereby, ejection fractions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A high-fat diet increased cardiac PPARa expression, fatty acid oxidation, and UCP3 levels with decreased glycolysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hypoxia was unable to alter the high PPARa expression or reverse the metabolic changes caused by the high-fat diet, with the result that [ATP] and contractile function decreased significantly.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The adaptive metabolic changes caused by hypoxia in control mouse hearts were found to have occurred already in PPARa-deficient (PPARa(-/-)) mouse hearts and sustained function in hypoxia despite an inability for further metabolic remodeling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that decreased cardiac PPARa expression is essential for adaptive metabolic remodeling in hypoxia, but is prevented by dietary fat.-Cole, M. A., Abd Jamil, A. H., Heather, L. C., Murray, A. J., Sutton, E. R., Slingo, M., Sebag-Montefiore, L., Tan, S. C., Aksentijevic, D., Gildea, O. S., Stuckey, D. J., Yeoh, K. K., Carr, C. A., Evans, R. D., Aasum, E., Schofield, C. J., Ratcliffe, P. J., Neubauer, S., Robbins, P. A., Clarke, K.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>On the pivotal role of PPARa in adaptation of the heart to hypoxia and why fat in the diet increases hypoxic injury.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The leaves of Diospyros kaki exert beneficial effects on a benzalkonium chloride-induced murine dry eye model.</Gene>
<Gene>PURPOSE:</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, the beneficial effects of the oral administration of ethanol extract of Diospyros kaki (EEDK) were tested on a mouse dry eye model induced by benzalkonium chloride (BAC).</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>A solution of 0.2% BAC was administered topically to mouse eyes for 14 days, twice daily, to induce dry eye.</Gene>
<Gene>Various concentrations of EEDK were administrated daily by oral gavage for 14 days after BAC treatment.</Gene>
<Gene>Preservative-free eye drops were instilled in the positive-control group.</Gene>
<Gene>The tear secretion volume (Schirmer's test), tear break-up time (BUT), and fluorescein score were measured on the ocular surface.</Gene>
<Gene>BAC-induced corneal damage was tested with hematoxylin-eosin staining.</Gene>
<Gene>Moreover, apoptotic cell death in the corneal epithelial layer was investigated with terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase-mediated dUTP nick-end labeling (TUNEL) staining.</Gene>

<Gene>The protein expression level of interleukin-1alpha (IL-1a), IL-1b, IL-6, tumor necrosis factor- alpha (TNF-a), and monocyte chemotactic protein-1 (MCP-1) was determined with western blot analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, squamous metaplasia in the corneal epithelial layer was detected with immunofluorescent staining for cytokeratine-10.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The cellular proliferation in the cornea was examined with immunohistochemical staining for Ki-67.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>EEDK treatment resulted in prolonged BUT, decreased fluorescein score, increased tear volume, and smoother epithelial cells compared with BAC treatment alone in the cornea.</Gene>
<Gene>Moreover, EEDK treatment inhibited the inflammatory response and corneal epithelial cell death in a BAC-induced murine dry eye model, and changes in squamous cells were inhibited.</Gene>
<Gene>Proliferative activity in the corneal epithelium cells was improved with EEDK.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>EEDK could be a potential therapeutic agent in the clinical treatment of dry eye.</Gene>
<Gene>Long noncoding RNA LINP1 regulates repair of DNA double-strand breaks in triple-negative breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) play critical roles during tumorigenesis by functioning as scaffolds that regulate protein-protein, protein-DNA or protein-RNA interactions.</Gene>

<Gene>Using a clinically guided genetic screening approach, we identified lncRNA in nonhomologous end joining (NHEJ) pathway 1 (LINP1), which is overexpressed in human triple-negative breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found that LINP1 enhances repair of DNA double-strand breaks by serving as a scaffold linking Ku80 and DNA-PKcs, thereby coordinating the NHEJ pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, blocking LINP1, which is regulated by p53 and epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) signaling, increases the sensitivity of the tumor-cell response to radiotherapy in breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Metabolic Symbiosis Enables Adaptive Resistance to Anti-angiogenic Therapy that Is Dependent on mTOR Signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Therapeutic targeting of tumor angiogenesis with VEGF inhibitors results in demonstrable, but transitory efficacy in certain human tumors and mouse models of cancer, limited by unconventional forms of adaptive/evasive resistance.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In one such mouse model, potent angiogenesis inhibitors elicit compartmental reorganization of cancer cells around remaining blood vessels.</Gene>
<Gene>The glucose and lactate transporters GLUT1 and MCT4 are induced in distal hypoxic cells in a HIF1a-dependent fashion, indicative of glycolysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tumor cells proximal to blood vessels instead express the lactate transporter MCT1, and p-S6, the latter reflecting mTOR signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Normoxic cancer cells import and metabolize lactate, resulting in upregulation of mTOR signaling via glutamine metabolism enhanced by lactate catabolism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, metabolic symbiosis is established in the face of angiogenesis inhibition, whereby hypoxic cancer cells import glucose and export lactate, while normoxic cells import and catabolize lactate.</Gene>
<Gene>mTOR signaling inhibition disrupts this metabolic symbiosis, associated with upregulation of the glucose transporter GLUT2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Progesterone-Dependent Induction of Phospholipase C-Related Catalytically Inactive Protein 1 (PRIP-1) in Decidualizing Human Endometrial Stromal Cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Decidualization denotes the transformation of endometrial stromal cells into specialized decidual cells.</Gene>
<Gene>In pregnancy, decidual cells form a protective matrix around the implanting embryo, enabling coordinated trophoblast invasion and formation of a functional placenta.</Gene>

<Gene>Continuous progesterone (P4) signaling renders decidual cells resistant to various environmental stressors, whereas withdrawal inevitably triggers tissue breakdown and menstruation or miscarriage.</Gene>

<Gene>Here, we show that PLCL1, coding phospholipase C (PLC)-related catalytically inactive protein 1 (PRIP-1), is highly induced in response to P4 signaling in decidualizing human endometrial stromal cells (HESCs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Knockdown experiments in undifferentiated HESCs revealed that PRIP-1 maintains basal phosphoinositide 3-kinase/Protein kinase B activity, which in turn prevents illicit nuclear translocation of the transcription factor forkhead box protein O1 and induction of the apoptotic activator BIM.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By contrast, loss of this scaffold protein did not compromise survival of decidual cells.</Gene>

<Gene>PRIP-1 knockdown did also not interfere with the responsiveness of HESCs to deciduogenic cues, although the overall expression of differentiation markers, such as PRL, IGFBP1, and WNT4, was blunted.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, we show that PRIP-1 in decidual cells uncouples PLC activation from intracellular Ca(2+) release by attenuating inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In summary, PRIP-1 is a multifaceted P4-inducible scaffold protein that gates the activity of major signal transduction pathways in the endometrium.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It prevents apoptosis of proliferating stromal cells and contributes to the relative autonomy of decidual cells by silencing PLC signaling downstream of Gq protein-coupled receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Medial HOXA genes demarcate haematopoietic stem cell fate during human development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pluripotent stem cells (PSCs) may provide a potential source of haematopoietic stem/progenitor cells (HSPCs) for transplantation; however, unknown molecular barriers prevent the self-renewal of PSC-HSPCs.</Gene>

<Gene>Using two-step differentiation, human embryonic stem cells (hESCs) differentiated in vitro into multipotent haematopoietic cells that had the CD34(+)CD38(-/lo)CD90(+)CD45(+)GPI-80(+) fetal liver (FL) HSPC immunophenotype, but exhibited poor expansion potential and engraftment ability.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transcriptome analysis of immunophenotypic hESC-HSPCs revealed that, despite their molecular resemblance to FL-HSPCs, medial HOXA genes remained suppressed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Knockdown of HOXA7 disrupted FL-HSPC function and caused transcriptome dysregulation that resembled hESC-derived progenitors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of medial HOXA genes prolonged FL-HSPC maintenance but was insufficient to confer self-renewal to hESC-HSPCs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Stimulation of retinoic acid signalling during endothelial-to-haematopoietic transition induced the HOXA cluster and other HSC/definitive haemogenic endothelium genes, and prolonged HSPC maintenance in culture.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, medial HOXA gene expression induced by retinoic acid signalling marks the establishment of the definitive HSPC fate and controls HSPC identity and function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Metallothionein-1 as a biomarker of altered redox metabolism in hepatocellular carcinoma cells exposed to sorafenib.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Sorafenib, a kinase inhibitor active against various solid tumours, induces oxidative stress and ferroptosis, a new form of oxidative necrosis, in some cancer cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Clinically-applicable biomarkers that reflect the impact of sorafenib on the redox metabolism of cancer cells are lacking.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>We used gene expression microarrays, real-time PCR, immunoblot, protein-specific ELISA, and gene reporter constructs encoding the enzyme luciferase to study the response of a panel of cancer cells to sorafenib.</Gene>
<Gene>Tumour explants prepared from surgical hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) samples and serum samples obtained from HCC patients receiving sorafenib were also used.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>We observed that genes of the metallothionein-1 (MT1) family are induced in the HCC cell line Huh7 exposed to sorafenib.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sorafenib increased the expression of MT1G mRNA in a panel of human cancer cells, an effect that was not observed with eight other clinically-approved kinase inhibitors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We identified the minimal region of the MT1G promoter that confers inducibility by sorafenib to a 133 base pair region containing an Anti-oxidant Response Element (ARE) and showed the essential role of the transcription factor NRF2 (Nuclear factor erythroid 2-Related Factor 2).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We examined the clinical relevance of our findings by analysing the regulation of MT1G in five tumour explants prepared from surgical HCC samples.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, we showed that the protein levels of MT1 increase in the serum of some HCC patients receiving sorafenib, and found an association with reduced overall survival.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>These findings indicate that MT1 constitute a biomarker adapted for exploring the impact of sorafenib on the redox metabolism of cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Telomere Replication Stress Induced by POT1 Inactivation Accelerates Tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Genome sequencing studies have revealed a number of cancer-associated mutations in the telomere-binding factor POT1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we show that when combined with p53 deficiency, depletion of murine POT1a in common lymphoid progenitor cells fosters genetic instability, accelerates the onset, and increases the severity of T cell lymphomas.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In parallel, we examined human and mouse cells carrying POT1 mutations found in cutaneous T cell lymphoma (CTCL) patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of POT1 activates ATR-dependent DNA damage signaling and induces telomere fragility, replication fork stalling, and telomere elongation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggest that these phenotypes are linked to impaired CST (CTC1-STN1-TEN1) function at telomeres.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lastly, we show that proliferation of cancer cells lacking POT1 is enabled by the attenuation of the ATR kinase pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results uncover a role for defective telomere replication during tumorigenesis.</Gene>
<Gene>Loss of the Protein Tyrosine Phosphatase PTPN22 Reduces Mannan-Induced Autoimmune Arthritis in SKG Mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cytoplasmic phosphatase, protein tyrosine phosphatase nonreceptor type 22 (PTPN22), is a negative regulator of T cell signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genome-wide association studies have shown that single-nucleotide polymorphisms in PTPN22 confer an increased risk of developing multiple autoimmune diseases in humans.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The precise function of PTPN22 and how the variant protein contributes to autoimmunity is not well understood.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To address this issue, we investigated the effect of PTPN22 deficiency on disease susceptibility in a mouse model of autoimmune arthritis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The SKG mouse expresses a hypomorphic mutant allele of ZAP70, which, upon exposure to fungal Ags, predisposes the mice to a CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T cell-mediated autoimmune arthritis that closely resembles rheumatoid arthritis in humans.</Gene>
<Gene>Surprisingly, SKG Ptpn22(-/-) mice developed less severe mannan-induced arthritis compared with SKG mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Diminution of disease was not due to significant alterations in thymocyte development or repertoire selection in SKG Ptpn22(-/-) mice, even though T cell-mediated signal transduction was improved.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Instead, Ptpn22 deficiency appeared to bias CD4 Th cell differentiation away from the Th17 lineage, which is pathogenic in this setting, to a more Th1/T regulatory-focused response.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data show that even small perturbations in TCR signal transduction pathways can have profound consequences on the differentiation of T cell lineages and thus for the development of autoimmune diseases.</Gene>
<Gene>T-bet Activates Th1 Genes through Mediator and the Super Elongation Complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The transcription factor T-bet directs Th1 cell differentiation, but the molecular mechanisms that underlie this lineage-specific gene regulation are not completely understood.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we show that T-bet acts through enhancers to allow the recruitment of Mediator and P-TEFb in the form of the super elongation complex (SEC).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Th1 genes are occupied by H3K4me3 and RNA polymerase II in Th2 cells, while T-bet-mediated recruitment of P-TEFb in Th1 cells activates transcriptional elongation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>P-TEFb is recruited to both genes and enhancers, where it activates enhancer RNA transcription.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>P-TEFb inhibition and Mediator and SEC knockdown selectively block activation of T-bet target genes, and P-TEFb inhibition abrogates Th1-associated experimental autoimmune uveitis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T-bet activity is independent of changes in NF-kB RelA and Brd4 binding, with T-bet- and NF-kB-mediated pathways instead converging to allow P-TEFb recruitment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data provide insight into the mechanism through which lineage-specifying factors promote differentiation of alternative T cell fates.</Gene>

<Gene>Investigating core genetic-and-epigenetic cell cycle networks for stemness and carcinogenic mechanisms, and cancer drug design using big database mining and genome-wide next-generation sequencing data.</Gene>
<Gene>Recent studies have demonstrated that cell cycle plays a central role in development and carcinogenesis.</Gene>

<Gene>Thus, the use of big databases and genome-wide high-throughput data to unravel the genetic and epigenetic mechanisms underlying cell cycle progression in stem cells and cancer cells is a matter of considerable interest.</Gene>

<Gene>Real genetic-and-epigenetic cell cycle networks (GECNs) of embryonic stem cells (ESCs) and HeLa cancer cells were constructed by applying system modeling, system identification, and big database mining to genome-wide next-generation sequencing data.</Gene>
<Gene>Real GECNs were then reduced to core GECNs of HeLa cells and ESCs by applying principal genome-wide network projection.</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, we investigated potential carcinogenic and stemness mechanisms for systems cancer drug design by identifying common core and specific GECNs between HeLa cells and ESCs.</Gene>

<Gene>Integrating drug database information with the specific GECNs of HeLa cells could lead to identification of multiple drugs for cervical cancer treatment with minimal side-effects on the genes in the common core.</Gene>

<Gene>We found that dysregulation of miR-29C, miR-34A, miR-98, and miR-215; and methylation of ANKRD1, ARID5B, CDCA2, PIF1, STAMBPL1, TROAP, ZNF165, and HIST1H2AJ in HeLa cells could result in cell proliferation and anti-apoptosis through NFkB, TGF-b, and PI3K pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also identified 3 drugs, methotrexate, quercetin, and mimosine, which repressed the activated cell cycle genes, ARID5B, STK17B, and CCL2, in HeLa cells with minimal side-effects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A recurrent p.Arg92Trp variant in steroidogenic factor-1 (NR5A1) can act as a molecular switch in human sex development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cell lineages of the early human gonad commit to one of the two mutually antagonistic organogenetic fates, the testis or the ovary.</Gene>

<Gene>Some individuals with a 46,XX karyotype develop testes or ovotestes (testicular or ovotesticular disorder of sex development; TDSD/OTDSD), due to the presence of the testis-determining gene, SRY Other rare complex syndromic forms of TDSD/OTDSD are associated with mutations in pro-ovarian genes that repress testis development (e.g. WNT4); however, the genetic cause of the more common non-syndromic forms is unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Steroidogenic factor-1 (known as NR5A1) is a key regulator of reproductive development and function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Loss-of-function changes in NR5A1 in 46,XY individuals are associated with a spectrum of phenotypes in humans ranging from a lack of testis formation to male infertility.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in NR5A1 in 46,XX women are associated with primary ovarian insufficiency, which includes a lack of ovary formation, primary and secondary amenorrhoea as well as early menopause.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we show that a specific recurrent heterozygous missense mutation (p.Arg92Trp) in the accessory DNA-binding region of NR5A1 is associated with variable degree of testis development in 46,XX children and adults from four unrelated families.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Remarkably, in one family a sibling raised as a girl and carrying this NR5A1 mutation was found to have a 46,XY karyotype with partial testicular dysgenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These unique findings highlight how a specific variant in a developmental transcription factor can switch organ fate from the ovary to testis in mammals and represents the first missense mutation causing isolated, non-syndromic 46,XX testicular/ovotesticular DSD in humans.</Gene>
<Gene>Male 11b-HSD1 Knockout Mice Fed Trans-Fats and Fructose Are Not Protected From Metabolic Syndrome or Nonalcoholic Fatty Liver Disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) defines a spectrum of conditions from simple steatosis to nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) and cirrhosis and is regarded as the hepatic manifestation of the metabolic syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>Glucocorticoids can promote steatosis by stimulating lipolysis within adipose tissue, free fatty acid delivery to liver and hepatic de novo lipogenesis.</Gene>
<Gene>Glucocorticoids can be reactivated in liver through 11b-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase type 1 (11b-HSD1) enzyme activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of 11b-HSD1 has been suggested as a potential treatment for NAFLD.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To test this, male mice with global (11b-HSD1 knockout</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>[KO]) and liver-specific (LKO) 11b-HSD1 loss of function were fed the American Lifestyle Induced Obesity Syndrome (ALIOS) diet, known to recapitulate the spectrum of NAFLD, and metabolic and liver phenotypes assessed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Body weight, muscle and adipose tissue masses, and parameters of glucose homeostasis showed that 11b-HSD1KO and LKO mice were not protected from systemic metabolic disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Evaluation of hepatic histology, triglyceride content, and blinded NAFLD activity score assessment indicated that levels of steatosis were similar between 11b-HSD1KO, LKO, and control mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Unexpectedly, histological analysis revealed significantly increased levels of immune foci present in livers of 11b-HSD1KO but not LKO or control mice, suggestive of a transition to NASH.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This was endorsed by elevated hepatic expression of key immune cell and inflammatory markers.</Gene>
<Gene>These data indicate that 11b-HSD1-deficient mice are not protected from metabolic disease or hepatosteatosis in the face of a NAFLD-inducing diet.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, global deficiency of 11b-HSD1 did increase markers of hepatic inflammation and suggests a critical role for 11b-HSD1 in restraining the transition to NASH.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VHL-deficient renal cancer cells gain resistance to mitochondria-activating apoptosis inducers by activating AKT through the IGF1R-PI3K pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We previously developed (2-deoxyglucose)-(ABT-263) combination therapy (2DG-ABT), which induces apoptosis by activating Bak in the mitochondria of highly glycolytic cells with varied genetic backgrounds.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, the rates of apoptosis induced by 2DG-ABT were lower in von Hippel-Lindau (VHL)-deficient cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The re-expression of VHL protein in these cells lowered IGF1R expression in a manner independent of oxygen concentration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lowering IGF1R expression via small interfering RNA (siRNA) sensitized the cells to 2DG-ABT, suggesting that IGF1R interfered with the activation of apoptosis by the mitochondria.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To determine which of the two pathways activated by IGF1R, the Ras-ERK pathway or the PI3K-AKT pathway, was involved in the impairment of mitochondria activation, the cells were treated with a specific inhibitor of either PI3K or ERK, and 2DG-ABT was added to activate the mitochondria.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The apoptotic rates resulting from 2DG-ABT treatment were higher in the cells treated with the PI3K inhibitor, while the rates remained approximately the same in the cells treated with the ERK inhibitor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In 2DG-ABT-sensitive cells, a 4-h 2DG treatment caused the dissociation of Mcl-1 from Bak, while ABT treatment alone caused the dissociation of Bcl-xL from Bak without substantially reducing Mcl-1 levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In 2DG-ABT-resistant cells, Mcl-1 dissociated from Bak only when AKT activity was inhibited during the 4-h 2DG treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, in VHL-deficient cells, IGF1R activated AKT and stabilized the Bak-Mcl-1 complex, thereby conferring cell resistance to apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A role for the yeast CLIP170 ortholog, the plus-end-tracking protein Bik1, and the Rho1 GTPase in Snc1 trafficking.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The diversity of microtubule functions is dependent on the status of tubulin C-termini.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To address the physiological role of the C-terminal aromatic residue of a-tubulin, a tub1-Glu yeast strain expressing an a-tubulin devoid of its C-terminal amino acid was used to perform a genome-wide-lethality screen.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The identified synthetic lethal genes suggested links with endocytosis and related processes.</Gene>

<Gene>In the tub1-Glu strain, the routing of the v-SNARE Snc1 was strongly impaired, with a loss of its polarized distribution in the bud, and Abp1, an actin patch or endocytic marker, developed comet-tail structures.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Snc1 trafficking required dynamic microtubules but not dynein and kinesin motors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, deletion of the microtubule plus-end-tracking protein Bik1 (a CLIP170 ortholog), which is preferentially recruited to the C-terminal residue of a-tubulin, similarly resulted in Snc1 trafficking defects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, constitutively active Rho1 rescued both Bik1 localization at the microtubule plus-ends in tub1-Glu strain and a correct Snc1 trafficking in a Bik1-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results provide the first evidence for a role of microtubule plus-ends in membrane cargo trafficking in yeast, through Rho1- and Bik1-dependent mechanisms, and highlight the importance of the C-terminal a-tubulin amino acid in this process.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Proteinase-activated receptor 2 (PAR2) in hepatic stellate cells - evidence for a role in hepatocellular carcinoma growth in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>Previous studies have established that proteinase-activated receptor 2 (PAR2) promotes migration and invasion of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells, suggesting a role in HCC progression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we assessed the impact of PAR2 in HCC stromal cells on HCC growth using LX-2 hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) and Hep3B cells as model.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>PAR2 expression and function in LX-2 cells was analysed by RT-PCR, confocal immunofluorescence, electron microscopy, and [Ca(2+)]i measurements, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The impact of LX-2-expressed PAR2 on tumour growth in vivo was monitored using HCC xenotransplantation experiments in SCID mice, in which HCC-like tumours were induced by coinjection of LX-2 cells and Hep3B cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To characterise the effects of PAR2 activation in LX-2 cells, various signalling pathways were analysed by immunoblotting and proteome profiler arrays.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Following verification of functional PAR2 expression in LX-2 cells, in vivo studies showed that these cells promoted tumour growth and angiogenesis of HCC xenografts in mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These effects were significantly reduced when F2RL1 (encoding PAR2) was downregulated by RNA interference (RNAi).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro studies confirmed these results demonstrating RNAi mediated inhibition of PAR2 attenuated Smad2/3 activation in response to TGF-b1 stimulation in LX-2 cells and blocked the pro-mitotic effect of LX-2 derived conditioned medium on Hep3B cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, PAR2 stimulation with trypsin or a PAR2-selective activating peptide (PAR2-AP) led to activation of different intracellular signalling pathways, an increased secretion of pro-angiogenic and pro-mitotic factors and proteinases, and an enhanced migration rate across a collagen-coated membrane barrier.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Silencing F2RL1 by RNAi or pharmacological inhibition of Src, hepatocyte growth factor receptor (Met), platelet-derived growth factor receptor (PDGFR), p42/p44 mitogen activated protein kinase (MAPK) or matrix-metalloproteinases (MMPs) blocked PAR2-AP-induced migration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>PAR2 in HSCs plays a crucial role in promoting HCC growth presumably by mediating migration and secretion of pro-angiogenic and pro-mitotic factors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, PAR2 in stromal HSCs may have relevance as a therapeutic target of HCC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MicroRNA-203 mimics age-related aortic smooth muscle dysfunction of cytoskeletal pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Increased aortic stiffness is a biomarker for subsequent adverse cardiovascular events.</Gene>
<Gene>We have previously reported that vascular smooth muscle Src-dependent cytoskeletal remodelling, which contributes to aortic plasticity, is impaired with ageing.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we use a multi-scale approach to determine the molecular mechanisms behind defective Src-dependent signalling in an aged C57BL/6 male mouse model.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Increased aortic stiffness, as measured in vivo by pulse wave velocity, was found to have a comparable time course to that in humans.</Gene>
<Gene>Bioinformatic analyses predicted several miRs to regulate Src-dependent cytoskeletal remodelling.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>qRT-PCR was used to determine the relative levels of predicted miRs in aortas and, notably, the expression of miR-203 increased almost twofold in aged aorta.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Increased miR-203 expression was associated with a decrease in both mRNA and protein expression of Src, caveolin-1 and paxillin in aged aorta.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Probing with phospho-specific antibodies confirmed that overexpression of miR-203 significantly attenuated Src and extracellular signal regulated kinase (ERK) signalling, which we have previously found to regulate vascular smooth muscle stiffness.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, transfection of miR-203 into aortic tissue from young mice increased phenylephrine-induced aortic stiffness ex vivo, mimicking the aged phenotype.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Upstream of miR-203, we found that DNA methyltransferases (DNMT) 1, 3a, and 3b are also significantly decreased in the aged mouse aorta and that DNMT inhibition significantly increases miR-203 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, the age-induced increase in miR-203 may be caused by epigenetic promoter hypomethylation in the aorta.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings indicate that miR-203 promotes a re-programming of Src/ERK signalling pathways in vascular smooth muscle, impairing the regulation of stiffness in aged aorta.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Combination of the histone deacetylase inhibitor depsipeptide and 5-fluorouracil upregulates major histocompatibility complex class II and p21 genes and activates caspase-3/7 in human colon cancer HCT-116 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Epigenetic anticancer drugs such as histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitors have been combined with existing anticancer drugs for synergistic or additive effects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the present study, we found that a very low concentration of depsipeptide, an HDAC inhibitor, potentiated the antitumor activity of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) in a human colon cancer cell model using HCT-116, HT29, and SW48 cells via the inhibition of colony formation ability or cellular viability.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Exposure to a combination of 5-FU (1.75 uM) and 1 nM depsipeptide for 24 and 48 h resulted in a 3- to 4-fold increase in activated caspase-3/7, while 5-FU alone failed to activate caspase-3/7. Microarray and subsequent gene ontology analyses revealed that compared to 5-FU or depsipeptide alone, the combination treatment of 5-FU and depsipeptide upregulated genes related to cell death and the apoptotic process consistent with the inhibition of colony formation and caspase-3/7 activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These analyses indicated marked upregulation of antigen processing and presentation of peptide or polysaccharide antigen via major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class (GO:0002504) and MHC protein complex (GO:0042611).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Compared with vehicle controls, the cells treated with the combination of 5-FU and depsipeptide showed marked induction (3- to 8.5-fold) of expression of MHC class II genes, but not of MHC class I genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, our global analysis of gene expression, which was focused on genes involved in the molecular regulation of MHC class II genes, showed enhancement of pro-apoptotic PCAF and CIITA after the combination of 5-FU and depsipeptide.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results may indicate a closer relationship between elevation of MHC class II expression and cellular apoptosis induced by the combination of depsipeptide and 5-FU.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to report that the combination of 5-FU and depsipeptide induces human colon cancer cell apoptosis in a concerted manner with the induction of MHC class II gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IGFBP1 increases b-cell regeneration by promoting a- to b-cell transdifferentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>There is great interest in therapeutically harnessing endogenous regenerative mechanisms to increase the number of b cells in people with diabetes.</Gene>
<Gene>By performing whole-genome expression profiling of zebrafish islets, we identified 11 secreted proteins that are upregulated during b-cell regeneration.</Gene>
<Gene>We then tested the proteins' ability to potentiate b-cell regeneration in zebrafish at supraphysiological levels.</Gene>
<Gene>One protein, insulin-like growth factor (Igf) binding-protein 1 (Igfbp1), potently promoted b-cell regeneration by potentiating a- to b-cell transdifferentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using various inhibitors and activators of the Igf pathway, we show that Igfbp1 exerts its regenerative effect, at least partly, by inhibiting Igf signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Igfbp1's effect on transdifferentiation appears conserved across species: Treating mouse and human islets with recombinant IGFBP1 in vitro increased the number of cells co-expressing insulin and glucagon threefold.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, a prospective human study showed that having high IGFBP1 levels reduces the risk of developing type-2 diabetes by more than 85%.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, we identify IGFBP1 as an endogenous promoter of b-cell regeneration and highlight its clinical importance in diabetes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Small RNA in situ hybridization in Caenorhabditis elegans, combined with RNA-seq, identifies germline-enriched microRNAs.</Gene>
<Gene>Over four hundred different microRNAs (miRNAs) have been identified in the genome of the model organism the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans.</Gene>

<Gene>As the germline is dedicated to the preservation of each species, and almost half of all the cells in an adult nematode are germline, it is likely that regulatory miRNAs are important for germline development and maintenance.</Gene>
<Gene>In C. elegans the miR35 family has strong maternal effects, contributing to normal embryogenesis and to adult fecundity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To determine whether any particular miRNAs are greatly enriched in the C. elegans germline we used RNA-seq to compare the miRNA populations in several germline-defective strains of adult C. elegans worms, including glp-4(germline proliferation-4), glh-1(germline helicase-1) and dcr-1(dicer-1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Statistical analyses of RNA-seq comparisons identified 13 miRNAs that are germline-enriched, including seven members of the well-studied miR35 family that were reduced as much as 1000-fold in TaqMan qRT PCR miRNA assays.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Along with the miR35s, six others: miR-56 (a member of the miR51 family),-70, -244, -260 , -788 and -4813, none of which previously considered as such, were also identified by RNA-seq as germline-enriched candidates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
