text: <Gene>We went on to develop a successful miRNA in situ hybridization protocol for C. elegans, revealing miR35s specifically concentrate during oogenesis in the pachytene region of the gonad, and persist throughout early embryogenesis, while in adult animals neither let-7 nor miR-228 has a germline-bias.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>FANCM c.5101C>T mutation associates with breast cancer survival and treatment outcome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Breast cancer (BC) is a heterogeneous disease, and different tumor characteristics and genetic variation may affect the clinical outcome.</Gene>
<Gene>The FANCM c.5101C ></Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>T nonsense mutation in the Finnish population associates with increased risk of breast cancer, especially for triple-negative breast cancer patients.</Gene>

<Gene>To investigate the association of the mutation with disease prognosis, we studied tumor phenotype, treatment outcome, and patient survival in 3,933 invasive breast cancer patients, including 101 FANCM c.5101C > T mutation carriers and 3,832 non-carriers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We also examined association of the mutation with nuclear immunohistochemical staining of DNA repair markers in 1,240 breast tumors.</Gene>

<Gene>The FANCM c.5101C > T mutation associated with poor 10-year breast cancer-specific survival (hazard ratio (HR)=1.66, 95% confidence interval (CI) 1.09-2.52, p = 0.018), with a more pronounced survival effect among familial cases (HR = 2.93, 95% CI 1.5-5.76, p = 1.80 x 10(-3) ).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Poor disease outcome of the carriers was also found among the estrogen receptor (ER) positive subgroup of patients (HR = 1.8, 95% CI 1.09-2.98, p = 0.021).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Reduced survival was seen especially among patients who had not received radiotherapy (HR = 3.43, 95% CI 1.6-7.34, p = 1.50 x 10(-3) ) but not among radiotherapy treated patients (HR = 1.35, 95% CI 0.82-2.23, p = 0.237).</Gene>
<Gene>Significant interaction was found between the mutation and radiotherapy (p = 0.040).</Gene>
<Gene>Immunohistochemical analyses show that c.5101C > T carriers have reduced PAR-activity.</Gene>
<Gene>Our results suggest that FANCM c.5101C ></Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>T nonsense mutation carriers have a reduced breast cancer survival but postoperative radiotherapy may diminish this survival disadvantage.</Gene>
<Gene>Long-Lived CD4+IFN-g+ T Cells rather than Short-Lived CD4+IFN-g+IL-10+ T Cells Initiate Rapid IL-10 Production To Suppress Anamnestic T Cell Responses during Secondary Malaria Infection.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>T cells that produce IFN-g are the source of host-protective IL-10 during primary infection with a number of different pathogens, including Plasmodium spp.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The fate of these CD4(+)IFN-g(+)IL-10(+) T cells following clearance of primary infection and their subsequent influence on the course of repeated infections is, however, presently unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, utilizing IFN-g-yellow fluorescent protein (YFP) and IL-10-GFP dual reporter mice, we show that primary malaria infection-induced CD4(+)YFP(+)GFP(+) T cells have limited memory potential, do not stably express IL-10, and are disproportionately lost from the Ag-experienced CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T cell memory population during the maintenance phase postinfection.</Gene>
<Gene>CD4(+)YFP(+)GFP(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T cells generally exhibited a short-lived effector rather than effector memory T cell phenotype postinfection and expressed high levels of PD-1, Lag-3, and TIGIT, indicative of cellular exhaustion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consistently, the surviving CD4(+)YFP(+)GFP(+) T cell-derived cells were unresponsive and failed to proliferate during the early phase of secondary infection.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, CD4(+)YFP(+)GFP(-) T cell-derived cells expanded rapidly and upregulated IL-10 expression during secondary infection.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Correspondingly, CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>T cells were the major producers within an accelerated and amplified IL-10 response during the early stage of secondary malaria infection.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Notably, IL-10 exerted quantitatively stronger regulatory effects on innate and CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T cell responses during primary and secondary infections, respectively.</Gene>
<Gene>The results in this study significantly improve our understanding of the durability of IL-10-producing CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T cells postinfection and provide information on how IL-10 may contribute to optimized parasite control and prevention of immune-mediated pathology during repeated malaria infections.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Alcohol consumption and prostate cancer incidence and progression: A Mendelian randomisation study.</Gene>
<Gene>Prostate cancer is the most common cancer in men in developed countries, and is a target for risk reduction strategies.</Gene>
<Gene>The effects of alcohol consumption on prostate cancer incidence and survival remain unclear, potentially due to methodological limitations of observational studies.</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, we investigated the associations of genetic variants in alcohol-metabolising genes with prostate cancer incidence and survival.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We analysed data from 23,868 men with prostate cancer and 23,051 controls from 25 studies within the international PRACTICAL Consortium.</Gene>

<Gene>Study-specific associations of 68 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in 8 alcohol-metabolising genes (Alcohol Dehydrogenases (ADHs) and Aldehyde Dehydrogenases (ALDHs)) with prostate cancer diagnosis and prostate cancer-specific mortality, by grade, were assessed using logistic and Cox regression models, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The data across the 25 studies were meta-analysed using fixed-effect and random-effects models.</Gene>
<Gene>We found little evidence that variants in alcohol metabolising genes were associated with prostate cancer diagnosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Four variants in two genes exceeded the multiple testing threshold for associations with prostate cancer mortality in fixed-effect meta-analyses.</Gene>

<Gene>SNPs within ALDH1A2 associated with prostate cancer mortality were rs1441817 (fixed effects hazard ratio, HRfixed  = 0.78; 95% confidence interval (95%CI):0.66,0.91; p values = 0.002); rs12910509, HRfixed  = 0.76; 95%CI:0.64,0.91; p values = 0.003); and rs8041922 (HRfixed  = 0.76; 95%CI:0.64,0.91; p values = 0.002).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These SNPs were in linkage disequilibrium with each other.</Gene>
<Gene>In ALDH1B1, rs10973794 (HRfixed  = 1.43; 95%CI:1.14,1.79; p values = 0.002) was associated with prostate cancer mortality in men with low-grade prostate cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that alcohol consumption is unlikely to affect prostate cancer incidence, but it may influence disease progression.</Gene>
<Gene>Elevated Hypothalamic Glucocorticoid Levels Are Associated With Obesity and Hyperphagia in Male Mice.</Gene>

<Gene>Glucocorticoid (Gc) excess, from endogenous overproduction in disorders of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis or exogenous medical therapy, is recognized to cause adverse metabolic side effects.</Gene>
<Gene>The Gc receptor (GR) is widely expressed throughout the body, including brain regions such as the hypothalamus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the extent to which chronic Gcs affect Gc concentrations in the hypothalamus and impact on GR and target genes is unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To investigate this, we used a murine model of corticosterone (Cort)-induced obesity and analyzed Cort levels in the hypothalamus and expression of genes relevant to Gc action.</Gene>
<Gene>Mice were administered Cort (75 ug/mL) or ethanol (1%, vehicle) in drinking water for 4 weeks.</Gene>
<Gene>Cort-treated mice had increased body weight, food intake, and adiposity.</Gene>
<Gene>As expected, Cort increased plasma Cort levels at both zeitgeber time 1 and zeitgeber time 13, ablating the diurnal rhythm.</Gene>

<Gene>Liquid chromatography dual tandem mass spectrometry revealed a 4-fold increase in hypothalamic Cort, which correlated with circulating levels and concentrations of Cort in other brain regions.</Gene>

<Gene>This occurred despite decreased 11b-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase (Hsd11b1) expression, the gene encoding the enzyme that regenerates active Gcs, whereas efflux transporter Abcb1 mRNA was unaltered.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, although Cort decreased hypothalamic GR (Nr3c1) expression 2-fold, the Gc-induced leucine zipper (Tsc22d3) mRNA increased, which indicated elevated GR activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In keeping with the development of hyperphagia and obesity, Cort increased Agrp, but there were no changes in Pomc, Npy, or Cart mRNA in the hypothalamus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In summary, chronic Cort treatment causes chronic increases in hypothalamic Cort levels and a persistent elevation in Agrp, a mediator in the development of metabolic disturbances.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Role of angiotensin II type 1a receptor in renal injury induced by deoxycorticosterone acetate-salt hypertension.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The aim of this study was to investigate the in vivo role of angiotensin II type 1a (AT1a) receptor in renal damage as a result of hypertension by using transgenic mice with AT1a receptor gene disruption.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transgenic mice that express human liver-type fatty acid binding protein (L-FABP) with or without disruption of the AT1a receptor gene (L-FABP(+/-) AT1a(-/-), and L-FABP(+/-) AT1a(+/+), respectively) were used with urinary L-FABP as an indicator of tubulointerstitial damage.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Those female mice were administered subcutaneously deoxycorticosterone acetate (DOCA)-salt tablets plus drinking water that contained 1% saline for 28 d after uninephrectomy.</Gene>

<Gene>In L-FABP(+/-) AT1a(+/+) mice that received DOCA-salt treatment, hypertension was induced and slight expansion of glomerular area, glomerular sclerosis, and tubulointerstitial damage were observed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In L-FABP(+/-) AT1a(-/-)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>mice that received DOCA-salt treatment, hypertension was similarly induced and the degree of glomerular damage was significantly more severe than in L-FABP(+/-)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>AT1a(+/+)-DOCA mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Urinary L-FABP levels were significantly higher in L-FABP(+/-)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>AT1a(-/-)-DOCA mice compared with those in L-FABP(+/-)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>AT1a(+/+)-DOCA mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hydralazine treatment significantly attenuated renal damage that was found in L-FABP(+/-)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>AT1a(-/-)-DOCA mice along with a reduction in blood pressure.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In summary, activation of the AT1a receptor may contribute to maintenance of the glomerular structure against hypertensive renal damage.-Hisamichi, M., Kamijo-Ikemori, A., Sugaya, T., Ichikawa, D., Natsuki, T., Hoshino, S., Kimura, K., Shibagaki, Y. Role of angiotensin II type 1a receptor in renal injury induced by deoxycorticosterone acetate-salt hypertension.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Increased intermediate M1-M2 macrophage polarization and improved cognition in mild cognitive impairment patients on w-3 supplementation.</Gene>

<Gene>Monocyte/macrophages of patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and Alzheimer disease (AD) are defective in phagocytosis and degradation amyloid b1-42 (Ab1-42), but are improved by w-3 fatty acids (w-3s).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The hypothesis of this study was that active Ab1-42 phagocytosis by macrophages prevents brain amyloidosis and thus maintains cognition.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We studied the effects of self-supplementation with a drink with w-3s, antioxidants, and resveratrol on Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) scores, macrophage M1M2 phenotype</Gene>

<Gene>[the ratio of inflammatory cluster of differentiation (CD)54+CD80 and proresolution markers CD163+CD206], and Ab1-42 phagocytosis in patients initially diagnosed as having MCI or subjective cognitive impairment (SCI).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>At baseline, the median MMSE score in patients in both the apolipoprotein E (ApoE) e3/e3 and ApoE e3/e4 groups was 26.0 and macrophage Ab1-42 phagocytosis was defective.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The MMSE rate of change increased in the ApoE e3/e3 group a median 2.2 points per year (P = 0.015 compared to 0) but did not change in the ApoE e3/e4 group (P = 0.014 between groups).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the ApoE e3/e3 group, all patients remained cognitively stable or improved; in the ApoE e3/e4 group, 1 recovered from dementia, but 3 lapsed into dementia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The macrophage phenotype polarized in patients bearing ApoE e3/e3 to an intermediate (green zone) M1-M2 type at the rate of 0.226 U/yr, whereas in patients bearing ApoE e3/e4, polarization was negative (P = 0.08 between groups).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The baseline M1M2 type in the extreme M1 (red zone) or M2 (white zone) was unfavorable for cognitive outcome.</Gene>
<Gene>Ab1-42 phagocytosis increased in both ApoE groups (P = 0.03 in each groups).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro, the lipidic mediator resolvin D1 (RvD1) down regulated the M1 type in patients with ApoE e3/e3 but in some patients with e3/e4, paradoxically up-regulated the M1 type.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Antioxidant/w-3/resveratrol supplementation was associated with favorable immune and cognitive responses in ApoE e3/e3 and individual patients bearing ApoE e3/e4, and brings into personalized clinical practice the immune benefits expected from w-3 mediators called resolvins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The validity of this study is limited by its small size and uncontrolled design.-Famenini, S., Rigali, E. A., Olivera-Perez, H. M., Dang, J., Chang, M T., Halder, R., Rao, R. V., Pellegrini, M., Porter, V., Bredesen, D., Fiala, M. Increased intermediate M1-M2 macrophage polarization and improved cognition in mild cognitive impairment patients on w-3 supplementation.</Gene>
<Gene>Pannexin3 inhibits TNF-a-induced inflammatory response by suppressing NF-kB signalling pathway in human dental pulp cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human dental pulp cells (HDPCs) play a crucial role in dental pulp inflammation.</Gene>
<Gene>Pannexin 3 (Panx3), a member of Panxs (Pannexins), has been recently found to be involved in inflammation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the mechanism of Panx3 in human dental pulp inflammation remains unclear.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, the role of Panx3 in inflammatory response was firstly explored, and its potential mechanism was proposed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Immunohistochemical staining showed that Panx3 levels were diminished in inflamed human and rat dental pulp tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro, Panx3 expression was significantly down-regulated in HDPCs following a TNF-a challenge in a concentration-dependent way, which reached the lowest level at 10 ng/ml of TNF-a. Such decrease could be reversed by MG132, a proteasome inhibitor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Unlike MG132, BAY 11-7082, a NF-kB inhibitor, even reinforced the inhibitory effect of TNF-a. Quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) were used to investigate the role of Panx3 in inflammatory response of HDPCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TNF-a-induced pro-inflammatory cytokines, interleukin (IL)-1b and IL-6, were significantly lessened when Panx3 was overexpressed in HDPCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, Panx3 knockdown exacerbated the expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, Western blot, dual-luciferase reporter assay, immunofluorescence staining, qRT-PCR and ELISA results showed that Panx3 participated in dental pulp inflammation in a NF-kB-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings suggested that Panx3 has a defensive role in dental pulp inflammation, serving as a potential target to be exploited for the intervention of human dental pulp inflammation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The anti-ageing hormone klotho induces Nrf2-mediated antioxidant defences in human aortic smooth muscle cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Vascular ageing in conditions such as atherosclerosis, diabetes and chronic kidney disease, is associated with the activation of the renin angiotensin system (RAS) and diminished expression of antioxidant defences mediated by the transcription factor nuclear factor erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The anti-ageing hormone klotho promotes longevity and protects against cardiovascular and renal diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Klotho has been shown to activate Nrf2 and attenuate oxidative damage in neuronal cells, however, the mechanisms by which it protects against vascular smooth muscle cell VSMC dysfunction elicited by Angiotensin II (AngII) remain to be elucidated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>AngII contributes to vascular ageing and atherogenesis by enhancing VSMC oxidative stress, senescence and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study demonstrates that soluble klotho (1 nM, 24 hrs) significantly induces expression of Nrf2 and the antioxidant enzymes haeme oxygenase (HO-1) and peroxiredoxin-1 (Prx-1) and enhances glutathione levels in human aortic smooth muscle cells (HASMC).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Silencing of Nrf2 attenuated the induction of HO-1 and Prx-1 expression by soluble klotho.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, soluble klotho protected against AngII-mediated HASMC apoptosis and senescence via activation of Nrf2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, our findings highlight a novel Nrf2-mediated mechanism underlying the protective actions of soluble klotho in HAMSC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Targeting klotho may thus represent a therapeutic strategy against VSMC dysfunction and cardiovascular ageing.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MicroRNA deep sequencing in two adult stem cell populations identifies miR-501 as a novel regulator of myosin heavy chain during muscle regeneration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are important regulators of skeletal muscle regeneration, but the underlying mechanisms are still incompletely understood.</Gene>

<Gene>Here, comparative miRNA sequencing analysis of myogenic progenitor cells (MPs) and non-myogenic fibroblast-adipocyte progenitors (FAPs) during cardiotoxin (CTX)-induced muscle injury uncovered miR-501 as a novel muscle-specific miRNA. miR-501 is an intronic miRNA and its expression levels in MPs correlated with its host gene, chloride channel, voltage-sensitive 5 (Clcn5).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Pharmacological inhibition of miR-501 dramatically blunted the induction of embryonic myosin heavy chain (MYH3) and, to a lesser extent, adult myosin isoforms during muscle regeneration, and promoted small-diameter neofibers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>An unbiased target identification approach in primary myoblasts validated gigaxonin as a target of miR-501 that mimicked the effect of miR-501 inhibition on MYH3 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the mdx mouse model, which models a pathological disease state, not only was miR-501 induced in regenerating skeletal muscle, but also its serum levels were increased, which correlated with the disease state of the animals.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our results suggest that miR-501 plays a key role in adult muscle regeneration and might serve as a novel serum biomarker for the activation of adult muscle stem cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Reduced adiponectin expression after high-fat diet is associated with selective up-regulation of ALDH1A1 and further retinoic acid receptor signaling in adipose tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Adiponectin is an adipocyte-derived adipokine with potent antidiabetic, anti-inflammatory, and antiatherogenic activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Long-term, high-fat diet results in gain of body weight, adiposity, further inflammatory-based cardiovascular diseases, and reduced adiponectin secretion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Vitamin A derivatives/retinoids are involved in several of these processes, which mainly take place in white adipose tissue (WAT).</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, we examined adiponectin expression as a function of dietary high-fat and high-vitamin A conditions in mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A decrease of adiponectin expression in addition to an up-regulation of aldehyde dehydrogenase A1 (ALDH1A1), retinoid signaling, and retinoic acid response element signaling was selectively observed in WAT of mice fed a normal-vitamin A, high-fat diet.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Reduced adiponectin expression in WAT was also observed in mice fed a high-vitamin A diet.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Adipocyte cell culture revealed that endogenous and synthetic retinoic acid receptor (RAR)a- and RARg-selective agonists, as well as a synthetic retinoid X receptor agonist, efficiently reduced adiponectin expression, whereas ALDH1A1 expression only increased with RAR agonists.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that reduced adiponectin expression under high-fat dietary conditions is dependent on 1) increased ALDH1A1 expression in adipocytes, which does not increase all-trans-retinoic acid levels; 2) further RAR ligand-induced, WAT-selective, increased retinoic acid response element-mediated signaling; and 3) RAR ligand-dependent reduction of adiponectin expression.-Landrier, J.-F., Kasiri, E., Karkeni, E., Mihaly, J., Beke, G., Weiss, K., Lucas, R., Aydemir, G., Salles, J., Walrand, S., de Lera, A. R., Ruhl, R. Reduced adiponectin expression after high-fat diet is associated with selective up-regulation of ALDH1A1 and further retinoic acid receptor signaling in adipose tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nebulette is a powerful cytolinker organizing desmin and actin in mouse hearts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the hearts of patients bearing nebulette mutations, a severe general disorganization in cardiomyocytes of the extrasarcomeric desmin intermediate filament system is frequently observed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the molecular and functional relationship between the desmin cytoskeleton and nebulette-containing sarcomeres is still unclear.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we report a high-affinity in vitro interaction between nebulette and desmin filaments.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A major interaction site has been mapped to the desmin a-helical rod domain, indicating that the filament core is directly involved in the binding of nebulette.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The disease-mutant desmin variants E245D and T453I exhibited increased binding affinity for nebulette, delayed filament assembly kinetics, and caused significant weakening of networks.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In isolated chick cardiomyocytes and sections from canine heart, we revealed by ground-state depletion and confocal microscopies that module 5 of nebulette extends outward from Z-disk-associated desmin filaments toward the center of the sarcomere.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Accordingly, in the myocardium of Des(-/-) mice, elevated levels of cardiac actin correlated with alterations in the distribution of nebulette.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggest that a well-organized desmin network is required to accommodate an optimal conformation of nebulette on sarcomeres to bind and recruit cardiac a-actin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hence we propose that nebulette acts in synergy with nebulin to reinforce and temporally fine-tune striated muscle relaxation-contraction cycles.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Drosophila vinculin is more harmful when hyperactive than absent, and can circumvent integrin to form adhesion complexes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Vinculin is a highly conserved protein involved in cell adhesion and mechanotransduction, and both gain and loss of its activity causes defective cell behaviour.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we examine how altering vinculin activity perturbs integrin function within the context of Drosophila development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Whereas loss of vinculin produced relatively minor phenotypes, gain of vinculin activity, through a loss of head-tail autoinhibition, caused lethality.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The minimal domain capable of inducing lethality is the talin-binding D1 domain, and this appears to require talin-binding activity, as lethality was suppressed by competition with single vinculin-binding sites from talin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activated Drosophila vinculin triggered the formation of cytoplasmic adhesion complexes through the rod of talin, but independently of integrin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These complexes contain a subset of adhesion proteins but no longer link the membrane to actin.</Gene>
<Gene>The negative effects of hyperactive vinculin were segregated into morphogenetic defects caused by its whole head domain and lethality caused by its D1 domain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings demonstrate the crucial importance of the tight control of the activity of vinculin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MEK inhibitors against MET-amplified non-small cell lung cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Several receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) including EGFR, ALK, and MET have been identified as therapeutic targets in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Among the downstream pathways of RTKs, the MAPK pathway is particularly important for cancer cell proliferation, differentiation, and survival.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, the effects of MEK inhibitors (trametinib and PD0325901) in several NSCLC cell lines with driver gene alterations, especially RTK genes, were tested in vitro using an MTT assay, and a wide range of sensitivities was found.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In particular, all the EGFR-mutated cell lines were resistant to MEK inhibitors, whereas all the MET-amplified cell lines were sensitive.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A bioinformatics technique and western blot analyses showed that the PI3K/AKT pathway is more activated in EGFR-mutated NSCLC than in MET-amplified NSCLC, and a PI3K inhibitor enhanced the sensitivity to trametinib in the EGFR-mutated cell lines, suggesting that this pathway is associated with resistance to MEK inhibitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although the HCC827 cell line (EGFR mutation) was resistant to MEK inhibitors, the HCC827CNXR cell line, whose driver gene shifts from EGFR to MET, exhibited enhanced sensitivity to MEK inhibitors, indicating the biological importance of the MAPK pathway for MET-amplified NCSLC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, a synergistic effect of crizotinib (a MET inhibitor) and trametinib was observed in MET-amplified NCLC cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings indicate that the MAPK pathway is biologically important for MET-amplified NSCLC and strongly encourage the development of combination therapy with a MET inhibitor and a MEK inhibitor against MET-amplified NSCLC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Less is more: low expression of MT1-MMP is optimal to promote migration and tumourigenesis of breast cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>Membrane Type-1 Matrix Metalloproteinase (MT1-MMP) is a multifunctional protease implicated in metastatic progression ostensibly due to its ability to degrade extracellular matrix (ECM) components and allow migration of cells through the basement membrane.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Despite in vitro studies demonstrating this principle, this knowledge has not translated into the use of MMP inhibitors (MMPi) as effective cancer therapeutics, or been corroborated by evidence of in vivo ECM degradation mediated by MT1-MMP, suggesting that our understanding of the role of MT1-MMP in cancer progression is incomplete.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>MCF-7 and MDA-MB 231 breast cancer cell lines were created that stably overexpress different levels of MT1-MMP.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using 2D culture, we analyzed proMMP-2 activation (gelatin zymography), ECM degradation (fluorescent gelatin), ERK signaling (immunoblot), cell migration (transwell/scratch closure/time-lapse imaging), and viability (colorimetric substrate) to assess how different MT1-MMP levels affect these cellular parameters.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also utilized Matrigel 3D cell culture and avian embryos to examine how different levels of MT1-MMP expression affect morphological changes in 3D culture, and tumourigenecity and extravasation efficiency in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>In 2D culture, breast cancer cells expressing high levels of MT1-MMP were capable of widespread ECM degradation and TIMP-2-mediated proMMP-2 activation, but were not the most migratory.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Instead, cells expressing low levels of MT1-MMP were the most migratory, and demonstrated increased viability and ERK activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In 3D culture, MCF-7 breast cancer cells expressing low levels of MT1-MMP demonstrated an invasive protrusive phenotype, whereas cells expressing high levels of MT1-MMP demonstrated loss of colony structure and cell fragment release.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Similarly, in vivo analysis demonstrated increased tumourigenecity and metastatic capability for cells expressing low levels of MT1-MMP, whereas cells expressing high levels were devoid of these qualities despite the production of functional MT1-MMP protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>This study demonstrates that excessive ECM degradation mediated by high levels of MT1-MMP is not associated with cell migration and tumourigenesis, while low levels of MT1-MMP promote invasion and vascularization in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Differential expression of filamin B splice variants in giant cell tumor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Giant cell tumor of bone (GCT) is the most commonly reported non-malignant bone tumor in Hong Kong.</Gene>
<Gene>This kind of tumor usually affects people aged 20-40 years.</Gene>
<Gene>Also, it is well known for recurrence locally, especially when the tumor cannot be removed completely.</Gene>

<Gene>Filamins are actin-binding proteins which contain three family members, filamin A, B and C. They are the products of three different genes, FLNA, FLNB and FLNC, which can generate various transcript variants in different cell types.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we focused on the effects of FLNBv2 and FLNBv4 toward GCT cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The only difference between FLNBv2 and FLNBv4 is that FLNBv4 does not contain hinge 1 region.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found that the relative abundance of FLNBv4 varies among different GCT cell lines while the expression level of FLNBv4 in normal osteoblasts was only marginally detectable.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the functional aspect, overexpression of FLNBv4 led to upregulation of RANKL, OCN, OPG and RUNX2, which are closely related to GCT cell survival and differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, FLNBv4 can have a negative effect on cell viability of GCT cells when compare with FLNBv2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, splicing variants of FLNB are differentially expressed in GCT cells and may play a role in the proliferation and differentiation of tumor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Effects of the Bowen-Conradi syndrome mutation in EMG1 on its nuclear import, stability and nucleolar recruitment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Bowen-Conradi syndrome (BCS) is a severe genetic disorder that is characterised by various developmental abnormalities, bone marrow failure and early infant death.</Gene>
<Gene>This disease is caused by a single mutation leading to the aspartate 86 to glycine (D86G) exchange in the essential nucleolar RNA methyltransferase EMG1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>EMG1 is required for the synthesis of the small ribosomal subunit and is involved in modification of the 18S ribosomal RNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we identify the pre-ribosomal factors NOP14, NOC4L and UTP14A as members of a nucleolar subcomplex that contains EMG1 and is required for its recruitment to nucleoli.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The BCS mutation in EMG1 leads to reduced nucleolar localisation, accumulation of EMG1D86G in nuclear foci and its proteasome-dependent degradation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We further show that EMG1 can be imported into the nucleus by the importins (Imp) Impa/b or Impb/7.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, in addition to its role in nuclear import, binding of the Impb/7 heterodimer can prevent unspecific aggregation of both EMG1 and EMG1D86G on RNAs in vitro, indicating that the importins act as chaperones by binding to basic regions of the RNA methyltransferase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings further indicate that in BCS, nuclear disassembly of the import complex and release of EMG1D86G lead to its nuclear aggregation and degradation, resulting in the reduced nucleolar recruitment of the RNA methyltransferase and defects in the biogenesis of the small ribosomal subunit.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PTPN22 Is a Critical Regulator of Fcg Receptor-Mediated Neutrophil Activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Neutrophils act as a first line of defense against bacterial and fungal infections, but they are also important effectors of acute and chronic inflammation.</Gene>

<Gene>Genome-wide association studies have established that the gene encoding the protein tyrosine phosphatase nonreceptor 22 (PTPN22) makes an important contribution to susceptibility to autoimmune disease, notably rheumatoid arthritis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although PTPN22 is most highly expressed in neutrophils, its function in these cells remains poorly characterized.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We show in this article that neutrophil effector functions, including adhesion, production of reactive oxygen species, and degranulation induced by immobilized immune complexes, were reduced in Ptpn22(-/-) neutrophils.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Tyrosine phosphorylation of Lyn and Syk was altered in Ptpn22(-/-) neutrophils.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>On stimulation with immobilized immune complexes, Ptpn22(-/-) neutrophils manifested reduced activation of key signaling intermediates.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Ptpn22(-/-) mice were protected from immune complex-mediated arthritis, induced by the transfer of arthritogenic serum.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, in vivo neutrophil recruitment following thioglycollate-induced peritonitis and in vitro chemotaxis were not affected by lack of PTPN22.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggest an important role for PTPN22-dependent dephosphorylation events, which are required to enable full FcgR-induced activation, pointing to an important role for this molecule in neutrophil function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>High glucose repatterns human podocyte energy metabolism during differentiation and diabetic nephropathy.</Gene>
<Gene>Podocytes play a key role in diabetic nephropathy pathogenesis, but alteration of their metabolism remains unknown in human kidney.</Gene>

<Gene>By using a conditionally differentiating human podocyte cell line, we addressed the functional and molecular changes in podocyte energetics during in vitro development or under high glucose conditions.</Gene>

<Gene>In 5 mM glucose medium, we observed a stepwise activation of oxidative metabolism during cell differentiation that was characterized by peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor-g coactivator 1a (PGC-1a)-dependent stimulation of mitochondrial biogenesis and function, with concomitant reduction of the glycolytic enzyme content.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, when podocytes were cultured in high glucose (20 mM), stepwise oxidative phosphorylation biogenesis was aborted, and a glycolytic switch occurred, with consecutive lactic acidosis.</Gene>

<Gene>Expression of the master regulators of oxidative metabolism transcription factor A mitochondrial, PGC-1a, AMPK, and serine-threonine liver kinase B1 was altered by high glucose, as well as their downstream signaling networks.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Focused transcriptomics revealed that myocyte-specific enhancer factor 2C (MEF2C) and myogenic factor 5 (MYF5) expression was inhibited by high glucose levels, and endoribonuclease-prepared small interfering RNA-mediated combined inhibition of those transcription factors phenocopied the glycolytic shift that was observed in high glucose conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Accordingly, a reduced expression of MEF2C, MYF5, and PGC-1a was found in kidney tissue sections that were obtained from patients with diabetic nephropathy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings obtained in human samples demonstrate that MEF2C-MYF5-dependent bioenergetic dedifferentiation occurs in podocytes that are confronted with a high-glucose milieu.-Imasawa, T., Obre, E., Bellance, N., Lavie, J., Imasawa, T., Rigothier, C., Delmas, Y., Combe, C., Lacombe, D., Benard, G., Claverol, S., Bonneu, M., Rossignol, R. High glucose repatterns human podocyte energy metabolism during differentiation and diabetic nephropathy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Seven novel and six de novo PHEX gene mutations in patients with hypophosphatemic rickets.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Inactivating mutations in phosphate-regulating gene with homologies to endopeptidase on the X chromosome (PHEX) have been identified as a cause of X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets (XLH; OMIM 307800).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the present study, we enrolled 43 patients from 18 unrelated families clinically diagnosed with hypophosphatemic rickets and 250 healthy controls.</Gene>
<Gene>For each available individual, all 22 exons with their exon-intron boundaries of the PHEX gene were directly sequenced.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The levels of serum fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF23) were measured as well.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sequencing analysis detected 17 different PHEX gene mutations, and 7 of these were identified as novel: 3 missense mutations, including c.304G>A (p.Gly102Arg) in exon 3, c.229T>C (p.Cys77Arg) in exon 3 and c.824T>C (p.Leu275Pro) in exon 7; 2 deletion mutations, including c.528delT (p.Glu177LysfsX44) in exon 5 and c.1234delA (p.Ser412ValfsX12) in exon 11; and 2 alternative splicing mutations, including c.436_436+1delAG in intron 4 at splicing donor sites and c.1483-1G>C in intron 13 at splicing acceptor sites.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, 6 mutations were proven to be de novo in 6 sporadic cases and the probands were all females.</Gene>
<Gene>No mutations were found in the 250 healthy controls.</Gene>
<Gene>The serum levels of FGF23 varied widely among the patients with XLH, and no significant difference was found when compared with those of the healthy controls.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>On the whole, the findings of this study provide new insight into the spectrum of PHEX mutations and provide potential evidence of a critical domain in PHEX protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the finding of an overlap of the serum FGF23 levels between the patients with XLH and the healthy controls indicates its limited diagnostic value in XLH.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Autophagy activated by tuberin/mTOR/p70S6K suppression is a protective mechanism against local anaesthetics neurotoxicity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The local anaesthetics (LAs) are widely used for peripheral nerve blocks, epidural anaesthesia, spinal anaesthesia and pain management.</Gene>
<Gene>However, exposure to LAs for long duration or at high dosage can provoke potential neuronal damages.</Gene>
<Gene>Autophagy is an intracellular bulk degradation process for proteins and organelles.</Gene>
<Gene>However, both the effects of LAs on autophagy in neuronal cells and the effects of autophagy on LAs neurotoxicity are not clear.</Gene>
<Gene>To answer these questions, both lipid LAs (procaine and tetracaine) and amide LAs (bupivacaine, lidocaine and ropivacaine) were administrated to human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Neurotoxicity was evaluated by MTT assay, morphological alterations and median death dosage.</Gene>
<Gene>Autophagic flux was estimated by autolysosome formation (dual fluorescence LC3 assay), LC3-II generation and p62 protein degradation (immunoblotting).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Signalling alterations were examined by immunoblotting analysis.</Gene>
<Gene>Inhibition of autophagy was achieved by transfection with beclin-1 siRNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We observed that LAs decreased cell viability in a dose-dependent manner.</Gene>
<Gene>The neurotoxicity of LAs was tetracaine > bupivacaine > ropivacaine > procaine > lidocaine.</Gene>
<Gene>LAs increased autophagic flux, as reflected by increases in autolysosome formation and LC3-II generation, and decrease in p62 levels.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, LAs inhibited tuberin/mTOR/p70S6K signalling, a negative regulator of autophagy activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Most importantly, autophagy inhibition by beclin-1 knockdown exacerbated the LAs-provoked cell damage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggest that autophagic flux was up-regulated by LAs through inhibition of tuberin/mTOR/p70S6K signalling, and autophagy activation served as a protective mechanism against LAs neurotoxicity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, autophagy manipulation could be an alternative therapeutic intervention to prevent LAs-induced neuronal damage.</Gene>
<Gene>Role of protein arginine methyltransferase 5 in inflammation and migration of fibroblast-like synoviocytes in rheumatoid arthritis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To probe the role of protein arginine methyltransferase 5 (PRMT5) in regulating inflammation, cell proliferation, migration and invasion of fibroblast-like synoviocytes (FLSs) from patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>FLSs were separated from synovial tissues (STs) from patients with RA and osteoarthritis (OA).</Gene>
<Gene>An inhibitor of PRMT5 (EPZ015666) and short interference RNA (siRNA) against PRMT5 were used to inhibit PRMT5 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The standard of protein was measured by Western blot or immunofluorescence.</Gene>
<Gene>The excretion and genetic expression of inflammatory factors were, respectively, estimated by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) and real-time polymerase chain reaction (PCR).</Gene>
<Gene>Migration and invasion in vitro were detected by Boyden chamber assay.</Gene>
<Gene>FLSs proliferation was detected by BrdU incorporation.</Gene>
<Gene>Increased PRMT5 was discovered in STs and FLSs from patients with RA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In RA FLSs, the level of PRMT5 was up-regulated by stimulation with IL-1b and TNF-a. Inhibition of PRMT5 by EPZ015666 and siRNA-mediated knockdown reduced IL-6 and IL-8 production, and proliferation of RA FLSs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, inhibition of PRMT5 decreased in vitro migration and invasion of RA FLSs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, EPZ015666 restrained the phosphorylation of IkB kinaseb and IkBa, as well as nucleus transsituation of p65 as well as AKT in FLSs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PRMT5 regulated the production of inflammatory factors, cell proliferation, migration and invasion of RA FLS, which was mediated by the NF-kB and AKT pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggested that targeting PRMT5 to prevent synovial inflammation and destruction might be a promising therapy for RA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Telocytes: a potential defender in the spleen of Npc1 mutant mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Niemann-Pick disease, type C1 (Npc1), is an atypical lysosomal storage disorder caused by autosomal recessive inheritance of mutations in Npc1 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the Npc1 mutant mice (Npc1(-/-) ), the initial manifestation is enlarged spleen, concomitant with free cholesterol accumulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Telocytes (TCs), a novel type of interstitial cell, exist in a variety of tissues including spleen, presumably thought to be involved in many biological processes such as nursing stem cells and recruiting inflammatory cells.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, we found that the spleen is significantly enlarged in Npc1(-/-) mice, and the results from transmission electron microscopy examination and immunostaining using three different TCs markers, c-Kit, CD34 and Vimentin revealed significantly increased splenic TCs in Npc1(-/-) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, hematopoietic stem cells and macrophages were also elevated in Npc1(-/-) spleen.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, our data indicate that splenic TCs might alleviate the progress of splenic malfunction via recruiting hematopoietic stem cells and macrophages.</Gene>
<Gene>Keratin 19 as a key molecule in progression of human hepatocellular carcinomas through invasion and angiogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Keratin (K) 19-positive hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is well known to have a higher malignant potential than K19-negative HCC:</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the molecular mechanisms involved in K19-mediated progression of HCC remain unclear.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We attempted to clarify whether K19 directly affects cell survival and invasiveness in association with cellular senescence or epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) in K19-positive HCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>K19 expression was analysed in 136 HCC surgical specimens.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The relationship of K19 with clinicopathological factors and survival was analysed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Further, the effect of K19 on cell proliferation, invasion, and angiogenesis was examined by silencing K19 in the human HCC cell lines, HepG2, HuH-7, and PLC/PRF/5.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, we investigated HCC invasion, proliferation, and angiogenesis using K19-positive HCC specimens.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Analysis of HCC surgical specimens revealed that K19-positive HCC exhibited higher invasiveness, metastatic potential, and poorer prognosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro experiments using the human HCC cell lines revealed that K19 silencing suppressed cell growth by inducting apoptosis or upregulating p16 and p27, resulting in cellular senescence.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, transfection with K19 siRNA upregulated E-cadherin gene expression, significantly inhibited the invasive capacity of the cells, downregulated angiogenesis-related molecules such as vasohibin-1 (VASH1) and fibroblast growth factor 1 (FGFR1), and upregulated vasohibin-2 (VASH2).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>K19-positive HCC specimens exhibited a high MIB-1 labelling index, decreased E-cadherin expression, and high microvessel density around cancer foci.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION: K19 directly promotes cancer cell survival, invasion, and angiogenesis, resulting in HCC progression and poor clinical outcome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>K19 may therefore be a novel drug target for the treatment of K19-positive HCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In silico SNP analysis of the breast cancer antigen NY-BR-1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Breast cancer is one of the most common malignancies with increasing incidences every year and a leading cause of death among women.</Gene>
<Gene>Although early stage breast cancer can be effectively treated, there are limited numbers of treatment options available for patients with advanced and metastatic disease.</Gene>

<Gene>The novel breast cancer associated antigen NY-BR-1 was identified by SEREX analysis and is expressed in the majority (>70%) of breast tumors as well as metastases, in normal breast tissue, in testis and occasionally in prostate tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The biological function and regulation of NY-BR-1 is up to date unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>We performed an in silico analysis on the genetic variations of the NY-BR-1 gene using data available in public SNP databases and the tools SIFT, Polyphen and Provean to find possible functional SNPs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, we considered the allele frequency of the found damaging SNPs and also analyzed data from an in-house sequencing project of 55 breast cancer samples for recurring SNPs, recorded in dbSNP.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Over 2800 SNPs are recorded in the dbSNP and NHLBI ESP databases for the NY-BR-1 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Of these, 65 (2.07%) are synonymous SNPs, 191 (6.09%) are non-synoymous SNPs, and 2430 (77.48%)</Gene>
<Gene>are noncoding intronic SNPs.</Gene>
<Gene>As a result, 69 non-synoymous SNPs were predicted to be damaging by at least two, and 16 SNPs were predicted as damaging by all three of the used tools.</Gene>
<Gene>The SNPs rs200639888, rs367841401 and rs377750885 were categorized as highly damaging by all three tools.</Gene>
<Gene>Eight damaging SNPs are located in the ankyrin repeat domain (ANK), a domain known for its frequent involvement in protein-protein interactions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>No distinctive features could be observed in the allele frequency of the analyzed SNPs.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>

<Gene>Considering these results we expect to gain more insights into the variations of the NY-BR-1 gene and their possible impact on giving rise to splice variants and therefore influence the function of NY-BR-1 in healthy tissue as well as in breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Repeated otilonium bromide administration prevents neurotransmitter changes in colon of rats underwent to wrap restraint stress.</Gene>
<Gene>Otilonium bromide (OB) is a spasmolytic drug successfully used for the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS).</Gene>
<Gene>Its efficacy has been attributed to the block of L- and T-type Ca(2+) channels and muscarinic and tachykinin receptors in the smooth muscle.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, in healthy rats, repeated OB administration modified neurotransmitter expression and function suggesting other mechanisms of action.</Gene>

<Gene>On this basis, we investigated whether repeated OB treatment prevented the functional and neurochemical changes observed in the colon of rats underwent to wrap restrain stress (WRS) a psychosocial stressor considered suitable to reproduce the main IBS signs and symptoms.</Gene>
<Gene>In control, WRS and OB/WRS rats functional parameters were measured in vivo and morphological investigations were done ex vivo in the colon.</Gene>
<Gene>The results showed that OB counteracts most of the neurotransmitters changes caused by WRS.</Gene>
<Gene>In particular, the drug prevents the decrease in SP-, NK1r-, nNOS-, VIP-, and S100b-immunoreactivity (IR) and the increase in CGRP-, and CRF1r-IR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>On the contrary, OB does not affect the increase in CRF2r-IR neurons observed in WRS rats and does not interfere with the mild mucosal inflammation due to WRS.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, OB per se increases the Mr2 expression in the muscle wall and decreases the number of the myenteric ChAT-IR neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Functional findings show a significantly reduction in the number of spontaneous abdominal contraction in OB treated rats.</Gene>
<Gene>The ability of OB to block L-type Ca(2+) channels, also expressed by enteric neurons, might represent a possible mechanism through which OB exerts its actions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interleukin-10-mediated regenerative postnatal tissue repair is dependent on regulation of hyaluronan metabolism via fibroblast-specific STAT3 signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cytokine IL-10 has potent antifibrotic effects in models of adult fibrosis, but the mechanisms of action are unclear.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we report a novel finding that IL-10 triggers a signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3)-dependent signaling pathway that regulates hyaluronan (HA) metabolism and drives adult fibroblasts to synthesize an HA-rich pericellular matrix, which mimics the fetal regenerative wound healing phenotype with reduced fibrosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By using cre-lox-mediated novel, inducible, fibroblast-, keratinocyte-, and wound-specific STAT3 knockdown postnatal mice-plus syngeneic fibroblast cell-transplant models-we demonstrate that the regenerative effects of IL-10 in postnatal wounds are dependent on HA synthesis and fibroblast-specific STAT3-dependent signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The importance of IL-10-induced HA synthesis for regenerative wound healing is demonstrated by inhibition of HA synthesis in a murine wound model by administering 4-methylumbelliferone.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although IL-10 and STAT3 signaling were intact, the antifibrotic repair phenotype that is induced by IL-10 overexpression was abrogated in this model.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data show a novel role for IL-10 beyond its accepted immune-regulatory mechanism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The opportunity for IL-10 to regulate a fibroblast-specific formation of a regenerative, HA-rich wound extracellular matrix may lead to the development of innovative therapies to attenuate postnatal fibrosis in organ systems or diseases in which dysregulated inflammation and HA intersect.-Balaji, S., Wang, X., King, A., Le, L. D., Bhattacharya, S. S., Moles, C. M., Butte, M. J., de Jesus Perez, V. A., Liechty, K. W., Wight, T. N., Crombleholme, T. M., Bollyky, P. L., Keswani, S. G. Interleukin-10-mediated regenerative postnatal tissue repair is dependent on regulation of hyaluronan metabolism via fibroblast-specific STAT3 signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Filamin, a synaptic organizer in Drosophila, determines glutamate receptor composition and membrane growth.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Filamin is a scaffolding protein that functions in many cells as an actin-crosslinker.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>FLN90, an isoform of the Drosophila ortholog Filamin/cheerio that lacks the actin-binding domain, is here shown to govern the growth of postsynaptic membrane folds and the composition of glutamate receptor clusters at the larval neuromuscular junction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genetic and biochemical analyses revealed that FLN90 is present surrounding synaptic boutons.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>FLN90 is required in the muscle for localization of the kinase dPak and, downstream of dPak, for localization of the GTPase Ral and the exocyst complex to this region.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consequently, Filamin is needed for growth of the subsynaptic reticulum.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, in the absence of filamin, type-A glutamate receptor subunits are lacking at the postsynapse, while type-B subunits cluster correctly.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Receptor composition is dependent on dPak, but independent of the Ral pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus two major aspects of synapse formation, morphological plasticity and subtype-specific receptor clustering, require postsynaptic Filamin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Contribution of upregulated dipeptidyl peptidase 9 (DPP9) in promoting tumoregenicity, metastasis and the prediction of poor prognosis in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Dipeptidyl peptidase 9 (DPP9) is encoded by DPP9, which belongs to the DPP4 gene family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Proteins encoded by these genes have unique peptidase and extra-enzymatic functions that have been linked to various diseases including cancers.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we describe the expression pattern and biological function of DPP9 in non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The repression of DPP9 expression by small interfering RNA inhibited cell proliferation, migration, and invasion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, we explored the role of DPP9 in regulating epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The epithelial markers E-cadherin and MUC1 were significantly increased, while mesenchymal markers vimentin and S100A4 were markedly decreased in DPP9 knockdown cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The downregulation of DPP9 in the NSCLC cells induced the expression of apoptosis-associated proteins both in vitro and in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We investigated the protein expression levels of DPP9 by tissue microarray immunohistochemical assay (TMA-IHC) (n = 217).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Further we found mRNA expression levels of DPP9 in 30 pairs of clinical NSCLC tissues were significantly lower than in the adjacent non-cancerous tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Survival analysis showed that the overexpression of DPP9 was a significant independent factor for poor 5-year overall survival in patients with NSCLC (p = 0.003).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, DPP9 expression correlates with poor overall survival in NSCLC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Long-term exposure of MCF-7 breast cancer cells to ethanol stimulates oncogenic features.</Gene>
<Gene>Alcohol consumption is a risk factor for breast cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>Little is known regarding the mechanism, although it is assumed that acetaldehyde or estrogen mediated pathways play a role.</Gene>

<Gene>We previously showed that long-term exposure to 2.5 mM ethanol (blood alcohol ~0.012%) of MCF-12A, a human normal epithelial breast cell line, induced epithelial mesenchymal transition (EMT) and oncogenic transformation.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, we investigated in the human breast cancer cell line MCF-7, whether a similar exposure to ethanol at concentrations ranging up to peak blood levels in heavy drinkers would increase malignant progression.</Gene>

<Gene>Short-term (1-week) incubation to ethanol at as low as 1-5 mM (corresponding to blood alcohol concentration of ~0.0048-0.024%) upregulated the stem cell related proteins Oct4 and Nanog, but they were reduced after exposure at 25 mM. Long-term (4-week) exposure to 25 mM ethanol upregulated the Oct4 and Nanog proteins, as well as the malignancy marker Ceacam6.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DNA microarray analysis in cells exposed for 1 week showed upregulated expression of metallothionein genes, particularly MT1X. Long-term exposure upregulated expression of some malignancy related genes (STEAP4, SERPINA3, SAMD9, GDF15, KRT15, ITGB6, TP63, and PGR, as well as the CEACAM, interferon related, and HLA gene families).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Some of these findings were validated by RT-PCR.</Gene>

<Gene>A similar treatment also modulated numerous microRNAs (miRs) including one regulator of Oct4 as well as miRs involved in oncogenesis and/or malignancy, with only a few estrogen-induced miRs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Long-term 25 mM ethanol also induced a 5.6-fold upregulation of anchorage-independent growth, an indicator of malignant-like features.</Gene>
<Gene>Exposure to acetaldehyde resulted in little or no effect comparable to that of ethanol.</Gene>

<Gene>The previously shown alcohol induction of oncogenic transformation of normal breast cells is now complemented by the current results suggesting alcohol's potential involvement in malignant progression of breast cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>CenpH regulates meiotic G2/M transition by modulating the APC/CCdh1-cyclin B1 pathway in oocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Meiotic resumption (G2/M transition) and progression through meiosis I (MI) are two key stages for producing fertilization-competent eggs.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we report that CenpH, a component of the kinetochore inner plate, is responsible for G2/M transition in meiotic mouse oocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Depletion of CenpH by morpholino injection decreased cyclin B1 levels, resulting in attenuation of maturation-promoting factor (MPF) activation, and severely compromised meiotic resumption.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CenpH protects cyclin B1 from destruction by competing with the action of APC/C(Cdh1) Impaired G2/M transition after CenpH depletion could be rescued by expression of exogenous cyclin B1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Unexpectedly, blocking CenpH did not affect spindle organization and meiotic cell cycle progression after germinal vesicle breakdown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings reveal a novel role of CenpH in regulating meiotic G2/M transition by acting via the APC/C(Cdh1)-cyclin B1 pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A Critical Role for the Type I Interferon Receptor in Virus-Induced Autoimmune Diabetes in Rats.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The pathogenesis of human type 1 diabetes, characterized by immune-mediated damage of insulin-producing b-cells of pancreatic islets, may involve viral infection.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Essential components of the innate immune antiviral response, including type I interferon (IFN) and IFN receptor-mediated signaling pathways, are candidates for determining susceptibility to human type 1 diabetes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Numerous aspects of human type 1 diabetes pathogenesis are recapitulated in the LEW.1WR1 rat model.</Gene>
<Gene>Diabetes can be induced in LEW.1WR1 weanling rats challenged with virus or with the viral mimetic polyinosinic:polycytidylic acid (poly I:C).</Gene>
<Gene>We hypothesized that disrupting the cognate type I IFN receptor (type I IFN a/b receptor</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>[IFNAR]) to interrupt IFN signaling would prevent or delay the development of virus-induced diabetes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We generated IFNAR1 subunit-deficient LEW.1WR1 rats using CRISPR-Cas9 (clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats-associated protein 9) genome editing and confirmed functional disruption of the Ifnar1 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IFNAR1 deficiency significantly delayed the onset and frequency of diabetes and greatly reduced the intensity of insulitis after poly I:C treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The occurrence of Kilham rat virus-induced diabetes was also diminished in IFNAR1-deficient animals.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings firmly establish that alterations in innate immunity influence the course of autoimmune diabetes and support the use of targeted strategies to limit or prevent the development of type 1 diabetes.</Gene>
<Gene>Analysis of cellular and molecular antitumor effects upon inhibition of SATB1 in glioblastoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>The Special AT-rich Sequence Binding Protein 1 (SATB1) regulates the expression of many genes by acting as a global chromatin organizer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While in many tumor entities SATB1 overexpression has been observed and connected to pro-tumorigenic processes, somewhat contradictory evidence exists in brain tumors with regard to SATB1 overexpression in glioblastoma and its association with poorer prognosis and tumor progression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>On the functional side, initial data indicate that SATB1 may be involved in several tumor cell-relevant processes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>For the detailed analysis of the functional relevance and possible therapeutic potential of SATB1 inhibition, we employ transient siRNA-mediated knockdown and comprehensively analyze the cellular and molecular role of SATB1 in glioblastoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>In various cell lines with different SATB1 expression levels, a SATB1 gene dose-dependent inhibition of anchorage-dependent and -independent proliferation is observed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This is due to cell cycle-inhibitory and pro-apoptotic effects of SATB1 knockdown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular analyses reveal SATB1 knockdown effects on multiple important (proto-) oncogenes, including Myc, Bcl-2, Pim-1, EGFR, b-catenin and Survivin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Molecules involved in cell cycle, EMT and cell adhesion are affected as well.</Gene>

<Gene>The putative therapeutic relevance of SATB1 inhibition is further supported in an in vivo tumor xenograft mouse model, where the treatment with polymeric nanoparticles containing SATB1-specific siRNAs exerts antitumor effects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>Our results demonstrate that SATB1 may represent a promising target molecule in glioblastoma therapy whose inhibition or knockdown affects multiple crucial pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Concordance between PIK3CA mutations in endoscopic biopsy and surgically resected specimens of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: PIK3CA mutations are expected to be potential therapeutic targets for esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We aimed to clarify the concordance between PIK3CA mutations detected in endoscopic biopsy specimens and corresponding surgically resected specimens.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>We examined five hotspot mutations in the PIK3CA gene (E542K, E545K, E546K, H1047R, and H1047L) in formalin-fixed and paraffin-embedded tissue sections of paired endoscopic biopsy and surgically resected specimens from 181 patients undergoing curative resection for ESCC between 2000 and 2011 using a Luminex technology-based multiplex gene mutation detection kit.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Mutation analyses were successfully performed for both endoscopic biopsy and surgically resected specimens in all the cases.</Gene>
<Gene>A PIK3CA mutation was detected in either type of specimen in 13 cases (7.2%, 95% confidence interval: 3.9-12.0).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The overall concordance rate, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value were 98.3% (178/181), 90.9% (10/11), and 98.8% (168/170), respectively.</Gene>
<Gene>Among patients with a PIK3CA mutation detected in both types of specimens, the concordance between PIK3CA mutation genotypes was 100%.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>There were three cases with a discordant mutation status between the types of specimens (PIK3CA mutation in surgically resected specimen and wild-type in biopsy specimen in two cases, and the opposite pattern in one case), suggesting possible intratumoral heterogeneity in the PIK3CA mutation status.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>The PIK3CA mutation status was highly concordant between endoscopic biopsy and surgically resected specimens from the same patient, suggesting that endoscopic biopsy specimens can be clinically used to detect PIK3CA mutations in patients with ESCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Retrospective study of RAS/PIK3CA/BRAF tumor mutations as predictors of response to first-line chemotherapy with bevacizumab in metastatic colorectal cancer patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>After analysis of minor RAS mutations (KRAS exon 3, 4/NRAS) in the FIRE-3 and PRIME studies, an expanded range of RAS mutations were established as a negative predictive marker for the efficacy of anti-EGFR antibody treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BRAF and PIK3CA mutations may be candidate biomarkers for anti-EGFR targeted therapies.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, it remains unknown whether RAS/PIK3CA/BRAF tumor mutations can predict the efficacy of bevacizumab in metastatic colorectal cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We assessed whether selection according to RAS/PIK3CA/BRAF mutational status could be beneficial for patients treated with bevacizumab as first-line treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>Of the 1001 consecutive colorectal cancer patients examined for RAS, PIK3CA, and BRAF tumor mutations using a multiplex kit (LuminexR), we studied 90 patients who received combination chemotherapy with bevacizumab as first-line treatment for metastatic colorectal cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The objective response rate (ORR) and progression-free survival (PFS) were evaluated according to mutational status.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>The ORR was higher among patients with wild-type tumors (64.3%) compared to those with tumors that were only wild type with respect to KRAS exon 2 (54.8%), and the differences in ORR between patients with wild-type and mutant-type tumors were greater when considering only KRAS exon 2 mutations (6.8%) rather than RAS/PIK3CA/BRAF mutations (18.4%).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>There were no statistically significant differences in ORR or PFS between all wild-type tumors and tumors carrying any of the mutations.</Gene>
<Gene>Multivariate analysis revealed that liver metastasis and RAS and BRAF mutations were independent negative factors for disease progression after first-line treatment with bevacizumab.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Patient selection according to RAS/PIK3CA/</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BRAF mutations could help select patients who will achieve a better response to bevacizumab treatment.</Gene>
<Gene>We found no clinical benefit of restricting combination therapy with bevacizumab for metastatic colorectal cancer patients with EGFR-wild type tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Developmental Role of Macrophage Cannabinoid-1 Receptor Signaling in Type-2 Diabetes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Islet inflammation promotes b-cell loss and type-2 diabetes (T2D), a process replicated in Zucker Diabetic Fatty (ZDF) rats in which b-cell loss has been linked to cannabinoid-1 receptor (CB1R)-induced pro-inflammatory signaling in macrophages infiltrating pancreatic islets.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we analyzed CB1R signaling in macrophages and its developmental role in T2Da.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ZDF rats with global deletion of CB1R are protected from b-cell loss, hyperglycemia and nephropathy present in ZDF littermates.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Adoptive transfer of CB1R(-/-) bone marrow to ZDF rats also prevents b-cell loss and hyperglycemia, but not nephropathy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ZDF islets contain elevated levels of CB1R, IL-1b, TNF-a, the chemokine CCL2 and interferon regulatory factor-5 (IRF5), a marker of M1 inflammatory macrophage polarization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In primary cultured rodent and human macrophages, CB1R activation increased Irf5 expression, whereas knockdown of Irf5 blunted CB1R-induced secretion of inflammatory cytokines without affecting CCL2 expression, which was p38MAPKa-dependent.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Macrophage-specific in vivo knockdown of Irf5 protected ZDF rats from b-cell loss and hyperglycemia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, IRF5 is a crucial downstream mediator of diabetogenic CB1R signaling in macrophages and a potential therapeutic target.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Brain-derived neurotrophic factor attenuates doxorubicin-induced cardiac dysfunction through activating Akt signalling in rats.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The clinical application of doxorubicin (Dox) is limited by its adverse effect of cardiotoxicity.</Gene>
<Gene>Previous studies have suggested the cardioprotective effect of brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We hypothesize that BDNF could protect against Dox-induced cardiotoxicity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sprague Dawley rats were injected with Dox (2.5 mg/kg, 3 times/week, i.p.), in the presence or absence of recombinant BDNF (0.4 ug/kg, i.v.) for 2 weeks.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>H9c2 cells were treated with Dox (1 uM) and/or BDNF (400 ng/ml) for 24 hrs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Functional roles of BDNF against Dox-induced cardiac injury were examined both in vivo and in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Protein level of BDNF was reduced in Dox-treated rat ventricles, whereas BDNF and its receptor tropomyosin-related kinase B (TrkB) were markedly up-regulated after BDNF administration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Brain-derived neurotrophic factor significantly inhibited Dox-induced cardiomyocyte apoptosis, oxidative stress and cardiac dysfunction in rats.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Meanwhile, BDNF increased cell viability, inhibited apoptosis and DNA damage of Dox-treated H9c2 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Investigations of the underlying mechanisms revealed that BDNF activated Akt and preserved phosphorylation of mammalian target of rapamycin and Bad without affecting p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase and extracellular regulated protein kinase pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the beneficial effect of BDNF was abolished by BDNF scavenger TrkB-Fc or Akt inhibitor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, our findings reveal a potent protective role of BDNF against Dox-induced cardiotoxicity by activating Akt signalling, which may facilitate the safe use of Dox in cancer treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A 22q11.2 amplification in the region encoding microRNA-650 correlates with the epithelial to mesenchymal transition in breast cancer primary cultures of Mexican patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Breast cancer ranks first in incidence and mortality in working age women.</Gene>

<Gene>Cancer initiation and progression relies on accumulation of genetic and epigenetic aberrations that alter cellular processes, among them, epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) denotes particularly aggressive neoplasias given its capacity to invade and metastasize.</Gene>
<Gene>Several microRNAs (miRNA) have been found able to regulate gene expression at the core of EMT.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, the Affymetrix CytoScan HD array was used to analyze three different primary tumor cell isolates from Mexican breast cancer patients.</Gene>
<Gene>We found an amplification in band 22q11.2 shared by the three samples, in the region that encodes miRNA-650.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of this miRNA has been associated with downregulation of tumor suppressors ING4 and NDRG2, which have been implicated in cancer progression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using the Pathway Linker platform the ING4 and NDRG2 interaction networks showed a significant association with signaling pathways commonly deregulated in cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Also, several studies support their participation in the EMT.</Gene>

<Gene>Supporting the latter, we found that the three primary isolates were E-cadherin negative, vimentin positive, presented a cancer stem cell-like phenotype CD44+CD24-/low and were invasive in Transwell invasion assays.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This evidence suggests that the gain of region 22q11.2 contributes to trigger EMT.</Gene>
<Gene>This is the first evidence linking miR-650 and breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interference with Tim-3 protein expression attenuates the invasion of clear cell renal cell carcinoma and aggravates anoikis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Tumor cells resistant to anoikis are considered to be candidates for metastasis.</Gene>
<Gene>In the present study, the role of Tim-3 in anoikis and its influence on the invasion of clear cell renal cell carcinoma (ccRCC) was investigated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, polyhydroxylethylmethacrylate (poly-HEMA) was applied to two ccRCC cell lines, 786-O and Caki-2, to induce detachment from the extracellular matrix (ECM).</Gene>
<Gene>Tim-3 mRNA and protein expression levels were assayed by reverse transcription-quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) and western blot, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Anoikis was measured by Ho33342/PI double staining, acridine orange staining, and further determined using the CytoSelect  24-well Anoikis Assay kit.</Gene>
