<Gene>Apoptosis was measured using flow cytometry, E-cadherin and N-cadherin protein expression were determined using western blotting and a Chemicon cell invasion assay kit was used to quantify the invasive capacity of 786-O and Caki-2 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It was demonstrated that detachment from the ECM decreases transcription and the protein expression level of Tim-3 in 786-O and Caki-2 cells compared with control cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interference with Tim-3 expression using small interfering RNA exacerbated anoikis in 786-O and Caki-2 cells induced by poly-HEMA treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>E-cadherin upregulation, N-cadherin downregulation, and ECM detachment-induced reduction in invasion ability were all exacerbated by knockdown of Tim-3.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, interference with Tim-3 expression may attenuate the invasion of renal cell carcinoma by aggravating anoikis, indicating Tim-3 as a potential therapeutic target for treating ccRCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Increased frequency of peripheral blood follicular helper T cells and elevated serum IL-21 levels in patients with knee osteoarthritis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>An aberrant immune response has been implicated in the pathogenesis of osteoarthritis (OA).</Gene>
<Gene>However, the role of peripheral blood follicular helper T (TFH) cells in the pathogenesis of OA has yet to be elucidated.</Gene>
<Gene>The purpose of the present study was to examine the role of TFH cells and serum interleukin-21 (IL-21) in the pathogenesis of OA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Frequency of peripheral blood inducible costimulator (ICOS)+, programmed death 1 (PD-1)+, and IL-21+ CXCR5+CD4+ T cells in 40 patients with OA and 13 healthy controls (HCs) were examined by flow cytometry.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The disease state in individual patients was assessed using the Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC).</Gene>
<Gene>Concentrations of serum IL-21, interferon-g (INF-g), IL-4, IL-17A, and C-reactive protein (CRP) were determined, and the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was measured.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The percentages of CXCR5+CD4+ cells, PD-1+CXCR5+CD4+, ICOS+CXCR5+CD4+ and IL-21+CXCR5+CD4+ T cells in OA patients were signifcantly higher than those in the HCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, serum IL-21, IL-17A and IFN-g levels in OA patients were significantly higher than those in HCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of IL-21+TFH cells in OA patients demonstrated a positive correlation with OA disease activity, CRP levels and WOMAC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TFH cells and IL-21 appear to serve an important role in the progression of OA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IL-21+TFH cells may prove to be a marker of OA disease activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Syntaxin 2 Acts as Inhibitory SNARE for Insulin Granule Exocytosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Of the four syntaxins (Syns) specialized for exocytosis, syntaxin-2 is the least understood.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we employed syntaxin-2/epimorphin knockout (KO) mice to examine the role of syntaxin-2 in insulin secretory granule (SG) exocytosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Unexpectedly, syntaxin-2 KO mice exhibited paradoxical superior glucose homeostasis resulting from an enhanced insulin secretion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This was confirmed in vitro by pancreatic islet perifusion showing an amplified biphasic glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS) arising from an increase in size of the readily-releasable pool of insulin SGs and enhanced SG pool refilling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The increase in insulin exocytosis was attributed mainly from an enhanced recruitment of the larger pool of newcomer SGs that undergoes no residence time on plasma membrane before fusion, and to lesser extent also the predocked SGs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Consistently, syntaxin-2 depletion resulted in stimulation-induced increase in abundance of exocytotic complexes we previous demonstrated to mediate the fusion of newcomer SGs (Syn-3/VAMP8/SNAP25/Munc18b) and predocked SGs (Syn-1A/VAMP2/SNAP25/Muncn18a).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This work is first to show in mammals that syntaxin-2 could function as inhibitory SNARE protein, which when relieved, could promote exocytosis in pancreatic islet b-cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, syntaxin-2 may serve as a potential target to treat diabetes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Effect of ART1 on the proliferation and migration of mouse colon carcinoma CT26 cells in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Arginine-specific mono-ADP-ribosyltransferase 1 (ART1) is an important enzyme that catalyzes arginine-specific mono-ADP-ribosylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>There is evidence that arginine-specific mono-ADP-ribosylation may affect the proliferation of smooth muscle cells via the Rho-dependent signaling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Previous studies have demonstrated that ART1 may have a role in the proliferation, invasion and apoptosis of colon carcinoma in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, the effect of ART1 on the proliferation and invasion of colon carcinoma in vivo has yet to be elucidated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the present study, mouse colon carcinoma CT26 cells were infected with a lentivirus to produce ART1 gene silencing or overexpression, and were then subcutaneously transplanted.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To observe the effect of ART1 on tumor growth or liver metastasis in vivo, a spleen transplant tumor model of CT26 cells in BALB/c mice was successfully constructed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Expression levels of focal adhesion kinase (FAK), Ras homolog gene family member A (RhoA) and the downstream factors, c-myc, c-fos and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) proteins, were measured in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results demonstrated that ART1 gene silencing inhibited the growth of the spleen transplanted tumor and its ability to spread to the liver via metastasis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>There was also an accompanying increase in expression of FAK, RhoA, c-myc, c-fos and COX-2, whereas CT26 cells with ART1 overexpression demonstrated the opposite effect.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest a potential role for ART1 in the proliferation and invasion of CT26 cells and a possible mechanism in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Dclk1, a tumor stem cell marker, regulates pro-survival signaling and self-renewal of intestinal tumor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: More than 80% of intestinal neoplasia is associated with the adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) mutation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Doublecortin-like kinase 1 (Dclk1), a kinase protein, is overexpressed in colorectal cancer and specifically marks tumor stem cells (TSCs) that self-renew and increased the tumor progeny in Apc (Min/+) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the role of Dclk1 expression and its contribution to regulating pro-survival signaling for tumor progression in Apc mutant cancer is poorly understood.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>We analyzed DCLK1 and pro-survival signaling gene expression datasets of 329 specimens from TCGA Colon Adenocarcinoma Cancer Data.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The network of DCLK1 and pro-survival signaling was analyzed utilizing the GeneMANIA database.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We examined the expression levels of Dclk1 and other stem cell-associated markers, pro-survival signaling pathways, cell self-renewal in the isolated intestinal epithelial cells of Apc (Min/+) mice with high-grade dysplasia and adenocarcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To determine the functional role of Dclk1 for tumor progression, we knocked down Dclk1 and determined the pro-survival signaling pathways and stemness.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We used siRNA technology to gene silence pro-survival signaling in colon cancer cells in vitro.</Gene>
<Gene>We utilized FACS, IHC, western blot, RT-PCR, and clonogenic (self-renewal) assays.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>We found a correlation between DCLK1 and pro-survival signaling expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of Dclk1 and stem cell-associated markers Lgr5, Bmi1, and Musashi1 were significantly higher in the intestinal epithelial cells of Apc (Min/+) mice than in wild-type controls.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intestinal epithelial cells of Apc (Min/+) mice showed increased expression of pro-survival signaling, pluripotency and self-renewal ability.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the enteroids formed from the intestinal Dclk1(+) cells of Apc (Min/+) mice display higher pluripotency and pro-survival signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Dclk1 knockdown in Apc (Min/+) mice attenuates intestinal adenomas and adenocarcinoma, and decreases pro-survival signaling and self-renewal.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Knocking down RELA and NOTCH1 pro-survival signaling and DCLK1 in HT29 and DLD1 colon cancer cells in vitro reduced the tumor cells' ability to self-renew and survive.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>Our results indicate that Dclk1 is essential in advancing intestinal tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Knocking down Dclk1 decreases tumor stemness and progression and is thus predicted to regulate pro-survival signaling and tumor cell pluripotency.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study provides a strong rationale to target Dclk1 as a treatment strategy for colorectal cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Metalloprotease-disintegrin ADAM12 actively promotes the stem cell-like phenotype in claudin-low breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: ADAM12 is upregulated in human breast cancers and is a predictor of chemoresistance in estrogen receptor-negative tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ADAM12 is induced during epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition, a feature associated with claudin-low breast tumors, which are enriched in cancer stem cell (CSC) markers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It is currently unknown whether ADAM12 plays an active role in promoting the CSC phenotype in breast cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>ADAM12 expression was downregulated in representative claudin-low breast cancer cell lines, SUM159PT and Hs578T, using siRNA transfection or inducible shRNA expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cell characteristics commonly associated with the CSC phenotype in vitro (cell migration, invasion, anoikis resistance, mammosphere formation, ALDH activity, and expression of the CD44 and CD24 cell surface markers) and in vivo (tumor formation in mice using limiting dilution transplantation assays) were evaluated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RNA sequencing was performed to identify global gene expression changes after ADAM12 knockdown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>We found that sorted SUM159PT cell populations with high ADAM12 levels had elevated expression of CSC markers and an increased ability to form mammospheres.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ADAM12 knockdown reduced cell migration and invasion, decreased anoikis resistance, and compromised mammosphere formation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ADAM12 knockdown also diminished ALDEFLUOR(+) and CD44(hi)/CD24(-/lo) CSC-enriched populations in vitro and reduced tumorigenesis in mice in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RNA sequencing identified a significant overlap between ADAM12- and Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor (EGFR)-regulated genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consequently, ADAM12 knockdown lowered the basal activation level of EGFR, and this effect was abolished by batimastat, a metalloproteinase inhibitor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, incubation of cells with exogenously added EGF prevented the downregulation of CD44(hi)/CD24(-/lo) cell population by ADAM12 knockdown.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS: These results indicate that ADAM12 actively supports the CSC phenotype in claudin-low breast cancer cells via modulation of the EGFR pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Star-PAP, a poly(A) polymerase, functions as a tumor suppressor in an orthotopic human breast cancer model.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Star-PAP is a noncanonical poly(A) polymerase and required for the expression of a select set of mRNAs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the pathological role of Star-PAP in cancer largely remains unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we observed decreased expression of Star-PAP in breast cancer cell lines and tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Ectopic Star-PAP expression inhibited proliferation as well as colony-forming ability of breast cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In breast cancer patients, high levels of Star-PAP correlated with an improved prognosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, by regulating the expression of BIK (BCL2-interacting killer), Star-PAP induced apoptosis of breast cancer cells through the mitochondrial pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The growth of breast cancer xenografts in NOD/SCID mice was also inhibited by the doxycycline-induced Star-PAP overexpression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, Star-PAP sensitized breast cancer cells to chemotherapy drugs both in vitro and in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In mammary epithelial cells, Star-PAP knockdown partially transformed these cells and induced them to undergo epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings suggested that Star-PAP possesses tumor-suppressing activity and can be a valuable target for developing new cancer therapeutic strategies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Doxycycline attenuates breast cancer related inflammation by decreasing plasma lysophosphatidate concentrations and inhibiting NF-kB activation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>We previously discovered that tetracyclines increase the expression of lipid phosphate phosphatases at the surface of cells.</Gene>
<Gene>These enzymes degrade circulating lysophosphatidate and therefore doxycycline increases the turnover of plasma lysophosphatidate and decreases its concentration.</Gene>
<Gene>Extracellular lysophosphatidate signals through six G protein-coupled receptors and it is a potent promoter of tumor growth, metastasis and chemo-resistance.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These effects depend partly on the stimulation of inflammation that lysophosphatidate produces.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>In this work, we used a syngeneic orthotopic mouse model of breast cancer to determine the impact of doxycycline on circulating lysophosphatidate concentrations and tumor growth.</Gene>
<Gene>Cytokine/chemokine concentrations in tumor tissue and plasma were measured by multiplexing laser bead technology.</Gene>
<Gene>Leukocyte infiltration in tumors was analyzed by immunohistochemistry.</Gene>
<Gene>The expression of IL-6 in breast cancer cell lines was determined by RT-PCR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cell growth was measured in Matrigel  3D culture.</Gene>
<Gene>The effects of doxycycline on NF-kB-dependent signaling were analyzed by Western blotting.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: Doxycycline decreased plasma lysophosphatidate concentrations, delayed tumor growth and decreased the concentrations of several cytokines/chemokines (IL-1b, IL-6, IL-9, CCL2, CCL11, CXCL1, CXCL2, CXCL9, G-CSF, LIF, VEGF) in the tumor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results were compatible with the effects of doxycycline in decreasing the numbers of F4/80(+) macrophages and CD31(+) blood vessel endothelial cells in the tumor.</Gene>
<Gene>Doxycycline also decreased the lysophosphatidate-induced growth of breast cancer cells in three-dimensional culture.</Gene>
<Gene>Lysophosphatidate-induced Ki-67 expression was inhibited by doxycycline.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>NF-kB activity in HEK293 cells transiently expressing a NF-kB-luciferase reporter vectors was also inhibited by doxycycline.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Treatment of breast cancer cells with doxycycline also decreased the translocation of NF-kB to the nucleus and the mRNA levels for IL-6 in the presence or absence of lysophosphatidate.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>

<Gene>These results contribute a new dimension for understanding the anti-inflammatory effects of tetracyclines, which make them potential candidates for adjuvant therapy of cancers and other inflammatory diseases.</Gene>
<Gene>TAK1 regulates resident macrophages by protecting lysosomal integrity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hematopoietic cell survival and death is critical for development of a functional immune system.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we report that a protein kinase, TAK1, is selectively required for resident macrophage integrity during embryogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hematopoietic lineage-specific deletion of Tak1 gene (Tak1(HKO)) caused accumulation of cellular debris in the thymus in perinatal mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although no overt alteration in thymocytes and blood myeloid populations was observed in Tak1(HKO) mice, we found that thymic and lung macrophages were diminished.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the in vitro setting, Tak1 deficiency caused profound disruption of lysosomes and killed bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDMs) without any exogenous stressors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of the lysosomal protease, cathepsin B, partially blocked Tak1-deficient BMDM death, suggesting that leakage of the lysosomal contents is in part the cause of cell death.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To identify the trigger of this cell death, we examined involvement of TNF and Toll-like receptor pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Among them, we found that deletion of Tnfr1 partially rescued cell death.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, we show that Tnfr1 deletion partially restored thymic and lung macrophages in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that autocrine and potentially paracrine TNF kills Tak1-deficient macrophages during development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results reveal that TAK1 signaling maintains proper macrophage populations through protecting lysosomal integrity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Oxidized phagosomal NOX2 is replenished from lysosomes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In dendritic cells, the NADPH oxidase 2 (NOX2) is recruited to the phagosomal membrane during antigen uptake.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NOX2 produces reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the lumen of the phagosome which kill ingested pathogens, delay antigen breakdown and alter the peptide repertoire for presentation to T cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>How the integral membrane component of NOX2, cytochrome b558, traffics to phagosomes is incompletely understood.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we show in dendritic cells derived from human blood-isolated monocytes that cytochrome b558 is initially recruited to the phagosome from the plasma membrane during phagosome formation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cytochrome b558 also traffics from a lysosomal pool to phagosomes and this is required to replenish oxidatively damaged NOX2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We identified syntaxin-7, SNAP23 and VAMP8 as the soluble N-ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor attachment protein receptor (SNARE) proteins mediating this process.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data describe a key mechanism of how dendritic cells sustain ROS production after antigen uptake required to initiate T cell responses.</Gene>
<Gene>TIEG1 deficiency confers enhanced myocardial protection in the infarcted heart by mediating the Pten/Akt signalling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The transforming growth factor (TGF)-b-inducible early gene-1 (TIEG1) plays a crucial role in modulating cell apoptosis and proliferation in a number of diseases, including pancreatic cancer, leukaemia and osteoporosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the functional role of TIEG1 in the heart has not been fully defined.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we first investigated the role of TIEG1 in ischaemic heart disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>For in vitro experiments, cardiomyocytes were isolated from both TIEG1 knockout (KO) and wile-type (WT) mice, and the apoptotic ratios were evaluated after a 48-h ischaemic insult.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A cell proliferation assay was performed after 7 days of incubation under normoxic conditions.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, the angiogenic capacity of endothelial cells was determined by tube formation assay.</Gene>
<Gene>For in vivo experiments, a model of myocardial infarction (MI) was established using both TIEG1 KO and WT mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Echocardiography was performed at 3 and 28 days post-MI, whereas the haemodynamics test was performed 28 days post-MI.</Gene>

<Gene>Histological analyses of apoptosis, proliferation, angiogenesis and infarct zone assessments were performed using terminal deoxynucleotidyltransferase-mediated dUTP nick-end labelling (TUNEL) staining, BrdU immunostaining, a-smooth muscle actin (a-SMA)/CD31 immunostaining and Masson's trichrome staining, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Changes in the expression of related proteins caused by TIEG1 deficiency were confirmed using both reverse transcription-quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) and western blot analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our results demonstrated that the absence of TIEG1 prevented cardiomyocytes from undergoing apoptosis and promoted higher proliferation; it stimulated the proliferation of endothelial cells in vitro and in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Improved cardiac function and less scar formation were observed in TIEG1 KO mice, and we also observed the altered expression of phosphatase and tensin homolog (Pten), Akt and Bcl-2/Bax, as well as vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>On the whole, our findings indicate that the absence of TIEG1 plays a cardioprotective role in ischaemic heart disease by promoting changes in Pten/Akt signalling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The novel mitochondrial matrix protease Ste23 is required for efficient presequence degradation and processing.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Around 70% of mitochondrial precursor proteins are imported from the cytosol via N-terminal presequences, which are cleaved upon exposure to the mitochondrial processing protease MPP in the matrix.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cleaved presequence peptides then need to be efficiently degraded and impairment of this clearance step e.g. by amyloid beta peptides causes a feedback inhibition of MPP leading ultimately to accumulation of immature precursor proteins within mitochondria.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Degradation of mitochondrial peptides is performed by Cym1 in yeast and its homolog PreP in humans.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we identify the novel mitochondrial matrix protease Ste23 in yeast, a homolog of human insulin degrading enzyme, which is required for efficient peptide degradation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ste23 and Cym1 tightly cooperate to ensure the correct functioning of the essential presequence processing machinery.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RIPK3 interactions with MLKL and CaMKII mediate oligodendrocytes death in the developing brain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Oligodendrocyte progenitor cells (OPCs) death is a key contributor to cerebral white matter injury (WMI) in the developing brain.</Gene>
<Gene>A previous study by our group indicated that receptor-interacting proteins (RIPs) are crucial in mediating necroptosis in developing neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, whether this mechanism is involved in OPCs death is unclear.</Gene>
<Gene>We aimed to explore the mechanisms of RIP-mediated oligodendrocytes (OLs) death in the developing brain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Oligodendrocytes necroptosis was induced by oxygen-glucose deprivation plus caspase inhibitor zVAD treatment (OGD/zVAD) in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Western blotting and immunofluorescence were used to detect RIPK1, RIPK3, mixed lineage kinase domain-like protein (MLKL), and Ca(2+) and calmodulin-dependent protein kinase IId (CaMKIId).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Immunoprecipitation was used to assess the interactions between RIPK3 and RIPK1, MLKL, and CaMKIId.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Necrostatin-1 was used to disturb the RIPK3-RIPK1 interaction, and siRNA was used to inhibit RIPK3 or MLKL expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Oligodendrocytes death was examined using PI staining, EM, and cell membrane leakage assays.</Gene>
<Gene>In vivo, brain damage in neonatal rats was induced by hypoxia-ischemia (HI).</Gene>
<Gene>This was followed by an examination of myelin development.</Gene>
<Gene>We found that OGD/zVAD treatment upregulates the expression of RIPK3 and the interaction of RIPK3 with RIPK1, MLKL, and CaMKIId.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of the RIPK3-MLKL or RIPK3-CaMKIId interaction attenuates OLs death induced by OGD/zVAD.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These protective mechanisms involve the translocation of MLKL to the OLs membrane, and the phosphorylation of CaMKIId.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, inhibition of the RIPK3-RIPK1 interaction did not protect OLs death induced by OGD/zVAD.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vivo studies indicated that the disrupted development of myelin was attenuated after the inhibition of RIPK3-MLKL or RIPK3-CaMKIId interaction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, our data indicate that RIPK3 is a key factor in protection against OLs death and abnormal myelin development via its interaction with MLKL and CaMKIId after HI.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This suggests that RIPK3 may be a potential target for the treatment of WMI in neonates.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pleomorphic adenoma gene like-2 induces epithelial-mesenchymal transition via Wnt/b-catenin signaling pathway in human colorectal adenocarcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a critical step in the acquisition of metastatic and invasive power for tumor cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Colorectal adenocarcinoma (CRC) is a common cancer where metastasis is directly linked to patient survival.</Gene>
<Gene>Recent studies show that pleomorphic adenoma gene like-2 (PLAGL2) could induce tumor EMT and is an independent predictive factor associated with poor prognosis in cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the present study, we confirmed the role of PLAGL2 in the prognosis of CRC patients and provide molecular evidence of PLAGL2 promoted EMT in CRC cell line SW480.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found that PLAGL2 expression was upregulated in the paraffin-embedded CRC tissues compared to borderline or benign tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Experimental EMT induced by PLAGL2 plasmid transfection proved PLAGL2 protein overexpression could enhance the cell scratch wound-healing and transwell ability and significantly upregulated mesenchymal marker proteins, N-cadherin and vimentin and concurrently downregulated epithelial marker of E-cadherin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Subsequently, through western blot assay, we found that PLAGL2 could activate the wnt-signaling component b-catenin in the nuclei.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>More CRC cell metastasis to the lungs was observed when the PLAGL2 overexpressing SW480 cells were injected into the tail vein of rats, compared with the cell control and PLAGL2 silence group.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings indicated that PLAGL2 might be a very upstream key molecule regulating EMT involved in Wnt/b-catenin signaling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The tripartite motif-containing protein 3 on the proliferation and cytokine secretion of rheumatoid arthritis fibroblast-like synoviocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recent studies have revealed fibroblast-like synoviocytes (FLS) as a pivotal effector cell in the inflamed joint of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) patients.</Gene>
<Gene>FLS exhibit high proliferation rates and constitutive expression of cytokines, contributing to the pathogenesis of RA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we found that the expression of tripartite motif-containing protein 3 (TRIM3), a candidate tumor suppressor gene, was lower in synovial tissue samples of RA patients than in that of healthy controls.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We then investigated the role of TRIM3 on the proliferation and cytokine secretion of primary cultured FLS from RA patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Enforced expression of TRIM3 in RA FLS led to significantly decreased cell proliferation as indicated by Cell Counting Kit-8 assay, reduced secretion of tumor necrosis factor-a (TNF)-a, interleukin (IL)-1b and IL-6 as indicated by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays, and decreased p38 phosphorylation as assessed by western blot analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The proteins promoting cell cycles (cyclin D1 and PCNA) were downregulated and the protein negatively regulating cell cycle progression (p53 and p21) was upregulated after TRIM3 overexpression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, TRIM3 knockdown had reverse effects on cell proliferation, which was suppressed by the p38-specific inhibitor SB203580.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, the current results demonstrated the downregulation of TRIM3 expression in RA synovial tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, TRIM3 exerted an anti-proliferation role in RA FLS via p38 signaling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sox2 inhibits Wnt-b-catenin signaling and metastatic potency of cisplatin-resistant lung adenocarcinoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lung cancer remains one of the most common cancer-associated mortalities worldwide, and platinum-based doublet chemotherapies are recommended as the first-line treatment for advanced non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC).</Gene>
<Gene>However, the frequent development of multidrug resistance, to cisplatin regimens in particular, is a major cause of chemotherapy failure in patients with aggressive NSCLC.</Gene>

<Gene>Wnt/b-catenin signaling and sex-determining region Y box 2 (Sox2) have been implicated in the development and progression and resistance to epidermal growth factor receptor-targeting therapy in lung cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The present study aimed to explore the effects of Wnt/b-catenin and Sox2 signaling on the chemoresistance of cisplatin-resistant lung cancer cells by assessing the effects of Sox2 on Wnt/b-catenin signaling activity, cell migration, invasion and clonogenicity, and susceptibility to cisplatin in lung adenocarcinoma A549 cells and cisplatin-resistant A549/DDP cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results demonstrated that an enforced expression of Sox2 led to inhibition of Wnt/b-catenin signaling activity, potentially by upregulating glycogen synthase kinase 3 b in A549 and A549/DDP cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>An overexpression of Sox2 promoted cell migration and invasion, in addition to enhancing the clonogenic capacity in A549 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Notably, knockdown Sox2 using short hairpin RNA led to an enhanced susceptibility of A549 and A549/DDP cells to cisplatin, along with increased cell apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The present study thus suggests that Sox2 may be an important regulator in development of chemoresistance of lung cancer cells and may be a novel therapeutic target for treatment chemoresistant lung cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IQGAP1-siRNA inhibits proliferation and metastasis of U251 and U373 glioma cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IQ motif containing GTPase activating protein 1 (IQGAP1) is a scaffold protein, which is aberrantly expressed in several tumor types and is closely associated with the development, metastasis and prognosis of cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Several studies have demonstrated that IQGAP1 has broad prospects in the basic and clinical research of tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The present study aimed to explore the effects of IQGAP1-small interfering (si) NA on the proliferation and metastasis of U251 and U373 glioma cell lines, which markedly expressed IQGAP1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The human glioma cell lines (U251 and U373) were transfected with siRNA and transfection efficacy was confirmed by reverse transcription-quantitative polymerase chain reaction (RT-qPCR) and western blot analysis.</Gene>
<Gene>Cell proliferation was detected using the Cell Counting kit-8, and cell metastasis capabilities were detected using cell adhesion, migration and invasion assays.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, the expression levels of several tumor-associated genes were determined by RT-qPCR and western blotting.</Gene>
<Gene>The results indicated that IQGAP1 was expressed at higher levels in glioma tissues compared with in normal brain tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IQGAP1-siRNA significantly inhibited cell proliferation, and cell adhesion, migration and invasion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the expression levels of matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)2, Snail, MMP9, fibronectin 1 and Twist were suppressed, and E-cadherin was upregulated in response to siRNA-IQGAP1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The present study identified the function of IQGAP1 in glioma cell biology, and indicated that it may be considered a novel target for glioma treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>3-Hydroxyterphenyllin, a natural fungal metabolite, induces apoptosis and S phase arrest in human ovarian carcinoma cells.</Gene>

<Gene>In the present study, we evaluated 3-Hydroxyter-phenyllin (3-HT) as a potential anticancer agent using the human ovarian cancer cells A2780/CP70 and OVCAR-3, and normal human epithelial ovarian cells IOSE-364 as an in vitro model.</Gene>
<Gene>3-HT suppressed proliferation and caused cytotoxicity against A2780/CP70 and OVCAR-3 cells, while it exhibited lower cytotoxicity in IOSE-364 cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Subsequently, we found that 3-HT induced S phase arrest and apoptosis in a dose-independent manner.</Gene>
<Gene>Further investigation revealed that S phase arrest was related with DNA damage which mediated the ATM/p53/Chk2 pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Downregulation of cyclin D1, cyclin A2, cyclin E1, CDK2, CDK4 and Cdc25C, and the upregulation of Cdc25A and cyclin B1 led to the accumulation of cells in S phase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The apoptotic effect was confirmed by Hoechst 33342 staining, depolarization of mitochondrial membrane potential and activation of cleaved caspase-3 and PARP1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Additional results revealed both intrinsic and extrinsic apoptotic pathways were involved.</Gene>
<Gene>The intrinsic apoptotic pathway was activated through decreasing the protein levels of Bcl2, Bcl-xL and procaspase-9 and increasing the protein level of Puma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The induction of DR5 and DR4 indicated that the extrinsic apoptotic pathway was also activated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Induction of ROS and activation of ERK were observed in ovarian cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We therefore concluded that 3-HT possessed anti-proliferative effect on A2780/CP70 and OVCAR-3 cells, induced S phase arrest and caused apoptosis.</Gene>
<Gene>Taken together, we propose that 3-HT shows promise as a therapeutic candidate for treating ovarian cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>Induced pluripotent stem cells from patients with focal cortical dysplasia and refractory epilepsy.</Gene>

<Gene>Focal cortical dysplasia (FCD) is caused by numerous alterations, which can be divided into abnormalities of the cortical architecture and cytological variations; however, the exact etiology of FCD remains unknown.</Gene>

<Gene>The generation of induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) from the cells of patients with neurological diseases, and their subsequent tissue-specific differentiation, serves as an invaluable source for testing and studying the initial development and subsequent progression of diseases associated with the central nervous system.</Gene>
<Gene>A total of 2 patients demonstrating seizures refractory to drug treatment, characterized as FCD Type IIb, were enrolled in the present study.</Gene>
<Gene>Fibroblasts were isolated from residual skin fragments obtained from surgical treatment and from brain samples obtained during surgical resection.</Gene>

<Gene>iPSCs were generated following exposure of fibroblasts to viral vectors containing POU class 5 homeobox 1 (OCT4), sex determining region Y-box 2 (SOX2), Kruppel-like factor 4 and c-MYC genes, and were characterized by immunohistochemical staining for the pluripotent markers homeobox protein NANOG, SOX2, OCT4, TRA1-60 and TRA1-81.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The brain samples were tested with antibodies against protein kinase B (AKT), phosphorylated-AKT, mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and phosphorylated-mTOR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis of the AKT/mTOR pathway revealed a statistically significant difference between the cerebral tissues of the two patients, which were of different ages (45 and 12 years old).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Clones with the morphological features of embryonic cells were detected on the 13th day and were characterized following three subcultures.</Gene>
<Gene>The positive staining characteristics of the embryonic cells confirmed the successful generation of iPSCs derived from the patients' fibroblasts.</Gene>
<Gene>Therefore, the present study presents a method to obtain a useful cellular source that may help to understand embryonic brain development associated with FCD.</Gene>
<Gene>Insulin-like growth factor 1 receptor-mediated cell survival in hypoxia depends on the promotion of autophagy via suppression of the PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hypoxia is widely accepted as a fundamental biological phenomenon, which is strongly associated with tissue damage and cell viability under stress conditions.</Gene>
<Gene>Insulin-like growth factor-1</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>(IGF-1) is known to protect tissues from multiple types of damage, and protect cells from apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hypoxia is a regulatory factor of the IGF system, however the role of the IGF-1 receptor (IGF-1R) in hypoxia-induced apoptosis remains unclear.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The present study investigated the potential mechanisms associated with IGF-1R-associated apoptosis under hypoxic conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mouse embryonic fibroblasts exhibiting disruption or overexpression of IGF-1R (R- cells and R+ cells) were used to examine the level of apoptosis, autophagy, and production of reactive oxygen species (ROS).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The autophagy inhibitor 3-methyladenine was used to assess the effect of autophagy on ROS production and apoptosis under hypoxic conditions.</Gene>

<Gene>A potential downstream signaling pathway involving phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)/threonine protein kinase B (Akt)/mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) was identifiedby western blot analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results demonstrated that hypoxia induced apoptosis, increased ROS production, and promoted autophagy in a time-dependent manner relative to that observed under normoxia.</Gene>
<Gene>R+ cells exhibited a lower percentage of apoptotic cells, lower ROS production, and higher levels of autophagy when compared to that of R- cells.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, inhibition of autophagy led to increased ROS production and a higher percentage of apoptotic cells in the two cell types.</Gene>

<Gene>Furthermore, IGF-1R is related with PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling pathway and enhanced autophagy-associated protein expression, which was verified following treatment with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results indicated that IGF-1R may increase cell viability under hypoxic conditions by promoting autophagy and scavenging ROS production, which is closed with PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells-1 ameliorates experimental autoimmune neuritis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Experimental autoimmune neuritis (EAN) is a cluster of differentiation 4+ T helper 1 cell-mediated inflammatory demyelinating disease of the peripheral nervous system and serves as a useful animal model for Guillain-Barre syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>Triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells-1 (TREM-1) is an important receptor involved in sepsis and the innate inflammatory response.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Linear plasmid 17 (LP 17) peptide is a competitive antagonist of TREM-1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To investigate the role of TREM-1 in EAN, 64 male Lewis rats were randomly divided into four groups: Normal saline, complete Freund's adjuvant, EAN and LP 17.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The present study assessed the mRNA expression levels of TREM-1, tumor necrosis factor-a and interleukin-1b in sciatic nerves and peripheral blood mononuclear cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results demonstrated that inhibiting TREM-1 by administering LP 17 ameliorated symptoms and reduced inflammation in EAN rats.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The present study concluded that TREM-1 may be involved in the pathogenesis of EAN, and that inhibition of TREM-1 may ameliorate EAN.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Atorvastatin protects against contrast-induced nephropathy via anti-apoptosis by the upregulation of Hsp27 in vivo and in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) is an iatrogenic acute renal failure occurring following the intravascular injection of iodinated radiographic contrast medium.</Gene>
<Gene>However, the regulatory mechanisms for CIN remain to be fully elucidated.</Gene>
<Gene>The present study aimed to investigate whether atorvastatin protects against CIN via anti-apoptotic effects by the upregulation of Hsp27 in vivo and in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To determine whether atorvastatin attenuated CIN, the inflammatory response and apoptosis in vivo and in vitro, a rat model of iopamidol-induced CIN was used, and human embryonic proximal tubule (HK2) cell damage was assessed.</Gene>
<Gene>The rats were assigned into four groups (n=10 per group), as follows: Control rats; rats+atorvastatin; rats + iopamidol; rats+iopamidol+atorvastatin.</Gene>
<Gene>In vitro, the HK2 cells were treated with iopamidol in the presence or absence of atorvastatin, heat shock protein (Hsp)27 small interfering (si)RNA or pcDNA3.1-Hsp27.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The renal tissues were examined histopathologically and collected for western blot analysis.</Gene>
<Gene>The results showed that atorvastatin ameliorated the apoptosis and deterioration of renal function (P<0.05).</Gene>

<Gene>Furthermore, atorvastatin reduced the iopamidol-induced activity of B cell lymphoma-2 (Bcl-2)-associated X protein (Bax)/caspase-3 and increased the expression of Bcl-2 in vivo and in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Notably, following treatment with Hsp27 siRNA or pcDNA3.1-Hsp27, it was found that iopamidol enhanced or weakened the upregulation of Bax/caspase-3 and downregulation of Bcl-2 in the HK2 cells, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results of the present study suggested that atorvastatin protected against contrast-induced renal tubular cell apoptosis through the upregulation of Hsp27 in vivo and in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibitory effect of emodin on fatty acid synthase, colon cancer proliferation and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Fatty acid synthase (FASN) is a key anabolic enzyme for de novo fatty acid synthesis, which is important in the development of colon carcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The high expression of FASN is considered a promising molecular target for colon cancer therapy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Emodin, a naturally occurring anthraquinone, exhibits an anticancer effect in various types of human cancer, including colon cancer; however, the molecular mechanisms remain to be fully elucidated.</Gene>
<Gene>Cell viability was evaluated using a Cell Counting Kit-8 assay.</Gene>
<Gene>The apoptosis rate of cells was quantified via flow cytometry following Annexin V/propidium iodide staining.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>FASN activity was measured by monitoring oxidation of nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate at a wavelength of 340 nm, and intracellular free fatty acid levels were detected using a Free Fatty Acid Quantification kit.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Western blot analysis and reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction were used to detect target gene and protein expression.</Gene>
<Gene>The present study was performed to investigate whether the gene expression of FASN and its enzymatic activity are regulated by emodin in a human colon cancer cell line.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Emodin markedly inhibited the proliferation of HCT116 cells and a higher protein level of FASN was expressed, compared with that in SW480, SNU-C2A or SNU-C5 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Emodin significantly downregulated the protein expression of FASN in HCT116 cells, which was caused by protein degradation due to elevated protein ubiquitination.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Emodin also inhibited intracellular FASN enzymatic activity and reduced the levels of intracellular free fatty acids.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Emodin enhanced antiproliferation and apoptosis in a dose- and time-dependent manner.</Gene>
<Gene>The combined treatment of emodin and cerulenin, a commercial FASN inhibitor, had an additive effect on these activities.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Palmitate, the final product of the FASN reaction, rescued emodin-induced viability and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, emodin altered FASN-involved signaling pathways, including phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase/Akt and mitogen-activated protein kinases/extracellular signal-regulated kinases 1/2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggested that emodin-regulated cell growth and apoptosis were mediated by inhibiting FASN and provide a molecular basis for colon cancer therapy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Syndecan-1 is a novel molecular marker for triple negative inflammatory breast cancer and modulates the cancer stem cell phenotype via the IL-6/STAT3, Notch and EGFR signaling pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Inflammatory breast cancer (IBC), a particularly aggressive form of breast cancer, is characterized by cancer stem cell (CSC) phenotype.</Gene>
<Gene>Due to a lack of targeted therapies, the identification of molecular markers of IBC is of major importance.</Gene>

<Gene>The heparan sulfate proteoglycan Syndecan-1 acts as a coreceptor for growth factors and chemokines, modulating inflammation, tumor progression, and cancer stemness, thus it may emerge as a molecular marker for IBC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>We characterized expression of Syndecan-1 and the CSC marker CD44, Notch-1 & -3 and EGFR in carcinoma tissues of triple negative IBC (n = 13) and non-IBC (n = 17) patients using qPCR and immunohistochemistry.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Impact of siRNA-mediated Syndecan-1 knockdown on the CSC phenotype of the human triple negative IBC cell line SUM-149 and HER-2-overexpressing non-IBC SKBR3 cells employing qPCR, flow cytometry, Western blotting, secretome profiling and Notch pharmacological inhibition experiments.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Data were statistically analyzed using Student's t-test/Mann-Whitney U-test or one-way ANOVA followed by Tukey's multiple comparison tests.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Our data indicate upregulation and a significant positive correlation of Syndecan-1 with CD44 protein, and Notch-1 & -3 and EGFR mRNA in IBC vs non-IBC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ALDH1 activity and the CD44((+))CD24((-/low)) subset as readout of a CSC phenotype were reduced upon Syndecan-1 knockdown.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Functionally, Syndecan-1 silencing significantly reduced 3D spheroid and colony formation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Intriguingly, qPCR results indicate downregulation of the IL-6, IL-8, CCL20, gp130 and EGFR mRNA upon Syndecan-1 suppression in both cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, Syndecan-1 silencing significantly downregulated Notch-1, -3, -4 and Hey-1 in SUM-149 cells, and downregulated only Notch-3 and Gli-1 mRNA in SKBR3 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Secretome profiling unveiled reduced IL-6, IL-8, GRO-alpha and GRO a/b/g cytokines in conditioned media of Syndecan-1 knockdown SUM-149 cells compared to controls.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The constitutively activated STAT3 and NFkB, and expression of gp130, Notch-1 & -2, and EGFR proteins were suppressed upon Syndecan-1 ablation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mechanistically, gamma-secretase inhibition experiments suggested that Syndecan-1 may regulate the expression of IL-6, IL-8, gp130, Hey-1, EGFR and p-Akt via Notch signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>Syndecan-1 acts as a novel tissue biomarker and a modulator of CSC phenotype of triple negative IBC via the IL-6/STAT3, Notch and EGFR signaling pathways, thus emerging as a promising therapeutic target for IBC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Endothelial HIF-1a Enables Hypothalamic Glucose Uptake to Drive POMC Neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Glucose is the primary driver of hypothalamic proopiomelanocortin (POMC) neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that endothelial hypoxia-inducible factor 1a (HIF-1a) controls glucose uptake in the hypothalamus and that it is upregulated in conditions of undernourishment, during which POMC neuronal activity is decreased.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Endothelium-specific knockdown of HIF-1a impairs the ability of POMC neurons to adapt to the changing metabolic environment in vivo, resulting in overeating after food deprivation in mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The impaired functioning of POMC neurons was reversed ex vivo or by parenchymal glucose administration.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These observations indicate an active role for endothelial cells in the central control of metabolism and suggest that central vascular impairments may cause metabolic disorders.</Gene>
<Gene>A team of heterochromatin factors collaborates with small RNA pathways to combat repetitive elements and germline stress.</Gene>
<Gene>Repetitive sequences derived from transposons make up a large fraction of eukaryotic genomes and must be silenced to protect genome integrity.</Gene>
<Gene>Repetitive elements are often found in heterochromatin; however, the roles and interactions of heterochromatin proteins in repeat regulation are poorly understood.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that a diverse set of C. elegans heterochromatin proteins act together with the piRNA and nuclear RNAi pathways to silence repetitive elements and prevent genotoxic stress in the germ line.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutants in genes encoding HPL-2/HP1, LIN-13, LIN-61, LET-418/Mi-2, and H3K9me2 histone methyltransferase MET-2/SETDB1 also show functionally redundant sterility, increased germline apoptosis, DNA repair defects, and interactions with small RNA pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Remarkably, fertility of heterochromatin mutants could be partially restored by inhibiting cep-1/p53, endogenous meiotic double strand breaks, or the expression of MIRAGE1 DNA transposons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Functional redundancy among factors and pathways underlies the importance of safeguarding the genome through multiple means.</Gene>
<Gene>Folding of a single domain protein entering the endoplasmic reticulum precedes disulfide formation.</Gene>
<Gene>The relationship between protein synthesis, folding, and disulfide formation within the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) is poorly understood.</Gene>

<Gene>Previous studies have suggested that pre-existing disulfide links are absolutely required to allow protein folding and, conversely, that protein folding occurs prior to disulfide formation.</Gene>

<Gene>To address the question of what happens first within the ER, that is, protein folding or disulfide formation, we studied folding events at the early stages of polypeptide chain translocation into the mammalian ER using stalled translation intermediates.</Gene>
<Gene>Our results demonstrate that polypeptide folding can occur without complete domain translocation.</Gene>
<Gene>Protein disulfide isomerase (PDI) interacts with these early intermediates, but disulfide formation does not occur unless the entire sequence of the protein domain is translocated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This is the first evidence that folding of the polypeptide chain precedes disulfide formation within a cellular context and highlights key differences between protein folding in the ER and refolding of purified proteins.</Gene>
<Gene>Geranylgeranyl diphosphate synthase inhibition induces apoptosis that is dependent upon GGPP depletion, ERK phosphorylation and caspase activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bisphosphonates are diphosphate analogs that inhibit the intermediate enzymes of the mevalonate pathway.</Gene>

<Gene>Here, we compared the effects of a farnesyl diphosphate synthase inhibitor, zoledronate, and a geranylgeranyl diphosphate synthase (GGDPS) inhibitor, digeranyl bisphosphonate (DGBP), on lymphocytic leukemia cell proliferation and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both zoledronate and DGBP inhibited proliferation with DGBP doing so more potently.</Gene>
<Gene>DGBP was markedly less toxic than zoledronate toward the viability of healthy human peripheral blood mononuclear cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Addition of GGPP, but not farnesyl diphosphate (FPP), prevented the anti-proliferative effects of DGBP.</Gene>
<Gene>Both GGPP and FPP partially rescued the effects of zoledronate.</Gene>
<Gene>Co-treatment with DGBP and zoledronate was antagonistic.</Gene>

<Gene>To further assess the effects of the bisphosphonates, we analyzed annexin V and propidium iodide staining via flow cytometry and found that DGBP induced apoptosis more potently than zoledronate.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Western blots show that DGBP treatment altered expression and membrane affinity of some but not all geranylgeranylated small GTPases, activated caspases and increased ERK phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, the anti-proliferative effects of DGBP were blocked by treatment with a caspase inhibitor and by treatment with a MEK inhibitor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together, our findings indicate that DGBP is a more potent and selective compound than zoledronate in inducing apoptosis mediated through pathways that include caspases and MEK/ERK.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings support the further development of GGDPS inhibitors as anticancer therapeutics.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Arabidopsis RETINOBLASTOMA RELATED directly regulates DNA damage responses through functions beyond cell cycle control.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The rapidly proliferating cells in plant meristems must be protected from genome damage.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we show that the regulatory role of the Arabidopsis RETINOBLASTOMA RELATED (RBR) in cell proliferation can be separated from a novel function in safeguarding genome integrity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Upon DNA damage, RBR and its binding partner E2FA are recruited to heterochromatic gH2AX-labelled DNA damage foci in an ATM- and ATR-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These gH2AX-labelled DNA lesions are more dispersedly occupied by the conserved repair protein, AtBRCA1, which can also co-localise with RBR foci.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RBR and AtBRCA1 physically interact in vitro and in planta Genetic interaction between the RBR-silenced amiRBR and Atbrca1 mutants suggests that RBR and AtBRCA1 may function together in maintaining genome integrity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together with E2FA, RBR is directly involved in the transcriptional DNA damage response as well as in the cell death pathway that is independent of SOG1, the plant functional analogue of p53.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, plant homologs and analogues of major mammalian tumour suppressor proteins form a regulatory network that coordinates cell proliferation with cell and genome integrity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Androgen Stimulates Growth of Mouse Preantral Follicles In Vitro: Interaction With Follicle-Stimulating Hormone and With Growth Factors of the TGFb Superfamily.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Androgens are essential for the normal function of mature antral follicles but also have a role in the early stages of follicle development.</Gene>

<Gene>Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), the most common cause of anovulatory infertility, is characterized by androgen excess and aberrant follicle development that includes accelerated early follicle growth.</Gene>

<Gene>We have examined the effects of testosterone and dihydrotestosterone (DHT) on development of isolated mouse preantral follicles in culture with the specific aim of investigating interaction with follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), the steroidogenic pathway, and growth factors of the TGFb superfamily that are known to have a role in early follicle development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both testosterone and DHT stimulated follicle growth and augmented FSH-induced growth and increased the incidence of antrum formation among the granulosa cell layers of these preantral follicles after 72 hours in culture.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Effects of both androgens were reversed by the androgen receptor antagonist flutamide.</Gene>
<Gene>FSH receptor expression was increased in response to both testosterone and DHT, as was that of Star, whereas Cyp11a1 was down-regulated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The key androgen-induced changes in the TGFb signaling pathway were down-regulation of Amh, Bmp15, and their receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of Alk6 (Bmpr1b), a putative partner for Amhr2 and Bmpr2, by dorsomorphin resulted in augmentation of androgen-stimulated growth and modification of androgen-induced gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings point to varied effects of androgen on preantral follicle growth and function, including interaction with FSH-activated growth and steroidogenesis, and, importantly, implicate the intrafollicular TGFb system as a key mediator of androgen action.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings provide insight into abnormal early follicle development in PCOS.</Gene>
<Gene>The mTOR signal regulates myeloid-derived suppressor cells differentiation and immunosuppressive function in acute kidney injury.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) signal controls innate and adaptive immune response in multiple immunoregulatory contexts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) are a heterogeneous population of myeloid cells of potent immunosuppressive capacity.</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, we aimed to investigate the role of MDSCs in the protection of acute kidney injury (AKI) and the regulation of mTOR signal on MDSC's protective role in this context.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In mice AKI model, rapamycin administration was associated with improved renal function, restored histological damage and decreased CD4(+) and CD8(+) T-cell infiltration in kidney tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MDSCs, especially CD11b(+)Ly6G(+)Ly6C(low) G-MDSCs were recruited to the injured kidney following the interaction of CXCL1, CXCL2 and their receptor CXCR2 after inhibiting mTOR signal with rapamycin treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The adoptive transfer of rapamycin-treated MDSCs into the mice with AKI significantly improved the renal function, ameliorated histologic damages and limited the infiltration of T cells in kidney tissue.</Gene>

<Gene>In addition, the expression of pro-inflammatory cytokines IL-1b and IFN-g mRNA was downregulated while the expression of TGF-b1 and Foxp3 mRNA was upregulated in kidney tissue after transferring rapamycin-treated MDSCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Adoptive transfer of rapamycin-treated MDSCs also downregulated the serum levels of IL-1b, IL-6 and IFN-g and upregulated the serum levels of TGF-b1 compared with the IR group and PBS-treated MDSC group.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In in vitro study, inhibiting mTOR signal regulated the induction of MDSC towards the CD11b(+)Ly6G(+)Ly6C(low) G-MDSC subset.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The ability to suppress T-cell proliferation of both bone marrow-derived CD11b(+)Ly6G(+)Ly6C(low) G-MDSCs and CD11b(+)Ly6G(-)Ly6C(high) M-MDSCs was enhanced by mTOR signal inhibition via upregulating the expression of Arginase-1 and iNOS.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Accordingly, both G-MDSCs and M-MDSCs presented downregulated runx1 gene expression after rapamycin treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, our results demonstrated that MDSCs ameliorated AKI and the protective effect was enhanced by mTOR signal inhibition via promoting MDSCs recruitment, regulating the induction of MDSCs and strengthening their immunosuppressive activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>GWAS identifies population-specific new regulatory variants in FUT6 associated with plasma B12 concentrations in Indians.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Vitamin B12 is an important cofactor in one-carbon metabolism whose dysregulation is associated with various clinical conditions.</Gene>
<Gene>Indians have a high prevalence of B12 deficiency but little is known about the genetic determinants of circulating B12 concentrations in Indians.</Gene>

<Gene>We performed a genome-wide association study in 1001 healthy participants in the Pune Maternal Nutrition Study (PMNS), replication studies in 3418 individuals from other Indian cohorts and by meta-analysis identified new variants, rs3760775 (P = 1.2 x 10-23) and rs78060698 (P = 8.3 x 10-17) in FUT6 to be associated with circulating B12 concentrations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although in-silico analysis replicated both variants in Europeans, differences in the effect allele frequency, effect size and the linkage disequilibrium structure of credible set variants with the reported variants suggest population-specific characteristics in this region.</Gene>

<Gene>We replicated previously reported variants rs602662, rs601338 in FUT2, rs3760776, rs708686 in FUT6, rs34324219 in TCN1 (all P < 5 x 10-8), rs1131603 in TCN2 (P = 3.4 x 10-5), rs12780845 in CUBN (P = 3.0 x 10-3) and rs2270655 in MMAA (P = 2.0 x 10-3).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Circulating B12 concentrations in the PMNS and Parthenon study showed a significant decline with increasing age (P < 0.001), however, the genetic contribution to B12 concentrations remained constant.</Gene>

<Gene>Luciferase reporter and electrophoretic-mobility shift assay for the FUT6 variant rs78060698 using HepG2 cell line demonstrated strong allele-specific promoter and enhancer activity and differential binding of HNF4a, a key regulator of expression of various fucosyltransferases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hence, the rs78060698 variant, through regulation of fucosylation may control intestinal host-microbial interaction which could influence B12 concentrations.</Gene>
<Gene>Our results suggest that in addition to established genetic variants, population-specific variants are important in determining plasma B12 concentrations.</Gene>
<Gene>AGR2 ameliorates tumor necrosis factor-a-induced epithelial barrier dysfunction via suppression of NF-kB p65-mediated MLCK/p-MLC pathway activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intestinal epithelial barrier dysfunction plays a critical role in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).</Gene>

<Gene>Anterior gradient protein 2 homologue (AGR2) assists in maintaining intestinal homeostasis in dextran sulphate sodium-induced mouse ileocolitis; however, it is unclear whether it modulates intestinal barrier function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our study aimed to investigate the protective role of AGR2 in tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-a-induced intestinal epithelial barrier injury.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Caco-2 cell monolayers were pre-transfected with an AGR2 plasmid and then exposed to TNF-a. Epithelial permeability was assessed by detecting transepithelial electrical resistance and fluorescein isothiocyanate-dextran (40 kDa) flux.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The protein expression levels of zonula occludens-1 (ZO-1), occludin, claudin-1, myosin light chain kinase (MLCK)/p-MLC, and nuclear factor (NF)-kB p65 were determined by western blotting.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the cellular distributions of ZO-1, occludin, F-actin, and NF-kB p65 were evaluated by immunofluorescence staining.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results showed that the AGR2 mRNA and protein expression levels were both decreased in the Caco-2 cell monolayers, while AGR2 overexpression significantly ameliorated TNF-a-induced epithelial barrier hyperpermeability, increased the expression of tight junction (TJ) proteins and stabilized the cytoskeletal structure.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, AGR2 inhibited the changes in MLCK, MLC and p-MLC expression in response to TNF-a stimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, our study suggests that AGR2 inhibits TNF-a-induced Caco-2 cell hyperpermeability by regulating TJ and that this protective mechanism may be promoted by inhibition of NF-kB p65-mediated activation of the MLCK/p-MLC signaling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Skp2 deficiency restricts the progression and stem cell features of castration-resistant prostate cancer by destabilizing Twist.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) remains a major clinical challenge because of the lack of effective targeted therapy for its treatment.</Gene>
<Gene>The mechanism underlying how CRPC gains resistance toward hormone depletion and other forms of chemotherapy is poorly understood.</Gene>
<Gene>Research on understanding the factors that drive these processes is desperately needed to generate new therapies to cure the disease.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we discovered a fundamental role of S-phase protein kinase 2 (Skp2) in the formation and progression of CRPC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In transgenic adenocarcinoma mouse prostate model, Skp2 depletion leads to a profound repression of prostate tumor growth and distal metastasis and substantially prolonged overall survival.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We revealed that Skp2 regulates CRPC through Twist-mediated oncogenic functions including epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and cancer stem cell (CSC) acquisitions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mechanistically, Skp2 interacted with Twist and promoted the non-degradative ubiquitination of Twist.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consequently, Skp2 stabilized Twist protein expression by preventing proteasomal degradation of Twist by b-TrCP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found that Twist overexpression augments CSC self-renewal and population and that Skp2 inhibition reverts Twist's effects on CSC regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, genetically depleting or pharmacologically inactivating Skp2 synergistically re-sensitized CRPC cells toward chemotherapies such as paclitaxel or doxorubicin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Together, this study uncovering Skp2-mediated Twist stabilization and oncogenic functions in CRPC offers new knowledge on how CRPC progresses and acquires chemoresistance during tumor progression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It provides proof of principle that Skp2 targeting is a promising approach to combat metastatic CRPC by targeting Twist and CSCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Selective Targeting of SH2 Domain-Phosphotyrosine Interactions of Src Family Tyrosine Kinases with Monobodies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The binding of Src-homology 2 (SH2) domains to phosphotyrosine (pY) sites is critical for the autoinhibition and substrate recognition of the eight Src family kinases (SFKs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The high sequence conservation of the 120 human SH2 domains poses a significant challenge to selectively perturb the interactions of even the SFK SH2 family against the rest of the SH2 domains.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have developed synthetic binding proteins, termed monobodies, for six of the SFK SH2 domains with nanomolar affinity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Most of these monobodies competed with pY ligand binding and showed strong selectivity for either the SrcA (Yes, Src, Fyn, Fgr) or SrcB subgroup (Lck, Lyn, Blk, Hck).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interactome analysis of intracellularly expressed monobodies revealed that they bind SFKs but no other SH2-containing proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Three crystal structures of monobody-SH2 complexes unveiled different and only partly overlapping binding modes, which rationalized the observed selectivity and enabled structure-based mutagenesis to modulate inhibition mode and selectivity.</Gene>

<Gene>In line with the critical roles of SFK SH2 domains in kinase autoinhibition and T-cell receptor signaling, monobodies binding the Src and Hck SH2 domains selectively activated respective recombinant kinases, whereas an Lck SH2-binding monobody inhibited proximal signaling events downstream of the T-cell receptor complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results show that SFK SH2 domains can be targeted with unprecedented potency and selectivity using monobodies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>They are excellent tools for dissecting SFK functions in normal development and signaling and to interfere with aberrant SFK signaling networks in cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>FGFR2 is required for airway basal cell self-renewal and terminal differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Airway stem cells slowly self-renew and produce differentiated progeny to maintain homeostasis throughout the lifespan of an individual.</Gene>
<Gene>Mutations in the molecular regulators of these processes may drive cancer or degenerative disease, but are also potential therapeutic targets.</Gene>
<Gene>Conditionally deleting one copy of FGF receptor 2 (FGFR2) in adult mouse airway basal cells results in self-renewal and differentiation phenotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that FGFR2 signalling correlates with maintenance of expression of a key transcription factor for basal cell self-renewal and differentiation: SOX2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This heterozygous phenotype illustrates that subtle changes in receptor tyrosine kinase signalling can have significant effects, perhaps providing an explanation for the numerous changes seen in cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Dual role for Jumu in the control of hematopoietic progenitors in the Drosophila lymph gland.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The Drosophila lymph gland is a hematopoietic organ in which the maintenance of hematopoietic progenitor cell fate relies on intrinsic factors and extensive interaction with cells within a microenvironment.</Gene>
<Gene>The posterior signaling center (PSC) is required for maintaining the balance between progenitors and their differentiation into mature hemocytes.</Gene>
<Gene>Moreover, some factors from the progenitors cell-autonomously control blood cell differentiation.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we show that Jumeau (Jumu), a member of the forkhead (Fkh) transcription factor family, controls hemocyte differentiation of lymph gland through multiple regulatory mechanisms.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Jumu maintains the proper differentiation of prohemocytes by cell-autonomously regulating the expression of Col in medullary zone and by non-cell-autonomously preventing the generation of expanded PSC cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Jumu can also cell-autonomously control the proliferation of PSC cells through positive regulation of dMyc expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also show that a deficiency of jumu throughout the lymph gland can induce the differentiation of lamellocytes via activating Toll signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Evaluation of pancreatic cancer cell migration with multiple parameters in vitro by using an optical real-time cell mobility assay device.</Gene>
<Gene>BACKGROUND: Migration of cancer cell correlates with distant metastasis and local invasion, which are good targets for cancer treatment.</Gene>

<Gene>An optically accessible device "TAXIScan" was developed, which provides considerably more information regarding the cellular dynamics and less quantity of samples than do the existing methods.</Gene>

<Gene>Here, we report the establishment of a system to analyze the nature of pancreatic cancer cells using TAXIScan and we evaluated lysophosphatidic acid (LPA)-elicited pancreatic cell migration.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>Pancreatic cancer cell lines, BxPC3, PANC-1, AsPC1, and MIAPaCa-2, were analyzed for adhesion as well as migration towards LPA by TAXIScan using parameters such as velocity and directionality or for the number of migrated cells by the Boyden chamber methods.</Gene>

<Gene>To confirm that the migration was initiated by LPA, the expression of LPA receptors and activation of intracellular signal transductions were examined by quantitative reverse transcriptase polymerase reaction and western blotting.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Scaffold coating was necessary for the adhesion of pancreatic cancer cells, and collagen I and Matrigel were found to be good scaffolds.</Gene>

<Gene>BxPC3 and PANC-1 cells clearly migrated towards the concentration gradient formed by injecting 1 uL LPA, which was abrogated by pre-treatment with LPA inhibitor, Ki16425 (IC50 for the directionality ~ 1.86 uM).</Gene>
<Gene>The LPA dependent migration was further confirmed by mRNA and protein expression of LPA receptors as well as phosphorylation of signaling molecules.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>LPA1 mRNA was highest among the 6 receptors, and LPA1, LPA2 and LPA3 proteins were detected in BxPC3 and PANC-1 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Phosphorylation of Akt (Thr308 and Ser473) and p42/44MAPK in BxPC3 and PANC-1 cells was observed after LPA stimulation, which was clearly inhibited by pre-treatment with a compound Ki16425. CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We established a novel pancreatic cancer cell migration assay system using TAXIScan.</Gene>

<Gene>This assay device provides multiple information on migrating cells simultaneously, such as their morphology, directionality, and velocity, with a small volume of sample and can be a powerful tool for analyzing the nature of cancer cells and for identifying new factors that affect cell functions.</Gene>
<Gene>Hydrogen Peroxide Triggers a Dual Signaling Axis To Selectively Suppress Activated Human T Lymphocyte Migration.</Gene>
<Gene>H2O2 is an early danger cue required for innate immune cell recruitment to wounds.</Gene>
<Gene>To date, little is known about whether H2O2 is required for the migration of human adaptive immune cells to sites of inflammation.</Gene>
<Gene>However, oxidative stress is known to impair T cell activity, induce actin stiffness, and inhibit cell polarization.</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, we show that low oxidative concentrations of H2O2 also impede chemokinesis and chemotaxis of previously activated human T cells to CXCL11, but not CXCL10 or CXCL12.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that this deficiency in migration is due to a reduction in inflammatory chemokine receptor</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CXCR3 surface expression and cellular activation of lipid phosphatase SHIP-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
