text: <Gene>We demonstrate that H2O2 acts through an Src kinase to activate a negative regulator of PI3K signaling, SHIP-1 via phosphorylation, providing a molecular mechanism for H2O2-induced chemotaxis deficiency.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We hypothesize that although H2O2 serves as an early recruitment trigger for innate immune cells, it appears to operate as an inhibitor of T lymphocyte immune adaptive responses that are not required until later in the repair process.</Gene>
<Gene>HBEGF promotes gliomagenesis in the context of Ink4a/Arf and Pten loss.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Heparin-binding epidermal growth factor (EGF)-like growth factor (HBEGF) is a ligand for the EGF receptor (EGFR), one of the most commonly amplified receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) in glioblastoma (GBM).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While HBEGF has been found to be expressed in a subset of malignant gliomas, its sufficiency for glioma initiation has not been evaluated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we demonstrate that HBEGF can initiate GBM in mice in the context of Ink4a/Arf and Pten loss, and that these tumors are similar to the classical GBM subtype observed in patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Isogenic astrocytes from these mice showed activation not only of Egfr but also the RTK Axl in response to HBEGF stimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Deletion of either Egfr or Axl decreased the tumorigenic properties of HBEGF-transformed cells; however, only EGFR was able to rescue the phenotype in cells lacking both RTKs indicating that Egfr is required for activation of Axl in this context.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Silencing of HBEGF in vivo resulted in tumor regression and significantly increased survival, suggesting that HBEGF may be a clinically relevant target.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Myc enhances B-cell receptor signaling in precancerous B cells and confers resistance to Btk inhibition.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Dysregulation of the oncogenic transcription factor MYC induces B-cell transformation and is a driver for B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma (B-NHL).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MYC overexpression in B-NHL is associated with more aggressive phenotypes and poor prognosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although genomic studies suggest a link between MYC overexpression and B-cell receptor (BCR) signaling molecules in B-NHL, signaling pathways essential to Myc-mediated B-cell transformation have not been fully elucidated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We utilized intracellular phospho-flow cytometry to investigate the relationship between Myc and BCR signaling in pre-malignant B cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Utilizing the Eu-myc mouse model, where Myc is overexpressed specifically in B cells, both basal and stimulated BCR signaling were increased in precancerous B lymphocytes from Eu-myc mice compared with wild-type littermates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>B cells overexpressing Myc displayed constitutively higher levels of activated CD79a, Btk, Plcg2 and Erk1/2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Notably, Myc-overexpressing B cells maintained elevated BCR signaling despite treatment with ibrutinib, a Bruton's tyrosine kinase inhibitor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, PI3K/Akt pathway signaling was also increased in Eu-myc B cells, and this increase was partially suppressed with ibrutinib.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, experiments with Btk-null B cells revealed off-target effects of ibrutinib on BCR signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our data show that in pre-malignant B cells, Myc overexpression is sufficient to activate BCR and PI3K/Akt signaling pathways and further enhances signaling following BCR ligation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, our results indicate that precancerous B cells have already acquired enhanced survival and growth capabilities before transformation, and that elevated MYC levels confer resistance to pharmacologic inhibitors of BCR signaling, which has significant implications for B-NHL treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Klinefelter syndrome comorbidities linked to increased X chromosome gene dosage and altered protein interactome activity.</Gene>
<Gene>Klinefelter syndrome (KS) (47,XXY) is the most common male sex chromosome aneuploidy.</Gene>
<Gene>Diagnosis and clinical supervision remain a challenge due to varying phenotypic presentation and insufficient characterization of the syndrome.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we combine health data-driven epidemiology and molecular level systems biology to improve the understanding of KS and the molecular interplay influencing its comorbidities.</Gene>
<Gene>In total, 78 overrepresented KS comorbidities were identified using in- and out-patient registry data from the entire Danish population covering 6.8 million individuals.</Gene>

<Gene>The comorbidities extracted included both clinically well-known (e.g. infertility and osteoporosis) and still less established KS comorbidities (e.g. pituitary gland hypofunction and dental caries).</Gene>

<Gene>Several systems biology approaches were applied to identify key molecular players underlying KS comorbidities: Identification of co-expressed modules as well as central hubs and gene dosage perturbed protein complexes in a KS comorbidity network build from known disease proteins and their protein-protein interactions.</Gene>

<Gene>The systems biology approaches together pointed to novel aspects of KS disease phenotypes including perturbed Jak-STAT pathway, dysregulated genes important for disturbed immune system (IL4), energy balance (POMC and LEP) and erythropoietin signalling in KS.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We present an extended epidemiological study that links KS comorbidities to the molecular level and identify potential causal players in the disease biology underlying the identified comorbidities.</Gene>
<Gene>Searching for biomarkers of CDKL5 disorder: early-onset visual impairment in CDKL5 mutant mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CDKL5 disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder still without a cure.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Murine models of CDKL5 disorder have been recently generated raising the possibility of preclinical testing of treatments.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, unbiased, quantitative biomarkers of high translational value to monitor brain function are still missing.</Gene>
<Gene>Moreover, the analysis of treatment is hindered by the challenge of repeatedly and non-invasively testing neuronal function.</Gene>
<Gene>We analyzed the development of visual responses in a mouse model of CDKL5 disorder to introduce visually evoked responses as a quantitative method to assess cortical circuit function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cortical visual responses were assessed in CDKL5 null male mice, heterozygous females, and their respective control wild-type littermates by repeated transcranial optical imaging from P27 until P32.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>No difference between wild-type and mutant mice was present at P25-P26 whereas defective responses appeared from P27-P28 both in heterozygous and homozygous CDKL5 mutant mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results were confirmed by visually evoked potentials (VEPs) recorded from the visual cortex of a different cohort.</Gene>
<Gene>The previously imaged mice were also analyzed at P60-80 using VEPs, revealing a persistent reduction of response amplitude, reduced visual acuity and defective contrast function.</Gene>
<Gene>The level of adult impairment was significantly correlated with the reduction in visual responses observed during development.</Gene>
<Gene>Support vector machine showed that multi-dimensional visual assessment can be used to automatically classify mutant and wt mice with high reliability.</Gene>
<Gene>Thus, monitoring visual responses represents a promising biomarker for preclinical and clinical studies on CDKL5 disorder.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Downregulation of Talin1 promotes hepatocellular carcinoma progression through activation of the ERK1/2 pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Talin1 is an adaptor protein that conjugates integrins to the cytoskeleton and regulates integrins and focal adhesion signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Several studies have found that Talin1 is overexpressed in several tumor types and promotes tumor progression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, the explicit role of Talin1 in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) progression is still unclear and its functional mechanism remains largely unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we showed a trend of gradually decreasing expression of Talin1 from normal liver tissues to hepatocirrhosis, liver hyperplasia, the corresponding adjacent non-tumor, primary HCC, and eventually metastatic foci, indicating that Talin1 may correlate with HCC initiation to progression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Talin1 was significantly downregulated in HCC tissues compared with adjacent non-tumor tissues and low Talin1 expression was associated with HCC progression and poor prognosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, Talin1 knockdown induced epithelial-mesenchymal transition and promoted migration and invasion in SK-Hep-1 cells and HepG2 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mechanistically, we found that the ERK pathway was responsible for these promoting effects of Talin1 knockdown in HCC cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The promoting effects of Talin1 knockdown on epithelial-mesenchymal transition, migration, and invasion were reversed by U0126, a specific ERK1/2 inhibitor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, our results suggested that Talin1 might serve as a tumor suppressor in HCC and a potential prognostic biomarker for HCC patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Serum HOTAIR as a novel diagnostic biomarker for esophageal squamous cell carcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Early diagnosis of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) is an important issue to improve the prognosis.</Gene>
<Gene>HOX transcript antisense RNA (HOTAIR), a long noncoding RNA (lncRNA) expressed from the HOXC locus, has been recently revealed as an oncogenic regulator in ESCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study aimed to investigate whether serum HOTAIR is involved in the diagnosis of ESCC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, we detected serum HOTAIR expression in 50 patients with ESCC (including 42 tumor resection and 8 without surgery) and 20 healthy volunteers to investigate the role of serum HOTAIR in ESCC using the quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR) method.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Clinical data indicated that serum HOTAIR were correlated with TNM stage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression level of serum HOTAIR (0.189 + 0.010) was significantly higher in ESCC patients compared with that of healthy controls (0.055 + 0.008, P < 0.01).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The ROC curve analysis yielded an area under the ROC curve (AUC) value of 0.793 (95% CI: 0.692 to 0.895, P < 0.01).</Gene>
<Gene>Also, the serum HOTAIR expression level decreased obviously in postoperative samples (one month after the surgery) compared to preoperative specimens.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, there was a significant correlation between serum HOTAIR expression and the expression of HOTAIR in ESCC tissue according to Pearson correlation analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Our study, for the first time, demonstrated that serum HOTAIR might serve as a potential biomarker for the diagnosis of ESCC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A heptameric peptide purified from Spirulina sp. gastrointestinal hydrolysate inhibits angiotensin I-converting enzyme- and angiotensin II-induced vascular dysfunction in human endothelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, a marine microalga Spirulina sp.-derived protein was hydrolyzed using gastrointestinal enzymes to produce an angiotensin I (Ang I)-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitory peptide.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Following consecutive purification, the potent ACE inhibitory peptide was composed of 7 amino acids, Thr-Met-Glu-Pro-Gly-Lys-Pro (molecular weight, 759 Da).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis using the Lineweaver-Burk plot and molecular modeling suggested that the purified peptide acted as a mixed non-competitive inhibitor of ACE.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The inhibitory effects of the peptide against the cellular production of vascular dysfunction-related factors induced by Ang II were also investigated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In human endothelial cells, the Ang II-induced production of nitric oxide and reactive oxygen species was inhibited, and the expression of inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) was downregulated when the cells were cultured with the purified peptide.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, the peptide blocked the activation of p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results indicated that this Spirulina sp.-derived peptide warrants further investigation as a potential pharmacological inhibitor of ACE and vascular dysfunction.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Psoriasin promotes invasion, aggregation and survival of pancreatic cancer cells; association with disease progression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Psoriasin (S100A7) is an 11-kDa small calcium binding protein initially isolated from psoriatic skin lesions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It belongs to the S100 family of proteins which play an important role in a range of cell functions including proliferation, differentiation, migration and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Aberrant Psoriasin expression has been implicated in a range of cancers and is often associated with poor prognosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study examined the role of Psoriasin on pancreatic cancer cell functions and the implication in progression of the disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of Psoriasin was determined in a cohort of pancreatic tissues comprised of 126 pancreatic tumours and 114 adjacent non-tumour pancreatic tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Knockdown and overexpression of Psoriasin in pancreatic cancer cells was performed using specifically constructed plasmids, which either had anti-Psoriasin ribozyme transgene or the full length human Psoriasin coding sequence.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Psoriasin knockdown and overexpression was verified using conventional RT-PCR and qPCR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The effect of manipulating Psoriasin expression on pancreatic cancer cell functions was assessed using several in vitro cell function assays.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Local invasive pancreatic cancers extended beyond the pancreas expressed higher levels of Psoriasin transcripts compared with the cancers confined to the pancreas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Primary tumours with distant metastases exhibited a reduced expression of Psoriasin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Psoriasin overexpression cell lines exhibited significantly increased growth and migration compared to control cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, Psoriasin overexpression resulted in increased pancreatic cancer cell invasion which was associated with upregulation of matrix metalloproteinase-2 (MMP-2) and MMP-9.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of Psoriasin also promoted aggregation and survival of pancreatic cancer cells when they lost anchorage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, higher expression of Psoriasin was associated with local invasion in pancreatic cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Psoriasin expression is associated with pancreatic cancer cell growth, migration, cell-matrix adhesion, and invasion via regulation of MMPs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As such, the proposed implications of Psoriasin in invasion, disease progression and as a potential therapeutic target warrant further investigation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of Srcin1 contributes to the growth and metastasis of colorectal cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The adaptor protein Srcin1 is a novel Src-binding protein that regulates Src activation through C-terminal Src kinase (Csk).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Srcin1 behaves as a tumour suppressor in breast cancer, but the role of Srcin1 in the development of colorectal cancer (CRC) remains unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the present study, Srcin1 expression in normal tissue was examined by tissue microarray and assessed by immunohistochemistry in 10 patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the biological impact of Srcin1 knockdown on CRC cells was investigated in vitro and in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The results showed that Srcin1 was expressed in different types of normal human tissues, whereas its expression was increased in human CRC tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Srcin1 expression also correlated with tumour progression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The suppression of Srcin1 induced cell differentiation and G0/G1 cell cycle arrest.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, Srcin1 increased cell growth as well as the capacity of migration and invasion in CRC cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Srcin1 induced the activation of the Wnt/b-catenin signalling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, Srcin1 suppression sensitized cancer cells to 5-fluorouracil (5-FU)-induced apoptosis in vitro and in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Together, these results demonstrate that Srcin1 contributes to CRC carcinogenesis, invasion and metastasis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings provide a rationale for a mechanistic approach to CRC treatment based on the development of Srcin1-targeted therapies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The downstream of tyrosine kinase 7 is reduced in lung cancer and is associated with poor survival of patients with lung cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The downstream of tyrosine kinase 7 (DOK7) is an adaptor protein mediating signalling transduction between receptors and intracellular downstream molecules.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Reduced expression of DOK7 has been observed in breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The present study aimed to investigate the role played by DOK7 in lung cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of DOK7 at both mRNA and protein levels was evaluated in human lung cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A reduced expression of DOK7 transcripts was seen in lung cancers compared with normal lung tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Kaplan-Meier analyses showed that the reduced expression of DOK7 was associated with poorer overall survival and progression-free survival of patients with lung cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A further western blot analysis revealed a predominant expression of DOK7 isoform 1 (DOK7V1) in normal lung tissues, which was reduced in lung cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Forced overexpression of DOK7V1 in lung cancer cell lines, A549 and H3122 resulted in a decrease of in vitro cell proliferation and migration, while adhesion to extracellular matrix was enhanced following the expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, DOK7 was reduced in lung cancer and reduced DOK7 expression was associated with poorer survival.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DOK7 isoform 1 plays an inhibitory role on the proliferation and migration of lung cancer cells in which Akt pathway may be involved.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Novel nesprin-1 mutations associated with dilated cardiomyopathy cause nuclear envelope disruption and defects in myogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Nesprins-1 and -2 are highly expressed in skeletal and cardiac muscle and together with SUN (Sad1p/UNC84)-domain containing proteins and lamin A/C form the LInker of Nucleoskeleton-and-Cytoskeleton (LINC) bridging complex at the nuclear envelope (NE).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in nesprin-1/2 have previously been found in patients with autosomal dominant Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy (EDMD) as well as dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, three novel rare variants (R8272Q, S8381C and N8406K) in the C-terminus of the SYNE1 gene (nesprin-1) were identified in seven DCM patients by mutation screening.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of these mutants caused nuclear morphology defects and reduced lamin A/C and SUN2 staining at the NE.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>GST pull-down indicated that nesprin-1/lamin/SUN interactions were disrupted.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nesprin-1 mutations were also associated with augmented activation of the ERK pathway in vitro and in hearts in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>During C2C12 muscle cell differentiation, nesprin-1 levels are increased concomitantly with kinesin light chain (KLC-1/2) and immunoprecipitation and GST pull-down showed that these proteins interacted via a recently identified LEWD domain in the C-terminus of nesprin-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of nesprin-1 mutants in C2C12 cells caused defects in myoblast differentiation and fusion associated with dysregulation of myogenic transcription factors and disruption of the nesprin-1 and KLC-1/2 interaction at the outer nuclear membrane.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of nesprin-1a2 WT and mutants in zebrafish embryos caused heart developmental defects that varied in severity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings support a role for nesprin-1 in myogenesis and muscle disease, and uncover a novel mechanism whereby disruption of the LINC complex may contribute to the pathogenesis of DCM.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MUC1 in lung adenocarcinoma: cross-sectional genetic and serological study.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Mucin 1 (MUC1) contributes to the growth and metastasis of various cancers, including lung cancer, and MUC1 gene length polymorphisms are associated with susceptibility to lung cancer and its prognosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, the association between rs4072037, a single nucleotide polymorphism in MUC1, and lung cancer has not been well studied.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>In the present study, we determined the rs4072037 genotype and measured serum KL-6 levels to evaluate the association between lung adenocarcinoma (ADC) and rs4072037 or serum KL-6 levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DNA samples were available for 172 patients and these were included in the genomic analyses.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, 304 patients were included in the serum analyses.</Gene>
<Gene>Furthermore, 276 healthy volunteers were included in both genomic and serum analyses.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>The rs4072037 genotype was not associated with susceptibility to lung ADC or its prognosis.</Gene>

<Gene>Interestingly, serum KL-6 levels significantly differed according to rs4072037 genotype in those with T1 or T2 (P < 0.001), N0 or N1 (P = 0.002) and M0 (P < 0.001), but not in those with T3 or T4 (P = 0.882), N2 or N3 (P = 0.616) and M1a or M1b (P = 0.501).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Serum KL-6 levels were significantly associated with the presence of lung ADC, as well as with its progression and prognosis, indicating the crucial involvement of KL-6/MUC1 in the development of lung cancer and its progression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>

<Gene>Based on these findings, we conclude that rs4072037 does not have a significant impact on the pathogenesis or prognosis of lung ADC, whereas serum KL-6 levels, which might reflecting the molecular length of MUC1, are significantly associated with lung ADC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Global analysis of H3K27me3 as an epigenetic marker in prostate cancer progression.</Gene>
<Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>H3K27me3 histone marks shape the inhibition of gene transcription.</Gene>
<Gene>In prostate cancer, the deregulation of H3K27me3 marks might play a role in prostate tumor progression.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>We investigated genome-wide H3K27me3 histone methylation profile using chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) and 2X400K promoter microarrays to identify differentially-enriched regions in biopsy samples from prostate cancer patients.</Gene>
<Gene>H3K27me3 marks were assessed in 34 prostate tumors: 11 with Gleason score > 7 (GS > 7), 10 with Gleason score < 7 (GS < 7), and 13 morphologically normal prostate samples.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Here, H3K27me3 profiling identified an average of 386 enriched-genes on promoter regions in healthy control group versus 545 genes in GS < 7 and 748 genes in GS > 7 group.</Gene>

<Gene>We then ran a factorial discriminant analysis (FDA) and compared the enriched genes in prostate-tumor biopsies and normal biopsies using ANOVA to identify significantly differentially-enriched genes.</Gene>
<Gene>The analysis identified ALG5, EXOSC8, CBX1, GRID2, GRIN3B, ING3, MYO1D, NPHP3-AS1, MSH6, FBXO11, SND1, SPATS2, TENM4 and TRA2A genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These genes are possibly associated with prostate cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>Notably, the H3K27me3 histone mark emerged as a novel regulatory mechanism in poor-prognosis prostate cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Our findings point to epigenetic mark H3K27me3 as an important event in prostate carcinogenesis and progression.</Gene>
<Gene>The results reported here provide new molecular insights into the pathogenesis of prostate cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>Depletion of polycomb repressive complex 2 core component EED impairs fetal hematopoiesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2), a H3K27me3 methyltransferase complex, promotes the development of many organs by silencing ectopic transcription program.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, currently little is known about the role of PRC2 in blood and vascular development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we interrogated the function of embryonic ectoderm development (EED), a core PRC2 component, in both endothelial and hematopoietic tissues by inactivating a floxed murine EED allele with Tie2Cre, which catalyzes recombination in endothelial and hematopoietic lineages.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Murine EED(fl/fl);Tie2Cre (EED(CKO)) embryos died at embryonic day (E) 13.5.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We did not observe structural abnormalities of blood vessels or cardiac valves, suggesting that EED is dispensable in endothelial cells for initial steps of vascular development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>EED(CKO) embryos were pale and had abnormal livers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Flow cytometry of fetal liver cells showed that EED depletion significantly impeded erythroid maturation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>There was a corresponding increase in myeloid progenitors and granulocytes and macrophages, suggesting an attenuated differentiation path in myeloid lineages.</Gene>
<Gene>Moreover, EED depletion impaired the generation of hematopoietic stem cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, our study demonstrates that within Tie2Cre-recombined embryonic cells, EED is required for proper erythropoiesis and for formation of hematopoietic progenitor and stem cells, but is dispensable for endothelial lineage commitment and early vascular patterning.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Genetic Variation at the Sulfonylurea Receptor, Type 2 Diabetes, and Coronary Heart Disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Despite widespread clinical use in the treatment of type 2 diabetes, the impact of sulfonylurea therapy on cardiovascular outcomes remains uncertain.</Gene>
<Gene>Studies of naturally occurring genetic variation can be used to anticipate the expected clinical consequences of a pharmacological therapy.</Gene>

<Gene>A common missense variant in the gene encoding a component of the sulfonylurea receptor (ABCC8 p.A1369S) promotes closure of the target channel of sulfonylurea therapy and is associated with increased insulin secretion, thus mimicking the effects of sulfonylurea therapy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using individual-level data from 120,286 participants in the UK Biobank and summary association results from four large-scale genome-wide association studies, we examined the impact of this variant on cardiometabolic traits, type 2 diabetes, and coronary heart disease.</Gene>
<Gene>The p.A1369S variant was associated with a significantly lower risk of type 2 diabetes (odds ratio [OR] 0.93; 95% CI 0.91, 0.95; P = 1.2 x 10(-11)).</Gene>

<Gene>The variant was associated with increased BMI (+0.062 kg/m(2); 95% CI 0.037, 0.086; P = 8.1 x 10(-7)) but lower waist-to-hip ratio adjusted for BMI, a marker of abdominal fat distribution.</Gene>
<Gene>Furthermore, p.A1369S was associated with a reduced risk of coronary heart disease (OR 0.98; 95% CI 0.96, 0.99; P = 5.9 x 10(-4)).</Gene>
<Gene>These results suggest that, despite a known association with increased weight, long-term sulfonylurea therapy may reduce the risk of coronary heart disease.</Gene>
<Gene>Transforming activity and therapeutic targeting of C-terminal-binding protein 2 in Apc-mutated neoplasia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of the transcriptional coregulators C-terminal binding proteins 1 and 2 (CtBP1 and 2) occurs in many human solid tumors and is associated with poor prognosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CtBP modulates oncogenic gene expression programs and is an emerging drug target, but its oncogenic role is unclear.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Consistent with this oncogenic potential, exogenous CtBP2 transformed primary mouse and human cells to anchorage independence similarly to mutant H-Ras.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To investigate CtBP's contribution to in vivo tumorigenesis, Apc(min/+) mice, which succumb to massive intestinal polyposis, were bred to Ctbp2(+/-) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CtBP interacts with adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) protein, and is stabilized in both APC-mutated human colon cancers and Apc(min/+) intestinal polyps.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ctbp2 heterozygosity increased the median survival of Apc(min/+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>mice from 21 to 48 weeks, and reduced polyp formation by 90%, with Ctbp2(+/-) polyps exhibiting reduced levels of b-catenin and its oncogenic transcriptional target, cyclin D1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CtBP's potential as a therapeutic target was studied by treating Apc(min/+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>mice with the CtBP small-molecule inhibitors 4-methylthio-2-oxobutyric acid and 2-hydroxy-imino phenylpyruvic acid, both of which reduced polyposis by more than half compared with vehicle treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Phenocopying Ctbp2 deletion, both Ctbp inhibitors caused substantial decreases in the protein level of Ctbp2, as well its oncogenic partner b-catenin, and the effects of the inhibitors on CtBP and b-catenin levels could be modeled in an APC-mutated human colon cancer cell line.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CtBP2 is thus a druggable transforming oncoprotein critical for the evolution of neoplasia driven by Apc mutation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A TSPO ligand attenuates brain injury after intracerebral hemorrhage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) is a devastating disease without effective treatment.</Gene>
<Gene>After ICH, the immediate infiltration of leukocytes and activation of microglia are accompanied by a rapid up-regulation of the 18-kDa translocator protein (TSPO).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TSPO ligands have shown anti-inflammatory and neuroprotective properties in models of CNS injury.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we determined the impact of a TSPO ligand, etifoxine, on brain injury and inflammation in 2 mouse models of ICH.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>TSPO was up-regulated in Iba1(+) cells from brains of patients with ICH and in CD11b(+)CD45(int) cells from mice subjected to collagenase-induced ICH.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Etifoxine significantly reduced neurodeficits and perihematomal brain edema after ICH induction by injection of either autologous blood or collagenase.</Gene>

<Gene>In collagenase-induced ICH mice, the protection of etifoxine was associated with reduced leukocyte infiltration into the brain and microglial production of IL-6 and TNF-a. Etifoxine improved blood-brain barrier integrity and diminished cell death.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Notably, the protective effect of etifoxine was abolished in mice depleted of microglia by using a colony-stimulating factor 1 receptor inhibitor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results indicate that the TSPO ligand etifoxine attenuates brain injury and inflammation after ICH.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>TSPO may be a viable therapeutic target that requires further investigations in ICH.-Li, M., Ren, H., Sheth, K. N., Shi, F.-D., Liu, Q. A TSPO ligand attenuates brain injury after intracerebral hemorrhage.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Regulation of lung endothelial permeability and inflammatory responses by prostaglandin A2: role of EP4 receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The role of prostaglandin A2 (PGA2) in modulation of vascular endothelial function is unknown.</Gene>
<Gene>We investigated effects of PGA2 on pulmonary endothelial cell (EC) permeability and inflammatory activation and identified a receptor mediating these effects.</Gene>
<Gene>PGA2 enhanced the EC barrier and protected against barrier dysfunction caused by vasoactive peptide thrombin and proinflammatory bacterial wall lipopolysaccharide (LPS).</Gene>
<Gene>Receptor screening using pharmacological and molecular inhibitory approaches identified EP4 as a novel PGA2 receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>EP4 mediated barrier-protective effects of PGA2 by activating Rap1/Rac1 GTPase and protein kinase</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A targets at cell adhesions and cytoskeleton: VE-cadherin, p120-catenin, ZO-1, cortactin, and VASP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PGA2 also suppressed LPS-induced inflammatory signaling by inhibiting the NFkB pathway and expression of EC adhesion molecules ICAM1 and VCAM1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These effects were abolished by pharmacological or molecular inhibition of EP4.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In vivo, PGA2 was protective in two distinct models of acute lung injury (ALI): LPS-induced inflammatory injury and two-hit ALI caused by suboptimal mechanical ventilation and injection of thrombin receptor-activating peptide.</Gene>
<Gene>These protective effects were abolished in mice with endothelial-specific EP4 knockout.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The results suggest a novel role for the PGA2-EP4 axis in vascular EC protection that is critical for improvement of pathological states associated with increased vascular leakage and inflammation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RABL2 interacts with the intraflagellar transport-B complex and CEP19 and participates in ciliary assembly.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Proteins localized to the basal body and the centrosome play crucial roles in ciliary assembly and function.</Gene>
<Gene>Although RABL2 and CEP19 are conserved in ciliated organisms and have been implicated in ciliary/flagellar functions, their roles are poorly understood.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that RABL2 interacts with CEP19 and is recruited to the mother centriole and basal body in a CEP19-dependent manner and that CEP19 is recruited to the centriole probably via its binding to the centrosomal protein FGFR1OP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Disruption of the RABL2 gene in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii results in the nonflagellated phenotype, suggesting a crucial role of RABL2 in ciliary/flagellar assembly.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also show that RABL2 interacts, in its GTP-bound state, with the intraflagellar transport (IFT)-B complex via the IFT74-IFT81 heterodimer and that the interaction is disrupted by a mutation found in male infertile mice (Mot mice) with a sperm flagella motility defect.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intriguingly, RABL2 binds to CEP19 and the IFT74-IFT81 heterodimer in a mutually exclusive manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, exogenous expression of the GDP-locked or Mot-type RABL2 mutant in human cells results in mild defects in ciliary assembly.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results indicate that RABL2 localized to the basal body plays crucial roles in ciliary/flagellar assembly via its interaction with the IFT-B complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MRE11 stability is regulated by CK2-dependent interaction with R2TP complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The MRN (MRE11-RAD50-NBS1) complex is essential for repair of DNA double-strand breaks and stalled replication forks.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations of the MRN complex subunit MRE11 cause the hereditary cancer-susceptibility disease ataxia-telangiectasia-like disorder (ATLD).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that MRE11 directly interacts with PIH1D1, a subunit of heat-shock protein 90 cochaperone R2TP complex, which is required for the assembly of large protein complexes, such as RNA polymerase II, small nucleolar ribonucleoproteins and mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The MRE11-PIH1D1 interaction is dependent on casein kinase 2 (CK2) phosphorylation of two acidic sequences within the MRE11 C terminus containing serines 558/561 and 688/689.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, the PIH1D1 phospho-binding domain PIH-N is required for association with MRE11 phosphorylated by CK2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consistent with these findings, depletion of PIH1D1 resulted in MRE11 destabilization and affected DNA-damage repair processes dependent on MRE11.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, mutations of serines 688/689, which abolish PIH1D1 binding, also resulted in decreased MRE11 stability.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As depletion of R2TP frequently leads to instability of its substrates and as truncation mutation of MRE11 lacking serines 688/689 leads to decreased levels of the MRN complex both in ATLD patients and an ATLD mouse model, our results suggest that the MRN complex is a novel R2TP complex substrate and that their interaction is regulated by CK2 phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Aberrant caveolin-1-mediated Smad signaling and proliferation identified by analysis of adenine 474 deletion mutation (c.474delA) in patient fibroblasts: a new perspective on the mechanism of pulmonary hypertension.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A heterozygous caveolin-1 c.474delA mutation has been identified in a family with heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This frameshift mutation leads to a caveolin-1 protein that contains all known functional domains but has a change in only the final 20 amino acids of the C-terminus.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we studied how this mutation alters caveolin-1 function, using patient-derived fibroblasts.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Transmission electron microscopy showed that fibroblasts carrying the c.474delA mutation form typical caveolae.</Gene>
<Gene>Expression of mutated caveolin-1 in caveolin-1-null mouse fibroblasts failed to induce formation of caveolae due to retention of the mutated protein in the endoplasmic reticulum.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, coexpression of wild-type caveolin-1 with mutated caveolin-1 restored the ability to form caveolae.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, fibroblasts carrying the mutation showed twofold increase in proliferation rate associated with hyperphosphorylation of Smad1/5/8.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This mutation impaired the antiproliferative function of caveolin-1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of type I TGFb receptors ALK1/2/3/6 responsible for phosphorylation of Smad1/5/8 reduced the hyperproliferation seen in c.474delA fibroblasts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results demonstrate the critical role of the final 20 amino acids of caveolin-1 in modulating fibroblast proliferation by dampening Smad signaling and suggest that augmented Smad signaling and fibroblast hyperproliferation are contributing factors in the pathogenesis of PAH in patients with caveolin-1 c.474delA mutation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Oncogenic activity of amplified miniature chromosome maintenance 8 in human malignancies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Miniature chromosome maintenance (MCM) proteins play critical roles in DNA replication licensing, initiation and elongation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MCM8, one of the MCM proteins playing a critical role in DNA repairing and recombination, was found to have overexpression and increased DNA copy number in a variety of human malignancies.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The gain of MCM8 is associated with aggressive clinical features of several human cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Increased expression of MCM8 in prostate cancer is associated with cancer recurrence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Forced expression of MCM8 in RWPE1 cells, the immortalized but non-transformed prostate epithelial cell line, exhibited fast cell growth and transformation, while knock down of MCM8 in PC3, DU145 and LNCaP cells induced cell growth arrest, and decreased tumour volumes and mortality of severe combined immunodeficiency mice xenografted with PC3 and DU145 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MCM8 bound cyclin D1 and activated Rb protein phosphorylation by cyclin-dependent kinase 4 in vitro and in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cyclin D1/MCM8 interaction is required for Rb phosphorylation and S-phase entry in cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As a result, our study showed that copy number increase and overexpression of MCM8 may play critical roles in human cancer development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CYP4A in tumor-associated macrophages promotes pre-metastatic niche formation and metastasis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Tumor-associated macrophages (TAMs) play an essential role in metastasis.</Gene>
<Gene>However, what enables TAMs to have a superior capacity to establish pre-metastatic microenvironment in distant organs is unclear.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we have begun to uncover the effects of cytochrome P450 (CYP) 4A in TAMs on lung pre-metastatic niche formation and metastasis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CYP4A(+) TAM infiltration was positively associated with metastasis, pre-metastatic niche formation and poor prognosis in breast cancer patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The pharmacological inhibition of CYP4A reduced lung pre-metastatic niche formation (evidenced by a decrease in vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 1 positive (VEGFR1(+)) myeloid cell recruitment and pro-metastatic protein expression) and metastatic burden, accompanied with TAM polarization away from the M2 phenotype in spontaneous metastasis models of 4T1 breast cancer and B16F10 melanoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Co-implantation of 4T1 cells with CYP4A10(high) macrophages promoted lung pre-metastatic niche formation and metastasis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Depletion of TAMs disrupted lung pre-metastatic niches and thereby prevented metastasis.</Gene>

<Gene>Treatment with the CM from CYP4A10(high) M2 macrophages (M2) increased pre-metastatic niche formation and metastatic burden in the lungs, whereas CYP4A inhibition attenuated these effects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro TAM polarization away from the M2 phenotype induced by CYP4A inhibition decreased VEGFR1(+) myeloid cell migration and fibronectin expression, accompanied with downregulation of STAT3 signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, overexpression of CYP4A or exogenous addition of 20-hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid promoted M2 polarization and cytokine production of macrophages and thereby enhanced migration of VEGFR1(+) myeloid cells, which were reversed by siRNA or pharmacological inhibition of STAT3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, a combined blocking M2 macrophage-derived factors TGF-b, VEGF and SDF-1 abolished VEGFR1(+) myeloid cell migration and fibroblast activation induced by CYP4A. In summary, CYP4A in TAMs is crucial for lung pre-metastatic niche formation and metastasis, and may serve as a potential therapeutic target in human cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Deletion of RhoA in Progesterone Receptor-Expressing Cells Leads to Luteal Insufficiency and Infertility in Female Mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ras homolog gene family, member A (RhoA) is widely expressed throughout the female reproductive system.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To assess its role in progesterone receptor-expressing cells, we generated RhoA conditional knockout mice RhoAd/d (RhoAf/f-Pgr-Cre+/-).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RhoAd/d female mice had comparable mating activity, serum luteinizing hormone, prolactin, and estradiol levels and ovulation with control but were infertile with progesterone insufficiency, indicating impaired steroidogenesis in RhoAd/d corpus luteum (CL).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RhoA was highly expressed in wild-type luteal cells and conditionally deleted in RhoAd/d CL.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Gestation day 3.5 (D3.5) RhoAd/d ovaries had reduced numbers of CL, less defined corpus luteal cord formation, and disorganized CL collagen IV staining.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RhoAd/d CL had lipid droplet and free cholesterol accumulation, indicating the availability of cholesterol for steroidogenesis, but disorganized b-actin and vimentin staining, indicating disrupted cytoskeleton integrity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cytoskeleton is important for cytoplasmic cholesterol movement to mitochondria and for regulating mitochondria.</Gene>
<Gene>Dramatically reduced expression of mitochondrial markers heat shock protein 60 (HSP60), voltage-dependent anion channel, and StAR was detected in RhoAd/d CL</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>. StAR carries out the rate-limiting step of steroidogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>StAR messenger RNA expression was reduced in RU486-treated D3.5 wild-type CL and tended to be induced in progesterone-treated D3.5 RhoAd/d CL, with parallel changes of HSP60 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data demonstrated the in vivo function of RhoA in CL luteal cell cytoskeleton integrity, cholesterol transport, StAR expression, and progesterone synthesis, and a positive feedback on StAR expression in CL by progesterone signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings provide insights into mechanisms of progesterone insufficiency.</Gene>
<Gene>Targeting group I p21-activated kinases to control malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor growth and metastasis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs) are devastating sarcomas for which no effective medical therapies are available.</Gene>

<Gene>Over 50% of MPSNTs are associated with mutations in NF1 tumor suppressor gene, resulting in activation of Ras and its effectors, including the Raf/Mek/Erk and PI3K/Akt/mTORC1 signaling cascades, and also the WNT/b-catenin pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As Group I p21-activated kinases (Group I Paks, PAK1/2/3) have been shown to modulate Ras-driven oncogenesis, we asked if these enzymes might regulate signaling in MPNSTs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study we found a strong positive correlation between the activity of PAK1/2/3 and the stage of human MPNSTs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We determined that reducing Group I Pak activity diminished MPNST cell proliferation and motility, and that these effects were not accompanied by significant blockade of the Raf/Mek/Erk pathway, but rather by reductions in Akt and b-catenin activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using the small molecule PAK1/2/3 inhibitor Frax1036 and the MEK1/2 inhibitor PD0325901, we showed that the combination of these two agents synergistically inhibited MPNST cell growth in vitro and dramatically decreased local and metastatic MPNST growth in animal models.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, these data provide new insights into MPNST signaling deregulation and suggest that co-targeting of PAK1/2/3 and MEK1/2 may be effective in the treatment of patients with MPNSTs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Defective Hand1 phosphoregulation uncovers essential roles for Hand1 in limb morphogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The morphogenesis of the vertebrate limbs is a complex process in which cell signaling and transcriptional regulation coordinate diverse structural adaptations in diverse species.</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, we examine the consequences of altering Hand1 dimer choice regulation within developing vertebrate limbs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although Hand1 deletion via the limb-specific Prrx1-Cre reveals a non-essential role for Hand1 in mouse limb morphogenesis, altering Hand1 phosphoregulation, and consequently Hand1 dimerization affinities, results in a severe truncation of proximal-anterior limb elements.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular analysis reveals a non-cell-autonomous mechanism that causes widespread cell death within the embryonic limb bud.</Gene>

<Gene>In addition, we observe changes in proximal-anterior gene regulation, including a reduction in the expression of Irx3, Irx5, Gli3 and Alx4, all of which are upregulated in Hand2 limb conditional knockouts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A reduction of Hand2 and Shh gene dosage improves the integrity of anterior limb structures, validating the importance of the Twist-family bHLH dimer pool in limb morphogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Autophagy suppresses Ras-driven epithelial tumourigenesis by limiting the accumulation of reactive oxygen species.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of Ras signalling occurs in ~30% of human cancers; however, activated Ras alone is not sufficient for tumourigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In a screen for tumour suppressors that cooperate with oncogenic Ras (Ras(V12)) in Drosophila, we identified genes involved in the autophagy pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bioinformatic analysis of human tumours revealed that several core autophagy genes, including GABARAP, correlate with oncogenic KRAS mutations and poor prognosis in human pancreatic cancer, supporting a potential tumour-suppressive effect of the pathway in Ras-driven human cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In Drosophila, we demonstrate that blocking autophagy at any step of the pathway enhances Ras(V12)-driven epithelial tissue overgrowth via the accumulation of reactive oxygen species and activation of the Jun kinase stress response pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Blocking autophagy in Ras(V12) clones also results in non-cell-autonomous effects with autophagy, cell proliferation and caspase activation induced in adjacent wild-type cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our study has implications for understanding the interplay between perturbations in Ras signalling and autophagy in tumourigenesis, which might inform the development of novel therapeutics targeting Ras-driven cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Oncogene advance online publication, 5 June 2017; doi:10.1038/onc.2017.175.</Gene>
<Gene>Mutations in N-acetylglucosamine (O-GlcNAc) transferase in patients with X-linked intellectual disability.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>N-Acetylglucosamine (O-GlcNAc) transferase (OGT) regulates protein O-GlcNAcylation, an essential and dynamic post-translational modification.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The O-GlcNAc modification is present on numerous nuclear and cytosolic proteins and has been implicated in essential cellular functions such as signaling and gene expression.</Gene>
<Gene>Accordingly, altered levels of protein O-GlcNAcylation have been associated with developmental defects and neurodegeneration.</Gene>
<Gene>However, mutations in the OGT gene have not yet been functionally confirmed in humans.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we report on two hemizygous mutations in OGT in individuals with X-linked intellectual disability (XLID) and dysmorphic features: one missense mutation (p.Arg284Pro) and one mutation leading to a splicing defect (c.463-6T>G).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Both mutations reside in the tetratricopeptide repeats of OGT that are essential for substrate recognition.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We observed slightly reduced levels of OGT protein and reduced levels of its opposing enzyme O-GlcNAcase in both patient-derived fibroblasts, but global O-GlcNAc levels appeared to be unaffected.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data suggest that mutant cells attempt to maintain global O-GlcNAcylation by down-regulating O-GlcNAcase expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We also found that the c.463-6T>G mutation leads to aberrant mRNA splicing, but no stable truncated protein was detected in the corresponding patient-derived fibroblasts.</Gene>

<Gene>Recombinant OGT bearing the p.Arg284Pro mutation was prone to unfolding and exhibited reduced glycosylation activity against a complex array of glycosylation substrates and proteolytic processing of the transcription factor host cell factor 1, which is also encoded by an XLID-associated gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that defects in O-GlcNAc homeostasis and host cell factor 1 proteolysis may play roles in mediation of XLID in individuals with OGT mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Dynamic subunit turnover in ESCRT-III assemblies is regulated by Vps4 to mediate membrane remodelling during cytokinesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The endosomal sorting complex required for transport (ESCRT)-III mediates membrane fission in fundamental cellular processes, including cytokinesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ESCRT-III is thought to form persistent filaments that over time increase their curvature to constrict membranes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Unexpectedly, we found that ESCRT-III at the midbody of human cells rapidly turns over subunits with cytoplasmic pools while gradually forming larger assemblies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ESCRT-III turnover depended on the ATPase VPS4, which accumulated at the midbody simultaneously with ESCRT-III subunits, and was required for assembly of functional ESCRT-III structures.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro, the Vps2/Vps24 subunits of ESCRT-III formed side-by-side filaments with Snf7 and inhibited further polymerization, but the growth inhibition was alleviated by the addition of Vps4 and ATP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>High-speed atomic force microscopy further revealed highly dynamic arrays of growing and shrinking ESCRT-III spirals in the presence of Vps4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Continuous ESCRT-III remodelling by subunit turnover might facilitate shape adaptions to variable membrane geometries, with broad implications for diverse cellular processes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MicroRNA-20a-mediated loss of autophagy contributes to breast tumorigenesis by promoting genomic damage and instability.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Gene expression analysis of The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) breast cancer data set show that miR-20a is upregulated in human breast cancer, especially in triple-negative subtype.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Gene Set Enrichment Analysis suggests that miR-20a expression negatively correlates with the autophagy/lysosome pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report here that miR-20a inhibits the basal and nutrient starvation-induced autophagic flux and lysosomal proteolytic activity, increases intracellular reactive oxygen species levels and DNA damage response by targeting several key regulators of autophagy, including BECN1, ATG16L1 and SQSTM1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Re-introduction of exogenous BECN1, ATG16L1 or SQSTM1 reverses the inhibitory effect of miR-20a on autophagy and decreases DNA damage.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A negative correlation between miR-20a and its target genes is observed in breast cancer tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Lower levels of BECN1, ATG16L1 and SQSTM1 are more common in triple-negative cancers than in other subtypes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>High levels of miR-20a also associate with higher frequency of copy-number alterations and DNA mutations in breast cancer patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Further studies in a xenograft mouse model show that miR-20a promotes tumor initiation and tumor growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, these findings suggest that miR-20a-mediated autophagy defect might be a new mechanism underlying the oncogenic function of miRNA during breast tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Oncogene advance online publication, 19 June 2017; doi:10.1038/onc.2017.193.</Gene>
<Gene>Genome-wide loss-of-function genetic screening identifies opioid receptor u1 as a key regulator of L-asparaginase resistance in pediatric acute lymphoblastic leukemia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>L-asparaginase is a critical chemotherapeutic agent for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL).</Gene>
<Gene>It hydrolyzes plasma asparagine into aspartate and NH3, causing asparagine deficit and inhibition of protein synthesis and eventually, leukemic cell death.</Gene>
<Gene>However, patient relapse often occurs due to development of resistance.</Gene>
<Gene>The molecular mechanism by which ALL cells acquire resistance to L-asparaginase is unknown.</Gene>
<Gene>Therefore, we sought to identify genes that are involved in L-asparaginase resistance in primary leukemic cells.</Gene>

<Gene>By unbiased genome-wide RNAi screening, we found that among 10 resistant ALL clones, six hits were for opioid receptor mu 1 (oprm1), two hits were for carbonic anhydrase 1 (ca1) and another two hits were for ubiquitin-conjugating enzyme E2C (ube2c).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also found that OPRM1 is expressed in all leukemic cells tested.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Specific knockdown of OPRM1 confers L-asparaginase resistance, validating our genome-wide retroviral shRNA library screening data.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Methadone, an agonist of OPRM1, enhances the sensitivity of parental leukemic cells, but not OPRM1-depleted cells, to L-asparaginase treatment, indicating that OPRM1 is required for the synergistic action of L-asparaginase and methadone, and that OPRM1 loss promotes leukemic cell survival likely through downregulation of the OPRM1-mediated apoptotic pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consistent with this premise, patient leukemic cells with relatively high levels of OPRM1 are more sensitive to L-asparaginase treatment compared to OPRM1-depleted leukemic cells, further indicating that OPRM1 loss has a crucial role in L-asparaginase resistance in leukemic patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, our study demonstrates for the first time, a novel OPRM1-mediated mechanism for L-asparaginase resistance in ALL, and identifies OPRM1 as a functional biomarker for defining high-risk subpopulations and for the detection of evolving resistant clones.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Oprm1 may also be utilized for effective treatment of L-asparaginase-resistant ALL.Oncogene advance online publication, 26 June 2017; doi:10.1038/onc.2017.211.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Discovery of long-range inhibitory signaling to ensure single axon formation.</Gene>
<Gene>A long-standing question in neurodevelopment is how neurons develop a single axon and multiple dendrites from common immature neurites.</Gene>

<Gene>Long-range inhibitory signaling from the growing axon is hypothesized to prevent outgrowth of other immature neurites and to differentiate them into dendrites, but the existence and nature of this inhibitory signaling remains unknown.</Gene>

<Gene>Here, we demonstrate that axonal growth triggered by neurotrophin-3 remotely inhibits neurite outgrowth through long-range Ca(2+) waves, which are delivered from the growing axon to the cell body.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These Ca(2+) waves increase RhoA activity in the cell body through calcium/calmodulin-dependent protein kinase I. Optogenetic control of Rho-kinase combined with computational modeling reveals that active Rho-kinase diffuses to growing other immature neurites and inhibits their outgrowth.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mechanistically, calmodulin-dependent protein kinase I phosphorylates a RhoA-specific GEF, GEF-H1, whose phosphorylation enhances its GEF activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, our results reveal that long-range inhibitory signaling mediated by Ca(2+) wave is responsible for neuronal polarization.</Gene>
<Gene>Emerging evidence suggests that gut microbiota influences immune function in the brain and may play a role in neurological diseases.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, the authors offer in vivo evidence from a Drosophila model that supports a role for gut microbiota in modulating the progression of Alzheimer's disease.</Gene>
<Gene>Angiotensin II subtype 1a receptor signaling in resident hepatic macrophages induces liver metastasis formation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Liver metastases from colorectal cancer (CRC) are a clinically significant problem.</Gene>
<Gene>The renin-angiotensin system is involved in tumor growth and metastases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study was designed to evaluate the role of angiotensin II subtype receptor 1a (AT1a) in the formation of liver metastasis in CRC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A model of liver metastasis was developed by intrasplenic injection of mouse colon cancer (CMT-93) into AT1a knockout mice (AT1aKO) and wild-type (C57BL/6) mice (WT).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Compared with WT mice, the liver weight and liver metastatic rate were significantly lower in AT1aKO.</Gene>
<Gene>The mRNA levels of CD31, transforming growth factor- b1 (TGF-b1), and F4/80 were suppressed in AT1aKO compared with WT.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Double immunofluorescence analysis showed that the number of accumulated F4/80(+) cells expressing TGF-b1 in metastatic areas was higher in WT than in AT1aKO.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The AT1aKO bone marrow (BM) (AT1aKO-BM)>WT showed suppressed formation of liver metastasis compared with WT-BM>WT.</Gene>
<Gene>However, the formation of metastasis was further suppressed in WT-BM>AT1aKO compared with AT1aKO-BM>WT.</Gene>

<Gene>In addition, accumulated F4/80(+) cells in the liver metastasis were not BM-derived F4/80(+) cells, but mainly resident hepatic F4/80(+) cells, and these resident hepatic F4/80(+) cells were positive for TGF-b1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Angiotensin II enhanced TGF-b1 expression in Kupffer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Treatment of WT with clodronate liposomes suppressed liver metastasis by diminishing TGF-b1(+) F4/80(+) cells accumulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The formation of liver metastasis correlated with collagen deposition in the metastatic area, which was dependent on AT1a signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggested that resident hepatic macrophages induced liver metastasis formation by induction of TGF-b1 through AT1a signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A Type 2 Diabetes-Associated Functional Regulatory Variant in a Pancreatic Islet Enhancer at the ADCY5 Locus.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular mechanisms remain unknown for most type 2 diabetes genome-wide association study identified loci.</Gene>
<Gene>Variants associated with type 2 diabetes and fasting glucose levels reside in introns of ADCY5, a gene that encodes adenylate cyclase 5.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Adenylate cyclase 5 catalyzes the production of cyclic AMP, which is a second messenger molecule involved in cell signaling and pancreatic b-cell insulin secretion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We demonstrated that type 2 diabetes risk alleles are associated with decreased ADCY5 expression in human islets and examined candidate variants for regulatory function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>rs11708067 overlaps a predicted enhancer region in pancreatic islets.</Gene>

<Gene>The type 2 diabetes risk rs11708067-A allele showed fewer H3K27ac ChIP-seq reads in human islets, lower transcriptional activity in reporter assays in rodent b-cells (rat 832/13 and mouse MIN6), and increased nuclear protein binding compared with the rs11708067-G allele.</Gene>

<Gene>Homozygous deletion of the orthologous enhancer region in 832/13 cells resulted in a 64% reduction in expression level of Adcy5, but not adjacent gene Sec22a, and a 39% reduction in insulin secretion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together, these data suggest that rs11708067-A risk allele contributes to type 2 diabetes by disrupting an islet enhancer, which results in reduced ADCY5 expression and impaired insulin secretion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutation of the a-tubulin Tuba1a leads to straighter microtubules and perturbs neuronal migration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Brain development involves extensive migration of neurons.</Gene>
<Gene>Microtubules (MTs) are key cellular effectors of neuronal displacement that are assembled from a/b-tubulin heterodimers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutation of the a-tubulin isotype TUBA1A is associated with cortical malformations in humans.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we provide detailed in vivo and in vitro analyses of Tuba1a mutants.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In mice carrying a Tuba1a missense mutation (S140G), neurons accumulate, and glial cells are dispersed along the rostral migratory stream in postnatal and adult brains.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Live imaging of Tuba1a-mutant neurons revealed slowed migration and increased neuronal branching, which correlated with directionality alterations and perturbed nucleus-centrosome (N-C) coupling.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Tuba1a mutation led to increased straightness of newly polymerized MTs, and structural modeling data suggest a conformational change in the a/b-tubulin heterodimer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that Tuba8, another a-tubulin isotype previously associated with cortical malformations, has altered function compared with Tuba1a.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our work shows that Tuba1a plays an essential, noncompensated role in neuronal saltatory migration in vivo and highlights the importance of MT flexibility in N-C coupling and neuronal-branching regulation during neuronal migration.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Prdm1 Regulates Thymic Epithelial Function To Prevent Autoimmunity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Autoimmunity is largely prevented by medullary thymic epithelial cells (TECs) through their expression and presentation of tissue-specific Ags to developing thymocytes, resulting in deletion of self-reactive T cells and supporting regulatory T cell development.</Gene>

<Gene>The transcription factor Prdm1 has been implicated in autoimmune diseases in humans through genome-wide association studies and in mice using cell type-specific deletion of Prdm1 in T and dendritic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this article, we demonstrate that Prdm1 functions in TECs to prevent autoimmunity in mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Prdm1 is expressed by a subset of mouse TECs, and conditional deletion of Prdm1 in either Keratin 14- or Foxn1-expressing cells in mice resulted in multisymptom autoimmune pathology.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Notably, the development of Foxp3(+) regulatory T cells occurs normally in the absence of Blimp1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, nude mice developed anti-nuclear Abs when transplanted with Prdm1 null TECs, but not wild-type TECs, indicating that Prdm1 functions in TECs to regulate autoantibody production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that Prdm1 acts independently of Aire, a crucial transcription factor implicated in medullary TEC function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, our data highlight a previously unrecognized role for Prdm1 in regulating thymic epithelial function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Gankyrin induces STAT3 activation in tumor microenvironment and sorafenib resistance in hepatocellular carcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Most hepatocellular carcinomas (HCC) develop as a result of chronic liver inflammation.</Gene>
<Gene>We have shown that the oncoprotein gankyrin is critical for inflammation-induced tumorigenesis in the colon.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although the in vitro function of gankyrin is well known, its role in vivo remains to be elucidated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We investigated the effect of gankyrin in the tumor microenvironment of mice with liver parenchymal cell-specific gankyrin ablation (Alb-Cre;gankyrin(f/f) ) and gankyrin deletion both in liver parenchymal and non-parenchymal cells (Mx1-Cre;gankyrin(f/f) ).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Gankyrin upregulates vascular endothelial growth factor expression in tumor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Gankyrin binds to Src homology 2 domain-containing protein tyrosine phosphatase-1 (SHP-1), mainly expressed in liver non-parenchymal cells, resulting in phosphorylation and activation of signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Gankyrin deficiency in non-parenchymal cells, but not in parenchymal cells, reduced STAT3 activity, interleukin (IL)-6 production, and cancer stem cell marker (Bmi1 and epithelial cell adhesion molecule [EpCAM]) expression, leading to attenuated tumorigenic potential.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Chronic inflammation enhances gankyrin expression in the human liver.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Gankyrin expression in the tumor microenvironment is negatively correlated with progression-free survival in patients undergoing sorafenib treatment for HCC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, gankyrin appears to play a critical oncogenic function in tumor microenvironment and may be a potential target for developing therapeutic and preventive strategies against HCC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pet10p is a yeast perilipin that stabilizes lipid droplets and promotes their assembly.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Pet10p is a yeast lipid droplet protein of unknown function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show that it binds specifically to and is stabilized by droplets containing triacylglycerol (TG).</Gene>
<Gene>Droplets isolated from cells with a PET10 deletion strongly aggregate, appear fragile, and fuse in vivo when cells are cultured in oleic acid.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pet10p binds early to nascent droplets, and their rate of appearance is decreased in pet10D Moreover, Pet10p functionally interacts with the endoplasmic reticulum droplet assembly factors seipin and Fit2 to maintain proper droplet morphology.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The activity of Dga1p, a diacylglycerol acyltransferase, and TG accumulation were both 30-35% lower in the absence of Pet10p.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Pet10p contains a PAT domain, a defining property of perilipins, which was not previously known to exist in yeast.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We propose that the core functions of Pet10p and other perilipins extend beyond protection from lipases and include the preservation of droplet integrity as well as collaboration with seipin and Fit2 in droplet assembly and maintenance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Monoallelic characteristic-bearing heterozygous L1053X in BRCA2 gene among Sudanese women with breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Breast cancer (BC) is the most common type of cancer in women.</Gene>
<Gene>Among many risk factors of BC, mutations in BRCA2 gene were found to be the primary cause in 5-10% of cases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The majority of deleterious mutations are frameshift or nonsense mutations.</Gene>
<Gene>Most of the reported BRCA2 mutations are protein truncating mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>The study aimed to describe the pattern of mutations including single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) and variants of the BRCA2 (exon11) gene among Sudanese women patients diagnosed with BC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study a specific region of BRCA2 exon 11 was targeted using PCR and DNA sequencing.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Early onset cases 25/45 (55.6%) were premenopausal women with a mean age of 36.6 years.</Gene>
<Gene>Multiparity was more frequent within the study amounting to 30 cases (66.6%), with a mean parity of 4.1.</Gene>
<Gene>Ductal type tumor was the predominant type detected in 22 cases (48.8%) among the reported histotypes.</Gene>
<Gene>A heterozygous monoallelic nonsense mutation at nucleotide 3385 was found in four patients out of 9, where TTA codon was converted into the stop codon TGA.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>This study detected a monoallelic nonsense mutation in four Sudanese female patients diagnosed with early onset BC from different families.</Gene>
<Gene>Further work is needed to demonstrate its usefulness in screening of BC.</Gene>
<Gene>A20 Restrains Thymic Regulatory T Cell Development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Maintaining immune tolerance requires the production of Foxp3-expressing regulatory T (Treg) cells in the thymus.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of NF-kB transcription factors is critically required for Treg cell development, partly via initiating Foxp3 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NF-kB activation is controlled by a negative feedback regulation through the ubiquitin editing enzyme A20, which reduces proinflammatory signaling in myeloid cells and B cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In naive CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>T cells, A20 prevents kinase RIPK3-dependent necroptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using mice deficient for A20 in T lineage cells, we show that thymic and peripheral Treg cell compartments are quantitatively enlarged because of a cell-intrinsic developmental advantage of A20-deficient thymic Treg differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A20-deficient thymic Treg cells exhibit reduced dependence on IL-2 but unchanged rates of proliferation and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of the NF-kB transcription factor RelA was enhanced, whereas nuclear translocation of c-Rel was decreased in A20-deficient thymic Treg cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, we found that the increase in Treg cells in T cell-specific A20-deficient mice was already observed in CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>single-positive CD25(+) GITR(+) Foxp3(-) thymic Treg cell progenitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Treg cell precursors expressed high levels of the tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily molecule GITR, whose stimulation is closely linked to thymic Treg cell development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A20-deficient Treg cells efficiently suppressed effector T cell-mediated graft-versus-host disease after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation, suggesting normal suppressive function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Holding thymic production of natural Treg cells in check, A20 thus integrates Treg cell activity and increased effector T cell survival into an efficient CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T cell response.</Gene>
<Gene>An Ag-globin G->A gene polymorphism associated with b(0)39 thalassemia globin gene and high fetal hemoglobin production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>Increase of the expression of g-globin gene and high production of fetal hemoglobin (HbF) in b-thalassemia patients is widely accepted as associated with a milder or even asymptomatic disease.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The search for HbF-associated polymorphisms (such as the XmnI, BCL11A and MYB polymorphisms) has recently gained great attention, in order to stratify b-thalassemia patients with respect to expectancy of the first transfusion, need for annual intake of blood, response to HbF inducers (the most studied of which is hydroxyurea).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>Ag-globin gene sequencing was performed on genomic DNA isolated from a total of 75 b-thalassemia patients, including 31 b(0)39/b(0)39, 33 b(0)39/b(+)IVSI-110, 9 b(+)IVSI-110/b(+)IVSI-110, one b(0)IVSI-1/b(+)IVSI-6 and one b(0)39/b(+)IVSI-6.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>The results show that the rs368698783 polymorphism is present in b-thalassemia patients in the 5'UTR sequence (+25) of the Ag-globin gene, known to affect the LYAR (human homologue of mouse Ly-1 antibody reactive clone) binding site 5'-GGTTAT-3'.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
