text: <Gene>This Ag(+25 G->A) polymorphism is associated with the Gg-globin-XmnI polymorphism and both are linked with the b(0)39-globin gene, but not with the b(+)IVSI-110-globin gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In agreement with the expectation that this mutation alters the LYAR binding activity, we found that the Ag(+25 G->A) and Gg-globin-XmnI polymorphisms are associated with high HbF in erythroid precursor cells isolated from b(0)39/b(0)39 thalassemia patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>As a potential explanation of our findings, we hypothesize that in b-thalassemia the Gg-globin-XmnI/Ag-globin-(G->A) genotype is frequently under genetic linkage with b(0)-thalassemia mutations, but not with the b(+)-thalassemia mutation here studied (i.e. b(+)IVSI-110) and that this genetic combination has been selected within the population of b(0)-thalassemia patients, due to functional association with high HbF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we describe the characterization of the rs368698783 (+25 G->A) polymorphism of the Ag-globin gene associated in b(0)39 thalassemia patients with high HbF in erythroid precursor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Flavin monooxygenases regulate Caenorhabditis elegans axon guidance and growth cone protrusion with UNC-6/Netrin signaling and Rac GTPases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The guidance cue UNC-6/Netrin regulates both attractive and repulsive axon guidance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our previous work showed that in C. elegans, the attractive UNC-6/Netrin receptor UNC-40/DCC stimulates growth cone protrusion, and that the repulsive receptor, an UNC-5:UNC-40 heterodimer, inhibits growth cone protrusion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have also shown that inhibition of growth cone protrusion downstream of the UNC-5:UNC-40 repulsive receptor involves Rac GTPases, the Rac GTP exchange factor UNC-73/Trio, and the cytoskeletal regulator UNC-33/CRMP, which mediates Semaphorin-induced growth cone collapse in other systems.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The multidomain flavoprotein monooxygenase (FMO) MICAL (Molecule Interacting with CasL) also mediates growth cone collapse in response to Semaphorin by directly oxidizing F-actin, resulting in depolymerization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The C. elegans genome does not encode a multidomain MICAL-like molecule, but does encode five flavin monooxygenases (FMO-1, -2, -3, -4, and 5) and another molecule, EHBP-1, similar to the non-FMO portion of MICAL.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that FMO-1, FMO-4, FMO-5, and EHBP-1 may play a role in UNC-6/Netrin directed repulsive guidance mediated through UNC-40 and UNC-5 receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in fmo-1, fmo-4, fmo-5, and ehbp-1 showed VD/DD axon guidance and branching defects, and variably enhanced unc-40 and unc-5 VD/DD axon guidance defects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Developing growth cones in vivo of fmo-1, fmo-4, fmo-5, and ehbp-1 mutants displayed excessive filopodial protrusion, and transgenic expression of FMO-5 inhibited growth cone protrusion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations suppressed growth cone inhibition caused by activated UNC-40 and UNC-5 signaling, and activated Rac GTPase CED-10 and MIG-2, suggesting that these molecules are required downstream of UNC-6/Netrin receptors and Rac GTPases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>From these studies we conclude that FMO-1, FMO-4, FMO-5, and EHBP-1 represent new players downstream of UNC-6/Netrin receptors and Rac GTPases that inhibit growth cone filopodial protrusion in repulsive axon guidance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Peptide array based screening reveals a large number of proteins interacting with the ankyrin repeat domain of the zDHHC17 S-acyltransferase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>zDHHC</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>S-acyl-transferases are enzymes catalyzing protein S-acylation, a common post-translational modification on proteins frequently affecting their membrane targeting and trafficking.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The ankyrin-repeat (AR) domain of zDHHC17 (HIP14) and zDHHC13 (HIP14L) S-acyltransferases, which is involved in both substrate recruitment and S-acylation-independent functions, was recently shown to bind at least six proteins, by specific recognition of a consensus sequence in them.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To further refine the rules governing binding to the AR of zDHHC17, we employed peptide arrays based on zDHHC AR-binding motif (zDABM) sequences of synaptosomal-associated protein 25 (SNAP25) and cysteine string protein alpha (CSPa).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Quantitative comparisons of the binding preferences of 400 peptides allowed us to construct a position-specific scoring matrix (PSSM) for zDHHC17 AR binding, with which we predicted and subsequently validated many putative zDHHC17 interactors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We identified 95 human zDABM sequences with unexpected versatility in amino-acid usage; these sequences were distributed among 90 proteins, of which 62 have not been previously implicated in zDHHC17/13 binding.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These zDABM-containing proteins included all family members of the SNAP25, sprouty, cornifelin, ankyrin, and SLAIN-motif containing families; seven endogenous Gag polyproteins sharing the same binding sequence; and several proteins involved in cytoskeletal organization, cell communication, and regulation of signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A dozen of the zDABM-containing proteins had more than one zDABM sequence, while isoform-specific binding to the AR of zDHHC17 was identified for the Ena/VASP-like protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The large number of zDABM sequences within the human proteome suggests that zDHHC17 may be an interaction hub regulating many cellular processes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Disease-associated mutations in human BICD2 hyperactivate motility of dynein-dynactin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bicaudal D2 (BICD2) joins dynein with dynactin into a ternary complex (termed DDB) capable of processive movement.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Point mutations in the BICD2 gene have been identified in patients with a dominant form of spinal muscular atrophy, but how these mutations cause disease is unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To investigate this question, we have developed in vitro motility assays with purified DDB and BICD2's membrane vesicle partner, the GTPase Rab6a. Rab6a-GTP, either in solution or bound to artificial liposomes, released BICD2 from an autoinhibited state and promoted robust dynein-dynactin transport.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In these assays, BICD2 mutants showed an enhanced ability to form motile DDB complexes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Increased retrograde transport by BICD2 mutants also was observed in cells using an inducible organelle transport assay.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>When overexpressed in rat hippocampal neurons, the hyperactive BICD2 mutants decreased neurite growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our results reveal that dominant mutations in BICD2 hyperactivate DDB motility and suggest that an imbalance of minus versus plus end-directed microtubule motility in neurons may underlie spinal muscular atrophy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Functional divergence of chloroplast Cpn60a subunits during Arabidopsis embryo development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Chaperonins are a class of molecular chaperones that assist in the folding and assembly of a wide range of substrates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In plants, chloroplast chaperonins are composed of two different types of subunits, Cpn60a and Cpn60b, and duplication of Cpn60a and Cpn60b genes occurs in a high proportion of plants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the importance of multiple Cpn60a and Cpn60b genes in plants is poorly understood.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we found that loss-of-function of CPNA2 (AtCpn60a2), a gene encoding the minor Cpn60a subunit in Arabidopsis thaliana, resulted in arrested embryo development at the globular stage, whereas the other AtCpn60a gene encoding the dominant Cpn60a subunit, CPNA1 (AtCpn60a1), mainly affected embryonic cotyledon development at the torpedo stage and thereafter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Further studies demonstrated that CPNA2 can form a functional chaperonin with CPNB2 (AtCpn60b2) and CPNB3 (AtCpn60b3), while the functional partners of CPNA1 are CPNB1 (AtCpn60b1) and CPNB2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also revealed that the functional chaperonin containing CPNA2 could assist the folding of a specific substrate, KASI (b-ketoacyl-[acyl carrier protein] synthase I), and that the KASI protein level was remarkably reduced due to loss-of-function of CPNA2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the reduction in the KASI protein level was shown to be the possible cause for the arrest of cpna2 embryos.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings indicate that the two Cpn60a subunits in Arabidopsis play different roles during embryo development through forming distinct chaperonins with specific AtCpn60b to assist the folding of particular substrates, thus providing novel insights into functional divergence of Cpn60a subunits in plants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Targeted Pth4-expressing cell ablation impairs skeletal mineralization in zebrafish.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Skeletal development and mineralization are essential processes driven by the coordinated action of neural signals, circulating molecules and local factors.</Gene>
<Gene>Our previous studies revealed that the novel neuropeptide Pth4, synthesized by hypothalamic cells, was involved in bone metabolism via phosphate regulation in adult zebrafish.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we investigate the role of pth4 during skeletal development using single-cell resolution, two-photon laser ablation of Pth4:eGFP-expressing cells and confocal imaging in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using a stable transgenic Pth4:eGFP zebrafish line, we identify Pth4:eGFP-expressing cells as post-mitotic neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>After targeted ablation of eGFP-expressing cells in the hypothalamus, the experimental larvae exhibited impaired mineralization of the craniofacial bones whereas cartilage development was normal.</Gene>

<Gene>In addition to a decrease in pth4 transcript levels, we noted altered expression of phex and entpd5, genes associated with phosphate homeostasis and mineralization, as well as a delay in the expression of osteoblast differentiation markers such as sp7 and sparc.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, these results suggest that Pth4-expressing hypothalamic neurons participate in the regulation of bone metabolism, possibly through regulating phosphate balance during zebrafish development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Protein tyrosine phosphatase PTPN22 is dispensable for dendritic cell antigen processing and promotion of T-cell activation by dendritic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The PTPN22R620W single nucleotide polymorphism increases the risk of developing multiple autoimmune diseases including type 1 diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis and lupus.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PTPN22 is highly expressed in antigen presenting cells (APCs) where the expression of the murine disease associated variant orthologue (Ptpn22R619W) is reported to dysregulate pattern recognition receptor signalling in dendritic cells (DCs) and promote T-cell proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Because T-cell activation is dependent on DC antigen uptake, degradation and presentation, we analysed the efficiency of these functions in splenic and GM-CSF bone marrow derived DC from wild type (WT), Ptpn22-/- or Ptpn22R619W mutant mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Results indicated no differential ability of DCs to uptake antigen via macropinocytosis or receptor-mediated endocytosis.</Gene>
<Gene>Antigen degradation and presentation was also equal as was WT T-cell conjugate formation and subsequent T-cell proliferation.</Gene>

<Gene>Despite the likely presence of multiple phosphatase-regulated pathways in the antigen uptake, processing and presentation pathways that we investigated, we observed that Ptpn22 and the R619W autoimmune associated variant were dispensable.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These important findings indicate that under non-inflammatory conditions there is no requirement for Ptpn22 in DC dependent antigen uptake and T-cell activation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings reveal that perturbations in antigen uptake and processing, a fundamental pathway determining adaptive immune responses, are unlikely to provide a mechanism for the risk associated with the Ptpn22 autoimmune associated polymorphism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thiamine deficiency activates hypoxia inducible factor-1a to facilitate pro-apoptotic responses in mouse primary astrocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thiamine is an essential enzyme cofactor required for proper metabolic function and maintenance of metabolism and energy production in the brain.</Gene>

<Gene>In developed countries, thiamine deficiency (TD) is most often manifested following chronic alcohol consumption leading to impaired mitochondrial function, oxidative stress, inflammation and excitotoxicity.</Gene>
<Gene>These biochemical lesions result in apoptotic cell death in both neurons and astrocytes.</Gene>

<Gene>Comparable histological injuries in patients with hypoxia/ischemia and TD have been described in the thalamus and mammillary bodies, suggesting a congruency between the cellular responses to these stresses.</Gene>
<Gene>Consistent with hypoxia/ischemia, TD stabilizes and activates Hypoxia Inducible Factor-1a (HIF-1a) under physiological oxygen levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the role of TD-induced HIF-1a in neurological injury is currently unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using Western blot analysis and RT-PCR, we have demonstrated that TD induces HIF-1a expression and activity in primary mouse astrocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We observed a time-dependent increase in mRNA and protein expression of the pro-apoptotic and pro-inflammatory HIF-1a target genes MCP1, BNIP3, Nix and Noxa during TD.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also observed apoptotic cell death in TD as demonstrated by PI/Annexin V staining, TUNEL assay, and Cell Death ELISA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pharmacological inhibition of HIF-1a activity using YC1 and thiamine repletion both reduced expression of pro-apoptotic HIF-1a target genes and apoptotic cell death in TD.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results demonstrate that induction of HIF-1a mediated transcriptional up-regulation of pro-apoptotic/inflammatory signaling contributes to astrocyte cell death during thiamine deficiency.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>An inducible mouse model of podocin-mutation-related nephrotic syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mutations in the NPHS2 gene, encoding podocin, cause hereditary nephrotic syndrome.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The most common podocin mutation, R138Q, is associated with early disease onset and rapid progression to end-stage renal disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Knock-in mice carrying a R140Q mutation, the mouse analogue of human R138Q, show developmental arrest of podocytes and lethal renal failure at neonatal age.</Gene>

<Gene>Here we created a conditional podocin knock-in model named NPHS2 R140Q/-, using a tamoxifen-inducible Cre recombinase, which permits to study the effects of the mutation in postnatal life.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Within the first week of R140Q hemizygosity induction the animals developed proteinuria, which peaked after 4-5 weeks.</Gene>
<Gene>Subsequently the animals developed progressive renal failure, with a median survival time of 12 (95% CI: 11-13) weeks.</Gene>
<Gene>Foot process fusion was observed within one week, progressing to severe and global effacement in the course of the disease.</Gene>
<Gene>The number of podocytes per glomerulus gradually diminished to 18% compared to healthy controls 12-16 weeks after induction.</Gene>
<Gene>The fraction of segmentally sclerosed glomeruli was 25%, 85% and 97% at 2, 4 and 8 weeks, respectively.</Gene>
<Gene>Severe tubulointerstitial fibrosis was present at later disease stage and was correlated quantitatively with the level of proteinuria at early disease stages.</Gene>
<Gene>While R140Q podocin mRNA expression was elevated, protein abundance was reduced by more than 50% within one week following induction.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Whereas miRNA21 expression persistently increased during the first 4 weeks, miRNA-193a expression peaked 2 weeks after induction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, the inducible R140Q-podocin mouse model is an auspicious model of the most common genetic cause of human nephrotic syndrome, with a spontaneous disease course strongly reminiscent of the human disorder.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This model constitutes a valuable tool to test the efficacy of novel pharmacological interventions aimed to improve podocyte function and viability and attenuate proteinuria, glomerulosclerosis and progressive renal failure.</Gene>
<Gene>Netrin-1 is a novel regulator of vascular endothelial function in diabetes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Netrin-1, a secreted laminin-like protein identified as an axon guidance molecule, has been shown to be of critical importance in the cardiovascular system.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recent studies have revealed pro-angiogenic, anti-apoptotic and anti-inflammatory properties of netrin-1 as well as cardioprotective actions against myocardial injury in diabetic mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>AIM: To examine the role of netrin-1 in diabetes-and high glucose (HG)-induced vascular endothelial dysfunction (VED) using netrin-1 transgenic mice (Tg3) and cultured bovine aortic endothelial cells (BAEC).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MAIN OUTCOME: Overexpression of netrin-1 prevented diabetes-induced VED in aorta from diabetic mice and netrin-1 treatment attenuated HG-induced impairment of nitric oxide synthase (NOS) function in BAECs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS AND RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Experiments were performed in Tg3 and littermate control (WT) mice rendered diabetic with streptozotocin (STZ) and in BAECs treated with HG (25 mmol/L).</Gene>
<Gene>Levels of netrin-1 and its receptor DCC, markers of inflammation and apoptosis and vascular function were assessed in aortas from diabetic and non-diabetic Tg3 and WT mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Vascular netrin-1 in WT mice was reduced under diabetic conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Aortas from non-diabetic Tg3 and WT mice showed similar maximum endothelium-dependent relaxation (MEDR) (83% and 87%, respectively).</Gene>
<Gene>MEDR was markedly impaired in aorta from diabetic WT mice (51%).</Gene>
<Gene>This effect was significantly blunted in Tg3 diabetic aortas (70%).</Gene>

<Gene>Improved vascular relaxation in Tg3 diabetic mice was associated with increased levels of phospho-ERK1/2 and reduced levels of oxidant stress, NFkB, COX-2, p16INK4A, cleaved caspase-3 and p16 and p53 mRNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Netrin-1 treatment prevented the HG-induced decrease in NO production and elevation of oxidative stress and apoptosis in BAECs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Diabetes decreases aortic levels of netrin-1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, overexpression of netrin-1 attenuates diabetes-induced VED and limits the reduction of NO levels, while increasing expression of p-ERK1/2, and suppressing oxidative stress and inflammatory and apoptotic processes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Enhancement of netrin-1 function may be a useful therapeutic means for preventing vascular dysfunction in diabetes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Zinc-finger protein 418 overexpression protects against cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>This study aimed to investigated the effect and mechanism of zinc-finger protein 418 (ZNF418) on cardiac hypertrophy caused by aortic banding (AB), phenylephrine (PE) or angiotensin II (Ang II) in vivo and in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>The expression of ZNF418 in hearts of patients with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) and AB-induced cardiac hypertrophy mice, as well as in Ang II- or PE-induced hypertrophic primary cardiomyocytes was detected by western blotting.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Then, the expression of ZNF418 was up-regulated or down-regulated in AB-induced cardiac hypertrophy mice and Ang II -induced hypertrophic primary cardiomyocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The hypertrophic responses and fibrosis were evaluated by echocardiography and histological analysis.</Gene>
<Gene>The mRNA levels of hypertrophy markers and fibrotic markers were detected by RT-qPCR.</Gene>
<Gene>Furthermore, the phosphorylation and total levels of c-Jun were measured by western blotting.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>ZNF418 was markedly down-regulated in hearts of cardiac hypertrophy and hypertrophic primary cardiomyocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Down-regulated ZNF418 exacerbated the myocyte size and fibrosis, moreover increased the mRNA levels of ANP, BNP, b-MHC, MCIP1.4, collagen 1a, collagen III, MMP-2 and fibronection in hearts of AB-treated ZNF418 knockout mice or Ang II-treated cardiomyocytes with AdshZNF418.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, these hypertrophic responses were reduced in the ZNF418 transgenic (TG) mice treated by AB and the AdZNF418-transfected primary cardiomyocytes treated by Ang II.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, the deficiency of ZNF418 enhanced the phosphorylation level of c-jun, and overexpression of ZNF418 suppressed the phosphorylation level of c-jun in vivo and in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>ZNF418 maybe attenuate hypertrophic responses by inhibiting the activity of c-jun/AP-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ICSBP is essential for the development of mouse type I interferon-producing cells and for the generation and activation of CD8alpha(+) dendritic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interferon (IFN) consensus sequence-binding protein (ICSBP) is a transcription factor playing a critical role in the regulation of lineage commitment, especially in myeloid cell differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we have characterized the phenotype and activation pattern of subsets of dendritic cells (DCs) in ICSBP(-/-) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Remarkably, the recently identified mouse IFN-producing cells (mIPCs) were absent in all lymphoid organs from ICSBP(-/-) mice, as revealed by lack of CD11c(low)B220(+)Ly6C(+)CD11b(-) cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In parallel, CD11c(+) cells isolated from ICSBP(-/-) spleens were unable to produce type I IFNs in response to viral stimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ICSBP(-/-)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>mice also displayed a marked reduction of the DC subset expressing the CD8alpha marker (CD8alpha(+) DCs) in spleen, lymph nodes, and thymus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, ICSBP(-/-) CD8alpha(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DCs exhibited a markedly impaired phenotype when compared with WT DCs.</Gene>

<Gene>They expressed very low levels of costimulatory molecules (intercellular adhesion molecule [ICAM]-1, CD40, CD80, CD86) and of the T cell area-homing chemokine receptor CCR7, whereas they showed higher levels of CCR2 and CCR6, as revealed by reverse transcription PCR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, these cells were unable to undergo full phenotypic activation upon in vitro culture in presence of maturation stimuli such as lipopolysaccharide or poly (I:C), which paralleled with lack of Toll-like receptor (TLR)3 mRNA expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, cytokine expression pattern was also altered in ICSBP(-/-)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DCs, as they did not express interleukin (IL)-12p40 or IL-15, but they displayed detectable IL-4 mRNA levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>On the whole, these results indicate that ICSBP is a crucial factor in the regulation of two possibly linked processes: (a) the development and activity of mIPCs, whose lack in ICSBP(-/-) mice may explain their high susceptibility to virus infections</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>; (b) the generation and activation of CD8alpha(+) DCs, whose impairment in ICSBP(-/-) mice can be responsible for the defective generation of a Th1 type of immune response.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NF-kappa B genes have a major role in inflammatory breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>IBC (Inflammatory Breast cancer) is a rare form of breast cancer with a particular phenotype.</Gene>
<Gene>New molecular targets are needed to improve the treatment of this rapidly fatal disease.</Gene>
<Gene>Given the role of NF-kappaB-related genes in cell proliferation, invasiveness, angiogenesis and inflammation, we postulated that they might be deregulated in IBC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>We measured the mRNA expression levels of 60 NF-kappaB-related genes by using real-time quantitative RT-PCR in a well-defined series of 35 IBCs, by comparison with 22 stage IIB and III non inflammatory breast cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Twenty-four distant metastases of breast cancer served as "poor prognosis" breast tumor controls.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS: Thirty-five (58%) of the 60 NF-kappaB-related genes were significantly upregulated in IBC compared with non IBC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The upregulated genes were NF-kappaB genes (NFKB1, RELA, IKBKG, NFKBIB, NFKB2, REL, CHUK), apoptosis genes (MCL1L, TNFAIP3/A20, GADD45B, FASLG, MCL1S, IER3L, TNFRSF10B/TRAILR2), immune response genes (CD40, CD48, TNFSF11/RANKL, TNFRSF11A/RANK, CCL2/MCP-1, CD40LG, IL15, GBP1), proliferation genes (CCND2, CCND3, CSF1R, CSF1, SOD2), tumor-promoting genes (CXCL12, SELE, TNC, VCAM1, ICAM1, PLAU/UPA) or angiogenesis genes (PTGS2/COX2, CXCL1/GRO1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Only two of these 35 genes (PTGS2/COX2 and CXCL1/GRO1)were also upregulated in breast cancer metastases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We identified a five-gene molecular signature that matched patient outcomes, consisting of IL8 and VEGF plus three NF-kappaB-unrelated genes that we had previously identified as prognostic markers in the same series of IBC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>The NF-kappaB pathway appears to play a major role in IBC, possibly contributing to the unusual phenotype and aggressiveness of this form of breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Some upregulated NF-kappaB-related genes might serve as novel therapeutic targets in IBC.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Bone morphogenetic protein-4 interacts with activin and GnRH to modulate gonadotrophin secretion in LbetaT2 gonadotrophs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have shown previously that, in sheep primary pituitary cells, bone morphogenetic proteins (BMP)-4 inhibits FSHbeta mRNA expression and FSH release.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, in mouse LbetaT2 gonadotrophs, others have shown a stimulatory effect of BMPs on basal or activin-stimulated FSHbeta promoter-driven transcription.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As a species comparison with our previous results, we used LbetaT2 cells to investigate the effects of BMP-4 on gonadotrophin mRNA and secretion modulated by activin and GnRH.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BMP-4 alone had no effect on FSH production, but enhanced the activin+GnRH-induced stimulation of FSHbeta mRNA and FSH secretion, without any effect on follistatin mRNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BMP-4 reduced LHbeta mRNA up-regulation in response to GnRH (+/-activin) and decreased GnRH receptor expression, which would favour FSH, rather than LH, synthesis and secretion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast to sheep pituitary gonadotrophs, which express only BMP receptor types IA (BMPRIA) and II (BMPRII), LbetaT2 cells also express BMPRIB. Smad1/5 phosphorylation induced by BMP-4, indicating activation of BMP signalling, was the same whether BMP-4 was used alone or combined with activin+/-GnRH.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We hypothesized that activin and/or GnRH pathways may be modulated by BMP-4, but neither the activin-stimulated phosphorylation of Smad2/3 nor the GnRH-induced ERK1/2 or cAMP response element-binding phosphorylation were modified.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the GnRH-induced activation of p38 MAPK was decreased by BMP-4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This was associated with increased FSHbeta mRNA levels and FSH secretion, but decreased LHbeta mRNA levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results confirm 1. BMPs as important modulators of activin and/or GnRH-stimulated gonadotrophin synthesis and release and 2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>important species differences in these effects, which could relate to differences in BMP receptor expression in gonadotrophs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Curcumin decreases specificity protein expression in bladder cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Curcumin is the active component of tumeric, and this polyphenolic compound has been extensively investigated as an anticancer drug that modulates multiple pathways and genes.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, 10 to 25 micromol/L curcumin inhibited 253JB-V and KU7 bladder cancer cell growth, and this was accompanied by induction of apoptosis and decreased expression of the proapoptotic protein survivin and the angiogenic proteins vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) and VEGF receptor 1 (VEGFR1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Because expression of survivin, VEGF, and VEGFR1 are dependent on specificity protein (Sp) transcription factors, we also investigated the effects of curcumin on Sp protein expression as an underlying mechanism for the apoptotic and antiangiogenic activity of this compound.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results show that curcumin induced proteasome-dependent down-regulation of Sp1, Sp3, and Sp4 in 253JB-V and KU7 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, using RNA interference with small inhibitory RNAs for Sp1, Sp3, and Sp4, we observed that curcumin-dependent inhibition of nuclear factor kappaB (NF-kappaB)-dependent genes, such as bcl-2, survivin, and cyclin D1, was also due, in part, to loss of Sp proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Curcumin also decreased bladder tumor growth in athymic nude mice bearing KU7 cells as xenografts and this was accompanied by decreased Sp1, Sp3, and Sp4 protein levels in tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results show for the first time that one of the underlying mechanisms of action of curcumin as a cancer chemotherapeutic agent is due, in part, to decreased expression of Sp transcription factors in bladder cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The Kruppel-like factor 9 (KLF9) network in HEC-1-A endometrial carcinoma cells suggests the carcinogenic potential of dys-regulated KLF9 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>Kruppel-like factor 9 (KLF9) is a transcriptional regulator of uterine endometrial cell proliferation, adhesion and differentiation; processes essential for pregnancy success and which are subverted during tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The network of endometrial genes controlled by KLF9 is largely unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Over-expression of KLF9 in the human endometrial cancer cell line HEC-1-A alters cell morphology, proliferative indices, and differentiation, when compared to KLF9 under-expressing HEC-1-A cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This cell line provides a unique model for identifying KLF9 downstream gene targets and signaling pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS: HEC-1-A sub-lines differing in relative levels of KLF9 were subjected to microarray analysis to identify differentially-regulated RNAs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: KLF9 under-expression induced twenty four genes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The KLF9-suppressed mRNAs encode protein participants in: aldehyde metabolism (AKR7A2, ALDH1A1); regulation of the actin cytoskeleton and cell motility (e.g., ANK3, ITGB8); cellular detoxification (SULT1A1, ABCC4); cellular signaling (e.g., ACBD3, FZD5, RAB25, CALB1); and transcriptional regulation (PAX2, STAT1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sixty mRNAs were more abundant in KLF9 over-expressing sub-lines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The KLF9-induced mRNAs encode proteins which participate in: regulation and function of the actin cytoskeleton (COTL1, FSCN1, FXYD5, MYO10); cell adhesion, extracellular matrix and basement membrane formation (e.g., AMIGO2, COL4A1, COL4A2, LAMC2, NID2); transport (CLIC4); cellular signaling (e.g., BCAR3, MAPKAPK3); transcriptional regulation [e.g., KLF4, NR3C1 (glucocorticoid receptor), RXRalpha], growth factor/cytokine actions (SLPI, BDNF); and membrane-associated proteins and receptors (e.g., CXCR4, PTCH1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the abundance of mRNAs that encode hypothetical proteins (KLF9-inhibited: C12orf29 and C1orf186; KLF9-induced: C10orf38 and C9orf167) were altered by KLF9 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human endometrial tumors of high tumor grade had decreased KLF9 mRNA abundance.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>

<Gene>KLF9 influences the expression of uterine epithelial genes through mechanisms likely involving its transcriptional activator and repressor functions and which may underlie altered tumor biology with aberrant KLF9 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A chemical compound commonly used to inhibit PKR, {8-(imidazol-4-ylmethylene)-6H-azolidino[5,4-g] benzothiazol-7-one}, protects neurons by inhibiting cyclin-dependent kinase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of the double-stranded RNA-dependent protein kinase (PKR) has been implicated in the pathogenesis of several neurodegenerative diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We find that a compound widely used as a pharmacological inhibitor of this enzyme, referred to as PKR inhibitor (PKRi), {8-(imidazol-4-ylmethylene)-6H-azolidino[5,4-g]benzothiazol-7-one}, protects against the death of cultured cerebellar granule and cortical neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PKRi also prevents striatal neurodegeneration and improves behavioral outcomes in a chemically induced mouse model of Huntington's disease.</Gene>
<Gene>Surprisingly, PKRi fails to block the phosphorylation of eIF2alpha, a downstream target of PKR, and does not reduce the autophosphorylation of PKR enzyme immunoprecipitated from neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, neurons lacking PKR are fully protected from apoptosis by PKRi, demonstrating that neuroprotection by this compound is not mediated by PKR inhibition.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using in vitro kinase assays we investigated whether PKRi affects any other protein kinase.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These analyses demonstrated that PKRi has no major inhibitory effect on pro-apoptotic kinases such as the c-Jun N-terminal kinases, the p38 MAP kinases and the death-associated protein kinases, or on other kinases including c-Raf, MEK1, MKK6 and MKK7. PKRi does, however, inhibit the activity of certain cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs), including CDK1, CDK2 and CDK5 both in vitro and in low potassium-treated neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consistent with its inhibitory action on mitotic CDKs, the treatment of HT-22 and HEK293T cell lines with PKRi sharply reduces the rate of cell cycle progression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together with the established role of CDK activation in the promotion of neurodegeneration, our results suggest that PKRi exerts its neuroprotective action by inhibiting CDK.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Gammadelta T lymphocyte homeostasis is negatively regulated by beta2-microglobulin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Successful application of gammadelta T cells in adoptive cell therapies depends upon our ability to maintain these cells in vivo.</Gene>
<Gene>Using an adoptive transfer model to study lymphopenia-induced homeostatic expansion, we show that CD8(+) and NK1.1(+) gammadelta T cell subsets are differentially regulated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While CD8(+) gammadelta T cells have an early and sustained advantage following transfer into TCRbeta(-/-)/delta(-/-) mice, NK1.1(+) gammadelta T cells proliferate slowly and are maintained at low numbers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The advantage of the CD8(+) subset could not be explained by increased bcl-2 or cytokine receptor expression but did correlate with Vgamma4(+) and Vdelta5(+) expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Despite the role of CD8 in MHC class I recognition by alphabeta T cells, beta(2)-microglobulin (beta(2)m)-associated MHC class I molecules were not required for CD8(+) gammadelta T cell homeostatic expansion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Surprisingly, all gammadelta T cells, including the CD8(+) subset, exhibited enhanced proliferation following adoptive transfer into Rag1(-/-)/beta(2)m(-/-) compared with Rag1(-/-) recipients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This effect was most notable for the NK1.1(+) subset, which expresses high levels of NKG2A/CD94 and Ly49.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although expression of these inhibitory receptors correlated with poor homeostatic expansion in the presence of beta(2)m, gammadelta T cell homeostatic proliferation in TCRbeta(-/-)/delta(-/-) mice was not altered in the presence of Ly49C/I- and NKG2-blocking Abs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While the mechanism by which beta(2)m negatively regulates gammadelta T cell homeostasis remains to be determined, this observation is unique to gammadelta T cells and confirms that multiple mechanisms are in place to maintain strict regulation of both the size and the composition of the gammadelta T cell pool.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Neuregulin-1 beta and neuregulin-1 alpha differentially affect the migration and invasion of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors (MPNSTs) are the most common malignancy associated with neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These Schwann cell lineage-derived sarcomas aggressively invade adjacent nerve and soft tissue, frequently precluding surgical resection.</Gene>
<Gene>Little is known regarding the mechanisms underlying this invasive behavior.</Gene>

<Gene>We have shown that MPNSTs express neuregulin-1 (NRG-1) beta isoforms, which promote Schwann cell migration during development, and NRG-1 alpha isoforms, whose effects on Schwann cells are poorly understood.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hypothesizing that NRG-1 beta and/or NRG-1 alpha promote MPNST invasion, we found that NRG-1 beta promoted MPNST migration in a substrate-specific manner, markedly enhancing migration on laminin but not on collagen type I or fibronectin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The NRG-1 receptors erbB3 and erbB4 were present in MPNST invadopodia (processes mediating invasion), partially colocalized with focal adhesion kinase and the laminin receptor beta(1)-integrin and coimmunoprecipitated with beta(1)-integrin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NRG-1 beta stimulated human and murine MPNST cell migration and invasion in a concentration-dependent manner in three-dimensional migration assays, acting as a chemotactic factor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both baseline and NRG-1 beta-induced migration were erbB-dependent and required the action of MEK 1/2, SAPK/JNK, PI-3 kinase, Src family kinases and ROCK-I/II.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, NRG-1 alpha had no effect on the migration and invasion of some MPNST lines and inhibited the migration of others.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While NRG-1 beta potently and persistently activated Erk 1/2, SAPK/JNK, Akt and Src family kinases, NRG-1 alpha did not activate Akt and activated these other kinases with kinetics distinct from those evident in NRG-1 beta-stimulated cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings suggest that NRG-1 beta enhances MPNST migration and that NRG-1 beta and NRG-1 alpha differentially modulate this process.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sca-1+ stem cell survival and engraftment in the infarcted heart: dual role for preconditioning-induced connexin-43.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>We report that elevated connexin-43 (Cx-43) in stem cells preconditioned with insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) is cytoprotective and reprograms the cells for cardiomyogenic differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS AND RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Sca-1+ cells were preconditioned with 100 nmol/L IGF-1 for 30 minutes followed by 8 hours of oxygen glucose deprivation to assess the cytoprotective effects of preconditioning.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>LDH release assay, cytochrome c release, and mitochondrial membrane potential assay showed improved survival of preconditioned Sca-1+ cells under oxygen glucose deprivation compared with nonpreconditioned Sca-1+ cells via PI3K/Akt-dependent caspase-3 downregulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We observed PI3K/Akt-dependent upregulation of cardiac-specific markers including MEF-2c (2.5-fold), GATA4 (3.1-fold), and Cx-43 (3.5-fold).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cx-43 inhibition with specific RNA interference reduced cell survival under oxygen glucose deprivation and after transplantation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In vivo studies were performed in a female rat model of acute myocardial infarction (n=78).</Gene>

<Gene>Animals were grouped to receive intramyocardially 70 microL Dulbecco modified Eagles medium without cells (group 1) or containing male 1 x 10(6) nonpreconditioned Sca-1+ cells (group 2) or preconditioned Sca-1+ (group 3) cells labeled with PKH26. Survival of the preconditioned Sca-1+ cells was 5.5-fold higher in group 3 compared with group 2 at 7 days after transplantation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Confocal imaging after actinin and Cx-43 specific immunostaining showed extensive engraftment and myogenic differentiation of preconditioned Sca-1+ cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Compared with group 2, group 3 showed increased blood vessel density (22.3+/-1.7 per microscopic field; P<0.0001) and attenuated infarction size (23.3+/-3.6%; P=0.002).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Heart function indices including ejection fraction (56.2+/-3.5; P=0.029) and fractional shortening (24.3+/-2.1; P=0.03) were improved in group 3 compared with group 2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Preconditioning with IGF-1 reprograms Sca-1+ for prosurvival signaling and cardiomyogenic differentiation with an important role for Cx-43 in this process.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hematopoietic- and neurologic-expressed sequence 1 (Hn1) depletion in B16.F10 melanoma cells promotes a differentiated phenotype that includes increased melanogenesis and cell cycle arrest.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Hematopoietic- and neurologic-expressed sequence 1 (Hn1) gene encodes a small protein that is highly conserved among species.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hn1 expression is upregulated in regenerating neural tissues, including the axotomized adult rodent facial motor nerve and dedifferentiating retinal pigment epithelial cells of the Japanese newt.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It is also expressed in numerous tissues during embryonic development as well as in regions of the adult brain that exhibit high plasticity.</Gene>
<Gene>Hn1 has also been reported as a marker for human ovarian carcinoma and it is expressed in high-grade human gliomas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study was directed toward understanding the function of Hn1 in a murine melanoma cell line.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hn1 mRNA and protein were identified in B16.F10 cells and in tumors formed from these cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of Hn1 protein expression with siRNA increased melanogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hn1-depleted cells expressed higher levels of the melanogenic proteins tyrosinase and Trp2 and an increased interaction between actin and Rab27a.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The in vitro cell growth rate of Hn1-depleted cells was significantly reduced due to G1/S cell cycle arrest.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This was consistent with a reduction in the phosphorylation of retinoblastoma protein as well as lower levels of p27 and increased expression of p21.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Decreased expression of c-Met, the receptor for hepatocyte growth factor, was also detected in the Hn1-depleted cells, however HGF-dependent stimulation of phosphorylated-ERK was unaffected.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hn1 depletion also led to increased basal levels of phosphorylated p38 MAPK, while basal ERK phosphorylation was reduced.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, Hn1-depleted cells had reduced expression of transcription factors MITF and USF-1, and increased expression of TFE3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data, coupled with reports on Hn1 expression in regeneration and development, suggest that Hn1 functions as a suppressor of differentiation in cells undergoing repair or proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A novel combination of factors, termed SPIE, which promotes dopaminergic neuron differentiation from human embryonic stem cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Stromal-Derived Inducing Activity (SDIA) is one of the most efficient methods of generating dopaminergic (DA) neurons from embryonic stem cells (ESC).</Gene>
<Gene>DA neuron induction can be achieved by co-culturing ESC with the mouse stromal cell lines PA6 or MS5.</Gene>
<Gene>The molecular nature of this effect, which has been termed "SDIA" is so far unknown.</Gene>
<Gene>Recently, we found that factors secreted by PA6 cells provided lineage-specific instructions to induce DA differentiation of human ESC (hESC).</Gene>
<Gene>METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS:</Gene>

<Gene>In the present study, we compared PA6 cells to various cell lines lacking the SDIA effect, and employed genome expression analysis to identify differentially-expressed signaling molecules.</Gene>

<Gene>Among the factors highly expressed by PA6 cells, and known to be associated with CNS development, were stromal cell-derived factor 1 (SDF-1/CXCL12), pleiotrophin (PTN), insulin-like growth factor 2 (IGF2), and ephrin B1 (EFNB1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>When these four factors, the combination of which was termed SPIE, were applied to hESC, they induced differentiation to TH-positive neurons in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RT-PCR and western blot analysis confirmed the expression of midbrain specific markers, including engrailed 1, Nurr1, Pitx3, and dopamine transporter (DAT) in cultures influenced by these four molecules.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Electrophysiological recordings showed that treatment of hESC with SPIE induced differentiation of neurons that were capable of generating action potentials and forming functional synaptic connections.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE:</Gene>
<Gene>The combination of SDF-1, PTN, IGF2, and EFNB1 mimics the DA phenotype-inducing property of SDIA and was sufficient to promote differentiation of hESC to functional midbrain DA neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings provide a method for differentiating hESC to form DA neurons, without a requirement for the use of animal-derived cell lines or products.</Gene>
<Gene>Protein kinase C alpha-dependent signaling mediates endometrial cancer cell growth and tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Endometrial cancer is the most common invasive gynecologic malignancy, yet molecular mechanisms and signaling pathways underlying its etiology and pathophysiology remain poorly characterized.</Gene>
<Gene>We sought to define a functional role for the protein kinase C (PKC) isoform, PKCalpha, in an established cell model of endometrial adenocarcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ishikawa cells depleted of PKCalpha protein grew slower, formed fewer colonies in anchorage-independent growth assays and exhibited impaired xenograft tumor formation in nude mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Consistent with impaired growth, PKCalpha knockdown increased levels of the cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitors p21(Cip1/WAF1) (p21) and p27(Kip1) (p27).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Despite the absence of functional phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN) protein in Ishikawa cells, PKCalpha knockdown reduced Akt phosphorylation at serine 473 and concomitantly inhibited phosphorylation of the Akt target, glycogen synthase kinase-3beta (GSK-3beta).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PKCalpha knockdown also resulted in decreased basal ERK phosphorylation and attenuated ERK activation following EGF stimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>p21 and p27 expression was not increased by treatment of Ishikawa cells with ERK and Akt inhibitors, suggesting that PKCalpha regulates CDK expression independently of Akt and ERK.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Immunohistochemical analysis of Grade 1 endometrioid adenocarcinoma revealed aberrant PKCalpha expression, with foci of elevated PKCalpha staining, not observed in normal endometrium.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These studies demonstrate a critical role for PKCalpha signaling in endometrial tumorigenesis by regulating expression of CDK inhibitors p21 and p27 and activation of Akt and ERK-dependent proliferative pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, targeting PKCalpha may provide novel therapeutic options in endometrial tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>H3 histamine receptor-mediated activation of protein kinase Calpha inhibits the growth of cholangiocarcinoma in vitro and in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Histamine regulates functions via four receptors (HRH1, HRH2, HRH3, and HRH4).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The d-myo-inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate (IP(3))/Ca(2+)/protein kinase C (PKC)/mitogen-activated protein kinase pathway regulates cholangiocarcinoma growth.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We evaluated the role of HRH3 in the regulation of cholangiocarcinoma growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of HRH3 in intrahepatic and extrahepatic cell lines, normal cholangiocytes, and human tissue arrays was measured.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In Mz-ChA-1 cells stimulated with (R)-(alpha)-(-)-methylhistamine dihydrobromide (RAMH), we measured (a) cell growth, (b) IP(3) and cyclic AMP levels, and (c) phosphorylation of PKC and mitogen-activated protein kinase isoforms.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Localization of PKCalpha was visualized by immunofluorescence in cell smears and immunoblotting for PKCalpha in cytosol and membrane fractions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Following knockdown of PKCalpha, Mz-ChA-1 cells were stimulated with RAMH before evaluating cell growth and extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK)-1/2 phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vivo experiments were done in BALB/c nude mice.</Gene>
<Gene>Mice were treated with saline or RAMH for 44 days and tumor volume was measured.</Gene>
<Gene>Tumors were excised and evaluated for proliferation, apoptosis, and expression of PKCalpha, vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)-A, VEGF-C, VEGF receptor 2, and VEGF receptor 3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HRH3 expression was found in all cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RAMH inhibited the growth of cholangiocarcinoma cells.</Gene>
<Gene>RAMH increased IP(3) levels and PKCalpha phosphorylation and decreased ERK1/2 phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RAMH induced a shift in the localization of PKCalpha expression from the cytosolic domain into the membrane region of Mz-ChA-1 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Silencing of PKCalpha prevented RAMH inhibition of Mz-ChA-1 cell growth and ablated RAMH effects on ERK1/2 phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vivo, RAMH decreased tumor growth and expression of VEGF and its receptors; PKCalpha expression was increased.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RAMH inhibits cholangiocarcinoma growth by PKCalpha-dependent ERK1/2 dephosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Modulation of PKCalpha by histamine receptors may be important in regulating cholangiocarcinoma growth.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sox2 is required for maintenance and differentiation of bronchiolar Clara, ciliated, and goblet cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The bronchioles of the murine lung are lined by a simple columnar epithelium composed of ciliated, Clara, and goblet cells that together mediate barrier function, mucociliary clearance and innate host defense, vital for pulmonary homeostasis.</Gene>

<Gene>In the present work, we demonstrate that expression of Sox2 in Clara cells is required for the differentiation of ciliated, Clara, and goblet cells that line the bronchioles of the postnatal lung.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The gene was selectively deleted in Clara cells utilizing Scgb1a1-Cre, causing the progressive loss of Sox2 in the bronchioles during perinatal and postnatal development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The rate of bronchiolar cell proliferation was decreased and associated with the formation of an undifferentiated, cuboidal-squamous epithelium lacking the expression of markers of Clara cells (Scgb1a1), ciliated cells (FoxJ1 and alpha-tubulin), and goblet cells (Spdef and Muc5AC).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By adulthood, bronchiolar cell numbers were decreased and Sox2 was absent in extensive regions of the bronchiolar epithelium, at which time residual Sox2 expression was primarily restricted to selective niches of CGRP staining neuroepithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Allergen-induced goblet cell differentiation and mucus production was absent in the respiratory epithelium lacking Sox2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro, Sox2 activated promoter-luciferase reporter constructs for differentiation markers characteristic of Clara, ciliated, and goblet cells, Scgb1a1, FoxJ1, and Agr2, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sox2 physically interacted with Smad3 and inhibited TGF-beta1/Smad3-mediated transcriptional activity in vitro, a pathway that negatively regulates proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sox2 is required for proliferation and differentiation of Clara cells that serve as the progenitor cells from which Clara, ciliated, and goblet cells are derived.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Activated Ras alters lens and corneal development through induction of distinct downstream targets.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Mammalian Ras genes regulate diverse cellular processes including proliferation and differentiation and are frequently mutated in human cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Tumor development in response to Ras activation varies between different tissues and the molecular basis for these variations are poorly understood.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The murine lens and cornea have a common embryonic origin and arise from adjacent regions of the surface ectoderm.</Gene>
<Gene>Activation of the fibroblast growth factor (FGF) signaling pathway induces the corneal epithelial cells to proliferate and the lens epithelial cells to exit the cell cycle.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The molecular mechanisms that regulate the differential responses of these two related tissues have not been defined.</Gene>
<Gene>We have generated transgenic mice that express a constitutively active version of human H-Ras in their lenses and corneas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: Ras transgenic lenses and corneal epithelial cells showed increased proliferation with concomitant increases in cyclin D1 and D2 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This initial increase in proliferation is sustained in the cornea but not in the lens epithelial cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Coincidentally, cdk inhibitors p27Kip1 and p57Kip2 were upregulated in the Ras transgenic lenses but not in the corneas.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Phospho-Erk1 and Erk2 levels were elevated in the lens but not in the cornea and Spry 1 and Spry 2, negative regulators of Ras-Raf-Erk signaling, were upregulated more in the corneal than in the lens epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both lens and corneal differentiation programs were sensitive to Ras activation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Ras transgenic embryos showed a distinctive alteration in the architecture of the lens pit.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Ras activation, though sufficient for upregulation of Prox1, a transcription factor critical for cell cycle exit and initiation of fiber differentiation, is not sufficient for induction of terminal fiber differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of Keratin 12, a marker of corneal epithelial differentiation, was reduced in the Ras transgenic corneas.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>Collectively, these results suggest that Ras activation a) induces distinct sets of downstream targets in the lens and cornea resulting in distinct cellular responses and b) is sufficient for initiation but not completion of lens fiber differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Association of adipocyte genes with ASP expression: a microarray analysis of subcutaneous and omental adipose tissue in morbidly obese subjects.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Prevalence of obesity is increasing to pandemic proportions.</Gene>
<Gene>However, obese subjects differ in insulin resistance, adipokine production and co-morbidities.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Based on fasting plasma analysis, obese subjects were grouped as Low Acylation Stimulating protein (ASP) and Triglyceride (TG) (LAT) vs High ASP and TG (HAT).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Subcutaneous (SC) and omental (OM) adipose tissues (n = 21) were analysed by microarray, and biologic pathways in lipid metabolism and inflammation were specifically examined.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS: LAT and HAT groups were matched in age, obesity, insulin, and glucose, and had similar expression of insulin-related genes (InsR, IRS-1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ASP related genes tended to be increased in the HAT group and were correlated (factor B, adipsin, complement C3, p < 0.01 each).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Differences between LAT and HAT group were almost exclusively in SC tissue, with little difference in OM tissue.</Gene>
<Gene>Increased C5L2 (p < 0.01), an ASP receptor, in HAT suggests a compensatory ASP pathway, associated with increased TG storage.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>HAT adipose tissue demonstrated increased lipid related genes for storage (CD36, DGAT1, DGAT2, SCD1, FASN, and LPL), lipolysis (HSL, CES1, perilipin), fatty acid binding proteins (FABP1, FABP3) and adipocyte differentiation markers (CEBPalpha, CEBPbeta, PPARgamma).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By contrast, oxidation related genes were decreased (AMPK, UCP1, CPT1, FABP7).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HAT subjects had increased anti-inflammatory genes TGFB1, TIMP1, TIMP3, and TIMP4 while proinflammatory PIG7 and MMP2 were also significantly increased; all genes, p < 0.025.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION: Taken together, the profile of C5L2 receptor, ASP gene expression and metabolic factors in adipose tissue from morbidly obese HAT subjects suggests a compensatory response associated with the increased plasma ASP and TG.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of GPR30 inhibits the growth of prostate cancer cells through sustained activation of Erk1/2, c-jun/c-fos-dependent upregulation of p21, and induction of G(2) cell-cycle arrest.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>G-protein-coupled receptor-30 (GPR30)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>shows estrogen-binding affinity and mediates non-genomic signaling of estrogen to regulate cell growth.</Gene>

<Gene>We here showed for the first time, in contrast to the reported promoting action of GPR30 on the growth of breast and ovarian cancer cells, that activation of GPR30 by the receptor-specific, non-estrogenic ligand G-1 inhibited the growth of androgen-dependent and androgen-independent prostate cancer (PCa) cells in vitro and PC-3 xenografts in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, G-1 elicited no growth or histological changes in the prostates of intact mice and did not inhibit growth in quiescent BPH-1, an immortalized benign prostatic epithelial cell line.</Gene>

<Gene>Treatment of PC-3 cells with G-1 induced cell-cycle arrest at the G(2) phase and reduced the expression of G(2)-checkpoint regulators (cyclin-A2, cyclin-B1, cdc25c, and cdc2) and phosphorylation of their common transcriptional regulator NF-YA in PC-3 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>With extensive use of siRNA-knockdown experiments and the MEK inhibitor PD98059 in this study, we dissected the mechanism underlying G-1-induced inhibition of PC-3 cell growth, which was mediated through GPR30, followed by sustained activation of Erk1/2 and a c-jun/c-fos-dependent upregulation of p21, resulting in the arrest of PC-3 growth at the G(2) phase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The discovery of this signaling pathway lays the foundation for future development of GPR30-based therapies for PCa.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>HOXB13, a target of DNMT3B, is methylated at an upstream CpG island, and functions as a tumor suppressor in primary colorectal tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: A hallmark of cancer cells is hypermethylation of CpG islands (CGIs), which probably arises from upregulation of one or more DNA methyltransferases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The purpose of this study was to identify the targets of DNMT3B, an essential DNA methyltransferase in mammals, in colon cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS:</Gene>
<Gene>Chromatin immunoprecipitation with DNMT3B specific antibody followed by CGI microarray identified genes with or without CGIs, repeat elements and genomic contigs in RKO cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ChIP-Chop analysis showed that the majority of the target genes including P16, DCC, DISC1, SLIT1, CAVEOLIN1, GNA11, TBX5, TBX18, HOXB13 and some histone variants, that harbor CGI in their promoters, were methylated in multiple colon cancer cell lines but not in normal colon epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Further, these genes were reactivated in RKO cells after treatment with 5-aza-2'-deoxycytidine, a DNA hypomethylating agent.</Gene>

<Gene>COBRA showed that the CGIs encompassing the promoter and/or coding region of DCC, TBX5, TBX18, SLIT1 were methylated in primary colorectal tumors but not in matching normal colon tissues whereas GNA11 was methylated in both.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MassARRAY analysis demonstrated that the CGI located approximately 4.5 kb upstream of HOXB13 +1 site was tumor-specifically hypermethylated in primary colorectal cancers and cancer cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>HOXB13</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>upstream CGI was partially hypomethylated in DNMT1(-/-)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>HCT cells but was almost methylation free in cells lacking both DNMT1 and DNMT3B. Analysis of tumor suppressor properties of two aberrantly methylated transcription factors, HOXB13 and TBX18, revealed that both inhibited growth and clonogenic survival of colon cancer cells in vitro, but only HOXB13 abolished tumor growth in nude mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE:</Gene>

<Gene>This is the first report that identifies several important tumor suppressors and transcription factors as direct DNMT3B targets in colon cancer and as potential biomarkers for this cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Further, this study shows that methylation at an upstream CGI of HOXB13 is unique to colon cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Forced homo- and heterodimerization of all gp130-type receptor complexes leads to constitutive ligand-independent signaling and cytokine-independent growth.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Naturally ligand independent constitutively active gp130 variants were described to be responsible for inflammatory hepatocellular adenomas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recently, we genetically engineered a ligand-independent constitutively active gp130 variant based on homodimerization of Jun leucine zippers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Because also heterodimeric complexes within the gp130 family may have tumorigenic potential, we seek to generate ligand-independent constitutively active heterodimers for all known gp130-receptor complexes based on IL-15/IL-15R alpha-sushi fusion proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ligand-independent heterodimerization of gp130 with WSX-1, LIFR, and OSMR and of OSMR with GPL led to constitutive, ligand-independent STAT1 and/or STAT3 and ERK1/2 phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, these receptor combinations induced transcription of the STAT3 target genes c-myc and Pim-1 and factor-independent growth of stably transduced Ba/F3-gp130 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we establish the IL-15/IL-15R alpha-sushi system as a new system to mimic constitutive and ligand-independent activation of homo- and heterodimeric receptor complexes, which might be applicable to other heterodimeric receptor families.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A mutated IL-15 protein, which was still able to bind the IL-15R alpha-sushi domain, but not to beta- and gamma-receptor chains, in combination with the 2A peptide technology may be used to translate our in vitro data into the in vivo situation to assess the tumorigenic potential of gp130-heterodimeric receptor complexes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The timing of perinatal hypoxia/ischemia events in term neonates: a retrospective autopsy study. HSPs, ORP-150 and COX2 are reliable markers to classify acute, perinatal events.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>The understanding of the cellular responses implicated in perinatal brain damages and the characterization of the various mechanisms involved might open new horizons for understanding the time of onset of a brain hypoxic-ischemic lesion and for effective therapeutic strategies.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>We performed an immunohistochemical investigation on brain and brainstem sections of 47 peripartum deaths.</Gene>

<Gene>The gradation and localization of the expression of antibodies such as TNFalpha, IL-1beta, IL-6, HSPs, beta APP, anti-TrypH, GAP43, GFAP, COX2, ORP-150, could be correlated with an hypoxic-ischemic damage to document a significant correlation between response and the time of onset acute (</=8 hs) or non-acute (>/=8 hs </=48 hs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS AND DISCUSSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>In non-acute cases HSP70 reaction was prominent in the neuron cytoplasm, while in acute cases a mild reaction was evident in sporadic fields.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>HSP90 exhibited a similar pattern of positivity as HSP70.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In acute group, ORP150 expressed an intense reaction showing a granular pattern in the cytoplasm of the neurons in the cortex of the infarcted areas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In non-acute group the positive reaction was more intense in astrocytes and less extended in neurons.</Gene>
<Gene>COX2 reaction exhibited the strongest positive reaction in the neuronal cell bodies of acute cases, while a immunolabeling was prominent in the glial cytoplasm in the non-acute cases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS: Chaperones HSP70 and 90, ORP-150 reaction, and COX2 protein, have provided very interesting results.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results would suggest to the clinicians to extend the differential diagnosis of a too large perinatal hypoxic-ischemic insult category to delineate a more accurate chronological judgement.</Gene>
<Gene>Activation of the JNK signalling pathway by macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF) and dependence on CXCR4 and CD74.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK) is a member of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) family and controls essential processes such as inflammation, cell differentiation, and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>JNK signalling is triggered by extracellular signals such as cytokines and environmental stresses.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF) is a pleiotropic pro-inflammatory cytokine with chemokine-like functions in leukocyte recruitment and atherosclerosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MIF promotes MAPK signalling through ERK1/2, while it can either activate or inhibit JNK phosphorylation, depending on the cell type and underlying stimulation context.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MIF activities are mediated by non-cognate interactions with the CXC chemokine receptors CXCR2 and CXCR4 or by ligation of CD74, which is the cell surface expressed form of the class II invariant chain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ERK1/2 signalling stimulated by MIF is dependent on CD74, but the receptor pathway involved in MIF activation of the JNK pathway is unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we comprehensively characterize the stimulatory effect of MIF on the canonical JNK/c-Jun/AP-1 pathway in fibroblasts and T cell lines and identify the upstream signalling components.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Physiological concentrations of recombinant MIF triggered the phosphorylation of JNK and c-Jun and rapidly activated AP-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In T cells, MIF-mediated activation of the JNK pathway led to upregulated gene expression of the inflammatory chemokine CXCL8.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of JNK signalling by MIF involved the upstream kinases PI3K and SRC and was found to be dependent on CXCR4 and CD74.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together, these data show that the CXCR4/CD74/SRC/PI3K axis mediates a rapid and transient activation of the JNK pathway as triggered by the inflammatory cytokine MIF in T cells and fibroblasts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TLR1/2, TLR7, and TLR9 signals directly activate human peripheral blood naive and memory B cell subsets to produce cytokines, chemokines, and hematopoietic growth factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recently, it has been reported that using multiple signals, murine and human B cells secrete several cytokines with pro-inflammatory and immunoregulatory properties.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We present the first comprehensive analysis of 24 cytokines, chemokines, and hematopoietic growth factors production by purified human peripheral blood B cells (CD19+), and naive (CD19+CD27-) and memory (CD19+CD27+) B cells in response to direct and exclusive signaling provided by toll-like receptor (TLR) ligands Pam3CSK (TLR1/TLR2), Imiquimod (TLR7), and GpG-ODN2006 (TLR9).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>All three TLR ligands stimulated B cells (CD19+) to produce cytokines IL-1a, IL-1b, IL-6, TNF-a, IL-13, and IL-10, and chemokines MIP-1a, MIP-1b, MCP-1, IP-10, and IL-8.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, GM-CSF and G-CSF production was predominantly induced by TLR2 agonist.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Most cytokines/chemokines/hematopoietic growth factors were predominantly or exclusively produced by memory B cells, and in general, TLR2 signal was more powerful than signal provided viaTLR7 and TLR9.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>No significant secretion of eotaxin, IFN-a, IFN-g, IL-2, IL-3, IL-4, IL-5, IL-7, IL-15, IL-17, IL-12p40, IL-12p70, and TNF-b (lymphotoxin) was observed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data demonstrate that human B cells can be directly activated viaTLR1/TLR2, TLR7, and TLR9 to induce secretion of cytokines, chemokines, and hematopoietic growth factors and suggest a role of B cells in immune response against microbial pathogenesis and immune homeostasis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Severe polyposis in Apc(1322T) mice is associated with submaximal Wnt signalling and increased expression of the stem cell marker Lgr5.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND AND AIMS:</Gene>
<Gene>Adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) is a tumour suppressor gene mutated in the germline of patients with familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and somatically in most colorectal cancers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>APC mutations impair b-catenin degradation, resulting in increased Wnt signalling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The most frequent APC mutation is a codon 1309 truncation that is associated with severe FAP.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A previous study compared two mouse models of intestinal tumorigenesis, Apc(R850X) (Min) and Apc(1322T) (1322T), the latter a model of human codon 1309 changes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>1322T mice had more severe polyposis but, surprisingly, these tumours had lower levels of nuclear b-catenin than Min tumours.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The consequences of these different b-catenin levels were investigated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>Enterocytes were isolated from 1322T and Min tumours by microdissection and gene expression profiling was performed.</Gene>
<Gene>Differentially expressed Wnt targets and other stem cell markers were validated using quantitative PCR, in situ hybridisation and immunohistochemistry.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: As expected, lower nuclear b-catenin levels in 1322T lesions were associated with generally lower levels of Wnt target expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, expression of the Wnt target and stem cell marker Lgr5 was significantly higher in 1322T tumours than in Min tumours.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Other stem cell markers (Musashi1, Bmi1 and the Wnt target Cd44) were also at higher levels in 1322T tumours.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, expression of the Bmp antagonist Gremlin1 was higher in 1322T tumours, together with lower Bmp2 and Bmp4 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>The severe phenotype caused by truncation of Apc at codon 1322 is associated with an increased number of stem cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, a submaximal level of Wnt signalling favours the stem cell phenotype and this may promote tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A level of Wnt signalling exists that is too high for optimal tumour growth.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The kinesin superfamily protein KIF17 is regulated by the same transcription factor (NRF-1) as its cargo NR2B in neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
