text: <Gene>The kinesin superfamily of motor proteins is known to be ATP-dependent transporters of various types of cargoes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In neurons, KIF17 is found to transport vesicles containing the N-methyl-D-aspartate receptor NR2B subunit from the cell body specifically to the dendrites.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These subunits are intimately associated with glutamatergic neurotransmission as well as with learning and memory.</Gene>

<Gene>Glutamatergic synapses are highly energy-dependent, and recently we found that the same transcription factor, nuclear respiratory factor 1 (NRF-1), co-regulates energy metabolism (via its regulation of cytochrome c oxidase and other mitochondrial enzymes) and neurochemicals of glutamatergic transmission (NR1, NR2B, GluR2, and nNOS).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The present study tested our hypothesis that NRF-1 also transcriptionally regulates KIF17.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By means of in silico analysis, electrophoretic mobility shift and supershift assays, in vivo chromatin immunoprecipitation assays, promoter mutations, and real-time quantitative PCR, we found that NRF-1 (but not NRF-2) functionally regulates Kif17, but not Kif1a, gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NRF-1 binding sites on Kif17 gene are highly conserved among mice, rats, and humans.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Silencing of NRF-1 with small interference RNA blocked the up-regulation of Kif17 mRNA and proteins (and of Grin1 and Grin2b) induced by KCl-mediated depolarization, whereas over-expressing NRF-1 rescued these transcripts and proteins from being suppressed by TTX.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, NRF-1 co-regulates oxidative enzymes that generate energy and neurochemicals that consume energy related to glutamatergic neurotransmission, such as KIF17, NR1, and NR2B, thereby ensuring that energy production matches energy utilization at the molecular and cellular levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Renal pro-apoptotic proteins are reduced by growth hormone resistance but not by visceral fat removal.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Growth hormone (GH) receptor knockout (GHRKO) mice are highly insulin sensitive and long-lived.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Surgical visceral fat removal (VFR) improves insulin signaling in normal mice and rats and extends longevity in rats.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have previously demonstrated decreased expression of certain pro-apoptotic genes in kidneys of GHRKO mice and suggested that this could contribute to the increased longevity of these animals.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The aim of the present study was to examine the level of the following proteins: caspase-3, caspase-9, caspase-8, bax, bad, phospho-bad, bcl-2, Smac/DIABLO, Apaf-1, phospho-p53 (pp53) and cytochrome c in male GHRKO and normal (N) mice subjected to VFR or sham surgery, at approximately six months of age.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The kidneys were collected two months after VFR.</Gene>
<Gene>Caspase-3, caspase-8, bax, bad, Smac/DIABLO, Apaf-1 and pp53 levels were decreased in GHRKO mice as compared to N animals.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VFR did not change the level of any of the examined proteins.</Gene>

<Gene>The decreased renal levels of pro-apoptotic proteins could contribute to the extended life-span caused by targeted disruption of the GH receptor gene but are apparently not involved in mediating the effects of VFR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Deletion of growth hormone receptor gene but not visceral fat removal decreases expression of apoptosis-related genes in the kidney-potential mechanism of lifespan extension.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mice homozygous for the targeted disruption of the growth hormone (GH) receptor (Ghr) gene (GH receptor knockout; GHRKO; KO) are hypoinsulinemic, highly insulin sensitive, normoglycemic, and long-lived.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Visceral fat removal (VFR) is a surgical intervention which improves insulin signaling in normal (N) mice and rats and extends longevity in rats.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have previously demonstrated decreased expression level of certain pro-apoptotic genes in skeletal muscles and suggested that this may contribute to the regulation of longevity in GHRKO mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Alterations in apoptosis-related genes expression in the kidneys also may potentially lead to lifespan extension.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this context, we decided to examine the renal expression of the following genes: caspase-3, caspase-9, caspase-8, bax, bad, bcl-2, Smac/DIABLO, Apaf-1, p53, and cytochrome c1 (cyc1) in male GHRKO and N mice subjected to VFR or sham surgery, at approximately 6 months of age.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The kidneys were collected 2 months after VFR.</Gene>
<Gene>As a result, caspase-3, caspase-9, and bax expressions were decreased in KO mice as compared to N animals.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expressions of Smac/DIABLO, caspase-8, bcl-2, bad, and p53 did not differ between KOs and N mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VFR did not change the expression of the examined genes in KO or N mice.</Gene>
<Gene>In conclusion, endocrine abnormalities in GHRKO mice result in decreased expression of pro-apoptotic genes and VFR did not alter the examined genes expression in N and KO mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data are consistent with a model in which alterations of GH signaling and/or insulin sensitivity lead to increased lifespan mediated by decreased renal expression of pro-apoptotic genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IL-1a mediated chorioamnionitis induces depletion of FoxP3+ cells and ileal inflammation in the ovine fetal gut.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Endotoxin induced chorioamnionitis increases IL-1 and provokes an inflammatory response in the fetal ileum that interferes with intestinal maturation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the present study, we tested in an ovine chorioamnionitis model whether IL-1 is a major cytokine driving the inflammatory response in the fetal ileum.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHOD:</Gene>

<Gene>Sheep bearing singleton fetuses received a single intraamniotic injection of recombinant ovine IL-1a at 7, 3 or 1 d before caesarian delivery at 125 days gestational age (term = 150 days).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: 3 and 7 d after IL-1a administration, intestinal mRNA levels for IL-4, IL-10, IFN-g and TNF-a were strongly elevated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Numbers of CD3+ and CD4+ T-lymphocytes and myeloidperoxidase+ cells were increased whereas FoxP3+ T-cells were detected at low frequency.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This increased proinflammatory state was associated with ileal mucosal barrier loss as demonstrated by decreased levels of the intestinal fatty acid binding protein and disruption of the tight junctional protein ZO-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>

<Gene>Intraamniotic IL-1a causes an acute detrimental inflammatory response in the ileum, suggesting that induction of IL-1 is a critical element in the pathophysiological effects of endotoxin induced chorioamnionitis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A disturbed balance between T-effector and FoxP3+ cells may contribute to this process.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Aberrant expression of costimulatory molecules in splenocytes of the mevalonate kinase-deficient mouse model of human hyper-IgD syndrome (HIDS).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>OBJECTIVE:</Gene>
<Gene>We sought to determine the activation status and proliferative capacities of splenic lymphocyte populations from a mevalonate kinase-deficient mouse model of hyper-IgD syndrome (HIDS).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We previously reported that murine mevalonate kinase gene ablation was embryonic lethal for homozygous mutants while heterozygotes (Mvk (+/-)) demonstrated several phenotypic features of human HIDS including increased serum levels of IgD, IgA, and TNFa, temperature dysregulation, hematological abnormalities, and splenomegaly.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS AND RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>Flow cytometric analysis of cell surface activation markers on T and B lymphocytes, and macrophage populations, demonstrated aberrant expression of B7 glycoproteins in all splenic cell types studied.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Differences in expression levels between Mvk (+/-) and Mvk (+/+) littermate controls were observed in both the basal state (unstimulated) and after Concanavalin A (Con-A) stimulation in vitro of whole splenocyte cultures.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In Mvk (+/-) CD4 and CD8 T cells, alterations in expression of CD25, CD80, CD152, and CD28 were observed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mvk (+/-) splenic macrophages expressed altered levels of CD80, CD86, CD40, and CD11c while Mvk (+/-) B lymphocytes had differential expression of CD40, CD80, and CD86.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mvk (+/-) splenocyte subpopulations also exhibited altered proliferative capacities in response to in vitro stimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>

<Gene>We postulate that imbalances in the expression of cell surface proteins necessary for activation, proliferation, and regulation of the intensity and duration of an immune response may result in defective T cell activation, proliferation, and effector functions in our model and potentially in human HIDS.</Gene>
<Gene>Oxidized LDL receptor 1 (OLR1) as a possible link between obesity, dyslipidemia and cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recent studies have linked expression of lectin-like ox-LDL receptor 1 (OLR1) to tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We analyzed microarray data from Olr1 knockout (KO) and wild type (WT) mice for genes involved in cellular transformation and evaluated effects of OLR1 over-expression in normal mammary epithelial cells (MCF10A) and breast cancer cells (HCC1143) in terms of gene expression, migration, adhesion and transendothelial migration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Twenty-six out of 238 genes were inhibited in tissues of OLR1 KO mice; the vast majority of OLR1 sensitive genes contained NF-kB binding sites in their promoters.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Further studies revealed broad inhibition of NF-kB target genes outside of the transformation-associated gene pool, with enrichment themes of defense response, immune response, apoptosis, proliferation, and wound healing.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Transcriptome of Olr1 KO mice also revealed inhibition of de novo lipogenesis, rate-limiting enzymes fatty acid synthase (Fasn), stearoyl-CoA desaturase (Scd1) and ELOVL family member 6 (Elovl6), as well as lipolytic phospholipase A2 group IVB (Pla2g4b).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In studies comparing MCF10A and HCC1143, the latter displayed 60% higher OLR1 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Forced over-expression of OLR1 resulted in upregulation of NF-kB (p65) and its target pro-oncogenes involved in inhibition of apoptosis (BCL2, BCL2A1, TNFAIP3) and regulation of cell cycle (CCND2) in both cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Basal expression of FASN, SCD1 and PLA2G4B, as well as lipogenesis transcription factors PPARA, SREBF2 and CREM, was higher in HCC1143 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Over-expression of OLR1 in HCC1143 cells also enhanced cell migration, without affecting their adherence to TNFa-activated endothelium or transendothelial migration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>On the other hand, OLR1 neutralizing antibody inhibited both adhesion and transmigration of untreated HCC1143 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that OLR1 may act as an oncogene by activation of NF-kB target genes responsible for proliferation, migration and inhibition of apoptosis and de novo lipogenesis genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A small peptide modeled after the NRAGE repeat domain inhibits XIAP-TAB1-TAK1 signaling for NF-kB activation and apoptosis in P19 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In normal growth and development, apoptosis is necessary to shape the central nervous system and to eliminate excess neurons which are not required for innervation.</Gene>
<Gene>In some diseases, however, apoptosis can be either overactive as in some neurodegenerative disorders or severely attenuated as in the spread of certain cancers.</Gene>
<Gene>Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) transmit signals for regulating cell growth, differentiation, and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Responding to BMP receptors stimulated from BMP ligands, neurotrophin receptor-mediated MAGE homolog (NRAGE) binds and functions with the XIAP-TAK1-TAB1 complex to activate p38(MAPK) and induces apoptosis in cortical neural progenitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NRAGE contains a unique repeat domain that is only found in human, mouse, and rat homologs that we theorize is pivotal in its BMP MAPK role.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Previously, we showed that deletion of the repeat domain inhibits apoptosis, p38(MAPK) phosphorylation, and caspase-3 cleavage in P19 neural progenitor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also showed that the XIAP-TAB1-TAK1 complex is dependent on NRAGE for IKK-a/b phosphorylation and NF-kB activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>XIAP is a major inhibitor of caspases, the main executioners of apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although it has been shown previously that NRAGE binds to the RING domain of XIAP, it has not been determined which NRAGE domain binds to XIAP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we used fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) to determine that there is a strong likelihood of a direct interaction between NRAGE and XIAP occurring at NRAGE's unique repeat domain which we also attribute to be the domain responsible for downstream signaling of NF-kB and activating IKK subunits.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>From these results, we designed a small peptide modeled after the NRAGE repeat domain which we have determined inhibits NF-kB activation and apoptosis in P19 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These intriguing results illustrate that the paradigm of the NRAGE repeat domain may hold promising therapeutic strategies in developing pharmaceutical solutions for combating harmful diseases involving excessive downstream BMP signaling, including apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HIV-1 Tat activates indoleamine 2,3 dioxygenase in murine organotypic hippocampal slice cultures in a p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have established that activation of the tryptophan degrading enzyme indoleamine 2,3 dioxygenase (IDO) mediates the switch from cytokine-induced sickness behavior to depressive-like behavior.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Because human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) Tat protein causes depressive-like behavior in mice, we investigated its ability to activate IDO in organotypic hippocampal slice cultures (OHSCs) derived from neonatal C57BL/6 mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>Depressive-like behavior in C57BL/6J mice was assessed by the forced swim test.</Gene>
<Gene>Expression of cytokines and IDO mRNA in OHSCs was measured by real-time RT-PCR and cytokine protein was measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>p38 MAPK phosphorylation was analyzed by western blot.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: Intracerebroventricular (i.c.v.) administration of Tat (40 ng) induced depressive-like behavior in the absence of sickness.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Addition of Tat (40 ng/slice) to the medium of OHSCs induced IDO steady-state mRNA that peaked at 6 h. This effect was potentiated by pretreatment with IFNg.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tat also induced the synthesis and release of TNFa and IL-6 protein in the supernatant of the slices and increased expression of the inducible isoform of nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) and the serotonin transporter (SERT).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tat had no effect on endogenous synthesis of IFNg.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To explore the mechanisms of Tat-induced IDO expression, slices were pretreated with the p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) inhibitor SB 202190 for 30 min before Tat treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SB 202190 significantly decreased IDO expression induced by Tat, and this effect was accompanied by a reduction of Tat-induced expression of TNFa, IL-6, iNOS and SERT.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION: These data establish that Tat induces IDO expression via an IFNg-independent mechanism that depends upon activation of p38 MAPK.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Targeting IDO itself or the p38 MAPK signaling pathway could provide a novel therapy for comorbid depressive disorders in HIV-1-infected patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nemo-like kinase inhibits osteoblastogenesis by suppressing bone morphogenetic protein and WNT canonical signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The bone morphogenetic protein/Signaling mothers against decapentaplegic (BMP/Smad) and the WNT signaling pathways regulate the commitment of mesenchymal cells to the osteoblastic lineage.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nemo-like kinase (Nlk) is an evolutionary conserved kinase that suppresses Smad transactivation and WNT canonical signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, it is not clear whether these effects of Nlk have any consequence on the differentiation of mammalian cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To study the function of Nlk during the commitment of ST-2 bone marrow stromal cells to the osteoblastic fate, Nlk was downregulated by RNA interference (RNAi), following transfection of a specific small interfering (si)RNA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nlk downregulation increased alkaline phosphatase and osteocalcin expression and sensitized ST-2 cells to the effects of BMP2 and WNT3 on alkaline phosphatase mRNA expression and activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Accordingly, Nlk downregulation enhanced the effect of BMP2 on the transactivation of the BMP/Smad reporter construct 12xSBE-Oc-pGL3, and on the levels of phosphorylated Smad1/5/8, whereas it did not affect the transactivation of the transforming growth factor-b/Smad reporter pSBE-Luc.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nlk downregulation sensitized ST-2 cells to the effects of WNT3 on the transactivation of the WNT/T-cell factor (Tcf) reporter construct 16xTCF-Luc, whereas it did not affect cytosolic b-catenin levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To understand the function of Nlk in cells committed to the osteoblastic lineage, Nlk was suppressed by RNAi in primary calvarial osteoblasts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Downregulation of Nlk increased alkaline phosphatase and osteocalcin transcripts and sensitized osteoblasts to the effects of BMP2 on alkaline phosphatase activity and Smad1/5/8 transactivation and phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, Nlk suppresses osteoblastogenesis by opposing BMP/Smad and WNT canonical signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Blockade of Notch ligand d1 promotes allograft survival by inhibiting alloreactive Th1 cells and cytotoxic T cell generation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The Notch signaling pathway has been recently shown to contribute to T cell differentiation in vitro.</Gene>
<Gene>However, the in vivo function of Notch signaling in transplantation remains unknown.</Gene>
<Gene>In this study, we investigated the importance of Delta1 in regulating the alloimmune response in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Delta1 expression was upregulated on dendritic cells and monocytes/macrophages upon transplantation in a BALB/c into B6 vascularized cardiac transplant model.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Whereas administration of anti-Delta1 mAb only slightly delayed survival of cardiac allografts in this fully MHC-mismatched model, it significantly prolonged graft survival in combination with single-dose CTLA4-Ig or in CD28 knockout recipients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The prolongation of allograft survival was associated with Th2 polarization and a decrease in Th1 and granzyme B-producing cytotoxic T cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The survival benefit of Delta1 blockade was abrogated after IL-4 neutralization and in STAT6KO recipients, but was maintained in STAT4KO recipients, reinforcing the key role of Th2 cell development in its graft-prolonging effects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To our knowledge, these data demonstrate for the first time an important role of Delta1 in alloimmunity, identifying Delta1 ligand as a potential novel target for immunomodulation in transplantation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Acute myeloid leukemia of donor origin after allogeneic stem cell transplantation from a sibling who harbors germline XPD and XRCC3 homozygous polymorphisms.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A 54-year-old woman was diagnosed with infiltrative ductal breast carcinoma.</Gene>
<Gene>Two years after treatment, the patient developed an acute myeloid leukemia (AML) which harbored del(11q23) in 8% of the blast cells.</Gene>
<Gene>The patient was submitted for allogeneic stem cell transplantation (aSCT) from her HLA-compatible sister.</Gene>

<Gene>Ten months after transplantation, she relapsed with an AML with basophilic maturation characterized by CD45(low) CD33(high), CD117+, CD13(-/+), HLA Dr(high), CD123(high), and CD203c+ blast cells lacking expression of CD7, CD10, CD34, CD15, CD14, CD56, CD36, CD64, and cytoplasmic tryptase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Karyotype analysis showed the emergence of a new clone with t(2;14) and FISH analysis indicated the presence of MLL gene rearrangement consistent with del(11q23).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, AML blast cell DNA tested with microsatellite markers showed the same pattern as the donor's, suggesting that this AML emerged from donor cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Additionally, polymorphisms of the XPA, XPD, XRCC1, XRCC3 and RAD51 DNA repair genes revealed three unfavorable alleles with low DNA repair capacity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In summary, we report the first case of AML involving XPD and XRCC3 polymorphisms from donor origin following allogeneic stem cell transplantation and highlight the potential need for careful analysis of DNA repair gene polymorphisms in selecting candidate donors prior to allogeneic stem cell transplantation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of novel opsins and intrinsic light responses in the mammalian retinal ganglion cell line RGC-5. Presence of OPN5 in the rat retina.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The vertebrate retina is known to contain three classes of photoreceptor cells: cones and rods responsible for vision, and intrinsically photoresponsive retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) involved in diverse non-visual functions such as photic entrainment of daily rhythms and pupillary light responses.</Gene>

<Gene>In this paper we investigated the potential intrinsic photoresponsiveness of the rat RGC line, RGC-5, by testing for the presence of visual and non-visual opsins and assessing expression of the immediate-early gene protein c-Fos and changes in intracellular Ca(2+) mobilization in response to brief light pulses.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cultured RGC-5 cells express a number of photopigment mRNAs such as retinal G protein coupled receptor (RGR), encephalopsin/panopsin (Opn3), neuropsin (Opn5) and cone opsin (Opn1mw) but not melanopsin (Opn4) or rhodopsin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Opn5 immunoreactivity was observed in RGC-5 cells and in the inner retina of rat, mainly localized in the ganglion cell layer (GCL).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, white light pulses of different intensities and durations elicited changes both in intracellular Ca(2+) levels and in the induction of c-Fos protein in RGC-5 cell cultures.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The results demonstrate that RGC-5 cells expressing diverse putative functional photopigments display intrinsic photosensitivity which accounts for the photic induction of c-Fos protein and changes in intracellular Ca(2+) mobilization.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The presence of Opn5 in the GCL of the rat retina suggests the existence of a novel type of photoreceptor cell.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MUC13 mucin augments pancreatic tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The high death rate of pancreatic cancer is attributed to the lack of reliable methods for early detection and underlying molecular mechanisms of its aggressive pathogenesis.</Gene>
<Gene>Although MUC13, a newly identified transmembrane mucin, is known to be aberrantly expressed in ovarian and gastro-intestinal cancers, its role in pancreatic cancer is unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Herein, we investigated the expression profile and functions of MUC13 in pancreatic cancer progression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression profile of MUC13 in pancreatic cancer was investigated using a recently generated monoclonal antibody (clone PPZ0020) and pancreatic tissue microarrays.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of MUC13 was significantly (P < 0.005) higher in cancer samples compared with normal/nonneoplastic pancreatic tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>For functional analyses, full-length MUC13 was expressed in MUC13 null pancreatic cancer cell lines, MiaPaca and Panc1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MUC13 overexpression caused a significant (P < 0.05) increase in cell motility, invasion, proliferation, and anchorage-dependent or -independent clonogenicity while decreasing cell-cell and cell-substratum adhesion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Exogenous MUC13 expression significantly (P < 0.05) enhanced pancreatic tumor growth and reduced animal survival in a xenograft mouse model.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These tumorigenic characteristics correlated with the upregulation/phosphorylation of HER2, p21-activated kinase 1 (PAK1), extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK), Akt, and metastasin (S100A4), and the suppression of p53.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, suppression of MUC13 in HPAFII pancreatic cancer cells by short hairpin RNA resulted in suppression of tumorigenic characteristics, repression of HER2, PAK1, ERK, and S100A4, and upregulation of p53.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MUC13 suppression also significantly (P < 0.05) reduced tumor growth and increased animal survival.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results imply a role of MUC13 in pancreatic cancer and suggest its potential use as a diagnostic and therapeutic target.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Loss of myeloid related protein-8/14 exacerbates cardiac allograft rejection.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>The calcium-binding proteins myeloid-related protein (MRP)-8 (S100A8) and MRP-14 (S100A9) form MRP-8/14 heterodimers (S100A8/A9, calprotectin) that regulate myeloid cell function and inflammatory responses and serve as early serum markers for monitoring acute allograft rejection.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Despite functioning as a proinflammatory mediator, the pathophysiological role of MRP-8/14 complexes in cardiovascular disease is incompletely defined.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study investigated the role of MRP-8/14 in cardiac allograft rejection using MRP-14(-/-) mice that lack MRP-8/14 complexes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS AND RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>We examined parenchymal rejection after major histocompatibility complex class II allomismatched cardiac transplantation (bm12 donor heart and B6 recipients) in wild-type (WT) and MRP-14(-/-) recipients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Allograft survival averaged 5.9+2.9 weeks (n=10) in MRP-14(-/-) recipients compared with >12 weeks (n=15; P<0.0001) in WT recipients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Two weeks after transplantation, allografts in MRP-14(-/-) recipients had significantly higher parenchymal rejection scores (2.8+0.8; n=8) than did WT recipients (0.8+0.8; n=12; P<0.0001).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Compared with WT recipients, allografts in MRP-14(-/-) recipients had significantly increased T-cell and macrophage infiltration and increased mRNA levels of interferon-g and interferon-g-associated chemokines (CXCL9, CXCL10, and CXCL11), interleukin-6, and interleukin-17 with significantly higher levels of Th17 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MRP-14(-/-) recipients also had significantly more lymphocytes in the adjacent para-aortic lymph nodes than did WT recipients (cells per lymph node: 23.7+0.7x10(5) for MRP-14(-/-) versus 6.0+0.2x10(5) for WT; P<0.0001).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The dendritic cells (DCs) of the MRP-14(-/-) recipients of bm12 hearts expressed significantly higher levels of the costimulatory molecules CD80 and CD86 than did those of WT recipients 2 weeks after transplantation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mixed leukocyte reactions with allo-endothelial cell-primed MRP-14(-/-)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>DCs resulted in significantly higher antigen-presenting function than reactions using WT DCs.</Gene>
<Gene>Ovalbumin-primed MRP-14(-/-) DCs augmented proliferation of OT-II (ovalbumin-specific T cell receptor transgenic) CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T cells with increased interleukin-2 and interferon-g production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cardiac allografts of B6 major histocompatibility complex class II(-/-) hosts and of B6 WT hosts receiving MRP-14(-/-)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DCs had significantly augmented inflammatory cell infiltration and accelerated allograft rejection compared with WT DCs from transferred recipient allografts.</Gene>

<Gene>Bone marrow-derived MRP-14(-/-) DCs infected with MRP-8 and MRP-14 retroviral vectors showed significantly decreased CD80 and CD86 expression compared with controls, indicating that MRP-8/14 regulates B7-costimulatory molecule expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Our results indicate that MRP-14 regulates B7 molecule expression and reduces antigen presentation by DCs and subsequent T-cell priming.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The absence of MRP-14 markedly increased T-cell activation and exacerbated allograft rejection, indicating a previously unrecognized role for MRP-14 in immune cell biology.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TBX21 and HLX1 polymorphisms influence cytokine secretion at birth.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>TBX21 (T cell specific T-box transcription factor) and HLX1 (H.20-like homeobox 1) are crucial transcription factors of T(H)1-cells, inducing their differentiation and suppressing T(H)2 commitment, particularly important for early life immune development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study investigated the influence of TBX21 and HLX1 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs), which have previously been shown to be associated with asthma, on T(H)1/T(H)2 lineage cytokines at birth.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS AND FINDINGS:</Gene>
<Gene>Cord blood mononuclear cells (CBMCs) of 200 neonates were genotyped for two TBX21 and three HLX1 SNPs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CBMCs were stimulated with innate (Lipid A, LpA; Peptidoglycan, Ppg), adaptive stimuli (house dust mite Dermatophagoides pteronyssinus 1, Derp1) or mitogen (phytohemagglutinin, PHA).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cytokines, T-cells and mRNA expression of T(H)1/T(H)2-related genes were assessed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Atopic diseases during the first 3 years of life were assessed by questionnaire answered by the parents.</Gene>
<Gene>Carriers of TBX21 promoter SNP rs17250932 and HLX1 promoter SNP rs2738751 showed reduced or trendwise reduced (p<0.07) IL-5, IL-13 and TNF-a secretion after LpA-stimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Carriers of HLX1 SNP rs2738751 had lower IL-13 levels following Ppg-stimulation (p = 0.08).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Carriers of HLX1 exon 1 SNP rs12141189 showed increased IL-5 (LpA, p = 0.007;</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ppg, p = 0.10), trendwise increased IL-13 (LpA), higher GM-CSF (LpA/Ppg, p<0.05) and trendwise decreased IFN-g secretion (Derp1+LpA-stimulation, p = 0.1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Homozygous carriers of HLX1 promoter SNP rs3806325 showed increased IL-13 and IL-6 (unstimulated, p<0.03).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In carriers of TBX21 intron 3 SNP rs11079788 no differences in cytokine secretion were observed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>mRNA expression of T(H)1/T(H)2-related genes partly correlated with cytokines at protein level.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>TBX21 SNP rs11079788 carriers developed less symptoms of atopic dermatitis at 3 years of age (p = 0.03).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>Polymorphisms in TBX21 and HLX1 influenced primarily IL-5 and IL-13 secretion after LpA-stimulation in cord blood suggesting that genetic variations in the transcription factors essential for the T(H)1-pathway may contribute to modified T(H)2-immune responses already early in life.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Further follow-up of the cohort is required to study the polymorphisms' relevance for immune-mediated diseases such as childhood asthma.</Gene>
<Gene>IL-10 deficiency blocks the ability of LPS to regulate expression of tolerance-related molecules on dendritic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interleukin-10 (IL-10) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that plays an important role in regulating the local inflammatory immune response, but regulatory mechanisms of this cytokine have not been fully elucidated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we demonstrate that IL-10 deficiency renders LPS treatment ineffective in regulating the expression of CD40, CD80, CD86, B7-H2, and B7-DC on dendritic cells (DCs) and blocks upregulation of IL-27.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This inability to respond to LPS was found in both IL-10(-/-) bone marrow derived and splenic DCs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Compared with wild-type DCs, IL-10(-/-) DCs expressed similar levels of TLR4 and CD14, but produced less LPS-binding protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The deficiency in LPS-binding protein production may explain the failure of IL-10(-/-) DCs to respond normally to LPS.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, lack of IL-10 modulated the proportions of CD11c(+) CD8(+) and CD11c(+) B220(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DCs, which play an important role in local inflammatory responses and tolerance.</Gene>
<Gene>IL-10 deficiency also blocked expression of galectin-1, CD205, and CD103, which are necessary for central and peripheral tolerance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While they did not respond to LPS, IL-10(-/-) DCs produced increased levels of IL-6 and CCL4 after TNF-a treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together, our results demonstrate that IL-10 deficiency affects the immune functions of DCs, which may contribute to the increased severity of autoimmune diseases seen in IL-10(-/-) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>EGCG inhibits growth of human pancreatic tumors orthotopically implanted in Balb C nude mice through modulation of FKHRL1/FOXO3a and neuropilin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human pancreatic cancer is currently one of the fourth leading causes of cancer-related mortality with a 5-year survival rate of less than 5 %.</Gene>
<Gene>Since pancreatic carcinoma is largely refractory to conventional therapies, there is a strong medical need for the development of novel and innovative cancer preventive strategies.</Gene>
<Gene>The forkhead transcription factors of the O class (FOXO) play a major role in cell proliferation, angiogenesis, metastasis, and tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The objectives of this study were to examine whether FKHRL1/FOXO3a modulates antitumor activity of (-)-epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG), an active ingredient in green tea, in pancreatic cancer model in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PANC-1 cells were orthotopically implanted into Balb c nude mice and gavaged with EGCG after tumor formation.</Gene>
<Gene>Cell proliferation and apoptosis were measured by Ki67 and TUNEL staining, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of PI3K, AKT, ERK, and FOXO3a/FKHRL1 and its target genes were measured by the western blot analysis and/or q-RT-PCR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>FOXO-DNA binding was measured by gel shift assay.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>EGCG-treated mice showed significant inhibition in tumor growth which was associated with reduced phosphorylation of ERK, PI3K, AKT, and FKHRL1/FOXO3a, and modulation of FOXO target genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>EGCG induced apoptosis by upregulating Bim and activating caspase-3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>EGCG modulated markers of cell cycle (p27/KIP1), angiogenesis (CD31, VEGF, IL-6, IL-8, SEMA3F, and HIF1a), and metastasis (MMP2 and MMP7).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The inhibition of VEGF by EGCG was associated with suppression of neuropilin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>EGCG inhibited epithelial-mesenchymal transition by upregulating the expression of E-cadherin and inhibiting the expression of N-cadherin and Zeb1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest that EGCG inhibits pancreatic cancer orthotopic tumor growth, angiogenesis, and metastasis which are associated with inhibition of PI3K/AKT and ERK pathways and activation of FKHRL1/FOXO3a.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As a conclusion, EGCG can be used for the prevention and/or treatment of pancreatic cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>N-Myc and L-Myc are essential for hair cell formation but not maintenance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sensorineural hearing loss results from damage to the hair cells of the organ of Corti and is irreversible in mammals.</Gene>
<Gene>While hair cell regeneration may prove to be the ideal therapy after hearing loss, prevention of initial hair cell loss could provide even more benefit at a lower cost.</Gene>

<Gene>Previous studies have shown that the deletion of Atoh1 results in embryonic loss of hair cells while the absence of Barhl1, Gfi1, and Pou4f3 leads to the progressive loss of hair cells in newborn mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We recently reported that in the early embryonic absence of N-Myc (using Pax2-Cre), hair cells in the organ of Corti develop and remain until at least seven days after birth, with subsequent progressive loss.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, N-Myc plays a role in hair cell viability; however, it is unclear if this is due to its early expression in hair cell precursors and throughout the growing otocyst as it functions through proliferation or its late expression exclusively in differentiated hair cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the related family member L-Myc is mostly co-expressed in the ear, including in differentiated hair cells, but its function has not been studied and could be partially redundant to N-Myc.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To test for a long-term function of the Mycs in differentiated hair cells, we generated nine unique genotypes knocking out N-Myc and/or L-Myc after initial formation of hair cells using the well-characterized Atoh1-Cre.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We tested functionality of the auditory and vestibular systems at both P21 and four months of age and under the administration of the ototoxic drug cisplatin.</Gene>
<Gene>We conclude that neither N-Myc nor L-Myc is likely to play important roles in long-term hair cell maintenance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, it is likely that the late-onset loss of hair cells resulting from early deletion of the Mycs leads to an unsustainable developmental defect.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sphingosine kinase 1 is required for mesothelioma cell proliferation: role of histone acetylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Malignant pleural mesothelioma (MPM) is a devastating disease with an overall poor prognosis.</Gene>

<Gene>Despite the recent advances in targeted molecular therapies, there is a clear and urgent need for the identification of novel mesothelioma targets for the development of highly efficacious therapeutics.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS:</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, we report that the expression of Sphingosine Kinase 1 (SphK1) protein was preferentially elevated in MPM tumor tissues (49 epithelioid and 13 sarcomatoid) compared to normal tissue (n = 13).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, we also observed significantly elevated levels of SphK1 and SphK2 mRNA and SphK1 protein expression in MPM cell lines such as H2691, H513 and H2461 compared to the non-malignant mesothelial Met5 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The underlying mechanism appears to be mediated by SphK1 induced upregulation of select gene transcription programs such as that of CBP/p300 and PCAF, two histone acetyl transferases (HAT), and the down regulation of cell cycle dependent kinase inhibitor genes such as p27Kip1 and p21Cip1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, using immunoprecipitates of anti-acetylated histone antibody from SphK inhibitor, SphK-I2 treated Met5A and H2691 cell lysates, we also showed activation of other cell proliferation related genes, such as Top2A (DNA replication), AKB (chromosome remodeling and mitotic spindle formation), and suppression of p21 CIP1 and p27KIP1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The CDK2, HAT1 and MYST2 were, however, unaffected in the above study.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using SphK inhibitor and specific siRNA targeting either SphK1 or SphK2, we also unequivocally established that SphK1, but not SphK2, promotes H2691 mesothelioma cell proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using a multi-walled carbon nanotubes induced peritoneal mesothelioma mouse model, we showed that the SphK1-/- null mice exhibited significantly less inflammation and granulamatous nodules compared to their wild type counterparts.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE:</Gene>
<Gene>The lipid kinase SphK1 plays a positive and essential role in the growth and development of malignant mesothelioma and is therefore a likely therapeutic target.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Adipose tissue promotes a serum cytokine profile related to lower insulin sensitivity after chronic central leptin infusion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Obesity is an inflammatory state characterized by an augment in circulating inflammatory factors.</Gene>
<Gene>Leptin may modulate the synthesis of these factors by white adipose tissue decreasing insulin sensitivity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have examined the effect of chronic central administration of leptin on circulating levels of cytokines and the possible relationship with cytokine expression and protein content as well as with leptin and insulin signaling in subcutaneous and visceral adipose tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, we analyzed the possible correlation between circulating levels of cytokines and peripheral insulin resistance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We studied 18 male Wistar rats divided into controls (C), those treated icv for 14 days with a daily dose of 12 ug of leptin (L) and a pair-fed group (PF) that received the same food amount consumed by the leptin group.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Serum leptin and insulin were measured by ELISA, mRNA levels of interferon-g (IFN-g), interleukin-2 (IL-2), IL-4, IL-6, IL-10 and tumor necrosis factor-a (TNF-a) by real time PCR and serum and adipose tissue levels of these cytokines by multiplexed bead immunoassay.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Serum leptin, IL-2, IL-4, IFN-g and HOMA-IR were increased in L and TNF-a was decreased in PF and L. Serum leptin and IL-2 levels correlate positively with HOMA-IR index and negatively with serum glucose levels during an ip insulin tolerance test.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In L, an increase in mRNA levels of IL-2 was found in both adipose depots and IFN-g only in visceral tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of leptin signaling was increased and insulin signaling decreased in subcutaneous fat of L.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, leptin mediates the production of inflammatory cytokines by adipose tissue independent of its effects on food intake, decreasing insulin sensitivity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Critical role of neuronal pentraxin 1 in mitochondria-mediated hypoxic-ischemic neuronal injury.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Developing brain is highly susceptible to hypoxic-ischemic (HI) injury leading to severe neurological disabilities in surviving infants and children.</Gene>
<Gene>Previously, we have reported induction of neuronal pentraxin 1 (NP1), a novel neuronal protein of long-pentraxin family, following HI neuronal injury.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we investigated how this specific signal is propagated to cause the HI neuronal death.</Gene>

<Gene>We used wild-type (WT) and NP1 knockout (NP1-KO) mouse hippocampal cultures, modeled in vitro following exposure to oxygen glucose deprivation (OGD), and in vivo neonatal (P9-10) mouse model of HI brain injury.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results show induction of NP1 in primary hippocampal neurons following OGD exposure (4-8 h) and in the ipsilateral hippocampal CA1 and CA3 regions at 24-48 h post-HI compared to the contralateral side.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We also found increased PTEN activity concurrent with OGD time-dependent (4-8 h) dephosphorylation of Akt (Ser473) and GSK-3b (Ser9).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>OGD also caused a time-dependent decrease in the phosphorylation of Bad (Ser136), and Bax protein levels.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Immunofluorescence staining and subcellular fractionation analyses revealed increased mitochondrial translocation of Bad and Bax proteins from cytoplasm following OGD (4 h) and simultaneously increased release of Cyt C from mitochondria followed by activation of caspase-3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NP1 protein was immunoprecipitated with Bad and Bax proteins; OGD caused increased interactions of NP1 with Bad and Bax, thereby, facilitating their mitochondrial translocation and dissipation of mitochondrial membrane potential (D (m)).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This NP1 induction preceded the increased mitochondrial release of cytochrome C (Cyt C) into the cytosol, activation of caspase-3 and OGD time-dependent cell death in WT primary hippocampal neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, in NP1-KO neurons there was no translocation of Bad and Bax from cytosol to the mitochondria, and no evidence of D (m) loss, increased Cyt C release and caspase-3 activation following OGD; which resulted in significantly reduced neuronal death.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results indicate a regulatory role of NP1 in Bad/Bax-dependent mitochondrial release of Cyt C and caspase-3 activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together our findings demonstrate a novel mechanism by which NP1 regulates mitochondria-driven hippocampal cell death; suggesting NP1 as a potential therapeutic target against HI brain injury in neonates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Characterization and identification of subpopulations of mononuclear preosteoclasts induced by TNF-a in combination with TGF-b in rats.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Osteoclasts are unique multinucleated cells formed by fusion of preosteoclasts derived from cells of the monocyte/macrophage lineage, which are induced by RANKL.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, characteristics and subpopulations of osteoclast precursor cells are poorly understood.</Gene>

<Gene>We show here that a combination of TNF-a, TGF-b, and M-CSF efficiently generates mononuclear preosteoclasts but not multinucleated osteoclasts (MNCs) in rat bone marrow cultures depleted of stromal cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using a rat osteoclast-specific mAb, Kat1, we found that TNF-a and TGF-b specifically increased Kat1(+)c-fms(+) and Kat1(+)c-fms(-) cells but not Kat1(-)c-fms(+) cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Kat1(-)c-fms(+) cells appeared in early stages of culture, but Kat1(+)c-fms(+) and Kat1(+)c-fms(-) cells increased later.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Preosteoclasts induced by TNF-a, TGF-b, and M-CSF rapidly differentiated into osteoclasts in the presence of RANKL and hydroxyurea, an inhibitor of DNA synthesis, suggesting that preosteoclasts are terminally differentiated cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We further analyzed the expression levels of genes encoding surface proteins in bone marrow macrophages (BMM), preosteoclasts, and MNCs.</Gene>

<Gene>Preosteoclasts expressed itgam (CD11b) and chemokine receptors CCR1 and CCR2; however, in preosteoclasts the expression of chemokine receptors CCR1 and CCR2 was not up-regulated compared to their expression in BMM.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, addition of RANKL to preosteoclasts markedly increased the expression of CCR1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, expression of macrophage antigen emr-1 (F4/80) and chemokine receptor CCR5 was down-regulated in preosteoclasts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The combination of TNF-a, TGF-b, and M-CSF induced Kat1(+)CD11b(+) cells, but these cells were also induced by TNF-a alone.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, MIP-1a and MCP-1, which are ligands for CCR1 and CCR2, were chemotactic for preosteoclasts, and promoted multinucleation of preosteoclasts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, we found that Kat1(+)c-fms(+) cells were present in bone tissues of rats with adjuvant arthritis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data demonstrate that TNF-a in combination with TGF-b efficiently generates preosteoclasts in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We delineated characteristics that are useful for identifying and isolating rat preosteoclasts, and found that CCR1 expression was regulated in the fusion step in osteoclastogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of human selenoprotein H in neuronal cells enhances mitochondrial biogenesis and function through activation of protein kinase A, protein kinase B, and cyclic adenosine monophosphate response element-binding protein pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mitochondrial biogenesis is activated by nuclear encoded transcription co-activator peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor g coactivator-1a (PGC-1a), which is regulated by several upstream factors including protein kinase A and Akt/protein kinase B. We have previously shown that selenoprotein H enhances the levels of nuclear regulators for mitochondrial biogenesis, increases mitochondrial mass and improves mitochondrial respiratory rate, under physiological condition.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, overexpression of selenoprotein H protects neuronal HT22 cells from ultraviolet B irradiation-induced cell damage by lowering reactive oxygen species production, and inhibiting activation of caspase-3 and -9, as well as p53.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The objective of this study is to identify the cell signaling pathways by which selenoprotein H initiates mitochondrial biogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We first confirmed our previous observation that selenoprotein H transfected HT22 cells increased the protein levels of nuclear-encoded mitochondrial biogenesis factors, peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor g coactivator-1a, nuclear respiratory factor 1 and mitochondrial transcription factor</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A. We then observed that total and phosphorylation of protein kinase A, Akt/protein kinase B and cyclic adenosine monophosphate response element-binding protein (CREB) were significantly increased in selenoprotein H transfected cells compared to vector transfected HT22 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To verify whether the observed stimulating effects on mitochondrial biogenesis pathways are caused by selenoprotein H and mediated through CREB, we knocked down selenoprotein H mRNA level using siRNA and inhibited CREB with napthol AS-E phosphate in selenoprotein H transfected cells and repeated the measurements of the aforementioned biomarkers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results revealed that silencing of selenoprotein H not only decreased the protein levels of PGC-1a, nuclear respiratory factor 1 and mitochondrial transcription factor A, but also decreased the total and phosphorylation levels of protein kinase A, protein kinase B, and CREB.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Similarly, CREB inhibition reduced CREB activation and PGC-1a protein levels in selenoprotein H transfected cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, selenoprotein H transfection increased the activity of mitochondrial complexes and prevented the ultraviolet B induced fall of mitochondrial membrane potential.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that the effects of selenoprotein H on mitochondrial biogenesis and mitochondrial function are probably mediated through protein kinase A-CREB-PGC-1a and Akt/protein kinase B-CREB-PGC-1a pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Prohibitins and the cytoplasmic domain of CD86 cooperate to mediate CD86 signaling in B lymphocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD86 engagement on a CD40L/IL-4-primed murine B cell activates signaling intermediates that promote NF-kB activation to increase Oct-2 and mature IgG1 mRNA and protein expression, as well as the rate of IgG1 transcription, without affecting class switch recombination.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>One of the most proximal signaling intermediates identified is phospholipase Cg2, a protein reported to bind tyrosine residues, which are absent in the cytoplasmic domain of CD86.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using a proteomics-based identification approach, we show that the tyrosine-containing transmembrane adaptor proteins prohibitin (Phb)1 and Phb2 bind to CD86.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The basal expression of Phb1/2 and association with CD86 was low in resting B cells, whereas the level of expression and association increased primarily after priming with CD40.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The CD86-induced increase in Oct-2 and IgG1 was less when either Phb1/2 expression was reduced by short hairpin RNA or the cytoplasmic domain of CD86 was truncated or mutated at serine/threonine protein kinase C phosphorylation sites, which did not affect Phb1/2 binding to CD86.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using this approach, we also show that Phb1/2 and the CD86 cytoplasmic domain are required for the CD86-induced phosphorylation of IkBa, which we previously reported leads to NF-kB p50/p65 activation, whereas only Phb1/2 was required for the CD86-induced phosphorylation of phospholipase Cg2 and protein kinase Ca/b(II), which we have previously reported leads to NF-kB (p65) phosphorylation and subsequent nuclear translocation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, these findings suggest that Phb1/2 and the CD86 cytoplasmic domain cooperate to mediate CD86 signaling in a B cell through differential phosphorylation of distal signaling intermediates required to increase IgG1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>b-catenin is essential for efficient in vitro premyogenic mesoderm formation but can be partially compensated by retinoic acid signalling.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Previous studies have shown that P19 cells expressing a dominant negative b-catenin mutant (b-cat/EnR) cannot undergo myogenic differentiation in the presence or absence of muscle-inducing levels of retinoic acid (RA).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While RA could upregulate premyogenic mesoderm expression, including Pax3/7 and Meox1, only Pax3/7 and Gli2 could be upregulated by RA in the presence of b-cat/EnR. However, the use of a dominant negative construct that cannot be compensated by other factors is limiting due to the possibility of negative chromatin remodelling overriding compensatory mechanisms.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we set out to determine if b-catenin function is essential for myogenesis with and without RA, by creating P19 cells with reduced b-catenin transcriptional activity using an shRNA approach, termed P19[shb-cat] cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The loss of b-catenin resulted in a reduction of skeletal myogenesis in the absence of RA as early as premyogenic mesoderm, with the loss of Pax3/7, Eya2, Six1, Meox1, Gli2, Foxc1/2, and Sox7 transcript levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Chromatin immunoprecipitation identified an association of b-catenin with the promoter region of the Sox7 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Differentiation of P19[shb-cat] cells in the presence of RA resulted in the upregulation or lack of repression of all of the precursor genes, on day 5 and/or 9, with the exception of Foxc2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, expression of Sox7, Gli2, the myogenic regulatory factors and terminal differentiation markers remained inhibited on day 9 and overall skeletal myogenesis was reduced.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, b-catenin is essential for in vitro formation of premyogenic mesoderm, leading to skeletal myogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RA can at least partially compensate for the loss of b-catenin in the expression of many myogenic precursor genes, but not for myoblast gene expression or overall myogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Aberrant Mer receptor tyrosine kinase expression contributes to leukemogenesis in acute myeloid leukemia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) continues to be extremely difficult to treat successfully, and the unacceptably low overall survival rates mandate that we assess new potential therapies to ameliorate poor clinical response to conventional therapy.</Gene>
<Gene>Abnormal tyrosine kinase activation in AML has been associated with poor prognosis and provides strategic targets for novel therapy development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We found that Mer receptor tyrosine kinase was over-expressed in a majority of pediatric (29/36, 80%) and adult (10/10, 100%) primary AML patient blasts at the time of diagnosis, and 100% of patient samples at the time of relapse.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mer was also found to be expressed in 12 of 14 AML cell lines (86%).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, normal bone marrow myeloid precursors expressed little to no Mer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Following AML cell line stimulation with Gas6, a Mer ligand, we observed activation of prosurvival and proliferative signaling pathways, including phosphorylation of ERK1/2, p38, MSK1, CREB, ATF1, AKT and STAT6.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To assess the phenotypic role of Mer in AML, two independent short-hairpin RNA (shRNA) constructs were used to decrease Mer expression in the AML cell lines Nomo-1 and Kasumi-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Reduction of Mer protein levels significantly increased rates of myeloblast apoptosis two to threefold in response to serum starvation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, myeloblasts with knocked-down Mer demonstrated decreased colony formation by 67-87%, relative to control cell lines (P<0.01).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>NOD-SCID-gamma mice transplanted with Nomo-1 myeloblasts with reduced levels of Mer had a significant prolongation in survival compared with mice transplanted with the parental or control cell lines (median survival 17 days in parental and control cell lines, versus 32-36 days in Mer knockdown cell lines, P<0.0001).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest a role for Mer in acute myeloid leukemogenesis and indicate that targeted inhibition of Mer may be an effective therapeutic strategy in pediatric and adult AML.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>OX40L/Jagged1 cosignaling by GM-CSF-induced bone marrow-derived dendritic cells is required for the expansion of functional regulatory T cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Earlier, we had demonstrated that treatment with low dose of GM-CSF can prevent the development of experimental autoimmune thyroiditis (EAT), experimental autoimmune myasthenia gravis, and type 1 diabetes, and could also reverse ongoing EAT and experimental autoimmune myasthenia gravis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The protective effect was mediated through the induction of tolerogenic CD11C(+)CD8a(-) dendritic cells (DCs) and consequent expansion of Foxp3(+) regulatory T cells (Tregs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Subsequently, we showed that GM-CSF acted specifically on bone marrow precursors and facilitated their differentiation into tolerogenic dendritic cells (DCs; GM-CSF-induced bone marrow-derived DCs [GM-BMDCs]), which directed Treg expansion in a contact-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This novel mechanism of Treg expansion was independent of TCR-mediated signaling but required exogenous IL-2 and cosignaling from DC-bound OX40L. In this study, we observed that OX40L-mediated signaling by GM-BMDCs, although necessary, was not sufficient for Treg expansion and required signaling by Jagged1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Concurrent signaling induced by OX40L and Jagged1 via OX40 and Notch3 receptors expressed on Tregs was essential for the Treg expansion with sustained FoxP3 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Adoptive transfer of only OX40L(+)Jagged1(+) BMDCs led to Treg expansion, increased production of IL-4 and IL-10, and suppression of EAT in the recipient mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results showed a critical role for OX40L- and Jagged1-induced cosignaling in GM-BMDC-induced Treg expansion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>AP4 is a mediator of epithelial-mesenchymal transition and metastasis in colorectal cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The basic helix-loop-helix transcription factor AP4/TFAP4/AP-4 is encoded by a c-MYC target gene and displays up-regulation concomitantly with c-MYC in colorectal cancer (CRC) and numerous other tumor types.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here a genome-wide characterization of AP4 DNA binding and mRNA expression was performed using a combination of microarray, genome-wide chromatin immunoprecipitation, next-generation sequencing, and bioinformatic analyses.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thereby, hundreds of induced and repressed AP4 target genes were identified.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Besides many genes involved in the control of proliferation, the AP4 target genes included markers of stemness (LGR5 and CD44) and epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) such as SNAIL, E-cadherin/CDH1, OCLN, VIM, FN1, and the Claudins 1, 4, and 7.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Accordingly, activation of AP4 induced EMT and enhanced migration and invasion of CRC cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, down-regulation of AP4 resulted in mesenchymal-epithelial transition and inhibited migration and invasion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, AP4 induction was required for EMT, migration, and invasion caused by ectopic expression of c-MYC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of AP4 in CRC cells resulted in decreased lung metastasis in mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Elevated AP4 expression in primary CRC significantly correlated with liver metastasis and poor patient survival.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings imply AP4 as a new regulator of EMT that contributes to metastatic processes in CRC and presumably other carcinomas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Nuclear factor-erythroid 2 (NF-E2) p45-related factor-2 (Nrf2) modulates dendritic cell immune function through regulation of p38 MAPK-cAMP-responsive element binding protein/activating transcription factor 1 signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nrf2 is a redox-responsive transcription factor that has been implicated in the regulation of DC immune function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Loss of Nrf2 results in increased co-stimulatory molecule expression, enhanced T cell stimulatory capacity, and increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) levels in murine immature DCs (iDCs).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It is unknown whether altered immune function of Nrf2-deficient DCs (Nrf2(-/-) iDCs) is due to elevated ROS levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, it is unclear which intracellular signaling pathways are involved in Nrf2-mediated regulation of DC function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using antioxidant vitamins to reset ROS levels in Nrf2(-/-)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>iDCs, we show that elevated ROS is not responsible for the altered phenotype and function of these DCs.</Gene>
<Gene>Pharmacological inhibitors were used to explore the role of key MAPKs in mediating the altered phenotype and function in Nrf2(-/-) iDCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We demonstrate that the increased co-stimulatory molecule expression (MHC II and CD86) and antigen-specific T cell activation capacity observed in Nrf2(-/-) iDCs was reversed by inhibition of p38 MAPK but not JNK.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, we provide evidence for increased phosphorylation of cAMP-responsive element binding protein (CREB) and activating transcription factor 1 (ATF1), transcription factors that are downstream of p38 MAPK.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The increased phosphorylation of CREB/ATF1 in Nrf2(-/-) iDCs was sensitive to p38 MAPK inhibition.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also show data to implicate heme oxygenase-1 as a potential molecular link between Nrf2 and CREB/ATF1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results indicate that dysregulation of p38 MAPK-CREB/ATF1 signaling axis underlies the altered function and phenotype in Nrf2-deficient DCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings provide new insights into the mechanisms by which Nrf2 mediates regulation of DC function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Superoxide dismutase 1 overexpression in mice abolishes maternal diabetes-induced endoplasmic reticulum stress in diabetic embryopathy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>OBJECTIVE: Both oxidative stress and endoplasmic reticulum stress (ER stress) are causal events in diabetic embryopathy.</Gene>
<Gene>We tested whether oxidative stress causes ER stress.</Gene>
<Gene>STUDY DESIGN:</Gene>

<Gene>Wild-type (WT) and superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1)-overexpressing day 8.75 embryos from nondiabetic WT control with SOD1 transgenic male and diabetic WT female with SOD1 transgenic male were analyzed for ER stress markers: C/EBP-homologous protein (CHOP), calnexin, eukaryotic initiation factor 2a (eIF2a), protein kinase ribonucleic acid (RNA)-like ER kinase (PERK), binding immunoglobulin protein, protein disulfide isomerase family A member 3, kinases inositol-requiring protein-1a (IRE1a), and the X-box binding protein (XBP1) messenger RNA (mRNA) splicing.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>Maternal diabetes significantly increased the levels of CHOP, calnexin, phosphorylated (p)-eIF2a, p-PERK, and p-IRE1a; triggered XBP1 mRNA splicing; and enhanced ER chaperone gene expression in WT embryos.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SOD1 overexpression blocked these diabetes-induced ER stress markers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION: Mitigating oxidative stress via SOD1 overexpression blocks maternal diabetes-induced ER stress in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Tcf19 is a novel islet factor necessary for proliferation and survival in the INS-1 b-cell line.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recently, a novel type 1 diabetes association locus was identified at human chromosome 6p31.3, and transcription factor 19 (TCF19) is a likely causal gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Little is known about Tcf19, and we now show that it plays a role in both proliferation and apoptosis in insulinoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Tcf19 is expressed in mouse and human islets, with increasing mRNA expression in nondiabetic obesity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of Tcf19 is correlated with b-cell mass expansion, suggesting that it may be a transcriptional regulator of b-cell mass.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Increasing proliferation and decreasing apoptotic cell death are two strategies to increase pancreatic b-cell mass and prevent or delay diabetes.</Gene>
<Gene>siRNA-mediated knockdown of Tcf19 in the INS-1 insulinoma cell line, a b-cell model, results in a decrease in proliferation and an increase in apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>There was a significant reduction in the expression of numerous cell cycle genes from the late G1 phase through the M phase, and cells were arrested at the G1/S checkpoint.</Gene>
<Gene>We also observed increased apoptosis and susceptibility to endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress after Tcf19 knockdown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>There was a reduction in expression of genes important for the maintenance of ER homeostasis (Bip, p58(IPK), Edem1, and calreticulin) and an increase in proapoptotic genes (Bim, Bid, Nix, Gadd34, and Pdia2).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, Tcf19 is necessary for both proliferation and survival and is a novel regulator of these pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of MAPK pathways due to DUSP4 loss promotes cancer stem cell-like phenotypes in basal-like breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Basal-like breast cancer (BLBC) is an aggressive disease that lacks a clinically approved targeted therapy.</Gene>
<Gene>Traditional chemotherapy is effective in BLBC, but it spares the cancer stem cell (CSC)-like population, which is likely to contribute to cancer recurrence after the initial treatment.</Gene>

<Gene>Dual specificity phosphatase-4 (DUSP4) is a negative regulator of the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathway that is deficient in highly aggressive BLBCs treated with chemotherapy, leading to aberrant MAPK activation and resistance to taxane-induced apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Herein, we investigated how DUSP4 regulates the MAP-ERK kinase (MEK) and c-jun-NH2-kinase (JNK) pathways in modifying CSC-like behavior.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DUSP4 loss increased mammosphere formation and the expression of the CSC-promoting cytokines interleukin (IL)-6 and IL-8.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These effects were caused in part by loss of control of the MEK and JNK pathways and involved downstream activation of the ETS-1 and c-JUN transcription factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Enforced expression of DUSP4 reduced the CD44(+)/CD24(-)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>population in multiple BLBC cell lines in a MEK-dependent manner, limiting tumor formation of claudin-low SUM159PT cells in mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings support the evaluation of MEK and JNK pathway inhibitors as therapeutic agents in BLBC to eliminate the CSC population.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CTR9/PAF1c regulates molecular lineage identity, histone H3K36 trimethylation and genomic imprinting during preimplantation development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genome-wide epigenetic reprogramming is required for successful preimplantation development.</Gene>
<Gene>Inappropriate or deficient chromatin regulation can result in defective lineage specification and loss of genomic imprinting, compromising normal development.</Gene>

<Gene>Here we report that two members of the RNA polymerase II associated factor, homolog (Saccharomyces cerevisiae) complex (PAF1 complex) components, Ctr9 and Rtf1, are required during mammalian preimplantation development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We demonstrate that Ctr9-deficient embryos fail to correctly specify lineages at the blastocyst stage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of some lineage specific factors is markedly reduced in Ctr9 knockdown embryos, including Eomes, Elf5 and Sox2, while others are inappropriately expressed (Oct4, Nanog, Gata6, Fgf4 and Sox17).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also show that several imprinted genes (Mest, Peg3, Snrpn and Meg3) are aberrantly expressed although allele specific DNA methylation is not altered.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We document a loss of histone H3 lysine 36 trimethylation (H3K36me3) in Ctr9-deficient embryos and confirm that knockdown of either Setd2 or Rtf1 results in similar phenotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings show that the PAF1 complex is required for mammalian development, likely through regulation of H3K36me3, and indicate functional conservation of the PAF1 complex from yeast to mammals in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mechanical ventilation enhances HMGB1 expression in an LPS-induced lung injury model.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Mechanical ventilation (MV) can augment inflammatory response in lipopolysaccharide (LPS) challenged lungs.</Gene>
<Gene>High mobility group box 1 protein (HMGB1) is a pro-inflammatory mediator in ventilator-induced lung injury, but its mechanisms are not well defined.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study investigated the role of HMGB1 in lung inflammation in response to the combination of MV and LPS treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS: Forty-eight male Sprague-Dawley rats were randomized to one of four groups: sham control; LPS treatment; mechanical ventilation; mechanical ventilation with LPS treatment.</Gene>

<Gene>Mechanically ventilated animals received 10 ml/kg tidal volumes at a rate of 40 breaths/min for 4 h. In the HMGB1-blockade study, sixteen rats were randomly assigned to HMGB1 antibody group or control antibody group and animals were subjected to MV+LPS as described above.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A549 cells were pre-incubated with different signal inhibitors before subjected to 4 h of cyclic stretch.</Gene>
<Gene>Lung wet/dry weight (W/D) ratio, total protein and IgG concentration, number of neutrophils in bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF), and lung histological changes were examined.</Gene>
<Gene>The levels of interleukin-1b (IL-1b), IL-6, tumor necrosis factor-a (TNF-a), macrophage inflammatory protein-2 (MIP-2) and HMGB1 in BALF were measured using ELISA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Real-time quantitative PCR and Western blot were used to analyze mRNA and protein expression of HMGB1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Western blot were employed to analyze the activation of IkB-a, NF-kB, JNK, ERK, and p38.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: MV significantly augmented LPS-induced lung injury and HMGB1 expression, which was correlated with the increase in IL-1b, IL-6 and MIP-2 levels in BALF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vivo, intratracheally administration of HMGB1 antibody significantly attenuated pulmonary inflammatory injury.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro experiments showed cyclic stretch induced HMGB1 expression through signaling pathways including p38 and NF-kB. CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The findings indicated that moderate tidal volume MV augmented LPS induced lung injury by up-regulating HMGB1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The mechanism of HMGB1-mediated lung injury is likely to be signaling through p38 and NF-kB pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
