text: <Gene>Protective roles of interferon-induced protein with tetratricopeptide repeats 3 (IFIT3) in dengue virus infection of human lung epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interferons (IFNs) are critical cytokines that regulate immune response against virus infections.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Dengue virus (DV) infections are a major public health concern worldwide, and especially in Asia.</Gene>
<Gene>In the present study, we investigated the effects and mechanisms of action of IFN-induced protein with tetratricopeptide repeats 3 (IFIT3) in human lung epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results demonstrated that DV infection induced expression of several IFITs, including IFIT1, IFIT2, IFIT3, and IFIT5 in A549 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Induction of IFIT3 by DV infection was also observed in human dendritic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In a knockdown study, we showed that a signal transducer and activator of transcription 2 (STAT2), but not STAT1 or STAT3, regulated DV-induced IFIT3 production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By using several different methods to evaluate cell death, we demonstrated that knockdown of IFIT3 led to cellular apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, knockdown of IFIT3 induced the expression of several apoptotic regulators such as caspase 3, caspase 8, caspase 9, and Bcl-2-associated X protein (BAX).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Such apoptotic effects and mechanisms were synergistically enhanced after DV infection.</Gene>
<Gene>Moreover, under conditions of IFIT3 deficiency, viral production increased, suggesting an anti-viral effect of IFIT3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, DV could suppress IFN-a-induced but not IFN-g-induced IFIT3 expression, a phenomenon similar to the regulation of STATs by DV.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, this study revealed some mechanisms of IFIT3 induction, and also demonstrated the protective roles of IFIT3 following IFN-a production in DV infection of human lung epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Toll-like receptor signaling adapter proteins govern spread of neuropathic pain and recovery following nerve injury in male mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Spinal Toll-like receptors (TLRs) and signaling intermediaries have been implicated in persistent pain states.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We examined the roles of two major TLR signaling pathways and selected TLRs in a mononeuropathic allodynia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>L5 spinal nerve ligation (SNL) was performed in wild type (WT, C57BL/6) male and female mice and in male Tlr2-/-Tlr3-/-, Tlr4-/-, Tlr5-/-, Myd88-/-, Triflps2, Myd88/Triflps2, Tnf-/-, and Ifnar1-/- mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also examined L5 ligation in Tlr4-/- female mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We examined tactile allodynia using von Frey hairs.</Gene>
<Gene>Iba-1 (microglia) and GFAP (astrocytes) were assessed in spinal cords by immunostaining.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tactile thresholds were analyzed by 1- and 2-way ANOVA and the Bonferroni post hoc test was used.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>In WT male and female mice, SNL lesions resulted in a persistent and robust ipsilateral, tactile allodynia.</Gene>
<Gene>In males with TLR2, 3, 4, or 5 deficiencies, tactile allodynia was significantly, but incompletely, reversed (approximately 50%) as compared to WT.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This effect was not seen in female Tlr4-/- mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Increases in ipsilateral lumbar Iba-1 and GFAP were seen in mutant and WT mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mice deficient in MyD88, or MyD88 and TRIF, showed an approximately 50% reduction in withdrawal thresholds and reduced ipsilateral Iba-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, TRIF and interferon receptor null mice developed a profound ipsilateral and contralateral tactile allodynia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In lumbar sections of the spinal cords, we observed a greater increase in Iba-1 immunoreactivity in the TRIF-signaling deficient mice as compared to WT, but no significant increase in GFAP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Removing MyD88 abrogated the contralateral allodynia in the TRIF signaling-deficient mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, IFNb, released downstream to TRIF signaling, administered intrathecally, temporarily reversed the tactile allodynia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>These observations suggest a critical role for the MyD88 pathway in initiating neuropathic pain, but a distinct role for the TRIF pathway and interferon in regulating neuropathic pain phenotypes in male mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>XB130 promotes proliferation and invasion of gastric cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: XB130 has been reported to be expressed by various types of cells such as thyroid cancer and esophageal cancer cells, and it promotes the proliferation and invasion of thyroid cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our previous study demonstrated that XB130 is also expressed in gastric cancer (GC), and that its expression is associated with the prognosis, but the role of XB130 in GC has not been well characterized.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, we investigated the influence of XB130 on gastric tumorigenesis and metastasis in vivo and in vitro using the MTT assay, clonogenic assay, BrdU incorporation assay, 3D culture, immunohistochemistry and immunofluorescence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Western blot analysis was also performed to identify the potential mechanisms involved.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>The proliferation, migration, and invasion of SGC7901 and MNK45 gastric adenocarcinoma cell lines were all significantly inhibited by knockdown of XB130 using small hairpin RNA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In a xenograft model, tumor growth was markedly inhibited after shXB130-transfected GC cells were implanted into nude mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>After XB130 knockdown, GC cells showed a more epithelial-like phenotype, suggesting an inhibition of the epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) process.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, silencing of XB130 reduced the expression of p-Akt/Akt, upregulated expression of epithelial markers including E-cadherin, a-catenin and b-catenin, and downregulated mesenchymal markers including fibronectin and vimentin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of oncoproteins related to tumor metastasis, such as MMP2, MMP9, and CD44, was also significantly reduced.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS: These findings indicate that XB130 enhances cell motility and invasiveness by modulating the EMT-like process, while silencing XB130 in GC suppresses tumorigenesis and metastasis, suggesting that it may be a potential therapeutic target.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mycobacterium massiliense induces inflammatory responses in macrophages through Toll-like receptor 2 and c-Jun N-terminal kinase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mycobacterium massiliense (Mmass) is an emerging, rapidly growing mycobacterium (RGM) that belongs to the M. abscessus (Mabc) group, albeit clearly differentiated from Mabc.</Gene>
<Gene>Compared with M. tuberculosis, a well-characterized human pathogen, the host innate immune response against Mmass infection is largely unknown.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, we show that Mmass robustly activates mRNA and protein expression of tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-a and interleukin (IL)-6 in murine bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDMs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Toll-like receptor (TLR)-2 and myeloid differentiation primary response gene 88 (MyD88), but neither TLR4 nor Dectin-1, are involved in Mmass-induced TNF-a or IL-6 production in BMDMs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mmass infection also activates the mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPKs; c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK), ERK1/2 and p38 MAPK) pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mmass-induced TNF-a and IL-6 production was dependent on JNK activation, while they were unaffected by either the ERK1/2 or p38 pathway in BMDMs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS), NADPH oxidase-2, and nuclear factor-kB are required for Mmass-induced proinflammatory cytokine generation in macrophages.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the S morphotype of Mmass showed lower overall induction of pro-inflammatory (TNF-a, IL-6, and IL-1b) and anti-inflammatory (IL-10) cytokines than the R morphotype, suggesting fewer immunogenic characteristics for this clinical strain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together, these results suggest that Mmass-induced activation of host proinflammatory cytokines is mediated through TLR2-dependent JNK and ROS signaling pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Endothelial NADPH oxidase 4 mediates vascular endothelial growth factor receptor 2-induced intravitreal neovascularization in a rat model of retinopathy of prematurity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PURPOSE:</Gene>
<Gene>NADPH oxidase-generated reactive oxygen species (ROS) are implicated in angiogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Isoforms of NADPH oxidase NOX1, NOX2, and NOX4 are reported to be expressed in endothelial cells (ECs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Of these, NOX1 and NOX2 have been reported to contribute to intravitreal neovascularization (IVNV) in oxygen-induced retinopathy (OIR) models.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we tested the hypothesis that the isoform NOX4 in ECs contributed to vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)-induced angiogenesis and IVNV. METHODS:</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Isoforms of NADPH oxidase MRNA were measured in several types of cultured vascular ecs: human retinal microvascular ECs (hRMVECs), choroidal ECs (CECs), and human umbilical vascular ECs (HUVECs) using real-time PCR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Newborn rat pups and dams were placed into an OIR model that cycled oxygen concentration between 50% and 10% every 24 h for 14 days, and then were placed in room air (RA) for an additional 4 days (rat OIR model).</Gene>
<Gene>NOX4 expression in retinal lysates from the RA-raised pups at postnatal day 0</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>(P0), P14, and P18 was determined with western blots.</Gene>
<Gene>STAT3 activation was determined as the ratio of phosphorylated STAT3 to total STAT3 with western blot analysis of retinal lysates from pups raised in RA or from the rat OIR model at P18.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Semiquantitative assessment of the density of NOX4 colabeling with lectin-stained retinal ECs was determined by immunolabeling of retinal cryosections from P18 pups in OIR or in RA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In hRMVECs transfected with NOX4 siRNA and treated with VEGF or control, 1) ROS generation was measured using the 5-(and-6)-chloromethyl-2',7'-dichlorodihydrofluorescein diacetate, acetyl ester fluorescence assay and 2) phosphorylated VEGF receptor 2 and STAT3, and total VEGFR2 and STAT3 were measured in western blot analyses.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VEGF-stimulated hRMVEC</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>proliferation was measured following transfection with NOX4 siRNA or STAT3 siRNA, or respective controls.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>NOX4 was the most prevalent isoform of NADPH oxidase in vascular ECs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NOX4 expression in retinal lysates was significantly decreased during development in RA.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Compared to RA, the expression of retinal NOX4 increased at P18.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>At p18 OIR, semiquantitative assessment of the density of lectin and NOX4 colabeling in retinal vascular ECs was greater in retinal cryosections and activated STAT3 was greater in retinal lysates when compared to the RA-raised pups.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In cultured hRMVECs, knockdown of NOX4 by siRNA transfection inhibited VEGF-induced ROS generation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VEGF induced a physical interaction of phosphorylated-VEGFR2 and NOX4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Knockdown of NOX4: 1) reduced VEGFR2 activation but did not abolish it and 2) abolished STAT3 activation in response to VEGF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Knockdown of either NOX4 or STAT3 inhibited VEGF-induced EC proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Our data suggest that in a model representative of human retinopathy of prematurity, NOX4 was increased at a time point when IVNV developed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>VEGF-activated NOX4 led to an interaction between VEGF-activated VEGFR2 and NOX4 that mediated EC proliferation via activation of STAT3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Altogether, our results suggest that NOX4 may regulate VEGFR2-mediated IVNV through activated STAT3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Large multiethnic Candidate Gene Study for C-reactive protein levels: identification of a novel association at CD36 in African Americans.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>C-reactive protein (CRP) is a heritable biomarker of systemic inflammation and a predictor of cardiovascular disease (CVD).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Large-scale genetic association studies for CRP have largely focused on individuals of European descent.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We sought to uncover novel genetic variants for CRP in a multiethnic sample using the ITMAT Broad-CARe (IBC) array, a custom 50,000 SNP gene-centric array having dense coverage of over 2,000 candidate CVD genes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We performed analyses on 7,570 African Americans (AA) from the Candidate gene Association Resource (CARe) study and race-combined meta-analyses that included 29,939 additional individuals of European descent from CARe, the Women's Health Initiative (WHI) and KORA studies.</Gene>

<Gene>We observed array-wide significance (p < 2.2 x 10(-6)) for four loci in AA, three of which have been reported previously in individuals of European descent (IL6R, p = 2.0 x 10(-6); CRP, p = 4.2 x 10(-71); APOE, p = 1.6 x 10(-6)).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The fourth significant locus, CD36 (p = 1.6 x 10(-6)), was observed at a functional variant (rs3211938) that is extremely rare in individuals of European descent.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We replicated the CD36 finding (p = 1.8 x 10(-5)) in an independent sample of 8,041 AA women from WHI; a meta-analysis combining the CARe and WHI AA results at rs3211938 reached genome-wide significance (p = 1.5 x 10(-10)).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the race-combined meta-analyses, 13 loci reached significance, including ten (CRP, TOMM40/APOE/APOC1, HNF1A, LEPR, GCKR, IL6R, IL1RN, NLRP3, HNF4A and BAZ1B/BCL7B) previously associated with CRP, and one (ARNTL) previously reported to be nominally associated with CRP.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Two novel loci were also detected (RPS6KB1, p = 2.0 x 10(-6); CD36, p = 1.4 x 10(-6)).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results highlight both shared and unique genetic risk factors for CRP in AA compared to populations of European descent.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Embelin suppresses growth of human pancreatic cancer xenografts, and pancreatic cancer cells isolated from KrasG12D mice by inhibiting Akt and Sonic hedgehog pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Pancreatic cancer is a deadly disease, and therefore effective treatment and/or prevention strategies are urgently needed.</Gene>

<Gene>The objectives of this study were to examine the molecular mechanisms by which embelin inhibited human pancreatic cancer cell growth in vitro, and xenografts in Balb C nude mice, and pancreatic cancer cell growth isolated from KrasG12D transgenic mice.</Gene>
<Gene>XTT assays were performed to measure cell viability.</Gene>
<Gene>AsPC-1 cells were injected subcutaneously into Balb c nude mice and treated with embelin.</Gene>
<Gene>Cell proliferation and apoptosis were measured by Ki67 and TUNEL staining, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of Akt, and Sonic Hedgehog (Shh) and their target gene products were measured by the immunohistochemistry, and Western blot analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The effects of embelin on pancreatic cancer cells isolated from 10-months old KrasG12D mice were also examined.</Gene>

<Gene>Embelin inhibited cell viability in pancreatic cancer AsPC-1, PANC-1, MIA PaCa-2 and Hs 766T cell lines, and these inhibitory effects were blocked either by constitutively active Akt or Shh protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Embelin-treated mice showed significant inhibition in tumor growth which was associated with reduced expression of markers of cell proliferation (Ki67, PCNA and Bcl-2) and cell cycle (cyclin D1, CDK2, and CDK6), and induction of apoptosis (activation of caspase-3 and cleavage of PARP, and increased expression of Bax).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, embelin inhibited the expression of markers of angiogenesis (COX-2, VEGF, VEGFR, and IL-8), and metastasis (MMP-2 and MMP-9) in tumor tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Antitumor activity of embelin was associated with inhibition of Akt and Shh pathways in xenografts, and pancreatic cancer cells isolated from KrasG12D mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, embelin also inhibited epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT) by up-regulating E-cadherin and inhibiting the expression of Snail, Slug, and ZEB1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest that embelin can inhibit pancreatic cancer growth, angiogenesis and metastasis by suppressing Akt and Shh pathways, and can be developed for the treatment and/or prevention of pancreatic cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Reversal of ischemic cardiomyopathy with Sca-1+ stem cells modified with multiple growth factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>We hypothesized that bone marrow derived Sca-1+ stem cells (BM Sca-1+) transduced with multiple therapeutic cytokines with diverse effects will induce faster angiomyogenic differentiation in the infarcted myocardium.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS AND RESULTS: BM Sca-1+ were purified from transgenic male mice expressing GFP.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Plasmids encoding for select quartet of growth factors, i.e., human IGF-1, VEGF, SDF-1a and HGF were prepared and used for genetic modification of Sca-1+ cells (GFSca-1+).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Scramble transfected cells (ScSca-1+) were used as a control.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RT-PCR and western blotting showed significantly higher expression of the growth factors in GFSca-1+.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Besides the quartet of the therapeutic growth factors, PCR based growth factor array showed upregulation of multiple angiogenic and prosurvival factors such as Ang-1, Ang-2, MMP9, Cx43, BMP2, BMP5, FGF2, and NGF in GFSca-1+</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(p<0.01 vs ScSca-1+).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>LDH and TUNEL assays showed enhanced survival of GFSca-1+ under lethal anoxia (p<0.01 vs ScSca-1+).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MTS assay showed significant increased cell proliferation in GFSca-1+</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(p<0.05 vs ScSca-1+).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>For in vivo study, female mice were grouped to receive the intramyocardial injection of 15 ul DMEM without cells (group-1) or containing 2.5 x 10(5)</Gene>
<Gene>ScSca-1+</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(group-2) or GFSca-1+ (group-3) immediately after coronary artery ligation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As indicated by Sry gene, a higher survival of GFSca-1+ in group-3 on day 4 (2.3 fold higher vs group-2) was observed with massive mobilization of stem and progenitor cells (cKit+, Mdr1+, Cxcr4+ cells).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Heart tissue sections immunostained for actinin and Cx43 at 4 weeks post engraftment showed extensive myofiber formation and expression of gap junctions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Immunostaining for vWF showed increased blood vessel density in both peri-infarct and infarct regions in group-3.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Infarct size was attenuated and the global heart function was improved in group-3 as compared to group-2.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSIONS: Administration of BM Sca-1+ transduced with multiple genes is a novel approach to treat infarcted heart for its regeneration.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IL-3 and CSF-1 interact to promote generation of CD11c+ IL-10-producing macrophages.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Unraveling the mechanisms of hematopoiesis regulated by multiple cytokines remains a challenge in hematology.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IL-3 is an allergic cytokine with the multilineage potential, while CSF-1 is produced in the steady state with restricted lineage coverage.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we uncovered an instructive role of CSF-1 in IL-3-mediated hematopoiesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CSF-1 significantly promoted IL-3-driven CD11c+ cell expansion and dampened basophil and mast cell generation from C57BL/6 bone marrow.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Further studies indicated that the CSF-1/CSF-1R axis contributed significantly to IL-3-induced CD11c+ cell generation through enhancing c-Fos-associated monopoiesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD11c+ cells induced by IL-3 or IL-3/CSF-1 were competent in cellular maturation and endocytosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both IL-3 and IL-3/CSF-1 cells lacked classical dendritic cell appearance and resembled macrophages in morphology.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Both populations produced a high level of IL-10, in addition to IL-1, IL-6 and TNFa, in response to LPS, and were relatively poor T cell stimulators.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, these findings reveal a role for CSF-1 in mediating the IL-3 hematopoietic pathway through monopoiesis, which regulates expansion of CD11c+ macrophages.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Postnatal exposure to a high-carbohydrate diet interferes epigenetically with thyroid hormone receptor induction of the adult male rat skeletal muscle glucose transporter isoform 4 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Early life nutritional intervention causes adult-onset insulin resistance and obesity in rats.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Thyroid hormone receptor (TR), in turn, transcriptionally enhances skeletal muscle Glut4 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We tested the hypothesis that reduced circulating thyroid-stimulating hormone and T4 concentrations encountered in postnatal (PN4-PN24) high-carbohydrate (HC) milk formula-fed versus the mother-fed controls (MF) would epigenetically interfere with TR induction of adult (100 days) male rat skeletal muscle Glut4 expression, thereby providing a molecular mechanism mediating insulin resistance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We observed increased DNA methylation of the CpG island with enhanced recruitment of Dnmt3a, Dnmt3b and MeCP2 in the glut4 promoter region along with reduced acetylation of histone (H)2A.Z and H4 particularly at the H4.lysine (K)16 residue, which was predominantly mediated by histone deacetylase 4 (HDAC4).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This was followed by enhanced recruitment of heterochromatin protein 1b to the glut4 promoter with increased Suv39H1 methylase concentrations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These changes reduced TR binding of the T3 response element of the glut4 gene (TREs; -473 to -450 bp) detected qualitatively in vivo (electromobility shift assay) and quantified ex vivo (chromatin immunoprecipitation).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the recruitment of steroid receptor coactivator and CREB-binding protein to the glut4 promoter-protein complex was reduced.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Co-immunoprecipitation experiments confirmed the interaction between TR and CBP to be reduced and HDAC4 to be enhanced in HC versus MF groups.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These molecular changes were associated with diminished skeletal muscle Glut4 mRNA and protein concentrations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We conclude that early postnatal exposure to HC diet epigenetically reduced TR induction of adult male skeletal muscle Glut4 expression, uncovering novel molecular mechanisms contributing to adult insulin resistance and obesity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Twist 1 regulates the expression of PPARg during hormone-induced 3T3-L1 preadipocyte differentiation: a possible role in obesity and associated diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Twist 1 is highly expressed in adipose tissue and has been associated with obesity and related disorders.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, the molecular function of Twist 1 in adipose tissue is unclear.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Twist 1 has been implicated in cell lineage determination and differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, we investigated both the role of Twist 1 in adipocyte precursor mobilization and the relationship of Twist 1 with other molecular determinants of adipocyte differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>We examined Twist 1 mRNA and protein expression in subcutaneous adipose tissues from diet-induced obese C57/BL6 mice and Wistar rats and in obese patients undergoing liposuction or adipose transplant surgeries.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Twist 1 expression was measured on days 0, 2, 4, 8, and 12 of 3T3-L1 differentiation in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The role of Twist 1 in adipogenesis was explored using retroviral interference of Twist 1 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Adipokine secretion was evaluated using a RayBioR Biotin Label-based Adipokine Array.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Twist 1 mRNA and protein levels were reduced in diet-induced obese mice and rats and in obese humans.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Twist 1 was upregulated during 3T3-L1 preadipocyte differentiation in vitro, beginning from the fourth day of differentiation induction.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Retroviral interference of Twist 1 expression did not significantly impair lipid formation; however, retroviral interference induced PPARg mRNA and protein expression on day 4 of differentiation induction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Adipokine array analyses revealed increased secretion of CXCR4 (19.55-fold), VEGFR1 (92.13-fold), L-21 R (63.55-fold), and IL-12 R beta 1 (59.66-fold) and decreased secretion of VEGFR3 (0.01-fold), TSLP R (0.071-fold), MIP-1 gamma (0.069-fold), TNF RI/TNFRSF1A (0.09-fold), and MFG-E8 (0.06-fold).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Twist 1 is a regulator of adipocyte gene expression although it is not likely to regulate differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We identified PPARg as a potential target of Twist 1 and found variation in the secretion of multiple adipokines, which might indicate a prospective mechanism linking Twist 1 expression with obesity or associated diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RBFOX1 cooperates with MBNL1 to control splicing in muscle, including events altered in myotonic dystrophy type 1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>With the goal of identifying splicing alterations in myotonic dystrophy 1 (DM1) tissues that may yield insights into targets or mechanisms, we have surveyed mis-splicing events in three systems using a RT-PCR screening and validation platform.</Gene>
<Gene>First, a transgenic mouse model expressing CUG-repeats identified splicing alterations shared with other mouse models of DM1.</Gene>

<Gene>Second, using cell cultures from human embryonic muscle, we noted that DM1-associated splicing alterations were significantly enriched in cytoskeleton (e.g. SORBS1, TACC2, TTN, ACTN1 and DMD) and channel (e.g. KCND3 and TRPM4) genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Third, of the splicing alterations occurring in adult DM1 tissues, one produced a dominant negative variant of the splicing regulator RBFOX1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Notably, half of the splicing events controlled by MBNL1 were co-regulated by RBFOX1, and several events in this category were mis-spliced in DM1 tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results suggest that reduced RBFOX1 activity in DM1 tissues may amplify several of the splicing alterations caused by the deficiency in MBNL1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Leukemia inhibitory factor protects the lung during respiratory syncytial viral infection.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infects the lung epithelium where it stimulates the production of numerous host cytokines that are associated with disease burden and acute lung injury.</Gene>

<Gene>Characterizing the host cytokine response to RSV infection, the regulation of host cytokines and the impact of neutralizing an RSV-inducible cytokine during infection were undertaken in this study.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>A549, primary human small airway epithelial (SAE) cells and wild-type, TIR-domain-containing adapter-inducing interferon-b (Trif) and mitochondrial antiviral-signaling protein (Mavs) knockout (KO) mice were infected with RSV and cytokine responses were investigated by ELISA, multiplex analysis and qPCR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Neutralizing anti-leukemia inhibitory factor (LIF) IgG or control IgG was administered to a group of wild-type animals prior to RSV infection.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS AND DISCUSSION:</Gene>

<Gene>RSV-infected A549 and SAE cells release a network of cytokines, including newly identified RSV-inducible cytokines LIF, migration inhibitory factor (MIF), stem cell factor (SCF), CCL27, CXCL12 and stem cell growth factor beta (SCGF-b).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These RSV-inducible cytokines were also observed in the airways of mice during an infection.</Gene>
<Gene>To identify the regulation of RSV inducible cytokines, Mavs and Trif deficient animals were infected with RSV.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vivo induction of airway IL-1b, IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-12(p40), IFN-g, CCL2, CCL5, CCL3, CXCL1, IP-10/CXCL10, IL-22, MIG/CXCL9 and MIF were dependent on Mavs expression in mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Loss of Trif expression in mice altered the RSV induction of IL-1b, IL-5, CXCL12, MIF, LIF, CXCL12 and IFN-g. Silencing of retinoic acid-inducible gene-1 (RIG-I) expression in A549 cells had a greater impact on RSV-inducible cytokines than melanoma differentiation-associated protein 5 (MDA5) and laboratory of genetics and physiology 2 (LGP2), and Trif expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To evaluate the role of LIF in the airways during RSV infection, animals were treated with neutralizing anti-LIF IgG, which enhanced RSV pathology observed with increased airspace protein content, apoptosis and airway hyperresponsiveness compared to control IgG treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>RSV infection in the epithelium induces a network of immune factors to counter infection, primarily in a RIG-I dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of LIF protects the lung from lung injury and enhanced pathology during RSV infection.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Rac1 signaling is critical to cardiomyocyte polarity and embryonic heart development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Defects in cardiac septation are the most common form of congenital heart disease, but the mechanisms underlying these defects are still poorly understood.</Gene>
<Gene>The small GTPase Rac1 is implicated in planar cell polarity of epithelial cells in Drosophila; however, its role in mammalian cardiomyocyte polarity is not clear.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We tested the hypothesis that Rac1 signaling in the second heart field regulates cardiomyocyte polarity, chamber septation, and right ventricle development during embryonic heart development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS AND RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Mice with second heart field-specific deficiency of Rac1 (Rac1(SHF)) exhibited ventricular and atrial septal defects, a thinner right ventricle myocardium, and a bifid cardiac apex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Fate-mapping analysis showed that second heart field contribution to the interventricular septum and right ventricle was deficient in Rac1(SHF) hearts.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Notably, cardiomyocytes had a spherical shape with disrupted F-actin filaments in Rac1(SHF) compared with elongated and well-aligned cardiomyocytes in littermate controls.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of Scrib, a core protein in planar cell polarity, was lost in Rac1(SHF) hearts with decreased expression of WAVE and Arp2/3, leading to decreased migratory ability.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, Rac1-deficient neonatal cardiomyocytes displayed defects in cell projections, lamellipodia formation, and cell elongation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, apoptosis was increased and the expression of Gata4, Tbx5, Nkx2.5, and Hand2 transcription factors was decreased in the Rac1(SHF) right ventricle myocardium.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>Deficiency of Rac1 in the second heart field impairs elongation and cytoskeleton organization of cardiomyocytes and results in congenital septal defects, thin right ventricle myocardium, and a bifid cardiac apex.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our study suggests that Rac1 signaling is critical to cardiomyocyte polarity and embryonic heart development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BIS targeting induces cellular senescence through the regulation of 14-3-3 zeta/STAT3/SKP2/p27 in glioblastoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cellular senescence is an important mechanism for preventing tumor progression.</Gene>

<Gene>The elevated expression of Bcl-2-interacting cell death suppressor (BIS), an anti-apoptotic and anti-stress protein, often correlates with poor prognosis in several cancers including glioblastoma; however, the role of BIS in the regulation of senescence has not been well defined.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we describe for the first time that the depletion of BIS induces G1 arrest and cellular senescence through the accumulation of p27 that is independent of p53, p21 or p16.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The increase in p27 expression in BIS-depleted cells was attributable to an impairment of the ubiquitin-mediated degradation of p27, which was caused by a decrease in S-phase kinase-associated protein 2 (SKP2) at the transcriptional level.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As an underlying molecular mechanism, we demonstrate that the loss of activity of signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (STAT3) was specifically linked to the suppression of SKP2 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Despite a reduction in phospho-STAT3 levels, total STAT3 levels were unexpectedly increased by BIS depletion, specifically in the insoluble fraction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results show that 14-3-3z expression is decreased by BIS knockdown and that 14-3-3z depletion per se significantly induced senescence phenotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the ectopic expression of 14-3-3z blocked senescence caused by BIS depletion, which was paralleled with a decrease in insoluble STAT3 in A172 glioblastoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings indicate that the impairment of the protein quality control conferred by BIS and/or 14-3-3z is critical for BIS depletion-induced senescence.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, BIS knockdown also induced senescence along with an accumulation of total STAT3 and p27 in several different cell types as well as embryonic fibroblasts derived from Bis-knock out mice with/without variations in 14-3-3z levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, our findings suggest that a downregulation of BIS expression could serve as a potential strategy for restricting tumor progression via an induction of senescence through the regulation of STAT3/SKP2/p27 pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Social defeat promotes a reactive endothelium in a brain region-dependent manner with increased expression of key adhesion molecules, selectins and chemokines associated with the recruitment of myeloid cells to the brain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Repeated social defeat (RSD) in mice causes myeloid cell trafficking to the brain that contributes to the development of prolonged anxiety-like behavior.</Gene>
<Gene>Myeloid cell recruitment following RSD occurs in regions where neuronal and microglia activation is observed.</Gene>

<Gene>Thus, we hypothesized that crosstalk between neurons, microglia, and endothelial cells contributes to brain myeloid cell trafficking via chemokine signaling and vascular adhesion molecules.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that social defeat caused an exposure- and brain region-dependent increase in several key adhesion molecules and chemokines involved in the recruitment of myeloid cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>For example, RSD induced distinct patterns of adhesion molecule expression that may explain brain region-dependent myeloid cell trafficking.</Gene>
<Gene>VCAM-1 and ICAM-1 mRNA expression were increased in an exposure-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, RSD-induced VCAM-1 and ICAM-1 protein expression were localized to the vasculature of brain regions implicated in fear and anxiety responses, which spatially corresponded to previously reported patterns of myeloid cell trafficking.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Next, mRNA expression of additional adhesion molecules (E- and P-selectin, PECAM-1) and chemokines (CXCL1, CXCL2, CXCL12, CCL2) were determined in the brain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Social defeat induced an exposure-dependent increase in mRNA levels of E-selectin, CXCL1, and CXCL2 that increased with additional days of social defeat.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While CXCL12 was unaffected by RSD, CCL2 expression was increased by six days of social defeat.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Last, comparison between enriched CD11b(+) cells (microglia/macrophages) and enriched GLAST-1(+)/CD11b(-) cells (astrocytes) revealed RSD increased mRNA expression of IL-1b, CCL2, and CXCL2 in microglia/macrophages but not in astrocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, these data indicate that key mediators of leukocyte recruitment were increased in the brain vasculature following RSD in an exposure- and brain region-dependent manner.</Gene>
<Gene>Liver fibrosis occurs through dysregulation of MyD88-dependent innate B-cell activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Chronic liver disease mediated by activation of hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) leads to liver fibrosis.</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we postulated that the immune regulatory properties of HSCs might promote the profibrogenic activity of B cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Fibrosis is completely attenuated in carbon tetrachloride-treated, B cell-deficient uMT mice, showing that B cells are required.</Gene>
<Gene>The retinoic acid produced by HSCs augmented B-cell survival, plasma cell marker CD138 expression, and immunoglobulin G production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These activities were reversed following addition of the retinoic acid inhibitor LE540.</Gene>

<Gene>Transcriptional profiling of fibrotic liver B cells revealed increased expression of genes related to activation of nuclear factor k light chain enhancer of activated B cells, proinflammatory cytokine production, and CD40 signaling, suggesting that these B cells are activated and may be acting as inflammatory cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Biological validation experiments also revealed increased activation (CD44 and CD86 expression), constitutive immunoglobulin G production, and secretion of the proinflammatory cytokines tumor necrosis factor-a, monocyte chemoattractant protein-1, and macrophage inflammatory protein-1a.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Likewise, targeted deletion of B-cell-intrinsic myeloid differentiation primary response gene 88 signaling, an innate adaptor with involvement in retinoic acid signaling, resulted in reduced infiltration of migratory CD11c(+) dendritic cells and Ly6C(++) monocytes and, hence, reduced liver pathology.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>Liver fibrosis occurs through a mechanism of HSC-mediated augmentation of innate B-cell activity.</Gene>
<Gene>These findings highlight B cells as important "first responders" of the intrahepatic immune environment.</Gene>
<Gene>Loss of muscleblind-like 1 results in cardiac pathology and persistence of embryonic splice isoforms.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cardiac dysfunction is a prominent cause of mortality in myotonic dystrophy I (DM1), a disease where expanded CUG repeats bind and disable the muscleblind-like family of splice regulators.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Deletion of muscleblind-like 1 (Mbnl1(DE2/DE2)) in 129 sv mice results in QRS, QTc widening, bundle block and STc narrowing at 2-4 months of age.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>With time, cardiac function deteriorates further and at 6 months, decreased R wave amplitudes, sinus node dysfunction, cardiac hypertrophy, interstitial fibrosis, multi-focal myocardial fiber death and calcification manifest.</Gene>
<Gene>Sudden death, where no end point illness is overt, is observed at a median age of 6.5 and 4.8 months in ~67% and ~86% of male and female Mbnl1(DE2/DE2) mice, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mbnl1 depletion results in the persistence of embryonic splice isoforms in a network of cardiac RNAs, some of which have been previously implicated in DM1, regulating sodium and calcium currents, Scn5a, Junctin, Junctate, Atp2a1, Atp11a, Cacna1s, Ryr2, intra and inter cellular transport, Clta, Stx2, Tjp1, cell survival, Capn3, Sirt2, Csda, sarcomere and cytoskeleton organization and function, Trim55, Mapt, Pdlim3, Pdlim5, Sorbs1, Sorbs2, Fhod1, Spag9 and structural components of the sarcomere, Myom1, Tnnt2, Zasp.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus this study supports a key role for Mbnl1 loss in the initiation of DM1 cardiac disease.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>FLT3-ITD confers resistance to the PI3K/Akt pathway inhibitors by protecting the mTOR/4EBP1/Mcl-1 pathway through STAT5 activation in acute myeloid leukemia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>FLT3-ITD and FLT3-TKD are the most frequent tyrosine kinase mutations in acute myeloid leukemia (AML), with the former associated with poor prognosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we show that the PI3K inhibitor GDC-0941 or the Akt inhibitor MK-2206 induced apoptosis through the mitochondria-mediated intrinsic pathway more efficiently in hematopoietic 32D cells driven by FLT3-TKD (32D/TKD) than FLT3-ITD (32D/ITD), which robustly activated STAT5.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The resistance to GDC-0941 and MK-2206 was gained by expression of the constitutively activated STAT5 mutant STAT5A1*6 in 32D/TKD cells, while it was abrogated by the STAT5 inhibitor pimozide in 32D/ITD cells or FLT3-ITD-expressing human leukemic MV4-11 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>GDC-0941 or MK-2206 induced dephosphorylation of 4EBP1 more conspicuously in 32D/TKD than in 32D/ITD, which was prevented or augmented by STAT5A1*6 or pimozide, respectively, and correlated with downregulation of the eIF4E/eIF4G complex formation and Mcl-1 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, exogenous expression of Mcl-1 endowed resistance to GDC-0941 and MK-2206 on 32D/TKD cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, it was confirmed in primary AML cells with FLT3-ITD that pimozide enhanced 4EBP1 dephosphorylation and Mcl-1 downregulation to augment cytotoxicity of GDC-0941.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest that the robust STAT5 activation by FLT3-ITD protects cells treated with the PI3K/Akt pathway inhibitors from apoptosis by maintaining Mcl-1 expression through the mTORC1/4EBP1/eIF4E pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CCL20 is elevated during obesity and differentially regulated by NF-kB subunits in pancreatic b-cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Enhanced leukocytic infiltration into pancreatic islets contributes to inflammation-based diminutions in functional b-cell mass.</Gene>
<Gene>Insulitis (aka islet inflammation), which can be present in both T1DM and T2DM, is one factor influencing pancreatic b-cell death and dysfunction.</Gene>
<Gene>IL-1b, an inflammatory mediator in both T1DM and T2DM, acutely (within 1h) induced expression of the CCL20 gene in rat and human islets and clonal b-cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transcriptional induction of CCL20 required the p65 subunit of NF-kB to replace the p50 subunit at two functional kB sites within the CCL20 proximal gene promoter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The NF-kB p50 subunit prevents CCL20 gene expression during unstimulated conditions and overexpression of p50 reduces CCL20, but enhances cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2), transcript accumulation after exposure to IL-1b.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also identified differential recruitment of specific co-activator molecules to the CCL20 gene promoter, when compared with the CCL2 and COX2 genes, revealing distinct transcriptional requirements for individual NF-kB responsive genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, IL-1b, TNF-a and IFN-g individually increased the expression of CCR6, the receptor for CCL20, on the surface of human neutrophils.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We further found that the chemokine CCL20 is elevated in serum from both genetically obese db/db mice and in C57BL6/J mice fed a high-fat diet.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, these results are consistent with a possible activation of the CCL20-CCR6 axis in diseases with inflammatory components.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, interfering with this signaling pathway, either at the level of NF-kB-mediated chemokine production, or downstream receptor activation, could be a potential therapeutic target to offset inflammation-associated tissue dysfunction in obesity and diabetes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lower PRDM2 expression is associated with dopamine-agonist resistance and tumor recurrence in prolactinomas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>Dopamine agonists (DAs) are the first-line treatment for prolactinomas, which account for 25-30% of functioning pituitary adenomas, and bromocriptine (BRC) is the only commercially available DAs in China.</Gene>
<Gene>However, tumors are resistant to therapy in 5-18% of patients.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>The exomes of six responsive prolactinomas and six resistant prolactinomas were analyzed by whole-exome sequencing.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS: Using stringent variant calling and filtering parameters, ten somatic variants that were mainly associated with DNA repair or protein metabolic processes were identified.</Gene>
<Gene>New resistant variants were identified in multiple genes including PRDM2, PRG4, MUC4, DSPP, DPCR1, RP1L1, MX2, POTEF, C1orf170, and KRTAP10-3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of these genes was then quantified by real-time reverse-transcription PCR (RT-qPCR) in 12 prolactinomas and 3 normal pituitary glands.</Gene>
<Gene>The mRNA levels of PRDM2 were approximately five-fold lower in resistant prolactinomas than in responsive tumors (p < 0.05).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PRDM2 protein levels were lower in resistant prolactinomas than in responsive tumors, as determined by Western blotting and immunohistochemical analysis (p < 0.05).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of PRDM2 upregulated dopamine receptor D2 (D2DR) and inhibited the phosphorylation of ERK1/2 in MMQ cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PRDM2 showed a synergistic effect with BRC on the inhibition of prolactin (PRL) secretion and MMQ cell viability, and low PRDM2 expression was associated with tumor recurrence.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>PRDM2 downregulation may play a role in dopamine-agonist resistance and tumor recurrence in prolactinomas.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of a unique hepatocellular carcinoma line, Li-7, with CD13(+) cancer stem cells hierarchy and population change upon its differentiation during culture and effects of sorafenib.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUNDS:</Gene>
<Gene>Cancer stem cell (CSC) research has highlighted the necessity of developing drugs targeting CSCs.</Gene>

<Gene>We investigated a hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cell line that not only has CSC hierarchy but also shows phenotypic changes (population changes) upon differentiation of CSC during culture and can be used for screening drugs targeting CSC.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>Based on a hypothesis that the CSC proportion should decrease upon its differentiation into progenitors (population change), we tested HCC cell lines (HuH-7, Li-7, PLC/PRF/5, HLF, HLE) before and after 2 months culture for several markers (CD13, EpCAM, CD133, CD44, CD90, CD24, CD166).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tumorigenicity was tested using nude mice.</Gene>

<Gene>To evaluate the CSC hierarchy, we investigated reconstructivity, proliferation, ALDH activity, spheroid formation, chemosensitivity and microarray analysis of the cell populations sorted by FACS.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Only Li-7 cells showed a population change during culture: the proportion of CD13 positive cells decreased, while that of CD166 positive cells increased.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The high tumorigenicity of the Li-7 was lost after the population change.</Gene>

<Gene>CD13(+)/CD166(-) cells showed slow growth and reconstructed the bulk Li-7 populations composed of CD13(+)/CD166(-), CD13(-)/CD166(-) and CD13(-)/CD166(+) fractions, whereas CD13(-)/CD166(+) cells showed rapid growth but could not reproduce any other population.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD13(+)/CD166(-) cells showed high ALDH activity, spheroid forming ability and resistance to 5-fluorouracil.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Microarray analysis demonstrated higher expression of stemness-related genes in CD166(-) than CD166(+) fraction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results indicated a hierarchy in Li-7 cells, in which CD13(+)/CD166(-) and CD13(-)/CD166(+) cells serve as slow growing CSCs and rapid growing progenitors, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sorafenib selectively targeted the CD166(-) fraction, including CD13(+) CSCs, which exhibited higher mRNA expression for FGF3 and FGF4, candidate biomarkers for sorafenib.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>5-fluorouracil followed by sorafenib inhibited the growth of bulk Li-7 cells more effectively than the reverse sequence or either alone.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>We identified a unique HCC line, Li-7, which not only shows heterogeneity for a CD13(+) CSC hierarchy, but also undergoes a "population change" upon CSC differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sorafenib targeted the CSC in vitro, supporting the use of this model for screening drugs targeting the CSC.</Gene>
<Gene>This type of "heterogeneous, unstable" cell line may prove more useful in the CSC era than conventional "homogeneous, stable" cell lines.</Gene>
<Gene>Sexual Dimorphism in MAPK-Activated Protein Kinase-2 (MK2) Regulation of RANKL-Induced Osteoclastogenesis in Osteoclast Progenitor Subpopulations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Osteoclasts (OCs) are bone-resorptive cells critical for maintaining skeletal integrity through coupled bone turnover.</Gene>
<Gene>OC differentiation and activation requires receptor activator of NF-kB ligand (RANKL) signaling through the p38 MAPK pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However the role of the p38 MAPK substrate, MAPK-activated protein kinase 2 (MK2), is not clearly delineated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Within the bone marrow exists a specific subpopulation of defined osteoclast progenitor cells (dOCPs) with surface expression of B220(-)Gr1(-)CD11b(lo/-)CD115(+) (dOCP(lo/-)).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we isolated dOCPs from male and female mice to determine sex-specific effects of MK2 signaling in osteoclastogenesis (OCgen).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Male Mk2(-/-) mice display an increase in the dOCP(lo) cell population when compared to Mk2(+/+) mice, while female Mk2(-/-) and Mk2(+/+ )mice exhibit no difference.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Defined OCPs from male and female Mk2(+/+) and Mk2(-/-) bone marrow were treated with macrophage colony stimulation factor (M-CSF) and RANKL cytokines to promote OCgen.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RANKL treatment of dOCP(lo) cells stimulated p38 and MK2 phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) assays were used to quantify OC number, size, and TRAP enzyme activity post-RANKL stimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MK2 signaling was critical for male dOCP(lo) OCgen, yet MK2 signaling regulated OCgen from female dOCP- and CD11b(hi) subpopulations as well.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The functional gene, Ctsk, was attenuated in both male and female Mk2(-/-) dOCP(lo)-derived OCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, MK2 signaling was only critical for gene expression of pre-OC fusion genes, Oc-stamp andTm7sf4, in male OCgen.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, these data suggest there is a sexual dimorphism in MK2 signaling of OCP subpopulations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>TIPE2 Inhibits Lung Cancer Growth Attributing to Promotion of Apoptosis by Regulating Some Apoptotic Molecules Expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recent studies found that TIPE2 was involved in cancer development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, little is known about TIPE2 in lung cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our study aims to clarify the role of TIPE2 in lung carcinogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We examined the expression of TIPE2 in lung squamous cancer (LSC), small cell lung cancer and lung adenocarcinoma (AdC) tissues and found that TIPE2 expression was lost in small cell lung cancer, compared with adjacent non-tumor tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of TIPE2 significantly inhibited the growth of lung cancer cell H446 in vitro and even suppressed tumor formation in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Flow cytometry analysis found TIPE2 overexpression promoted apoptosis of H446.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In TIPE2 over-expression cells, caspase-3, caspase-9, and Bax were significantly up-regulated while Bcl-2 was down-regulated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, coincident results were shown by immunohistochemistry in tumors from nude mice.</Gene>
<Gene>TIPE2 inhibited the phosphorylation of Akt, while promoting the phosphorylation of P38, but had no effect on IkBa and ERK pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, TIPE2 promoted lung cancer cell apoptosis through affecting apoptosis-related molecules caspase-3, caspase-9, Bcl-2 and Bax, possibly via regulating P38 and Akt pathways, indicating that TIPE2 might be a novel marker for lung cancer diagnosis and therapy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cutting Edge: Dual Function of PPARg in CD11c+ Cells Ensures Immune Tolerance in the Airways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The respiratory tract maintains immune homeostasis despite constant provocation by environmental Ags.</Gene>
<Gene>Failure to induce tolerogenic responses to allergens incites allergic inflammation.</Gene>
<Gene>Despite the understanding that APCs have a crucial role in maintaining immune tolerance, the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood.</Gene>

<Gene>Using mice with a conditional deletion of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor g (PPARg) in CD11c(+) cells, we show that PPARg performs two critical functions in CD11c(+) cells to induce tolerance, thereby preserving immune homeostasis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>First, PPARg was crucial for the induction of retinaldehyde dehydrogenase (aldh1a2) selectively in CD103(+) dendritic cells, which we recently showed promotes Foxp3 expression in naive CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T cells.</Gene>
<Gene>Second, in all CD11c(+) cells, PPARg was required to suppress expression of the Th17-skewing cytokines IL-6 and IL-23p19.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Also, lack of PPARg in CD11c(+) cells induced p38 MAPK activity, which was recently linked to Th17 development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, PPARg favors immune tolerance by promoting regulatory T cell generation and blocking Th17 differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The impact of PPARa activation on whole genome gene expression in human precision cut liver slices.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Studies in mice have shown that PPARa is an important regulator of lipid metabolism in liver and key transcription factor involved in the adaptive response to fasting.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, much less is known about the role of PPARa in human liver.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>Here we set out to study the function of PPARa in human liver via analysis of whole genome gene regulation in human liver slices treated with the PPARa agonist Wy14643. RESULTS:</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Quantitative PCR indicated that PPARa is well expressed in human liver and human liver slices and that the classical PPARa targets PLIN2, VLDLR, ANGPTL4, CPT1A and PDK4 are robustly induced by PPARa activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transcriptomics analysis indicated that 617 genes were upregulated and 665 genes were downregulated by PPARa activation (q value < 0.05).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Many genes induced by PPARa activation were involved in lipid metabolism (ACSL5, AGPAT9, FADS1, SLC27A4), xenobiotic metabolism (POR, ABCC2, CYP3A5) or the unfolded protein response, whereas most of the downregulated genes were involved in immune-related pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Among the most highly repressed genes upon PPARa activation were several chemokines (e.g. CXCL9-11, CCL8, CX3CL1, CXCL6), interferon g-induced genes (e.g. IFITM1, IFIT1, IFIT2, IFIT3) and numerous other immune-related genes (e.g. TLR3, NOS2, and LCN2).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Comparative analysis of gene regulation by Wy14643 between human liver slices and primary human hepatocytes showed that down-regulation of gene expression by PPARa is much better captured by liver slices as compared to primary hepatocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In particular, PPARa activation markedly suppressed immunity/inflammation-related genes in human liver slices but not in primary hepatocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, several putative new target genes of PPARa were identified that were commonly induced by PPARa activation in the two human liver model systems, including TSKU, RHOF, CA12 and VSIG10L. CONCLUSION:</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our paper demonstrates the suitability and superiority of human liver slices over primary hepatocytes for studying the functional role of PPARa in human liver.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our data underscore the major role of PPARa in regulation of hepatic lipid and xenobiotic metabolism in human liver and reveal a marked immuno-suppressive/anti-inflammatory effect of PPARa in human liver slices that may be therapeutically relevant for non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>UBASH3B/Sts-1-CBL axis regulates myeloid proliferation in human preleukemia induced by AML1-ETO.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The t(8;21) rearrangement, which creates the AML1-ETO fusion protein, represents the most common chromosomal translocation in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Clinical data suggest that CBL mutations are a frequent event in t(8;21) AML, but the role of CBL in AML1-ETO-induced leukemia has not been investigated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we demonstrate that CBL mutations collaborate with AML1-ETO to expand human CD34+ cells both in vitro and in a xenograft model.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CBL depletion by shRNA also promotes the growth of AML1-ETO cells, demonstrating the inhibitory function of endogenous CBL in t(8;21) AML.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mechanistically, loss of CBL function confers hyper-responsiveness to thrombopoietin and enhances STAT5/AKT/ERK/Src signaling in AML1-ETO cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, we found the protein tyrosine phosphatase UBASH3B/Sts-1, which is known to inhibit CBL function, is upregulated by AML1-ETO through transcriptional and miR-9-mediated regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>UBASH3B/Sts-1 depletion induces an aberrant pattern of CBL phosphorylation and impairs proliferation in AML1-ETO cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The growth inhibition caused by UBASH3B/Sts-1 depletion can be rescued by ectopic expression of CBL mutants, suggesting that UBASH3B/Sts-1 supports the growth of AML1-ETO cells partly through modulation of CBL function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our study reveals a role of CBL in restricting myeloid proliferation of human AML1-ETO-induced leukemia, and identifies UBASH3B/Sts-1 as a potential target for pharmaceutical intervention.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Wnt signaling in age-related macular degeneration: human macular tissue and mouse model.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>The wingless-type MMTV integration site (Wnt) signaling is a group of signal transduction pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In canonical Wnt pathway, Wnt ligands bind to low-density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 5 or 6 (LRP5 or LRP6), resulting in phosphorylation and activation of the receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We hypothesize that canonical Wnt pathway plays a role in the retinal lesion of age-related macular degeneration (AMD), a leading cause of irreversible central visual loss in elderly.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>We examined LRP6 phosphorylation and Wnt signaling cascade in human retinal sections and plasma kallistatin, an endogenous inhibitor of the Wnt pathway in AMD patients and non-AMD subjects.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also used the Ccl2 (-/-) /Cx3cr1</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(-/-) /rd8 and Ccl2 (-/-) /Cx3cr1</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(gfp/gfp) mouse models with AMD-like retinal degeneration to further explore the involvement of Wnt signaling activation in the retinal lesions in those models and to preclinically evaluate the role of Wnt signaling suppression as a potential therapeutic option for AMD.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>We found higher levels of LRP6 (a key Wnt signaling receptor) protein phosphorylation and transcripts of the Wnt pathway-targeted genes, as well as higher beta-catenin protein in AMD macula compared to controls.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Kallistatin was decreased in the plasma of AMD patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Retinal non-phosphorylated-b-catenin and phosphorylated-LRP6 were higher in Ccl2 (-/-) /Cx3cr1</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(-/-) /rd8</Gene>
<Gene>mice than that in wild type.</Gene>
<Gene>Intravitreal administration of an anti-LRP6 antibody slowed the progression of retinal lesions in Ccl2 (-/-) /Cx3cr1</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(-/-) /rd8 and Ccl2 (-/-) /Cx3cr1</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(gfp/gfp) mice.</Gene>
<Gene>Electroretinography of treated eyes exhibited larger amplitudes compared to controls in both mouse models.</Gene>
<Gene>A2E, a retinoid byproduct associated with AMD was lower in the treated eyes of Ccl2 (-/-) /Cx3cr1</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(-/-) /rd8</Gene>
<Gene>mice.</Gene>
<Gene>Anti-LRP6 also suppressed the expression of Tnf-a and Icam-1 in Ccl2 (-/-) /Cx3cr1</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>(-/-) /rd8 retinas.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Wnt signaling may be disturbed in AMD patients, which could contribute to the retinal inflammation and increased A2E levels found in AMD.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Aberrant activation of canonical Wnt signaling might also contribute to the focal retinal degenerative lesions of mouse models with Ccl2 and Cx3cr1 deficiency, and intravitreal administration of anti-LRP6 antibody could be beneficial by deactivating the canonical Wnt pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HMGB1 promotes HCC progression partly by downregulating p21 via ERK/c-Myc pathway and upregulating MMP-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>High-mobility group box 1 (HMGB1) was found to be over-expressed in many kinds of human cancer, which binds with several receptors and activates RAGE-Ras-MAPK, Toll-like receptors, NF-kB, and Src family kinase signaling pathways and plays a crucial role in tumorigenesis and cancer progression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the function and mechanism of HMGB1 in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) remain unclear.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of HMGB1 on HCC progression and explore new molecular mechanism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>HMGB1 transient knockdown, stable knockdown, and re-expression were performed by transfection with specific siRNA, shRNA, or expression vector in HCCLM3 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Results showed that transient knockdown HMGB1 prevented cell proliferation, promoted apoptosis, induced S phase arrest, and inhibited migration and invasion in vitro, and stable knockdown HMGB1 inhibited xenograft growth in Balb/c athymic mice in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular mechanism investigation revealed that knockdown HMGB1 significantly reduced the activation of MAPKs, including ERK1/2, p38, SAPK/JNK, as well as MAPKKs (MEK1/2, SEK1) and its substrates (c-Jun, c-Myc); downregulated NF-kB/p65 expression and phosphorylation level; decreased MMP-2 expression and activity; and upregulated p21 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, c-Myc was firstly found to be involved in the promoting function of HMGB1 on HCC progression, which provided a novel clue for the inhibitory effect of HMGB1 on p21 expression by a p53-independent pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, these findings indicated that HMGB1 promoted HCC progression partly by enhancing the ERK1/2 and NF-kB pathways, upregulating MMP-2, and downregulating p21 via an ERK/c-Myc pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Role of MCP-1 on inflammatory processes and metabolic dysfunction following high-fat feedings in the FVB/N strain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Monocyte chemoattractant protein 1 (MCP-1) is known to be an important chemokine for macrophage recruitment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, targeting MCP-1 may prevent the perturbations associated with macrophage-induced inflammation in adipose tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, inconsistencies in the available animal literature have questioned the role of this chemokine in this process.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The purpose of this study was to examine the role of MCP-1 on obesity-related pathologies.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>Wild-type and MCP-1-deficient mice on an friend virus B NIH (FVB/N) background were assigned to either low-fat diet or high-fat diet (HFD) treatment for a period of 16 weeks.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Body weight and body composition were measured weekly and monthly, respectively.</Gene>
<Gene>Fasting blood glucose and insulin, and glucose tolerance were measured at 16 weeks.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Macrophages, T-cell markers, inflammatory mediators and markers of fibrosis were examined in the adipose tissue at the time of killing the mice.</Gene>

<Gene>RESULTS: As expected, HFD increased adiposity (body weight, fat mass, fat percent and adipocyte size), metabolic dysfunction (impaired glucose metabolism and insulin resistance) macrophage number (CD11b(+)F480(+) cells, and gene expression of EMR1 and CD11c), T-cell markers (gene expression of CD4 and CD8), inflammatory mediators (pNFkB and pJNK, and mRNA expression of MCP-1, CCL5, C-X-C motif chemokine-14, tumor necrosis factor a (TNF-a) and interleukin-6 (IL-6)) and fibrosis (expression of IL-10, IL-13, TGF-b and matrix metalloproteinase-2 (MMP2); P<0.05).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, contrary to our hypothesis, MCP-1 deficiency exacerbated many of these responses resulting in a further increase in adiposity (body weight, fat mass, fat percent and adipocyte size), metabolic dysregulation, macrophage markers (EMR1), inflammatory cell infiltration and fibrosis (formation of type I and III collagens, mRNA expression of IL-10 and MMP2; P<0.05).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS: These data suggest that MCP-1 may be a necessary component of the inflammatory response required for adipose tissue protection, remodeling and healthy expansion in the FVB/N strain in response to HFD feedings.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Search for regulatory factors of the pituitary-specific transcription factor PROP1 gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Pituitary-specific transcription factor PROP1, a factor important for pituitary organogenesis, appears on rat embryonic day 11.5 (E11.5) in SOX2-expressing stem/progenitor cells and always coexists with SOX2 throughout life.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PROP1-positive cells at one point occupy all cells in Rathke's pouch, followed by a rapid decrease in their number.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Their regulatory factors, except for RBP-J, have not yet been clarified.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study aimed to use the 3 kb upstream region and 1st intron of mouse prop1 to pinpoint a group of factors selected on the basis of expression in the early pituitary gland for expression of Prop1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Reporter assays for SOX2 and RBP-J showed that the stem/progenitor marker SOX2 has cell type-dependent inhibitory and activating functions through the proximal and distal upstream regions of Prop1, respectively, while RBP-J had small regulatory activity in some cell lines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Reporter assays for another 39 factors using the 3 kb upstream regions in CHO cells ultimately revealed that 8 factors, MSX2, PAX6, PIT1, PITX1, PITX2, RPF1, SOX8 and SOX11, but not RBP-J, regulate Prop1 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, a synergy effect with SOX2 was observed for an additional 10 factors, FOXJ1, HES1, HEY1, HEY2, KLF6, MSX1, RUNX1, TEAD2, YBX2 and ZFP36Ll, which did not show substantial independent action.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, we demonstrated 19 candidates, including SOX2, to be regulatory factors of Prop1 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Dioscin alleviates alcoholic liver fibrosis by attenuating hepatic stellate cell activation via the TLR4/MyD88/NF-kB signaling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The present work aimed to investigate the activities and underlying mechanisms of dioscin against alcoholic liver fibrosis (ALF).</Gene>
<Gene>In vivo liver fibrosis in mice was induced by an alcoholic liquid diet, and in vitro studies were performed on activated HSC-T6 and LX2 cells treated with lipopolysaccharide.</Gene>

<Gene>Our results showed that dioscin significantly attenuated hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) activation, improved collagen accumulation, and attenuated inflammation through down-regulating the levels of myeloid differentiation factor 88 (MyD88), nuclear factor kB (NF-kB), interleukin (IL)-1, IL-6 and tumour necrosis factor-a by decreasing Toll-like receptor (TLR)4 expression both in vivo and in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TLR4 overexpression was also decreased by dioscin, leading to the markedly down-regulated levels of MyD88, NF-kB, transforming growth factor-b1 (TGF-b1), a-smooth muscle actin (a-SMA) and type I collagen (COL1A1) in cultured HSCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Suppression of cellular MyD88 by ST2825 or abrogation of NF-kB by pyrrolidine dithiocarbamate eliminated the inhibitory effects of dioscin on the levels of TGF-b1, a-SMA and COL1A1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In a word, dioscin exhibited potent effects against ALF via altering TLR4/MyD88/NF-kB signaling pathway, which provided novel insights into the mechanisms of this compound as an antifibrogenic candidate for the treatment of ALF in the future.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transgelin increases metastatic potential of colorectal cancer cells in vivo and alters expression of genes involved in cell motility.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Transgelin is an actin-binding protein that promotes motility in normal cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although the role of transgelin in cancer is controversial, a number of studies have shown that elevated levels correlate with aggressive tumor behavior, advanced stage, and poor prognosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we sought to determine the role of transgelin more directly by determining whether experimental manipulation of transgelin levels in colorectal cancer (CRC) cells led to changes in metastatic potential in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>Isogenic CRC cell lines that differ in transgelin expression were characterized using in vitro assays of growth and invasiveness and a mouse tail vein assay of experimental metastasis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Downstream effects of transgelin overexpression were investigated by gene expression profiling and quantitative PCR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Stable overexpression of transgelin in RKO cells, which have low endogenous levels, led to increased invasiveness, growth at low density, and growth in soft agar.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression also led to an increase in the number and size of lung metastases in the mouse tail vein injection model.</Gene>
<Gene>Similarly, attenuation of transgelin expression in HCT116 cells, which have high endogenous levels, decreased metastases in the same model.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Investigation of mRNA expression patterns showed that transgelin overexpression altered the levels of approximately 250 other transcripts, with over-representation of genes that affect function of actin or other cytoskeletal proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Changes included increases in HOOK1, SDCCAG8, ENAH/Mena, and TNS1 and decreases in EMB, BCL11B, and PTPRD.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS: Increases or decreases in transgelin levels have reciprocal effects on tumor cell behavior, with higher expression promoting metastasis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Chronic overexpression influences steady-state levels of mRNAs for metastasis-related genes.</Gene>
<Gene>NF-kB functions as a molecular link between tumor cells and Th1/Tc1 T cells in the tumor microenvironment to exert radiation-mediated tumor suppression.</Gene>
label: Gene
