text: <Gene>Radiation modulates both tumor cells and immune cells in the tumor microenvironment to exert its anti-tumor activity; however, the molecular connection between tumor cells and immune cells that mediates radiation-exerted tumor suppression activity in the tumor microenvironment is largely unknown.</Gene>
<Gene>We report here that radiation induces rapid activation of the p65/p50 and p50/p50 NF-kB complexes in human soft tissue sarcoma (STS) cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Radiation-activated p65/p50 and p50/p50 bind to the TNFa promoter to activate its transcription in STS cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Radiation-induced TNFa induces tumor cell death in an autocrine manner.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A sublethal dose of Smac mimetic BV6 induces cIAP1 and cIAP2 degradation to increase tumor cell sensitivity to radiation-induced cell death in vitro and to enhance radiation-mediated suppression of STS xenografts in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of caspases, RIP1, or RIP3 blocks radiation/TNFa-induced cell death, whereas inhibition of RIP1 blocks TNFa-induced caspase activation, suggesting that caspases and RIP1 act sequentially to mediate the non-compensatory cell death pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, we determined in a syngeneic sarcoma mouse model that radiation up-regulates IRF3, IFNb, and the T cell chemokines CCL2 and CCL5 in the tumor microenvironment, which are associated with activation and increased infiltration of Th1/Tc1 T cells in the tumor microenvironment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, tumor-infiltrating T cells are in their active form since both the perforin and FasL pathways are activated in irradiated tumor tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consequently, combined BV6 and radiation completely suppressed tumor growth in vivo.</Gene>
<Gene>Therefore, radiation-induced NF-kB functions as a molecular link between tumor cells and immune cells in the tumor microenvironment for radiation-mediated tumor suppression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>NOTCH1 and SOX10 are Essential for Proliferation and Radiation Resistance of Cancer Stem-Like Cells in Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PURPOSE:</Gene>

<Gene>Although the existence of cancer stem cells (CSC) in adenoid cystic carcinoma (ACC) has been proposed, lack of assays for their propagation and uncertainty about molecular markers prevented their characterization.</Gene>
<Gene>Our objective was to isolate CSC from ACC and provide insight into signaling pathways that support their propagation.</Gene>

<Gene>EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN: To isolate CSC from ACC and characterize them, we used ROCK inhibitor-supplemented cell culture, immunomagnetic cell sorting, andin vitro/in vivoassays for CSC viability and tumorigenicity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>We identified in ACC CD133-positive CSC that expressed NOTCH1 and SOX10, formed spheroids, and initiated tumors in nude mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD133(+)ACC cells produced activated NOTCH1 (N1ICD) and generated CD133(-)cells that expressed JAG1 as well as neural differentiation factors NR2F1, NR2F2, and p27Kip1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Knockdowns ofNOTCH1, SOX10, and their common effectorFABP7had negative effects on each other, inhibited spheroidogenesis, and induced cell death pointing at their essential roles in CSC maintenance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Downstream effects ofFABP7knockdown included suppression of a broad spectrum of genes involved in proliferation, ribosome biogenesis, and metabolism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Among proliferation-linked NOTCH1/FABP7 targets, we identified SKP2 and its substrate p27Kip1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A g-secretase inhibitor, DAPT, selectively depleted CD133(+)cells, suppressed N1ICD and SKP2, induced p27Kip1, inhibited ACC growthin vivo, and sensitized CD133(+)cells to radiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS: These results establish in the majority of ACC the presence of a previously uncharacterized population of CD133(+)cells with neural stem properties, which are driven by SOX10, NOTCH1, and FABP7.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sensitivity of these cells to Notch inhibition and their dependence on SKP2 offer new opportunities for targeted ACC therapies.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Artery Tertiary Lymphoid Organs Control Multilayered Territorialized Atherosclerosis B-Cell Responses in Aged ApoE-/- Mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>OBJECTIVE:</Gene>
<Gene>Explore aorta B-cell immunity in aged apolipoprotein E-deficient (ApoE(-/-))</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>mice.</Gene>

<Gene>APPROACH AND RESULTS: Transcript maps, fluorescence-activated cell sorting, immunofluorescence analyses, cell transfers, and Ig-ELISPOT (enzyme-linked immunospot) assays showed multilayered atherosclerosis B-cell responses in artery tertiary lymphoid organs (ATLOs).</Gene>

<Gene>Aging-associated aorta B-cell-related transcriptomes were identified, and transcript atlases revealed highly territorialized B-cell responses in ATLOs versus atherosclerotic lesions: ATLOs showed upregulation of bona fide B-cell genes, including Cd19, Ms4a1 (Cd20), Cd79a/b, and Ighm although intima plaques preferentially expressed molecules involved in non-B effector responses toward B-cell-derived mediators, that is, Fcgr3 (Cd16), Fcer1g (Cd23), and the C1q family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ATLOs promoted B-cell recruitment.</Gene>
<Gene>ATLO B-2 B cells included naive, transitional, follicular, germinal center, switched IgG1(+), IgA(+), and IgE(+) memory cells, plasmablasts, and long-lived plasma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ATLOs recruited large numbers of B-1 cells whose subtypes were skewed toward interleukin-10(+) B-1b cells versus interleukin-10(-) B-1a cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ATLO B-1 cells and plasma cells constitutively produced IgM and IgG and a fraction of plasma cells expressed interleukin-10.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, ApoE(-/-)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>mice showed increased germinal center B cells in renal lymph nodes, IgM-producing plasma cells in the bone marrow, and higher IgM and anti-MDA-LDL (malondialdehyde-modified low-density lipoprotein) IgG serum titers.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS: ATLOs orchestrate dichotomic, territorialized, and multilayered B-cell responses in the diseased aorta; germinal center reactions indicate generation of autoimmune B cells within the diseased arterial wall during aging.</Gene>
<Gene>Calreticulin-mutant proteins induce megakaryocytic signaling to transform hematopoietic cells and undergo accelerated degradation and Golgi-mediated secretion.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Somatic calreticulin (CALR), Janus kinase 2 (JAK2), and thrombopoietin receptor (MPL) mutations essentially show mutual exclusion in myeloproliferative neoplasms (MPN), suggesting that they activate common oncogenic pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recent data have shown that MPL function is essential for CALR mutant-driven MPN.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the exact role and the mechanisms of action of CALR mutants have not been fully elucidated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>The murine myeloid cell line 32D and human HL60 cells overexpressing the most frequent CALR type 1 and type 2 frameshift mutants were generated to analyze the first steps of cellular transformation, in the presence and absence of MPL expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, mutant CALR protein stability and secretion were examined using brefeldin A, MG132, spautin-1, and tunicamycin treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>The present study demonstrates that the expression of endogenous Mpl, CD41, and the key megakaryocytic transcription factor NF-E2 is stimulated by type 1 and type 2 CALR mutants, even in the absence of exogenous MPL.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutant CALR expressing 32D cells spontaneously acquired cytokine independence, and this was associated with increased Mpl mRNA expression, CD41, and NF-E2 protein as well as constitutive activation of downstream signaling and response to JAK inhibitor treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Exogenous expression of MPL led to constitutive activation of STAT3 and 5, ERK1/2, and AKT, cytokine-independent growth, and reduction of apoptosis similar to the effects seen in the spontaneously outgrown cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We observed low CALR-mutant protein amounts in cellular lysates of stably transduced cells, and this was due to accelerated protein degradation that occurred independently from the ubiquitin-proteasome system as well as autophagy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CALR-mutant degradation was attenuated by MPL expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, we found high levels of mutated CALR and loss of downstream signaling after blockage of the secretory pathway and protein glycosylation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>These findings demonstrate the potency of CALR mutants to drive expression of megakaryocytic differentiation markers such as NF-E2 and CD41 as well as Mpl.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, CALR mutants undergo accelerated protein degradation that involves the secretory pathway and/or protein glycosylation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Prognostic factors in the myoepithelial-like spindle cell type of metaplastic breast cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>Metaplastic breast carcinoma (MBC) comprises a heterogeneous group of tumors with difficult to predict biological behavior.</Gene>
<Gene>A subset of MBC, characterized by spindle-shaped tumor cells with a myoepithelial-like immunophenotype, was entered into a retrospective study (n = 42, median follow-up time 43 months).</Gene>

<Gene>Molecular parameters (DNA sequences of mutation hot spots in AKT1, ALK, APC, BRAF, CDH1, CTNNB1, EGFR, ERBB2, FBXW7, FGFR2, FOXL2, GNAQ, GNAS, KIT, KRAS, MAP2K1, MET, MSH6, NRAS, PDGFRA, PIK3CA, PTEN, SF3B1, SMAD4, SRC, SRSF2, STK11, TP53, and U2AF1; copy numbers for EGFR, c-myc, FGFR, PLAG, c-met) were assessed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>None of the patients had axillary lymph node involvement.</Gene>
<Gene>In 13 cases, local recurrence developed after surgery (30.9 %).</Gene>
<Gene>Distant metastasis occurred in seven patients (17 %; four after local recurrence).</Gene>
<Gene>The most frequent genetic alteration was PIK3CA mutation (50 % of cases).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>None of the pathological parameters (size, grade, stage, Ki-67 labeling index) was significantly associated with disease-free survival (DFS) or overall survival (OS).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PIK3CA mutation, especially the H1047R type, tended to adversely affect OS.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Type of resection (mastectomy vs. breast-conserving therapy, width of margins) or adjuvant radiotherapy had no influence on DFS or OS, whereas in the group treated with radio-/chemotherapy, no local recurrence or metastasis and no death occurred.</Gene>

<Gene>We conclude that the spindle cell type of MBC with myoepithelial features exhibits a higher frequency of PIK3CA mutation than other types of metaplastic or basal-like breast cancer and may benefit from combined radio-/chemotherapy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Classical pathological parameters are not helpful in identifying the high-risk tumors among this subgroup of MBC.</Gene>
<Gene>E2F and GATA switches turn off WD repeat domain 77 expression in differentiating cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>WDR77 (WD repeat domain 77) is expressed during earlier lung development when cells are rapidly proliferating, but is absent from adult lung.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It is re-activated during lung tumorigenesis and is essential for lung cancer cell proliferation.</Gene>
<Gene>Signalling pathways/molecules that control WDR77 gene expression are unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Promoter mapping, gel shift assay and ChIP revealed that the WDR77 promoter contains bona fide response elements for E2F and GATA transcriptional factors as demonstrated in prostate cancer, lung cancer and erythroid cells, as well as in mouse lung tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The WDR77 promoter is transactivated by E2F1, E2F3, GATA1 and GATA6, but suppressed by E2F6, GATA1 and GATA3 in prostate cancer PC3 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>WDR77 expression is associated with E2F1, E2F3, GATA2 and GATA6 occupancy on the WDR77 gene, whereas, in contrast, E2F6, GATA1 and GATA3 occupancy is associated with the loss of WDR77 expression during erythroid maturation and lung development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>More importantly, the loss of WDR77 expression that results from E2F and GATA switches is required for cellular differentiation of erythroid and lung epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, lung cancer cells avoid post-mitotic differentiation by sustaining WDR77 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Altogether, the present study provides a novel molecular mechanism by which WDR77 is regulated during erythroid and lung development and lung tumorigenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A Critical Role for CD200R Signaling in Limiting the Growth and Metastasis of CD200+ Melanoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD200 is a cell surface glycoprotein that functions through engaging CD200R on cells of the myeloid lineage and inhibits their functions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of CD200 was implicated in a variety of human cancer cells, including melanoma cells; however, its roles in tumor growth and immunity are not clearly understood.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we used CD200R-deficient mice and the B16 tumor model to evaluate this issue.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We found that CD200R-deficient mice exhibited accelerated growth of CD200(+), but not CD200(-), B16 tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Strikingly, CD200R-deficient mice receiving CD200(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>B16 cells i.v. exhibited massive tumor growth in multiple organs, including liver, lung, kidney, and peritoneal cavity, whereas the growth of the same tumors in wild-type mice was limited.</Gene>

<Gene>CD200(+) tumors grown in CD200R-deficient mice contained higher numbers of CD11b(+)Ly6C(+) myeloid cells, exhibited increased expression of VEGF and HIF1a genes with increased angiogenesis, and showed significantly reduced infiltration of CD4(+) and CD8(+) T cells, presumably as the result of reduced expression of T cell chemokines, such as CXCL9 and CXCL16.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The liver from CD200R-deficient mice, under metastatic growth of CD200(+) tumors, contained significantly increased numbers of CD11b(+)Gr1(-) myeloid cells and Foxp3(+) regulatory T cells and reduced numbers of NK cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Liver T cells also had a reduced capacity to produce IFN-g or TNF-a. Taken together, we revealed a critical role for CD200R signaling in limiting the growth and metastasis of CD200(+) tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, targeting CD200R signaling may potentially interfere with the metastatic growth of CD200(+) tumors, like melanoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Adrenomedullin promotes the growth of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma through recruitment of myelomonocytic cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Stromal infiltration of myelomonocytic cells is a hallmark of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) and is related to a poor prognosis.</Gene>
<Gene>However, the detailed mechanism for the recruitment of myelomonocytic cells to pancreatic cancer tissue remains unclear.</Gene>

<Gene>In the present study, pancreatic cancer cells secreted high levels of adrenomedullin (ADM), and CD11b+ myelomonocytic cells expressed all components of ADM receptors, including GPR182, CRLR, RAMP2 and RAMP3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ADM enhanced the migration and invasion of myelomonocytic cells through activation of the MAPK, PI3K/Akt and eNOS signaling pathways, as well as the expression and activity of MMP-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ADM also promoted the adhesion and trans-endothelial migration of myelomonocytic cells by increasing expression of VCAM-1 and ICAM-1 in endothelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, ADM induced macrophages and myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) to express pro-tumor phenotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ADM knockdown in tumor-bearing mice or administration of AMA, an ADM antagonist, significantly inhibited the recruitment of myelomonocytic cells and tumor angiogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, in vivo depletion of myelomonocytic cells using clodronate liposomes suppressed the progression of PDAC.</Gene>
<Gene>These results reveal a novel function of ADM in PDAC, and suggest ADM is a promising target in the treatment of PDAC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TGF-b1 promotes colorectal cancer immune escape by elevating B7-H3 and B7-H4 via the miR-155/miR-143 axis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transforming growth factor-beta 1 (TGF-b1) suppresses T cell function, promoting tumor immune escape.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Yet, whether the depression of TGF-b1 on T cell function is mediated by co-inhibitory molecules B7-H3 and B7-H4 remains largely unclear.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we demonstrated that TGF-b1 elevated the expression of miR-155 in colorectal cancer cells through SMAD3 and SMAD4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The upregulated miR-155 attenuated miR-143 by inhibiting its direct target, the transcription factor CEBPB.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consequently, the direct target genes of miR-143, B7-H3 and B7-H4, were augmented in the cytoplasm and membrane of tumor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Over-expression of B7-H3 and B7-H4 in HCT-116 cells induced T cells to secrete TGF-b1 and the immunosuppressive cytokines IL-2, IL-6, and IL-17.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Restoration of miR-143 inhibited the growth of HCT-116 xenograft tumors in mice, and also repressed the expression of B7-H3 and B7-H4 in the tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, this study reveals the mechanism by which TGF-b1 leads to T cell-mediated tumor evasion through an increase in B7-H3 and B7-H4 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Catalytically defective receptor protein tyrosine kinase PTK7 enhances invasive phenotype by inducing MMP-9 through activation of AP-1 and NF-kB in esophageal squamous cell carcinoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Protein tyrosine kinase 7 (PTK7), a member of the catalytically defective receptor protein tyrosine kinase family, is upregulated in various cancers including esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we have explored the molecular mechanism of PTK7-dependent invasiveness in ESCC cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PTK7 knockdown reduced gelatin degradation and MMP-9 secretion in cultures of ESCC TE-10 cells, and showed reduced levels of MMP9 mRNA using real-time RT-PCR and luciferase reporter assays.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PTK7 knockdown decreased not only phosphorylation of NF-kB, IkB, ERK, and JNK, but also nuclear localization of NF-kB and AP-1 consisting of c-Fos and c-Jun. Activation of AP-1 and NF-kB requires PTK7-mediated activation of tyrosine kinases, including Src.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, NF-kB activation by PTK7 involves the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PTK7-mediated upregulation of MMP9 was also observed in other ESCC cell lines and in three-dimensional cultures of TE-10 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, MMP-9 expression positively correlated with PTK7 expression in ESCC tumor tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings demonstrate that PTK7 upregulates MMP9 through activation of AP-1 and NF-kB and, thus increases invasive properties of ESCC cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sertoli Cell Wt1 Regulates Peritubular Myoid Cell and Fetal Leydig Cell Differentiation during Fetal Testis Development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sertoli cells play a significant role in regulating fetal testis compartmentalization to generate testis cords and interstitium during development.</Gene>
<Gene>The Sertoli cell Wilms' tumor 1 (Wt1) gene, which encodes ~24 zinc finger-containing transcription factors, is known to play a crucial role in fetal testis cord assembly and maintenance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, whether Wt1 regulates fetal testis compartmentalization by modulating the development of peritubular myoid cells (PMCs) and/or fetal Leydig cells (FLCs) remains unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using a Wt1-/flox; Amh-Cre mouse model by deleting Wt1 in Sertoli cells (Wt1SC-cKO) at embryonic day 14.5 (E14.5), Wt1 was found to regulate PMC and FLC development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Wt1 deletion in fetal testis Sertoli cells caused aberrant differentiation and proliferation of PMCs, FLCs and interstitial progenitor cells from embryo to newborn, leading to abnormal fetal testis interstitial development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Specifically, the expression of PMC marker genes a-Sma, Myh11 and Des, and interstitial progenitor cell marker gene Vcam1 were down-regulated, whereas FLC marker genes StAR, Cyp11a1, Cyp17a1 and Hsd3b1 were up-regulated, in neonatal Wt1SC-cKO testes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The ratio of PMC:FLC were also reduced in Wt1SC-cKO testes, concomitant with a down-regulation of Notch signaling molecules Jag 1, Notch 2, Notch 3, and Hes1 in neonatal Wt1SC-cKO testes, illustrating changes in the differentiation status of FLC from their interstitial progenitor cells during fetal testis development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In summary, Wt1 regulates the development of FLC and interstitial progenitor cell lineages through Notch signaling, and it also plays a role in PMC development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, these effects confer fetal testis compartmentalization.</Gene>
<Gene>TNFa drives pulmonary arterial hypertension by suppressing the BMP type-II receptor and altering NOTCH signalling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Heterozygous germ-line mutations in the bone morphogenetic protein type-II receptor (BMPR-II) gene underlie heritable pulmonary arterial hypertension (HPAH).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although inflammation promotes PAH, the mechanisms by which inflammation and BMPR-II dysfunction conspire to cause disease remain unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we identify that tumour necrosis factor-a (TNFa) selectively reduces BMPR-II transcription and mediates post-translational BMPR-II cleavage via the sheddases, ADAM10 and ADAM17 in pulmonary artery smooth muscle cells (PASMCs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TNFa-mediated suppression of BMPR-II subverts BMP signalling, leading to BMP6-mediated PASMC proliferation via preferential activation of an ALK2/ACTR-IIA signalling axis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, TNFa, via SRC family kinases, increases pro-proliferative NOTCH2 signalling in HPAH PASMCs with reduced BMPR-II expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We confirm this signalling switch in rodent models of PAH and demonstrate that anti-TNFa immunotherapy reverses disease progression, restoring normal BMP/NOTCH signalling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, these findings identify mechanisms by which BMP and TNFa signalling contribute to disease, and suggest a tractable approach for therapeutic intervention in PAH.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bayesian network inference modeling identifies TRIB1 as a novel regulator of cell cycle progression and survival in cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Molecular networks governing cellular responses to targeted therapies are complex dynamic systems with non-intuitive behaviors.</Gene>
<Gene>Here we applied a novel computational strategy to infer probabilistic causal relationships between network components based on gene expression.</Gene>
<Gene>We constructed a model comprised of an ensemble of networks using multidimensional data from cell line models of cell cycle arrest caused by inhibition of MEK1/2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Through simulation of reverse-engineered Bayesian network modeling, we generated predictions of G1-S transition.</Gene>
<Gene>The model identified known components of the cell cycle machinery, such as CCND1, CCNE2 and CDC25A, as well as novel regulators of G1-S transition IER2, TRIB1 and TRIM27.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Experimental validation of this model confirmed 10 of 12 predicted genes to have a role in progression through the G1-S phase transition of the cell cycle.</Gene>
<Gene>Further analysis showed that TRIB1 regulated the cyclin D1 promoter via NF-kB and AP-1 sites and sensitized cells to TRAIL-induced apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In clinical specimens of breast cancer, TRIB1 levels correlated with expression of NF-kB and its target genes IL-8 and CSF2, and TRIB1 copy number and expression were predictive of clinical outcome.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together, our results establish a critical role for TRIB1 in cell cycle and survival that is mediated via the modulation of NF-kB signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activated niacin receptor HCA2 inhibits chemoattractant-mediated macrophage migration via Gbg/PKC/ERK1/2 pathway and heterologous receptor desensitization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The niacin receptor HCA2 is implicated in controlling inflammatory host responses with yet poorly understood mechanistic basis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We previously reported that HCA2 in A431 epithelial cells transduced Gbg-protein kinase C- and Gbg-metalloproteinase/EGFR-dependent MAPK/ERK signaling cascades.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we investigated the role of HCA2 in macrophage-mediated inflammation and the underlying mechanisms.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We found that proinflammatory stimulants LPS, IL-6 and IL-1b up-regulated the expression of HCA2 on macrophages.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Niacin significantly inhibited macrophage chemotaxis in response to chemoattractants fMLF and CCL2 by disrupting polarized distribution of F-actin and Gb protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Niacin showed a selected additive effect on chemoattractant-induced activation of ERK1/2, JNK and PI3K pathways, but only the MEK inhibitor UO126 reduced niacin-mediated inhibition of macrophage chemotaxis, while activation of ERK1/2 by EGF alone did not inhibit fMLF-mediated migration of HEK293T cells co-expressing HCA2 and fMLF receptor FPR1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, niacin induced heterologous desensitization and internalization of FPR1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, niacin rescued mice from septic shock by diminishing inflammatory symptoms and the effect was abrogated in HCA2(-/-) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that Gbg/PKC-dependent ERK1/2 activation and heterologous desensitization of chemoattractant receptors are involved in the inhibition of chemoattractant-induced migration of macrophages by niacin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, HCA2 plays a critical role in host protection against pro-inflammatory insults.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>NK1.1(-) CD4(+) NKG2D(+) T cells suppress DSS-induced colitis in mice through production of TGF-b.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>NKG2D(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>T cells are associated with tumour, infection and autoimmune diseases.</Gene>
<Gene>Some CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>NKG2D(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>T cells secrete IFN-g and TNF-a to promote inflammation, but others produce TGF-b and FasL to facilitate tumour evasion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, murine CD4(+) NKG2D(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T cells were further classified into NK1.1(-) CD4(+) NKG2D(+) and NK1.1(+) CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NKG2D(+) subpopulations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The frequency of NK1.1(-) CD4(+) NKG2D(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>cells decreased in inflamed colons, whereas more NK1.1(+) CD4(+) NKG2D(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>cells infiltrated into colons of mice with DSS-induced colitis.</Gene>
<Gene>NK1.1(-) CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NKG2D(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>cells expressed TGF-b and FasL without secreting IFN-g, IL-21 and IL-17 and displayed no cytotoxicity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The adoptive transfer of NK1.1(-) CD4(+) NKG2D(+) cells suppressed DSS-induced colitis largely dependent on TGF-b. NK1.1(-) CD4(+) NKG2D(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>cells did not expressed Foxp3, CD223 (LAG-3) and GITR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The subpopulation was distinct from NK1.1(+) CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NKG2D(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>cells in terms of surface markers and RNA transcription.</Gene>
<Gene>NK1.1(-) CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NKG2D(+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>cells also differed from Th2 or Th17 cells because the former did not express GATA-3 and ROR-gt.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, NK1.1(-) CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
