label: Gene

text: <Gene>cells exhibited immune regulatory functions, and this T cell subset could be developed to suppress inflammation in clinics.</Gene>
<Gene>CD38 promotes angiotensin II-induced cardiac hypertrophy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cardiac hypertrophy is an early hallmark during the clinical course of heart failure and regulated by various signalling pathways.</Gene>

<Gene>Recently, we observed that mouse embryonic fibroblasts from CD38 knockout mice were significantly resistant to oxidative stress such as H2 O2 -induced injury and hypoxia/reoxygenation-induced injury.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, we also found that CD38 knockout mice protected heart from ischaemia reperfusion injury through activating SIRT1/FOXOs-mediated antioxidative stress pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the role of CD38 in cardiac hypertrophy is not explored.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we investigated the roles and mechanisms of CD38 in angiotensin II (Ang-II)-induced cardiac hypertrophy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Following 14 days of Ang-II infusion with osmotic mini-pumps, a comparable hypertension was generated in both of CD38 knockout and wild-type mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the cardiac hypertrophy and fibrosis were much more severe in wild-type mice compared with CD38 knockout mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Consistently, RNAi-induced knockdown of CD38 decreased the gene expressions of atrial natriuretic factor (ANF) and brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) and reactive oxygen species generation in Ang-II-stimulated H9c2 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the expression of SIRT3 was elevated in CD38 knockdown H9c2 cells, in which SIRT3 may further activate the FOXO3 antioxidant pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The intracellular Ca(2+) release induced by Ang-II markedly decreased in CD38 knockdown H9c2 cells, which might be associated with the decrease of nuclear translocation of NFATc4 and inhibition of ERK/AKT phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We concluded that CD38 plays an essential role in cardiac hypertrophy probably via inhibition of SIRT3 expression and activation of Ca(2+) -NFAT signalling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, CD38 may be a novel target for treating cardiac hypertrophy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Dose-dependent functions of fibroblast growth factor 9 regulate the fate of murine XY primordial germ cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Male differentiation of primordial germ cells (PGCs) is initiated by the inhibition of entry into meiosis and exposure to male-inducing factor(s), which are regulated by somatic elements of the developing gonad.</Gene>
<Gene>Fibroblast growth factor 9 (FGF9) produced by pre-Sertoli cells is essential for male gonadal differentiation and also contributes to survival and male differentiation of XY PGCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, it is not clear how FGF9 regulates PGC fate.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using a PGC culture system, we identified dose-dependent, fate-determining functions of FGF9 in XY PGCs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Treatment with low levels of FGF9 (0.2 ng/ml) increased expression of male-specific Dnmt3L and Nanos2 in XY PGCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, treatment with high levels of FGF9 (25 ng/ml) suppressed male-specific gene expression and stimulated proliferation of XY PGCs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Western blotting showed that low FGF9 treatment enhanced p38 MAPK (mitogen-activated protein kinase) phosphorylation in the same cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, high FGF9 treatment significantly stimulated the ERK (extracellular signal-regulated kinase)1/2 signaling pathway in XY PGCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We investigated the relationship between the ERK1/2 signaling pathway stimulated by high FGF9 and regulation of PGC proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>An ERK1/2 inhibitor (U0126) suppressed the PGC proliferation that would otherwise be stimulated by high FGF9 treatment, and increased Nanos2 expression in XY PGCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, a p38 MAPK inhibitor (SB202190) significantly suppressed Nanos2 expression that would otherwise be stimulated by low FGF9 in XY PGCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, our results suggest that stage-specific expression of FGF9 in XY gonads regulates the balance between proliferation and differentiation of XY PGCs in a dose-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A single amino acid substitution confers B-cell clonogenic activity to the HIV-1 matrix protein p17.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recent data highlight the presence, in HIV-1-seropositive patients with lymphoma, of p17 variants (vp17s) endowed with B-cell clonogenicity, suggesting a role of vp17s in lymphomagenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We investigated the mechanisms responsible for the functional disparity on B cells between a wild-type p17 (refp17) and a vp17 named S75X. Here, we show that a single Arginine (R) to Glycine (G) mutation at position 76 in the refp17 backbone (p17R76G), as in the S75X variant, is per se sufficient to confer a B-cell clonogenic potential to the viral protein and modulate, through activation of the PTEN/PI3K/Akt signaling pathway,</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>different molecules involved in apoptosis inhibition (CASP-9, CASP-7, DFF-45, NPM, YWHAZ, Src, PAX2, MAPK8), cell cycle promotion and cancer progression (CDK1, CDK2, CDK8, CHEK1, CHEK2, GSK-3 beta, NPM, PAK1, PP2C-alpha).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, the only R to G mutation at position 76 was found to strongly impact on protein folding and oligomerization by altering the hydrogen bond network.</Gene>

<Gene>This generates a conformational shift in the p17 R76G mutant which enables a functional epitope(s), masked in refp17, to elicit B-cell growth-promoting signals after its interaction with a still unknown receptor(s).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings offer new opportunities to understand the molecular mechanisms accounting for the B-cell growth-promoting activity of vp17s.</Gene>
<Gene>TPL-2 restricts Ccl24-dependent immunity to Heligmosomoides polygyrus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TPL-2 (COT, MAP3K8) kinase activates the MEK1/2-ERK1/2 MAPK signaling pathway in innate immune responses following TLR, TNFR1 and IL-1R stimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TPL-2 contributes to type-1/Th17-mediated autoimmunity and control of intracellular pathogens.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We recently demonstrated TPL-2 reduces severe airway allergy to house dust mite by negatively regulating type-2 responses.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the present study, we found that TPL-2 deficiency resulted in resistance to Heligmosomoides polygyrus infection, with accelerated worm expulsion, reduced fecal egg burden and reduced worm fitness.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using co-housing experiments, we found resistance to infection in TPL-2 deficient mice (Map3k8-/-) was independent of microbiota alterations in H. polygyrus infected WT and Map3k8-/-mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, our data demonstrated immunity to H. polygyrus infection in TPL-2 deficient mice was not due to dysregulated type-2 immune responses.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Genome-wide analysis of intestinal tissue from infected TPL-2-deficient mice identified elevated expression of genes involved in chemotaxis and homing of leukocytes and cells, including Ccl24 and alternatively activated genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Indeed, Map3k8-/-mice had a significant influx of eosinophils, neutrophils, monocytes and Il4GFP+ T cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Conditional knockout experiments demonstrated that specific deletion of TPL-2 in CD11c+ cells, but not Villin+ epithelial cells, LysM+ myeloid cells or CD4+ T cells, led to accelerated resistance to H. polygyrus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In line with a central role of CD11c+ cells, CD11c+ CD11b+ cells isolated from TPL-2-deficient mice had elevated Ccl24.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, Ccl24 neutralization in TPL-2 deficient mice significantly decreased the expression of Arg1, Retnla, Chil3 and Ear11 correlating with a loss of resistance to H. polygyrus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These observations suggest that TPL-2-regulated Ccl24 in CD11c+CD11b+ cells prevents accelerated type-2 mediated immunity to H. polygyrus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Collectively, this study identifies a previously unappreciated role for TPL-2 controlling immune responses to H. polygyrus infection by restricting Ccl24 production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intrauterine growth retardation promotes fetal intestinal autophagy in rats via the mechanistic target of rapamycin pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) impairs fetal intestinal development, and is associated with high perinatal morbidity and mortality.</Gene>
<Gene>However, the mechanism underlying this intestinal injury is largely unknown.</Gene>
<Gene>We aimed to investigate this mechanism through analysis of intestinal autophagy and related signaling pathways in a rat model of IUGR.</Gene>
<Gene>Normal weight (NW) and IUGR fetuses were obtained from primiparous rats via ad libitum food intake and 50% food restriction, respectively.</Gene>
<Gene>Maternal serum parameters, fetal body weight, organ weights, and fetal blood glucose were determined.</Gene>
<Gene>Intestinal apoptosis, autophagy, and the mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) signaling pathway were analyzed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results indicated that maternal 50% food restriction reduced maternal serum glucose, bilirubin, and total cholesterol and produced IUGR fetuses, which had decreased body weight; blood glucose; and weights of the small intestine, stomach, spleen, pancreas, and kidney.</Gene>
<Gene>Decreased Bcl-2 and increased Casp9 mRNA expression was observed in IUGR fetal intestines.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis of intestinal autophagy showed that the mRNA expression of WIPI1, MAP1LC3B, Atg5, and Atg14 was also increased, while the protein levels of p62 were decreased in IUGR fetuses.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Compared to NW fetuses, IUGR fetuses showed decreased mTOR protein levels and enhanced mRNA expression of ULK1 and Beclin1 in the small intestine.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In summary, the results indicated that maternal 50% food restriction on gestational days 10-21 reduced maternal serum glucose, bilirubin, and total cholesterol contents, and produced IUGR fetuses that had low blood glucose and reduced small intestine weight.</Gene>
<Gene>Intestinal injury of IUGR fetuses caused by maternal food restriction might be due to enhanced apoptosis and autophagy via the mTOR signaling pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Gene expression profiling of the Notch-AhR-IL22 axis at homeostasis and in response to tissue injury.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Notch and Interleukin-22 signaling are known to regulate tissue homeostasis and response to injury in humans and mice, and the induction of endogenous arylhydrocarbon receptor ligands through Notch links the two pathways in a hierarchical fashion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, in adults the species-, organ- and injury-specific gene expression of the Notch-AhR-IL22 axis components is unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We therefore performed gene expression profiling of DLL1, DLL3, DLL4, DLK1, DLK2, JAG1, JAG2, Notch1, Notch2, Notch3, Notch4, ADAM17/TACE, PSEN1, BSG/CD147, RBP-J, HES1, HES5, HEY1, HEYL, AHR, ARNT, ARNT2, CYP1A1, CYP24A1, IL22, IL22RA1, IL22RA2, IL10RB, and STAT3 under homeostatic conditions in 10 mature murine and human organs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, the expression of these genes was assessed in murine models of acute sterile inflammation and progressive fibrosis.</Gene>
<Gene>We show that there are organ specific gene expression profiles of the Notch-AhR-IL22 axis in humans and mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although there is an overall interspecies congruency, specific differences between human and murine expression signatures do exist.</Gene>
<Gene>In murine tissues with AHR/ARNT expression CYP1A1 and IL22 were correlated with HES5 and HEYL expression, while in human tissues no such correlation was found.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Notch- and AhR-signaling are involved in renal inflammation and fibrosis with specific gene expression changes in each model.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Despite the presence of all Notch pathway molecules in the kidney and a model-specific induction of Notch ligands, IL22 was only upregulated in acute inflammation, but rapidly downregulated during regeneration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This implies that for targeting injury responses e.g. via Interleukin-22, species-specific differences, injury-type and timepoints have to be considered.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>No evidence for association between APOL1 kidney disease risk alleles and Human African Trypanosomiasis in two Ugandan populations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) manifests as an acute form caused by Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense (Tbr) and a chronic form caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambiense (Tbg).</Gene>
<Gene>Previous studies have suggested a host genetic role in infection outcomes, particularly for APOL1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have undertaken candidate gene association studies (CGAS) in a Ugandan Tbr and a Tbg HAT endemic area, to determine whether polymorphisms in IL10, IL8, IL4, HLAG, TNFA, TNX4LB, IL6, IFNG, MIF, APOL1, HLAA, IL1B, IL4R, IL12B, IL12R, HP, HPR, and CFH have a role in HAT.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODOLOGY AND RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>We included 238 and 202 participants from the Busoga Tbr and Northwest Uganda Tbg endemic areas respectively.</Gene>
<Gene>Single Nucleotide Polymorphism (SNP) genotype data were analysed in the CGAS.</Gene>
<Gene>The study was powered to find odds ratios > 2 but association testing of the SNPs with HAT yielded no positive associations i.e. none significant after correction for multiple testing.</Gene>
<Gene>However there was strong evidence for no association with Tbr HAT and APOL1 G2 of the size previously reported in the Kabermaido district of Uganda.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE:</Gene>

<Gene>A recent study in the Soroti and Kaberamaido focus in Central Uganda found that the APOL1 G2 allele was strongly associated with protection against Tbr HAT (odds ratio = 0.2, 95% CI: 0.07 to 0.48, p = 0.0001).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, in our study no effect of G2 on Tbr HAT was found, despite being well powered to find a similar sized effect (OR = 0.9281, 95% CI: 0.482 to 1.788, p = 0.8035).</Gene>
<Gene>It is possible that the G2 allele is protective from Tbr in the Soroti/Kabermaido focus but not in the Iganga district of Busoga, which differ in ethnicity and infection history.</Gene>
<Gene>Mechanisms underlying HAT infection outcome and virulence are complex and might differ between populations, and likely involve several host, parasite or even environmental factors.</Gene>
<Gene>Nonmuscle myosin II isoforms interact with sodium channel alpha subunits.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sodium channels play pivotal roles in health and diseases due to their ability to control cellular excitability.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The pore-forming alpha-subunits (sodium channel alpha subunits) of the voltage-sensitive channels (i.e., Nav1.1-1.9) and the nonvoltage-dependent channel (i.e., Nax) share a common structural motif and selectivity for sodium ions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We hypothesized that the actin-based nonmuscle myosin II motor proteins, nonmuscle myosin heavy chain-IIA/myh9, and nonmuscle myosin heavy chain-IIB/myh10 might interact with sodium channel alpha subunits to play an important role in their transport, trafficking, and/or function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Immunochemical and electrophysiological assays were conducted using rodent nervous (brain and dorsal root ganglia) tissues and ND7/23 cells coexpressing Nav subunits and recombinant myosins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Immunoprecipitation of myh9 and myh10 from rodent brain tissues led to the coimmunoprecipitation of Nax, Nav1.2, and Nav1.3 subunits, but not Nav1.1 and Nav1.6 subunits, expressed there.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Similarly, immunoprecipitation of myh9 and myh10 from rodent dorsal root ganglia tissues led to the coimmunoprecipitation of Nav1.7 and Nav1.8 subunits, but not Nav1.9 subunits, expressed there.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The functional implication of one of these interactions was assessed by coexpressing myh10 along with Nav1.8 subunits in ND7/23 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Myh10 overexpression led to three-fold increase ( P < 0.01) in the current density of Nav1.8 channels expressed in ND7/23 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Myh10 coexpression also hyperpolarized voltage-dependent activation and steady-state fast inactivation of Nav1.8 channels.</Gene>
<Gene>In addition, coexpression of myh10 reduced ( P < 0.01) the offset of fast inactivation and the amplitude of the ramp currents of Nav1.8 channels.</Gene>

<Gene>These results indicate that nonmuscle myosin heavy chain-IIs interact with sodium channel alpha subunits subunits in an isoform-dependent manner and influence their functional properties.</Gene>
<Gene>Downregulation of splicing regulator RBFOX1 compromises visual depth perception.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Rbfox1 is a splicing regulator that has been associated with various neurological conditions such as autism spectrum disorder, mental retardation, epilepsy, attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and schizophrenia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We show that in adult rodent retinas, Rbfox1 is expressed in all types of retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and in certain subsets of amacrine cells (ACs), within the inner nuclear (INL) and ganglion cell (GCL) layers.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In the INL, all Rbfox1-positive cells were colocalized with GABAergic ACs, however not all GABAergic ACs were immunostained for Rbfox1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the GCL, a vast majority of GABAergic dACs were Rbfox1-immunopositive.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, all cholinergic starburst ACs (SACs) in the INL (type a) and in the GCL (type b) were Rbfox1 positive.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of Rbfox1 in the retina significantly overlapped with expression of Rbfox2, another member of Rbfox family of proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Rbfox2, in addition to RGCs and ACs, was also expressed in horizontal cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In developing retinas at E12 and E15, Rbfox1 is localized to the cytoplasm of differentiating RGCs and ACs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Between P0 and P5, Rbfox1 subcellular localization switched from cytoplasmic to predominantly nuclear.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Downregulation of Rbfox1 in adult Rbfox1loxP/loxP mice had no detectable effect on retinal gross morphology.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, the visual cliff test revealed marked abnormalities of depth perception of these animals.</Gene>

<Gene>RNA sequencing of retinal transcriptomes of control and Rbfox1 knockout animals identified a number of Rbfox1-regulated genes that are involved in establishing neuronal circuits and synaptic transmission, including Vamp1, Vamp2, Snap25, Trak2, and Slc1A7, suggesting the role of Rbfox1 in facilitating synaptic communications between ACs and RGCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cooperative Enhancer Activation by TLX1 and STAT5 Drives Development of NUP214-ABL1/TLX1-Positive T Cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The NUP214-ABL1 fusion is a constitutively activated tyrosine kinase that is significantly associated with overexpression of the TLX1 and TLX3 transcription factors in T cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia (T-ALL).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that NUP214-ABL1 cooperates with TLX1 in driving T-ALL development using a transgenic mouse model and human T-ALL cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using integrated ChIP-sequencing, ATAC-sequencing, and RNA-sequencing data, we demonstrate that TLX1 and STAT5, the downstream effector of NUP214-ABL1, co-bind poised enhancer regions, and cooperatively activate the expression of key proto-oncogenes such as MYC and BCL2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of STAT5, downregulation of TLX1 or MYC, or interference with enhancer function through BET-inhibitor treatment leads to reduction of target gene expression and induction of leukemia cell death.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of Nrf2 in the liver is associated with stress resistance mediated by suppression of the growth hormone-regulated STAT5b transcription factor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The transcription factor Nrf2 (encoded by Nfe2l2) induces expression of numerous detoxifying and antioxidant genes in response to oxidative stress.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cytoplasmic protein Keap1 interacts with and represses Nrf2 function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Computational approaches were developed to identify factors that modulate Nrf2 in a mouse liver gene expression compendium.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Forty-eight Nrf2 biomarker genes were identified using profiles from the livers of mice in which Nrf2 was activated genetically in Keap1-null mice or chemically by a potent activator of Nrf2 signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The rank-based Running Fisher statistical test was used to determine the correlation between the Nrf2 biomarker genes and a test set of 81 profiles with known Nrf2 activation status demonstrating a balanced accuracy of 96%.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>For a large number of factors examined in the compendium, we found consistent relationships between activation of Nrf2 and feminization of the liver transcriptome through suppression of the male-specific growth hormone (GH)-regulated transcription factor STAT5b.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The livers of female mice exhibited higher Nrf2 activation than male mice in untreated or chemical-treated conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In male mice, Nrf2 was activated by treatment with ethinyl estradiol, whereas in female mice, Nrf2 was suppressed by treatment with testosterone.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nrf2 was activated in 5 models of disrupted GH signaling containing mutations in Pit1, Prop1, Ghrh, Ghrhr, and Ghr.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Out of 59 chemical treatments that activated Nrf2, 36 exhibited STAT5b suppression in the male liver.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Nrf2-STAT5b coupling was absent in in vitro comparisons of chemical treatments.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Treatment of male and female mice with 11 chemicals that induce oxidative stress led to activation of Nrf2 to greater extents in females than males.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The enhanced basal and inducible levels of Nrf2 activation in females relative to males provides a molecular explanation for the greater resistance often seen in females vs. males to age-dependent diseases and chemical-induced toxicity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cyp1b1 expression impacts the angiogenic and inflammatory properties of liver sinusoidal endothelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Cytochrome P450 1B1 (CYP1B1) is a member of the cytochrome p450 family of enzymes that catalyze mono-oxygenase reactions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although constitutive Cyp1b1 expression is limited in hepatocytes, its expression and function in liver sinusoidal endothelial cells (LSEC) remains unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we determined the impact of Cyp1b1 expression on LSEC properties prepared from Cyp1b1+/+ and Cyp1b1-/- mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>LSEC expressed PECAM-1, VE-cadherin, and B4 lectin similar to EC from other mouse tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cyp1b1</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>+/+ LSEC constitutively expressed significant levels of Cyp1b1, while Cyp1b1-/- LSEC lacked Cyp1b1 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>LSEC also expressed VEGFR3, PROX-1, and LYVE-1, VEGFR1 and VEGFR2, as well as other cell adhesion molecules including ICAM-1, ICAM-2, VCAM-1, and thrombospondin-1 (TSP1) receptors, CD36 and CD47.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the expression of PV-1 and stabilin (fenestration markers), and endoglin were limited in these cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The Cyp1b1-/- LSEC showed limited fenestration, and decreased levels of VEGF and BMP6.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cyp1b1-/- LSEC also showed a decrease in the levels of VE-cadherin and ZO-1 impacting adherens and gap junction formation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cyp1b1-/- LSEC were significantly more apoptotic, proliferated at a faster rate, and were less adherent and more migratory.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These changes were attributed, in part, to decreased amounts of TSP1 and increased AKT and ERK activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The expressions of integrins were also altered by the lack of Cyp1b1, but the ability of these cells to undergo capillary morphogenesis was minimally affected.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, Cyp1b1-/- LSEC expressed lower levels of inflammatory mediators MCP-1 and TNF-alpha.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, Cyp1b1 expression has a significant impact on LSEC angiogenic and inflammatory functions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The Yeast DNA Damage Checkpoint Kinase Rad53 Targets the Exoribonuclease, Xrn1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The highly conserved DNA damage response (DDR) pathway monitors the genomic integrity of the cell and protects against genotoxic stresses.</Gene>

<Gene>The apical kinases, Mec1 and Tel1 (ATR and ATM in human, respectively), initiate the DNA damage signaling cascade through the effector kinases, Rad53 and Chk1, to regulate a variety of cellular processes including cell cycle progression, DNA damage repair, chromatin remodeling, and transcription.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The DDR also regulates other cellular pathways, but direct substrates and mechanisms are still lacking.</Gene>
<Gene>Using a mass spectrometry-based phosphoproteomic screen in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, we identified novel targets of Rad53, many of which are proteins that are involved in RNA metabolism.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Of the 33 novel substrates identified, we verified that 12 are directly phosphorylated by Rad53 in vitro: Xrn1, Gcd11, Rps7b, Ded1, Cho2, Pus1, Hst1, Srv2, Set3, Snu23, Alb1, and Scp160.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We further characterized Xrn1, a highly conserved 5' exoribonuclease that functions in RNA degradation and the most enriched in our phosphoproteomics screen.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Phosphorylation of Xrn1 by Rad53 does not appear to affect Xrn1's intrinsic nuclease activity in vitro, but may affect its activity or specificity in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MicroRNA-451a overexpression induces accelerated neuronal differentiation of Ntera2/D1 cells and ablation affects neurogenesis in microRNA-451a-/- mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MiR-451a is best known for its role in erythropoiesis and for its tumour suppressor features.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show a role for miR-451a in neuronal differentiation through analysis of endogenous and ectopically expressed or silenced miR-451a in Ntera2/D1 cells during neuronal differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, we compared neuronal differentiation in the dentate gyrus of hippocampus of miR-451a-/- and wild type mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MiR-451a overexpression in lentiviral transduced Ntera2/D1 cells was associated with a significant shifting of mRNA expression of the developmental markers Nestin, betaIII Tubulin, NF200, DCX and MAP2 to earlier developmental time points, compared to control vector transduced cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In line with this, accelerated neuronal network formation in AB.G.miR-451a transduced cells, as well as an increase in neurite outgrowth both in number and length was observed.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MiR-451a targets genes MIF, AKT1, CAB39, YWHAZ, RAB14, TSC1, OSR1, POU3F2, TNS4, PSMB8, CXCL16, CDKN2D and IL6R were, moreover, either constantly downregulated or exhibited shifted expression profiles in AB.G.miR-451a transduced cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lentiviral knockdown of endogenous miR-451a expression in Ntera2/D1 cells resulted in decelerated differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Endogenous miR-451a expression was upregulated during development in the hippocampus of wildtype mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In situ hybridization revealed intensively stained single cells in the subgranular zone and the hilus of the dentate gyrus of wild type mice, while genetic ablation of miR-451a was observed to promote an imbalance between proliferation and neuronal differentiation in neurogenic brain regions, suggested by Ki67 and DCX staining.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, these results provide strong support for a role of miR-451a in neuronal maturation processes in vitro and in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Conditional Inactivation of Nf1 and Pten in Schwann Cells Results in Abnormal Neuromuscular Junction Maturation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The neuromuscular junction (NMJ) consists of three components, namely presynaptic motor neurons, postsynaptic muscle fibers and perisynaptic Schwann cells (PSCs).</Gene>
<Gene>The role of Schwann cells (SCs) in regulating NMJ structural and functional development remains unclear.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, mice with conditional inactivation of neurofibromin 1 (Nf1) and phosphatase and tensin homolog (Pten), specifically in SCs, resulted in delayed NMJ maturation that led to delayed muscle growth, recapitulating the muscular dystrophy condition observed in human neurofibromatosis type I syndrome (NF1) patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression levels of NMJ development related molecules such as cholinergic receptor, nicotinic, alpha polypeptide 1 (Chrna1), agrin (Agrn), dystrophin, muscular dystrophy (Dmd), laminin, beta 2 (Lamb2) and dystroglycan 1 (Dag1) were also downregulated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To further explore the molecular alterations in these SCs, NF1- and PTEN-related pathways were analyzed in mutant sciatic nerves.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As expected, hyperactive RAS/PI3K/AKT/mTOR signaling pathways were identified, suggesting the importance of these pathways for NMJ development, and subsequent muscle maturation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Melatonin receptor depletion suppressed hCG-induced testosterone expression in mouse Leydig cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Melatonin receptors MT1 and MT2 (genes officially named MTNR1A and MTNR1B, respectively) play crucial roles in melatonin-mediated regulation of circadian rhythms, the immune system, and control of reproduction in seasonally breeding animals.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, immunolocalization assay showed that MT1 and MT2 are highly expressed in Leydig cell membrane.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To understand the biological function of melatonin receptors in hCG-induced testosterone synthesis, we generated melatonin receptor knockdown cells using specific siRNA and performed testosterone detection after hCG treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found that knockdown of melatonin receptors, especially MTNR1A, led to an obvious decrease (> 60%) of testosterone level.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our further study revealed that knockdown of melatonin receptors repressed expression, at both the mRNA level and the protein level, of key steroidogenic genes, such as p450scc, p450c17 and StAR, which are essential for testosterone synthesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>hCG triggered endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress to regulate steroidogenic genes' expression and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To further investigate the potential roles of melatonin receptors in hCG-induced regulation of ER stress and apoptosis, we examined expression of some crucial ER stress markers, including Grp78, Chop, ATF4, Xbp1, and IRE1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found that inhibition of melatonin receptors increased hCG-induced expression of Grp78, Chop and ATF4, but not Xbp1 and IRE1, suggesting that hCG may modulate IRE1 signaling pathways in a melatonin receptor-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, our further data showed that knockdown of MTNR1A and MTNR1B promoted hCG-induced expression of apoptosis markers, including p53, caspase-3 and Bcl-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggested that the melatonin receptors MTNR1A and MTNR1B are essential to repress hCG-induced ER stress and cell apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our studies demonstrated that the mammalian melatonin receptors MT1 and MT2 are involved in testosterone synthesis via mediating multiple cell pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Use of Physcion to Improve Atopic Dermatitis-Like Skin Lesions through Blocking of Thymic Stromal Lymphopoietin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Physcion is well known for the treatment of carcinoma.</Gene>
<Gene>However, the therapeutic effect of physcion on atopic dermatitis (AD) through the inhibition of thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSLP) level remains largely unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we investigated the anti-AD effect of physcion using HMC-1 cells, splenocytes, and a murine model.</Gene>
<Gene>Treatment with physcion decreased production and mRNA expression levels of TSLP, IL-6, TNF-alpha, and IL-1beta in activated HMC-1 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Physcion reduced the expression levels of RIP2/caspase-1 and phospho (p)ERK/pJNK/pp38 in activated HMC-1 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Physcion suppressed the expression levels of pIKKbeta/NF-kappaB/pIkB in activated HMC-1 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, physcion attenuated the production levels of TSLP, IL-4, IL-6, TNF-, and IFN-gamma from activated splenocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Oral administration of physcion improved the severity of 2,4-dinitrochlorobenzene-induced AD-like lesional skin through reducing infiltration of inflammatory cells and mast cells, and the protein and mRNA levels of TSLP, IL-4, and IL-6 in the lesional skin tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Physcion attenuated histamine, IgE, TSLP, IL-4, IL-6, and TNF- levels in serum.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, physcion inhibited caspase-1 activation in the lesional skin tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings indicate that physcion could ameliorate AD-like skin lesions by inhibiting TSLP levels via caspase-1/MAPKs/NF-kB signalings, which would provide experimental evidence of the therapeutic potential of physcion for AD.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sarco(endo)plasmic reticulum Ca2+-ATPase-2 gene: structure and transcriptional regulation of the human gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The sarco(endo)plasmic reticulum Ca2+-ATPases (SERCAs) belong to a family of active calcium transport enzymes encoded by the SERCA1, 2, and 3 genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we describe the complete structure of the human SERCA2 gene and its 5 -regulatory region.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The hSERCA2 gene is located in chromosome 12 position q24.1 in Contig NT_009770.8, spans 70 kb, and is organized in 21 exons intervened by 20 introns.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The last two exons of the pre-mRNA produce by alternatively splicing the cardiac/slow-twitch muscle-specific SERCA2a isoform and the ubiquitous SERCA2b isoform.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The sequence of the proximal 225-bp regulatory region of the SERCA2 genes is 80% G+C-rich and is conserved among human, rabbit, rat, and mouse species.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It contains a TATA-like-box, an E-box/USF sequence, a CAAT-box, four Sp1 binding sites, and a thyroid hormone responsive element (TRE).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>There are two other conserved regulatory regions located between positions -410 to -661 bp and from -919 to -1410 bp.</Gene>
<Gene>Among the DNA cis-elements present in these two regulatory regions there are potential binding sites for: GATA-4, -5, -6, Nkx-2.5/Csx, OTF-1, USF, MEF-2, SRF, PPAR/RXR, AP-2, and TREs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Upstream from position -1.5 kb, there is no significant homology among the SERCA2 genes cloned.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the human gene has several repeated sequences mainly of the Alu and L2 type located upstream from position -1.7</Gene>
<Gene>kb, spanning in a continuous fashion for more than 40 kb.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, we report the cloning of 2.4 kb of 5-regulatory region and demonstrate that the proximal promoter region is sufficient for expression in cardiac myocytes, and the region from -225 to -1232 bp contains regulatory DNA elements which down-regulate the expression of the SERCA2 gene in neonatal cardiomyocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Increased proinflammatory endothelial response to S100A8/A9 after preactivation through advanced glycation end products.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>Atherosclerosis is an inflammatory disease in which a perpetuated activation of NFkappaB via the RAGE (receptor for advanced glycation end products)-MAPK signalling pathway may play an important pathogenetic role.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As recently S100 proteins have been identified as ligands of RAGE, we sought to determine the effects of the proinflammatory heterodimer of S100A8/S100A9 on the RAGE-NFkappaB mediated induction of proinflammatory gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVEC) were preincubated for 72 h with AGE-albumin or unmodified albumin for control, whereas AGE-albumin induction resulted in an upregulation of RAGE.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Following this preactivation, cells were stimulated for 48 h with heterodimeric human recombinant S100A8/S100A9.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Heterodimeric S100A8/S100A9 enhanced secretion of IL-6, ICAM-1, VCAM-1 and MCP1 in AGE-albumin pretreated HUVEC in a dose dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These effects could not be detected after stimulation with the homodimeric proteins S100A8, S100A9, S100A1 and S100B.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The effects of heterodimeric S100A8/S100A9 were reduced by inhibition of the MAP-kinase pathways ERK1/2 and p38 by PD 98059 and SB 203580, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION: The heterodimeric S100A8/S100A9 might therefore play a hitherto unknown role in triggering atherosclerosis in diabetes and renal failure, pathophysiological entities associated with a high AGE burden.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, blocking heterodimeric S100A8/S100A9 might represent a novel therapeutic modality in treating atherosclerosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human growth hormone (GH1) gene polymorphism map in a normal-statured adult population.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>OBJECTIVE:</Gene>
<Gene>GH1 gene presents a complex map of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in the entire promoter, coding and noncoding regions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The aim of the study was to establish the complete map of GH1 gene SNPs in our control normal population and to analyse its association with adult height.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>DESIGN, SUBJECTS AND MEASUREMENTS:</Gene>

<Gene>A systematic GH1 gene analysis was designed in a control population of 307 adults of both sexes with height normally distributed within normal range for the same population: -2 standard deviation scores (SDS) to +2 SDS.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>An analysis was performed on individual and combined genotype associations with adult height.</Gene>

<Gene>RESULTS: Twenty-five SNPs presented a frequency over 1%: 11 in the promoter (P1 to P11), three in the 5'UTR region (P12 to P14), one in exon 1 (P15), three in intron 1 (P16 to P18), two in intron 2 (P19 and P20), two in exon 4 (P21 and P22) and three in intron 4 (P23 to P25).</Gene>
<Gene>Twenty-nine additional changes with frequencies under 1% were found in 29 subjects.</Gene>
<Gene>P8, P19, P20 and P25 had not been previously described.</Gene>

<Gene>P6, P12, P17 and P25 accounted for 6.2% of the variation in adult height (P = 0.0007) in this population with genotypes A/G at P6, G/G at P6 and A/G at P12 decreasing height SDS (-0.063 +/- 0.031, -0.693 +/- 0.350 and -0.489 +/- 0.265, Mean +/- SE) and genotypes A/T at P17 and T/G at P25 increasing height SDS (+1.094 +/- 0.456 and +1.184 +/- 0.432).</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>This study established the GH1 gene sequence variation map in a normal adult height control population confirming the high density of SNPs in a relatively small gene.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our study shows that the more frequent SNPs did not significantly contribute to height determination, while only one promoter and two intronic SNPs contributed significantly to it.</Gene>
<Gene>Studies in larger populations will have to confirm the associations and in vitro functional studies will elucidate the mechanisms involved.</Gene>

<Gene>Systematic GH1 gene analysis in patients with growth delay and suspected GH deficiency/insufficiency will clarify whether different SNP frequencies and/or the presence of different sequence changes may be associated with phenotypes in them.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Frequencies of single nucleotide polymorphisms in genes regulating inflammatory responses in a community-based population.</Gene>
<Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Allele frequencies reported from public databases or articles are mostly based on small sample sizes.</Gene>
<Gene>Differences in genotype frequencies by age, race and sex have implications for studies designed to examine genetic susceptibility to disease.</Gene>

<Gene>In a community-based cohort of 9,960 individuals, we compared the allele frequencies of 49 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) of genes involved in inflammatory pathways to the frequencies reported on public databases, and examined the genotypes frequencies by age and sex.</Gene>

<Gene>The genes in which SNPs were analyzed include CCR2, CCR5, COX1, COX2, CRP, CSF1, CSF2, IFNG, IL1A, IL1B, IL2, IL4, IL6, IL8, IL10, IL13, IL18, LTA, MPO, NOS2A, NOS3, PPARD, PPARG, PPARGC1 and TNF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: Mean(SD) age was 53.2(15.5); 98% were Caucasians and 62% were women.</Gene>

<Gene>Only 1 out of 33 SNPs differed from the SNP500Cancer database in allele frequency by    >10% in Caucasians (n = 9,831), whereas 12 SNPs differed by    >10% (up to 50%) in African Americans (n = 105).</Gene>
<Gene>Two out of 15 SNPs differed from the dbSNP database in allele frequencies by    >10% in Caucasians, and 5 out of 15 SNPs differed by    >10% in African Americans.</Gene>
<Gene>Age was similar across most genotype groups.</Gene>
<Gene>Genotype frequencies did not differ by sex except for TNF(rs1799724), IL2(rs2069762), IL10(rs1800890), PPARG(rs1801282), and CRP(rs1800947) with differences of less than 4%.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>When estimating the size of samples needed for a study, particularly if a reference sample is used, one should take into consideration the size and ethnicity of the reference sample.</Gene>
<Gene>Larger sample size is needed for public databases that report allele frequencies in non-Caucasian populations.</Gene>
<Gene>Regulatory network of inflammation downstream of proteinase-activated receptors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Protease-activated receptors (PAR) are present in the urinary bladder, and their expression is altered in response to inflammation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PARs are a unique class of G protein-coupled that carry their own ligands, which remain cryptic until unmasked by proteolytic cleavage.</Gene>

<Gene>Although the canonical signal transduction pathway downstream of PAR activation and coupling with various G proteins is known and leads to the rapid transcription of genes involved in inflammation, the effect of PAR activation on the downstream transcriptome is unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have shown that intravesical administration of PAR-activating peptides leads to an inflammatory reaction characterized by edema and granulocyte infiltration.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, the inflammatory response to intravesical instillation of known pro-inflammatory stimuli such as E. coli lipopolysaccharide (LPS), substance P (SP), and antigen was strongly attenuated by PAR1- and to a lesser extent by PAR2-deficiency.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Here, cDNA array experiments determined inflammatory genes whose expression is dependent on PAR1 activation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>For this purpose, we compared the alteration in gene expression in wild type and PAR1-/- mice induced by classical pro-inflammatory stimuli (LPS, SP, and antigen).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>75 transcripts were considered to be dependent on PAR-1 activation and further annotated in silico by Ingenuity Pathways Analysis (IPA) and gene ontology (GO).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Selected transcripts were target validated by quantitative PCR (Q-PCR).</Gene>

<Gene>Among PAR1-dependent transcripts, the following have been implicated in the inflammatory process: b2m, ccl7, cd200, cd63, cdbpd, cfl1, dusp1, fkbp1a, fth1, hspb1, marcksl1, mmp2, myo5a, nfkbia, pax1, plaur, ppia, ptpn1, ptprcap, s100a10, sim2, and tnfaip2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, a balanced response to signals of injury requires a transient cellular activation of a panel of genes together with inhibitory systems that temper the overwhelming inflammation.</Gene>

<Gene>In this context, the activation of genes such as dusp1 and nfkbia seems to counter-balance the inflammatory response to PAR activation by limiting prolonged activation of p38 MAPK and increased cytokine production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, transcripts such as arf6 and dcnt1 that are involved in the mechanism of PAR re-sensitization would tend to perpetuate the inflammatory reaction in response to common pro-inflammatory stimuli.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>

<Gene>The combination of cDNA array results and genomic networks reveals an overriding participation of PAR1 in bladder inflammation, provides a working model for the involvement of downstream signaling, and evokes testable hypotheses regarding the transcriptome downstream of PAR1 activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It remains to be determined whether or not mechanisms targeting PAR1 gene silencing or PAR1 blockade will ameliorate the clinical manifestation of cystitis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>echinus, required for interommatidial cell sorting and cell death in the Drosophila pupal retina, encodes a protein with homology to ubiquitin-specific proteases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Programmed cell death is used to remove excess cells between ommatidia in the Drosophila pupal retina.</Gene>
<Gene>This death is required to establish the crystalline, hexagonal packing of ommatidia that characterizes the adult fly eye.</Gene>
<Gene>In previously described echinus mutants, interommatidial cell sorting, which precedes cell death, occurred relatively normally.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Interommatidial cell death was partially suppressed, resulting in adult eyes that contained excess pigment cells, and in which ommatidia were mildly disordered.</Gene>
<Gene>These results have suggested that echinus functions in the pupal retina primarily to promote interommatidial cell death.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>We generated a number of new echinus alleles, some likely null mutants.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Analysis of these alleles provides evidence that echinus has roles in cell sorting as well as cell death.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>echinus encodes a protein with homology to ubiquitin-specific proteases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These proteins cleave ubiquitin-conjugated proteins at the ubiquitin C-terminus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The echinus locus encodes multiple splice forms, including two proteins that lack residues thought to be critical for deubiquitination activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Surprisingly, ubiquitous expression in the eye of versions of Echinus that lack residues critical for ubiquitin specific protease activity, as well as a version predicted to be functional, rescue the echinus loss-of-function phenotype.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, genetic interactions were not detected between echinus loss and gain-of-function and a number of known apoptotic regulators.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These include Notch, EGFR, the caspases Dronc, Drice, Dcp-1, Dream, the caspase activators, Rpr, Hid, and Grim, the caspase inhibitor DIAP1, and Lozenge or Klumpfuss.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>

<Gene>The echinus locus encodes multiple splice forms of a protein with homology to ubiquitin-specific proteases, but protease activity is unlikely to be required for echinus function, at least when echinus is overexpressed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Characterization of likely echinus null alleles and genetic interactions suggests that echinus acts at a novel point(s) to regulate interommatidial cell sorting and/or cell death in the fly eye.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Saccharomyces cerevisiae HMO1 interacts with TFIID and participates in start site selection by RNA polymerase II.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Saccharomyces cerevisiae HMO1, a high mobility group B (HMGB) protein, associates with the rRNA locus and with the promoters of many ribosomal protein genes (RPGs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, the Sos recruitment system was used to show that HMO1 interacts with TBP and the N-terminal domain (TAND) of TAF1, which are integral components of TFIID.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Biochemical studies revealed that HMO1 copurifies with TFIID and directly interacts with TBP but not with TAND.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Deletion of HMO1 (Deltahmo1) causes a severe cold-sensitive growth defect and decreases transcription of some TAND-dependent genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Deltahmo1 also affects TFIID occupancy at some RPG promoters in a promoter-specific manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, over-expression of HMO1 delays colony formation of taf1 mutants lacking TAND (taf1DeltaTAND), but not of the wild-type strain, indicating a functional link between HMO1 and TAND.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, Deltahmo1 exhibits synthetic growth defects in some spt15 (TBP) and toa1 (TFIIA) mutants while it rescues growth defects of some sua7 (TFIIB) mutants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, Deltahmo1 causes an upstream shift in transcriptional start sites of RPS5, RPS16A, RPL23B, RPL27B and RPL32, but not of RPS31, RPL10, TEF2 and ADH1, indicating that HMO1 may participate in start site selection of a subset of class II genes presumably via its interaction with TFIID.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Plx1 is required for chromosomal DNA replication under stressful conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Polo-like kinase (Plk)1 is required for mitosis progression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, although Plk1 is expressed throughout the cell cycle, its function during S-phase is unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using Xenopus laevis egg extracts, we demonstrate that Plx1, the Xenopus orthologue of Plk1, is required for DNA replication in the presence of stalled replication forks induced by aphidicolin, etoposide or reduced levels of DNA-bound Mcm complexes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Plx1 binds to chromatin and suppresses the ATM/ATR-dependent intra-S-phase checkpoint that inhibits origin firing.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This allows Cdc45 loading and derepression of DNA replication initiation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Checkpoint activation increases Plx1 binding to the Mcm complex through its Polo box domain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Plx1 recruitment to chromatin is independent of checkpoint mediators Tipin and Claspin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Instead, ATR-dependent phosphorylation of serine 92 of Mcm2 is required for the recruitment of Plx1 to chromatin and for the recovery of DNA replication under stress.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Depletion of Plx1 leads to accumulation of chromosomal breakage that is prevented by the addition of recombinant Plx1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest that Plx1 promotes genome stability by regulating DNA replication under stressful conditions.</Gene>

text: <Gene>Plasma IP-10, apoptotic and angiogenic factors associated with fatal cerebral malaria in India.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Plasmodium falciparum in a subset of patients can lead to cerebral malaria (CM), a major contributor to malaria-associated mortality.</Gene>
<Gene>Despite treatment, CM mortality can be as high as 30%, while 10% of survivors of the disease may experience short- and long-term neurological complications.</Gene>

<Gene>The pathogenesis of CM is mediated by alterations in cytokine and chemokine homeostasis, inflammation as well as vascular injury and repair processes although their roles are not fully understood.</Gene>

<Gene>The hypothesis for this study is that CM-induced changes in inflammatory, apoptotic and angiogenic factors mediate severity of CM and that their identification will enable development of new prognostic markers and adjunctive therapies for preventing CM mortalities.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>Plasma samples (133) were obtained from healthy controls (HC, 25), mild malaria (MM, 48), cerebral malaria survivors (CMS, 48), and cerebral malaria non-survivors (CMNS, 12) at admission to the hospital in Jabalpur, India.</Gene>

<Gene>Plasma levels of 30 biomarkers ((IL-1beta, IL-1ra, IL-2, IL-4, IL-5, IL-6, IL-8, IL-9, IL-10, IL-12 (p70), IL-13, IL-15, IL-17, Eotaxin, FGF basic protein, G-CSF, GM-CSF, IFN-gamma, IP-10, MCP-1 (MCAF), MIP-1alpha, MIP-1beta, RANTES, TNF-alpha, Fas-ligand (Fas-L), soluble Fas (sFas), soluble TNF receptor 1 (sTNF-R1) and soluble TNF receptor 2 (sTNFR-2), PDGF bb and VEGF)) were simultaneously measured in an initial subset of ten samples from each group.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Only those biomarkers which showed significant differences in the pilot analysis were chosen for testing on all remaining samples.</Gene>
<Gene>The results were then compared between the four groups to determine their role in CM severity.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS: IP-10, sTNF-R2 and sFas were independently associated with increased risk of CM associated mortality.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CMNS patients had a significantly lower level of the neuroprotective factor VEGF when compared to other groups (P    < 0.0045).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The ratios of VEGF to IP-10, sTNF-R2, and sFas distinguished CM survivors from non survivors (P    < 0.0001).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>The results suggest that plasma levels of IP-10, sTNF-R2 and sFas may be potential biomarkers of CM severity and mortality.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VEGF was found to be protective against CM associated mortality and may be considered for adjunctive therapy to improve the treatment outcome in CM patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Effects of common germline genetic variation in cell cycle control genes on breast cancer survival: results from a population-based cohort.</Gene>
<Gene>INTRODUCTION: Somatic alterations have been shown to correlate with breast cancer prognosis and survival, but less is known about the effects of common inherited genetic variation.</Gene>
<Gene>Of particular interest are genes involved in cell cycle pathways, which regulate cell division.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>We examined associations between common germline genetic variation in 13 genes involved in cell cycle control (CCND1, CCND2, CCND3, CCNE1, CDK2 [p33], CDK4, CDK6, CDKN1A</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>[p21, Cip1], CDKN1B</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>[p27, Kip1], CDKN2A [p16], CDKN2B</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>[p15], CDKN2C [p18], and CDKN2D</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>[p19]) and survival among women diagnosed with invasive breast cancer participating in the SEARCH (Studies of Epidemiology and Risk factors in Cancer Heredity) breast cancer study.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>DNA from up to 4,470 women was genotyped for 85 polymorphisms that tag the known common polymorphisms (minor allele frequency    > 0.05) in the genes.</Gene>
<Gene>The genotypes of each polymorphism were tested for association with survival using Cox regression analysis.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>The rare allele of the tagging single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) rs2479717 is associated with an increased risk of death (hazard ratio = 1.26 per rare allele carried, 95% confidence interval: 1.12 to 1.42; P = 0.0001), which was not attenuated after adjusting for tumour stage, grade, and treatment.</Gene>
<Gene>This SNP is part of a large linkage disequilibrium block, which contains CCND3, BYSL, TRFP, USP49, C6ofr49, FRS3, and PGC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We evaluated the association of survival and somatic expression of these genes in breast tumours using expression microarray data from seven published datasets.</Gene>
<Gene>Elevated expression of the C6orf49 transcript was associated with breast cancer survival, adding biological interest to the finding.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>It is possible that CCND3 rs2479717, or another variant it tags, is associated with prognosis after a diagnosis of breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Further study is required to validate this finding.</Gene>
<Gene>Transcriptional profiling in C. elegans suggests DNA damage dependent apoptosis as an ancient function of the p53 family.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>In contrast to the three mammalian p53 family members, p53, which is generally involved in DNA damage responses, and p63 and p73 which are primarily needed for developmental regulation, cep-1 encodes for the single C. elegans p53-like gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>cep-1 acts as a transcription activator in a primordial p53 pathway that involves CEP-1 activation and the CEP-1 dependent transcriptional induction of the worm BH3 only domain encoding genes egl-1 and ced-13 to induce germ cell apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>EGL-1 and CED-13 proteins inactivate Bcl-2 like CED-9 to trigger CED-4 and CED-3 caspase dependent germ cell apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To address the function of p53 in global transcriptional regulation we investigate genome-wide transcriptional responses upon DNA damage and cep-1 deficiency.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Examining C. elegans expression profiles using whole genome Affymetrix GeneChip arrays, we found that 83 genes were induced more than two fold upon ionizing radiation (IR).</Gene>
<Gene>None of these genes, with exception of an ATP ribosylase homolog, encode for known DNA repair genes.</Gene>
<Gene>Using two independent cep-1 loss of function alleles we did not find genes regulated by cep-1 in the absence of IR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Among the IR-induced genes only three are dependent on cep-1, namely egl-1, ced-13 and a novel C. elegans specific gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The majority of IR-induced genes appear to be involved in general stress responses, and qRT-PCR experiments indicate that they are mainly expressed in somatic tissues.</Gene>
<Gene>Interestingly, we reveal an extensive overlap of gene expression changes occurring in response to DNA damage and in response to bacterial infection.</Gene>
<Gene>Furthermore, many genes induced by IR are also transcriptionally regulated in longevity mutants suggesting that DNA damage and aging induce an overlapping stress response.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>

<Gene>We performed genome-wide gene expression analyses which indicate that only a surprisingly small number of genes are regulated by CEP-1 and that DNA damage induced apoptosis via the transcriptional induction of BH3 domain proteins is likely to be an ancient DNA damage response function of the p53 family.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, although the apoptotic response to DNA damage is regulated through the transcriptional activity of CEP-1, other DNA damage responses do not appear to be regulated on the transcriptional level and do not require the p53 like gene cep-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Androgen regulation of the androgen receptor coregulators.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>The critical role of the androgen receptor (AR) in the development of prostate cancer is well recognized.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The transcriptional activity of AR is partly regulated by coregulatory proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>It has been suggested that these coregulators could also be important in the progression of prostate cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>The aim of this study was to identify coregulators whose expression is regulated by either the androgens and/or by the expression level of AR.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>We used empty vector and AR cDNA-transfected LNCaP cells (LNCaP-pcDNA3.1, and LNCaP-ARhi, respectively), and grew them for 4 and 24 hours in the presence of dihydrotestosterone (DHT) at various concentrations.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of 25 AR coregulators (SRC1, TIF2, PIAS1, PIASx, ARIP4, BRCA1, beta-catenin, AIB3, AIB1, CBP, STAT1, NCoR1, AES, cyclin D1, p300, ARA24, LSD1, BAG1L, gelsolin, prohibitin, JMJD2C, JMJD1A, MAK, PAK6 and MAGE11) was then measured by using real-time quantitative RT-PCR (Q-RT-PCR).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: Five of the coregulators (AIB1, CBP, MAK, BRCA1 and beta-catenin) showed more than 2-fold induction and 5 others (cyclin D1, gelsolin, prohibitin, JMJD1A, and JMJD2C) less than 2-fold induction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of AR did not affect the expression of the coregulators alone.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, overexpression of AR enhanced the DHT-stimulated expression of MAK, BRCA1, AIB1 and CBP and reduced the level of expression of beta-catenin, cyclinD1 and gelsolin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>In conclusion, we identified 5 coactivators whose expression was induced by androgens suggesting that they could potentiate AR signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overexpression of AR seems to sensitize cells for low levels of androgens.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The Drosophila protein palmitoylome: characterizing palmitoyl-thioesterases and DHHC palmitoyl-transferases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Palmitoylation is the post-translational addition of a palmitate moiety to a cysteine residue through a covalent thioester bond.</Gene>
<Gene>The addition and removal of this modification is controlled by both palmitoyl acyl-transferases and thioesterases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using bioinformatic analysis, we identified 22 DHHC family palmitoyl acyl-transferase homologs in the Drosophila genome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We used in situ hybridization,RT-PCR, and published FlyAtlas microarray data to characterize the expression patterns of all 22 fly homologs.</Gene>

<Gene>Our results indicate that all are expressed genes, but several, including CG1407, CG4676, CG5620, CG6017/dHIP14, CG6618, CG6627 and CG17257 appear to be enriched in neural tissues suggesting that they are important for neural function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, we have found that several may be expressed in a sex-specific manner with adult male specific expression of CG4483 and CG17195.</Gene>

<Gene>Using tagged versions of the DHHC genes, we demonstrate that fly DHHC proteins are primarily located in either the Golgi Apparatus or Endoplasmic Reticulum in S2 cells, except for CG1407, which was found on the plasma membrane.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also characterized the subcellular localization and expression of the three known thioesterases: Palmitoyl-protein Thioesterase 1 (Ppt1), Palmitoyl-protein Thioesterase 2 (Ppt2)and Acyl-protein Thioesterase 1 (APT1).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results indicate that Ppt1 and Ppt2 are the major lysosomal thioesterases while APT1 is the likely cytoplasmic thioesterase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, in vivo rescue experiments show that Ppt2 expression cannot rescue the neural inclusion phenotypes associated with loss of Ppt1, further supporting distinct functions and substrates for these two thioesterases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results will serve as the basis for a more complete understanding of the protein palmitoylome's normal cellular functions in the fly and will lead to further insights into the molecular etiology of diseases associated with the mis-regulation of palmitoylation.</Gene>
<Gene>Over-expression of ubiquitin carboxy terminal hydrolase-L1 induces apoptosis in breast cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Ubiquitin carboxy terminal hydrolase-L1 (UCH-L1) belongs to the UCH proteases family that deubiquitinates ubiquitin-protein conjugates in the ubiquitin-proteasome system.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Previous research showed that UCH-L1 was expressed in mouse retinal cells and testicular germ cells, and its function was associated with apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>But it is still unclear whether UCH-L1 is concerned with apoptosis in tumor cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In order to clarify the role of UCH-L1 in tumor cells, multi-drug resistance (MDR) human breast carcinoma cell line MCF7/Adr, that expresses relatively high UCH-L1, and its parental cell line MCF7, that expresses relatively low UCH-L1, were chosen for this study.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We transfected pcDNA3.1-UCH-L1 plasmid and UCH-L1 siRNA into MCF7 and MCF7/Adr cells, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2, 5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay, western blot, Hoechst 33258 staining assay and flow cytometry, we found that over-expression of UCH-L1 in MCF7 cells induced apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>On the other hand, silencing of UCH-L1 in MCF7/Adr cells led to the opposite effect.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, to explore the mechanism underling these observations, we further investigated the expression of phospho-Akt and its downstream signal phospho-IkB-alpha and other signal molecules including Fas, Fas-L, Trail, DR4, DR5, Bax, cytochrome C, active caspase-3, phospho-p53, phospho-Mdm-2, Bcl-2, Bcl-xL, p21 and p27.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The results indicated that the process of apoptosis triggered by UCH-L1 is, at least in part, probably through Phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)/Akt signal pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings suggest that modulating the ubiquitination and deubiquitination pathway could be a novel method for tumor therapy.</Gene>
<Gene>Lymphoid tissue inducer-like cells are an innate source of IL-17 and IL-22.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The interleukin (IL) 17 family of cytokines has emerged to be critical for host defense as well as the pathogenesis of autoimmune and autoinflammatory disorders, and serves to link adaptive and innate responses.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recent studies have identified a new subset of T cells that selectively produce IL-17 (Th17 cells; Bettelli, E., T. Korn, and V.K. Kuchroo. 2007.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Curr.</Gene>
<Gene>Opin.</Gene>
<Gene>Immunol.</Gene>
<Gene>19:652-657; Kolls, J.K., and A. Linden.</Gene>
<Gene>2004.</Gene>
<Gene>Immunity.</Gene>
<Gene>21:467-476), but the regulation of IL-17 production by innate immune cells is less well understood.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report that in vitro stimulation with IL-23 induced IL-17 production by recombination activating gene (Rag) 2(-/-) splenocytes but not Rag2(-/-) common gamma chain(-/-) splenocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found that a major source of IL-17 was CD4(+)CD3(-)NK1.1(-)CD11b(-)Gr1(-)CD11c(-)B220(-) cells, a phenotype that corresponds to lymphoid tissue inducer-like cells (LTi-like cells), which constitutively expressed the IL-23 receptor, aryl hydrocarbon receptor, and CCR6.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vivo challenge with the yeast cell wall product zymosan rapidly induced IL-17 production in these cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Genetic deletion of signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 reduced but did not abrogate IL-17 production in LTi-like cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, it appears that splenic LTi-like cells are a rapid source of IL-17 and IL-22, which might contribute to dynamic organization of secondary lymphoid organ structure or host defense.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SIRT1 histone deacetylase expression is associated with microsatellite instability and CpG island methylator phenotype in colorectal cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The class III histone deacetylase SIRT1 (sir2) is important in epigenetic gene silencing.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of SIRT1 reactivates silenced genes, suggesting a possible therapeutic approach of targeted reversal of aberrantly silenced genes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, SIRT1 may be involved in the well-known link between obesity, cellular energy balance and cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, a comprehensive study of SIRT1 using human cancer tissue with clinical outcome data is currently lacking, and its prognostic significance is uncertain.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using the database of 485 colorectal cancers in two independent prospective cohort studies, we detected SIRT1 overexpression in 180 (37%) tumors by immunohistochemistry.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We examined its relationship to the CpG island methylator phenotype (CIMP), related molecular events, clinical features including body mass index, and patient survival.</Gene>

<Gene>We quantified DNA methylation in eight CIMP-specific promoters (CACNA1G, CDKN2A, CRABP1, IGF2, MLH1, NEUROG1, RUNX3, and SOCS1) and eight other CpG islands (CHFR, HIC1, IGFBP3, MGMT, MINT1, MINT31, p14, and WRN) by MethyLight.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SIRT1 overexpression was associated with CIMP-high (   > or =6 of 8 methylated CIMP-specific promoters, P=0.002) and microsatellite instability (MSI)-high phenotype (P   <0.0001).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In both univariate and multivariate analyses, SIRT1 overexpression was significantly associated with the CIMP-high MSI-high phenotype (multivariate odds ratio, 3.20; 95% confidence interval, 1.35-7.59; P=0.008).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, mucinous component (P=0.01), high tumor grade (P=0.02), and fatty acid synthase overexpression (P=0.04) were significantly associated with SIRT positivity in multivariate analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SIRT1 was not significantly related with age, sex, tumor location, stage, signet ring cells, cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2), LINE-1 hypomethylation, KRAS, BRAF, BMI, PIK3CA, HDAC, p53, beta-catenin, COX-2, or patient prognosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, SIRT1 expression is associated with CIMP-high MSI-high colon cancer, suggesting involvement of SIRT1 in gene silencing in this unique tumor subtype.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Derivation of a novel undifferentiated human foetal phenotype in serum-free cultures with BMP-2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Skeletal stem and progenitor populations provide a platform for cell-based tissue regeneration strategies.</Gene>
<Gene>Optimized conditions for ex vivo expansion will be critical and use of serum-free culture may allow enhanced modelling of differentiation potential.</Gene>

<Gene>Maintenance of human foetal femur-derived cells in a chemically defined medium (CDM) with activin A and fibroblast growth factor-2 generated a unique undifferentiated cell population in comparison to basal cultures, with significantly reduced amino acid depletion, appearance and turnover, reduced alkaline phosphatase (ALP) activity and loss of type I and II collagen expression demonstrated by fluorescence immunocytochemistry.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Microarray analysis demonstrated up-regulation of CLU, OSR2, POSTN and RABGAP1 and down-regulation of differentiation-associated genes CRYAB, CSRP1, EPAS1, GREM1, MT1X and SRGN as validated by quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Application of osteogenic conditions to CDM cultures demonstrated partial rescue of ALP activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, the addition of bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP-2) resulted in reduced ALP levels, increased amino acid metabolism and, strikingly, a marked shift to a cobblestone-like cellular morphology, with expression of SOX-2 and SOX-9 but not STRO-1 as shown by immunocytochemistry, and significantly altered expression of metabolic genes (GFPT2, SC4MOL and SQLE), genes involved in morphogenesis (SOX15 and WIF1) and differentiation potential (C1orf19, CHSY-2,DUSP6, HMGCS1 and PPL).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These studies demonstrate the use of an intermediary foetal cellular model for differentiation studies in chemically defined conditions and indicate the in vitro reconstruction of the mesenchymal condensation phenotype in the presence of BMP-2, with implications therein for rescue studies, screening assays and skeletal regeneration research.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Melanocortin-4 receptor activation inhibits c-Jun N-terminal kinase activity and promotes insulin signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The melanocortin system is crucial to regulation of energy homeostasis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The melanocortin receptor type 4 (MC4R) modulates insulin signaling via effects on c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The melanocortin agonist NDP-MSH dose-dependently inhibited JNK activity in HEK293 cells stably expressing the human MC4R; effects were reversed by melanocortin receptor antagonist.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NDP-MSH time- and dose-dependently inhibited IRS-1(ser307) phosphorylation, effects also reversed by a specific melanocortin receptor antagonist.</Gene>
label: Gene
