Gene

text: <Gene>NDP-MSH augmented insulin-stimulated AKT phosphorylation in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The melanocortin agonist melanotan II increased insulin-stimulated AKT phosphorylation in the rat hypothalamus in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NDP-MSH increased insulin-stimulated glucose uptake in hypothalamic GT1-1 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The current study shows that the melanocortinergic system interacts with insulin signaling via novel effects on JNK activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Notch signaling is required for lateral induction of Jagged1 during FGF-induced lens fiber differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Previous studies of the developing lens have shown that Notch signaling regulates differentiation of lens fiber cells by maintaining a proliferating precursor pool in the anterior epithelium.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, whether Notch signaling is further required after the onset of fiber cell differentiation is not clear.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This work investigates the role of Notch2 and Jagged1 (Jag1) in secondary fiber cell differentiation using rat lens epithelial explants undergoing FGF-2 dependent differentiation in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>FGF induced Jag1 expression and Notch2 signaling (as judged by the appearance of activated Notch2 Intracellular Domain (N2ICD)) within 12-24 h. These changes were correlated with induction of the Notch effector, Hes5, upregulation of N-cadherin (N-cad), and downregulation of E-cadherin (E-cad), a cadherin switch characteristic of fiber cell differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Induction of Jag1 was efficiently blocked by U0126, a specific inhibitor of MAPK/ERK signaling, indicating a requirement for signaling through this pathway downstream of the FGF receptor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Other growth factors that activate MAPK/ERK signaling (EGF, PDGF, IGF) did not induce Jag1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of Notch signaling using gamma secretase inhibitors DAPT and L-685,458 or anti-Jag1 antibody markedly decreased FGF-dependent expression of Jag1 demonstrating Notch-dependent lateral induction.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, inhibition of Notch signaling reduced expression of N-cad, and the cyclin dependent kinase inhibitor, p57Kip2, indicating a direct role for Notch signaling in secondary fiber cell differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results demonstrate that Notch-mediated lateral induction of Jag1 is an essential component of FGF-dependent lens fiber cell differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TAK1 is an essential regulator of BMP signalling in cartilage.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TGFbeta activated kinase 1 (TAK1), a member of the MAPKKK family, controls diverse functions ranging from innate and adaptive immune system activation to vascular development and apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To analyse the in vivo function of TAK1 in cartilage, we generated mice with a conditional deletion of Tak1 driven by the collagen 2 promoter.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tak1(col2) mice displayed severe chondrodysplasia with runting, impaired formation of secondary centres of ossification, and joint abnormalities including elbow dislocation and tarsal fusion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This phenotype resembled that of bone morphogenetic protein receptor (BMPR)1 and Gdf5-deficient mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BMPR signalling was markedly impaired in TAK1-deficient chondrocytes as evidenced by reduced expression of known BMP target genes as well as reduced phosphorylation of Smad1/5/8 and p38/Jnk/Erk MAP kinases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TAK1 mediates Smad1 phosphorylation at C-terminal serine residues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings provide the first in vivo evidence in a mammalian system that TAK1 is required for BMP signalling and functions as an upstream activating kinase for Smad1/5/8 in addition to its known role in regulating MAP kinase pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our experiments reveal an essential role for TAK1 in the morphogenesis, growth, and maintenance of cartilage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A prospective cohort study shows unique epigenetic, genetic, and prognostic features of synchronous colorectal cancers.</Gene>
<Gene>BACKGROUND     ' AIMS:</Gene>

<Gene>Synchronous colorectal neoplasias (2 or more primary carcinomas identified in the same patient) are caused by common genetic and environmental factors and can be used to study the field effect.</Gene>
<Gene>Synchronous colon cancers have not been compared with control solitary cancers in a prospective study.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>We analyzed data collected from 47 patients with synchronous colorectal cancers and 2021 solitary colorectal cancers (controls) in 2 prospective cohort studies.</Gene>

<Gene>Tumors samples were analyzed for methylation in LINE-1 and 16 CpG islands (CACNA1G, CDKN2A [p16], CRABP1, IGF2, MLH1, NEUROG1, RUNX3, SOCS1, CHFR, HIC1, IGFBP3, MGMT, MINT1, MINT31, p14 [ARF], and WRN); microsatellite instability (MSI); the CpG island methylator phenotype (CIMP); 18q loss of heterozygosity; KRAS, BRAF, and PIK3CA mutations; and expression of beta-catenin, p53, p21, p27, cyclin D1, fatty acid synthase, and cyclooxygenase-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>Compared with patients with solitary colorectal cancer, synchronous colorectal cancer patients had reduced overall survival time (log-rank, P = .0048; hazard ratio [HR], 1.71; 95% confidence interval</Gene>
<Gene>Compared with solitary tumors, synchronous tumors more frequently contained BRAF mutations (P = .0041), CIMP-high (P = .013), and MSI-high (P = .037).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Methylation levels of LINE-1 (Spearman r = 0.82; P = .0072) and CpG island methylation (P    < .0001) correlated between synchronous cancer pairs from the same individuals.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Synchronous colorectal cancers had more frequent mutations in BRAF, were more frequently CIMP-</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>and MSI-high, and had a worse prognosis than solitary colorectal cancers.</Gene>
<Gene>Similar epigenomic and epigenetic events were frequently observed within a synchronous cancer pair, suggesting the presence of a field defect.</Gene>
<Gene>Regulation of Lhb and Egr1 gene expression by GNRH pulses in rat pituitaries is both c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK)- and extracellular signal-regulated kinase (ERK)-dependent.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Pulsatile GNRH regulates the gonadotropin subunit genes in a differential manner, with faster frequencies favoring Lhb gene expression and slower frequencies favoring Fshb.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Early growth response 1 (EGR1) is critical for Lhb gene transcription.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We examined GNRH regulation of EGR1 and its two corepressors, Ngfi-A-binding proteins 1 and 2 (NAB1 and NAB2), both in vivo and in cultured rat pituitary cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In rats, fast GNRH pulses (every 30 min) stably induced Egr1 primary transcript (PT) and mRNA 2-fold (P    < 0.05) for 1-24 h. In contrast, slow GNRH pulses (every 240 min) increased Egr1 PT at 24 h (6-fold; P    < 0.05) but increased Egr1 mRNA</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>4- to 5-fold between 4 and 24 h. Both GNRH pulse frequencies increased EGR1 protein 3- to 4-fold.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In cultured rat pituitary cells, GNRH pulses (every 60 min) increased Egr1 (PT, 2.5- to 3-fold; mRNA, 1.5- to 2-fold; P    < 0.05).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>GNRH pulses had little effect on Nab1/2 PT/mRNAs either in vivo or in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also examined specific intracellular signaling cascades activated by GNRH.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibitors of mitogen-activated protein kinase 8/9 (MAPK8/9 [also known as JNK]; SP600125) and MAP Kinase Kinase 1 (MAP2K1 [also known as MEK1]; PD98059) either blunted or totally suppressed the GNRH induction of Lhb PT and Egr1 PT/mRNA, whereas the MAPK14 (also known as p38) inhibitor SB203580 did not.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In summary, pulsatile GNRH stimulates Egr1 gene expression and protein in vivo but not in a frequency-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, GNRH-induced Egr1 gene expression is mediated by MAPK8/9 and MAPK1/3, and both are critical for Lhb gene transcription.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>U2OS cells lacking Chk1 undergo aberrant mitosis and fail to activate the spindle checkpoint.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Chk1 is a conserved protein kinase originally identified in fission yeast, required to delay entry of cells with damaged or unreplicated DNA into mitosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The requirement of Chk1 for both S and G2/M checkpoints has been elucidated while only few studies have connected Chk1 to the mitotic spindle checkpoint.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We used a small interference RNA strategy to investigate the role of Chk1 in unstressed conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Chk1 depletion in U2OS human osteosarcoma cells inhibited cell proliferation and raised the percentage of cells with a 4N DNA content, which correlated with accumulation of giant polynucleated cells morphologically distinct from apoptotic cells, while no increased number of cells in G2 or mitosis could be detected.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Down-regulation of Chk1 also caused accumulation of cells in the last step of cytokinesis, and of tetraploid cells in G1 phase, which coincided with activation of p53 and increased levels of p21.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, Chk1-depleted U2OS cells failed to arrest in mitosis after spindle disruption by nocodazole and showed decreased protein levels of Mad2 and BubR1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These studies show that U2OS cells lacking Chk1 undergo abnormal mitosis and fail to activate the spindle checkpoint, suggesting a role of Chk1 in this checkpoint.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Vitamin D receptor expression is associated with PIK3CA and KRAS mutations in colorectal cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Vitamin D is associated with decreased risks of various cancers, including colon cancer.</Gene>
<Gene>The vitamin D receptor (VDR) is a transcription factor, which plays an important role in cellular differentiation and inhibition of proliferation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A link between VDR and the RAS-mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) or phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K)-AKT pathway has been suggested.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the prognostic role of VDR expression or its relationship with PIK3CA or KRAS mutation remains uncertain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Among 619 colorectal cancers in two prospective cohort studies, 233 (38%) tumors showed VDR overexpression by immunohistochemistry.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We analyzed for PIK3CA and KRAS mutations and LINE-1 methylation by Pyrosequencing, microsatellite instability (MSI), and DNA methylation (epigenetic changes) in eight CpG island methylator phenotype (CIMP)-specific promoters [CACNA1G, CDKN2A (p16), CRABP1, IGF2, MLH1, NEUROG1, RUNX3, and SOCS1] by MethyLight (real-time PCR).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VDR overexpression was significantly associated with KRAS mutation (odds ratio, 1.55; 95% confidence interval, 1.11-2.16) and PIK3CA mutation (odds ratio, 2.17; 95% confidence interval, 1.36-3.47), both of which persisted in multivariate logistic regression analysis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VDR was not independently associated with body mass index, family history of colorectal cancer, tumor location (colon versus rectum), stage, tumor grade, signet ring cells, CIMP, MSI, LINE-1 hypomethylation, BRAF, p53, p21, beta-catenin, or cyclooxygenase-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VDR expression was not significantly related with patient survival, prognosis, or clinical outcome.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, VDR overexpression in colorectal cancer is independently associated with PIK3CA and KRAS mutations.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data support potential interactions between the VDR, RAS-MAPK and PI3K-AKT pathways, and possible influence by KRAS or PIK3CA mutation on therapy or chemoprevention targeting VDR.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Independent and cooperative roles of tumor necrosis factor-alpha, nuclear factor-kappaB, and bone morphogenetic protein-2 in regulation of metastasis and osteomimicry of prostate cancer cells and differentiation and mineralization of MC3T3-E1 osteoblast-like cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The molecular mechanisms involved in prostate cancer (PC) metastasis and bone remodeling are poorly understood.</Gene>

<Gene>We recently reported that phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)/protein kinase B (Akt) mediates transcriptional regulation and activation of bone morphogenetic protein (BMP)-2 signaling by nuclear factor (NF)-kappaB in bone metastatic prostate cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the present study, we demonstrate that NF-kappaB, whether activated by recombinant human tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha or by ectopic expression of the p65 subunit, is involved in extracellular matrix adhesion and invasion of osteotropic PC-3 and C4-2B, but not LNCaP, cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The enhanced metastatic potential was associated with transcriptional upregulation of osteopontin, osteocalcin, and collagen IA1 in osteotropic PC cells, suggesting their role in osteomimicry of PC cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Unlike BMP-4, BMP-2 protein enhanced the invasive properties of C4-2B cells, but not in LNCaP cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Also, this effect was nullified by Noggin.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, BMP-2 mediates TNF-alpha-induced invasion of C4-2B cells in a NF-kappaB-dependent fashion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>TNF-alpha or conditioned media (CM) of TNF-alpha-stimulated C4-2B cells upregulated BMP-2 and BMP-dependent Smad transcripts and inhibited receptor activator of NF-kappaB ligand transcripts in RAW 264.7 preosteoclast cells, respectively, implying that this factor may contribute to suppression of osteoclastogenesis via direct and paracrine mechanisms.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, CM of TNF-alpha-stimulate or BMP2-stimulated C4-2B cells induced in vitro mineralization of MC3T3-E1 osteoblast cells in a BMP-2-dependent and NF-kappaB-dependent manner, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, the results suggest that mutual interactions between these factors may be pivotal not only in enhancing the osteomimicry and metastatic potential of PC cells, but also in bone remodeling and in shifting the balance from osteoclastogenesis towards osteoblastogenesis.</Gene>
<Gene>The Mre11/Rad50/Nbs1 complex functions in resection-based DNA end joining in Xenopus laevis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) is essential to maintain genomic integrity.</Gene>

<Gene>In higher eukaryotes, DNA DSBs are predominantly repaired by non-homologous end joining (NHEJ), but DNA ends can also be joined by an alternative error-prone mechanism termed microhomology-mediated end joining (MMEJ).</Gene>
<Gene>In MMEJ, the repair of DNA breaks is mediated by annealing at regions of microhomology and is always associated with deletions at the break site.</Gene>

<Gene>In budding yeast, the Mre11/Rad5/Xrs2 complex has been demonstrated to play a role in both classical NHEJ and MMEJ, but the involvement of the analogous MRE11/RAD50/NBS1 (MRN) complex in end joining in higher eukaryotes is less certain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we demonstrate that in Xenopus laevis egg extracts, the MRN complex is not required for classical DNA-PK-dependent NHEJ.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the XMRN complex is necessary for resection-based end joining of mismatched DNA ends.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This XMRN-dependent end joining process is independent of the core NHEJ components Ku70 and DNA-PK, occurs with delayed kinetics relative to classical NHEJ and brings about repair at sites of microhomology.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data indicate a role for the X. laevis MRN complex in MMEJ.</Gene>
<Gene>A genetic screen for modifiers of Drosophila caspase Dcp-1 reveals caspase involvement in autophagy and novel caspase-related genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>Caspases are cysteine proteases with essential functions in the apoptotic pathway; their proteolytic activity toward various substrates is associated with the morphological changes of cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Recent reports have described non-apoptotic functions of caspases, including autophagy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In this report, we searched for novel modifiers of the phenotype of Dcp-1 gain-of-function (GF) animals by screening promoter element- inserted Drosophila melanogaster lines (EP lines).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>We screened approximately 15,000 EP lines and identified 72 Dcp-1-interacting genes that were classified into 10 groups based on their functions and pathways: 4 apoptosis signaling genes, 10 autophagy genes, 5 insulin/IGF and TOR signaling pathway genes, 6 MAP kinase and JNK signaling pathway genes, 4 ecdysone signaling genes, 6 ubiquitination genes, 11 various developmental signaling genes, 12 transcription factors, 3 translation factors, and 11 other unclassified genes including 5 functionally undefined genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Among them, insulin/IGF and TOR signaling pathway, MAP kinase and JNK signaling pathway, and ecdysone signaling are known to be involved in autophagy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Together with the identification of autophagy genes, the results of our screen suggest that autophagy counteracts Dcp-1-induced apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Consistent with this idea, we show that expression of eGFP-Atg5 rescued the eye phenotype caused by Dcp-1 GF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Paradoxically, we found that over-expression of full-length Dcp-1 induced autophagy, as Atg8b-GFP, an indicator of autophagy, was increased in the eye imaginal discs and in the S2 cell line.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, these data suggest that autophagy suppresses Dcp-1-mediated apoptotic cell death, whereas Dcp-1 positively regulates autophagy, possibly through feedback regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>We identified a number of Dcp-1 modifiers that genetically interact with Dcp-1-induced cell death.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results showing that Dcp-1 and autophagy-related genes influence each other will aid future investigations of the complicated relationships between apoptosis and autophagy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Negative feedback regulation of Wnt4 signaling by EAF1 and EAF2/U19.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Previous studies indicated that EAF (ELL-associated factor) family members, EAF1 and EAF2/U19, play a role in cancer and embryogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>For example, EAF2/U19 may serve as a tumor suppressor in prostate cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>At the same time, EAF2/U19 is a downstream factor in the non-canonical Wnt 4 signaling pathway required for eye development in Xenopus laevis, and along with EAF1, contributes to convergence and extension movements in zebrafish embryos through Wnt maintenance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we used zebrafish embryos and mammalian cells to show that both EAF1 and EAF2/U19 were up-regulated by Wnt4 (Wnt4a).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, we found that EAF1 and EAF2/U19 suppressed Wnt4 expression by directly binding to the Wnt4 promoter as seen in chromatin immunoprecipitation assays.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings indicate that an auto-regulatory negative feedback loop occurs between Wnt4 and the EAF family, which is conserved between zebrafish and mammalian.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The rescue experiments in zebrafish embryos showed that early embryonic development required the maintenance of the appropriate levels of Wnt4a through the feedback loop.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Others have demonstrated that the tumor suppressors p63, p73 and WT1 positively regulate Wnt4 expression while p21 has the opposite effect, suggesting that maintenance of appropriate Wnt4 expression may also be critical for adult tissue homeostasis and prevention against tumor initiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, the auto-regulatory negative feedback loop that controls expression of Wnt4 and EAF proteins may play an important role in both embryonic development and tumor suppression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings provide the first convincing line of evidence that EAF and Wnt4 form an auto-regulatory negative feedback loop in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Differential cytokine regulation by NF-kappaB and AP-1 in Jurkat T-cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Activator protein (AP)-1 and nuclear factor (NF)-kappaB largely control T-cell activation, following binding of foreign antigens to the T-cell receptor leading to cytokine secretion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Elevated levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines such as TNF, IL-6 and CXCL8 are associated with several human diseases including cystic fibrosis, pulmonary fibrosis and AIDS.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The aim of this study was to investigate the role of the transcription factors, AP-1 and NF-kappaB, in IL-6 and CXCL8 regulation in Jurkat T-cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS: Phorbol myristate acetate (PMA) exposure resulted in an up-regulation of AP-1 and down-regulation of NF-kappaB activity, however, exposure to heat killed (HK) Escherichia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>coli MG1655 resulted in a dose-dependent increase in NF-kappaB activity without affecting AP-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The cytokine profile revealed an up-regulation of the chemokine CXCL8 and the pro-inflammatory cytokines TNF, IL-2 and IL-6 following treatment with both PMA and HK E. coli, while the levels of the anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10 were not affected by PMA but were significantly down-regulated by HK E. coli.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>AP-1</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>activation was significantly increased 2 h after PMA exposure and continued to increase thereafter.</Gene>
<Gene>In contrast, NF-kappaB responded to PMA exposure by a rapid up-regulation followed by a subsequent down-regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Increased intracellular Ca2+ concentrations countered the down-regulation of NF-kappaB by PMA, while similar treatment with calcium ionophore resulted in a reduced NF-kappaB activity following induction with HK E. coli.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In order to further study NF-kappaB activation, we considered two up-stream signalling proteins, PKC and Bcl10.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Phosphorylated-PKC levels increased in response to PMA and HK E. coli, while Bcl10 levels significantly decreased following PMA treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using an NF-kappaB activation inhibitor, we observed complete inhibition of IL-6 expression while CXCL8 levels only decreased by 40% at the highest concentration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Treatment of Jurkat T-cells with PMA in the presence of JNK-inhibitor suppressed both CXCL8 and IL-6 while PKC-inhibitor primarily decreased CXCL8 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>The present study shows that NF-kappaB regulated IL-6 but not CXCL8.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This complex regulation of CXCL8 suggests that there is a need to further evaluate the signalling pathways in order to develop new treatment for diseases with elevated CXCL8 levels, such as AIDS and autoimmune diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Subtilase cytotoxin induces apoptosis in HeLa cells by mitochondrial permeabilization via activation of Bax/Bak, independent of C/EBF-homologue protein (CHOP), Ire1alpha or JNK signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Subtilase cytotoxin (SubAB) is an AB(5) cytotoxin produced by some strains of Shiga-toxigenic Escherichia coli.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The A subunit is a subtilase-like serine protease and cleaves an endoplasmic reticulum (ER) chaperone, BiP, leading to transient inhibition of protein synthesis and cell cycle arrest at G(1) phase, and inducing caspase-dependent apoptosis via mitochondrial membrane damage in Vero cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we investigated the mechanism of mitochondrial permeabilization in HeLa cells.</Gene>
<Gene>SubAB-induced cytochrome c release into cytosol did not depend on mitochondrial permeability transition pore (PTP), since cyclosporine A did not suppress cytochrome c release.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SubAB did not change the expression of anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 or Bcl-XL and pro-apoptotic Bax or Bak, but triggered Bax and Bak conformational changes and association of Bax with Bak.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Silencing using siRNA of both bax and bak genes, but not bax, bak, or bim alone, resulted in reduction of cytochrome c release, caspase-3 activation, DNA ladder formation and cytotoxicity, indicating that Bax and Bak were involved in apoptosis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SubAB activated ER transmembrane transducers, Ire1alpha, and cJun N-terminal kinase (JNK), and induced C/EBF-homologue protein (CHOP).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To investigate whether these signals were involved in cytochrome c release by Bax activation, we silenced ire1alpha, jnk or chop; however, silencing did not decrease SubAB-induced cytochrome c release, suggesting that these signals were not necessary for SubAB-induced mitochondrial permeabilization by Bax activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Themis2/ICB1 is a signaling scaffold that selectively regulates macrophage Toll-like receptor signaling and cytokine production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Thymocyte expressed molecule involved in selection 1 (Themis1, SwissProt accession number Q8BGW0) is the recently characterised founder member of a novel family of proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A second member of this family, Themis2 (Q91YX0), also known as ICB1 (Induced on contact with basement membrane 1), remains unreported at the protein level despite microarray and EST databases reporting Themis2 mRNA expression in B cells and macrophages.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS:</Gene>

<Gene>Here we characterise Themis2 protein for the first time and show that it acts as a macrophage signalling scaffold, exerting a receptor-, mediator- and signalling pathway-specific effect on TLR responses in RAW 264.7 macrophages.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Themis2</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>over-expression enhanced the LPS-induced production of TNF but not IL-6 or Cox-2, nor TNF production induced by ligands for TLR2 (PAM3) or TLR3 (poly IratioC).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, LPS-induced activation of the MAP kinases ERK and p38 was enhanced in cells over-expressing Themis2 whereas the activation of JNK, IRF3 or NF-kappaB p65, was unaffected.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Depletion of Themis2 protein by RNA inteference inhibited LPS-induced TNF production in primary human macrophages demonstrating a requirement for Themis2 in this event.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Themis2 was inducibly tyrosine phosphorylated upon LPS challenge and interacted with Lyn kinase (P25911), the Rho guanine nucleotide exchange factor, Vav (P27870), and the adaptor protein Grb2 (Q60631).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mutation of either tyrosine 660 or a proline-rich sequence (PPPRPPK) simultaneously interrupted this complex and reduced by approximately 50% the capacity of Themis2 to promote LPS-induced TNF production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, Themis2 protein expression was induced during macrophage development from murine bone marrow precursors and was regulated by inflammatory stimuli both in vitro and in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE:</Gene>
<Gene>We hypothesise that Themis2 may constitute a novel, physiological control point in macrophage inflammatory responses.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>No evidence of altered alveolar macrophage polarization, but reduced expression of TLR2, in bronchoalveolar lavage cells in sarcoidosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous inflammatory disease, possibly of infectious aetiology.</Gene>

<Gene>We aimed to investigate whether the degree of functional polarization of alveolar macrophages (AMs), or Toll-like receptor (TLR) expression, is associated with sarcoidosis or with distinct clinical manifestations of this disease.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>Total BAL cells (cultured four or 24 h in medium, or stimulated 24 h with LPS) from 14 patients and six healthy subjects, sorted AMs from 22 patients (Lofgren's syndrome n = 11) and 11 healthy subjects, and sorted CD4+ T cells from 26 patients (Lofgren's syndrome n = 13) and seven healthy subjects, were included.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using real-time PCR, the relative gene expression of IL-10, IL-12p35, IL-12p40, IL-23p19, CCR2, CCR7, iNOS, CXCL10, CXCL11, CXCL16, CCL18, CCL20, CD80, and CD86, and innate immune receptors TLR2, TLR4, and TLR9, was quantified in sorted AMs, and for selected genes in total BAL cells, while IL-17A was quantified in T cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>We did not find evidence of a difference with regard to alveolar macrophage M1/M2 polarization between sarcoidosis patients and healthy controls.</Gene>
<Gene>TLR2 gene expression was significantly lower in sorted AMs from patients, particular in Lofgren's patients.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CCL18 gene expression in AMs was significantly higher in patients compared to controls.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, the IL-17A expression was lower in Lofgren's patients' CD4+ T cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Overall, there was no evidence for alveolar macrophage polarization in sarcoidosis.</Gene>

<Gene>However, there was a reduced TLR2 mRNA expression in patients with Lofgren's syndrome, which may be of relevance for macrophage interactions with a postulated sarcoidosis pathogen, and for the characteristics of the ensuing T cell response.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Microparticles carrying Sonic hedgehog favor neovascularization through the activation of nitric oxide pathway in mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Microparticles (MPs) are vesicles released from plasma membrane upon cell activation and during apoptosis.</Gene>
<Gene>Human T lymphocytes undergoing activation and apoptosis generate MPs bearing morphogen Shh (MPs(Shh+)) that are able to regulate in vitro angiogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODOLOGY/PRINCIPAL FINDINGS:</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we investigated the ability of MPs(Shh+) to modulate neovascularization in a model of mouse hind limb ischemia.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mice were treated in vivo for 21 days with vehicle, MPs(Shh+), MPs(Shh+) plus cyclopamine or cyclopamine alone, an inhibitor of Shh signalling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Laser doppler analysis revealed that the recovery of the blood flow was 1.4 fold higher in MPs(Shh+)-treated mice than in controls, and this was associated with an activation of Shh pathway in muscles and an increase in NO production in both aorta and muscles.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MPs(Shh+)-mediated effects on flow recovery and NO production were completely prevented when Shh signalling was inhibited by cyclopamine.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In aorta, MPs(Shh+) increased activation of eNOS/Akt pathway, and VEGF expression, being inhibited by cyclopamine.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>By contrast, in muscles, MPs(Shh+) enhanced eNOS expression and phosphorylation and decreased caveolin-1 expression, but cyclopamine prevented only the effects of MPs(Shh+) on eNOS pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Quantitative RT-PCR revealed that MPs(Shh+) treatment increased FGF5, FGF2, VEGF A and C mRNA levels and decreased those of alpha5-integrin, FLT-4, HGF, IGF-1, KDR, MCP-1, MT1-MMP, MMP-2, TGFbeta1, TGFbeta2, TSP-1 and VCAM-1, in ischemic muscles.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS/SIGNIFICANCE:</Gene>
<Gene>These findings suggest that MPs(Shh+) may contribute to reparative neovascularization after ischemic injury by regulating NO pathway and genes involved in angiogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Phylogenetic and developmental study of CD4, CD8 alpha and beta T cell co-receptor homologs in two amphibian species, Xenopus tropicalis and Xenopus laevis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD4 and CD8 co-receptors play critical roles in T cell development and activation by interacting both with T cell receptors and MHC molecules.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although homologs of these genes have been identified in many jawed vertebrates, there are still unresolved gaps concerning their evolution and specialization in MHC interaction and T cell function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using experimental and computational procedures we identified CD4, CD8alpha and CD8beta gene homologs both in Xenopus tropicalis, whose full genome has been sequenced, and its sister species Xenopus laevis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Multiple alignments of deduced amino acid sequences reveal a poor conservation of the residues involved in binding of CD4 to MHC class II, and CD8alpha to class I in non-mammalian species, presumably related to the co-evolutionary pressure of MHC I and II genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Phylogenetic study suggests that Xenopodinae co-receptor genes are more closely related to their homologs in other tetrapods than those of bony fish.</Gene>
<Gene>Furthermore, the developmental and cell-specific expression patterns of these genes in X. laevis are very similar to that of mammals.</Gene>
<Gene>X. laevis CD4 is mainly expressed by peripheral non-CD8 T cells and detected in the thymus as early as four days post-fertilization (dpf) at the onset of thymic organogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD8beta expression is specific to adult surface CD8(+) T cells and thymocytes, and is first detected in the thymus at 5 dpf in parallel with productive TCRgamma transrcipts, whereas productive TCRbeta and alpha rearrangements are not detected before 7-9 dpf.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Comparative transcriptome profiling analyses during the lag phase uncover YAP1, PDR1, PDR3, RPN4, and HSF1 as key regulatory genes in genomic adaptation to the lignocellulose derived inhibitor HMF for Saccharomyces cerevisiae.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>The yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae is able to adapt and in situ detoxify lignocellulose derived inhibitors such as furfural and HMF.</Gene>
<Gene>The length of lag phase for cell growth in response to the inhibitor challenge has been used to measure tolerance of strain performance.</Gene>
<Gene>Mechanisms of yeast tolerance at the genome level remain unknown.</Gene>

<Gene>Using systems biology approach, this study investigated comparative transcriptome profiling, metabolic profiling, cell growth response, and gene regulatory interactions of yeast strains and selective gene deletion mutations in response to HMF challenges during the lag phase of growth.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>We identified 365 candidate genes and found at least 3 significant components involving some of these genes that enable yeast adaptation and tolerance to HMF in yeast.</Gene>

<Gene>First, functional enzyme coding genes such as ARI1, ADH6, ADH7, and OYE3, as well as gene interactions involved in the biotransformation and inhibitor detoxification were the direct driving force to reduce HMF damages in cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expressions of these genes were regulated by YAP1 and its closely related regulons.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Second, a large number of PDR genes, mainly regulated by PDR1 and PDR3, were induced during the lag phase and the PDR gene family-centered functions, including specific and multiple functions involving cellular transport such as TPO1, TPO4, RSB1, PDR5, PDR15, YOR1, and SNQ2, promoted cellular adaptation and survival in order to cope with the inhibitor stress.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Third, expressed genes involving degradation of damaged proteins and protein modifications such as SHP1 and SSA4, regulated by RPN4, HSF1, and other co-regulators, were necessary for yeast cells to survive and adapt the HMF stress.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A deletion mutation strain Deltarpn4 was unable to recover the growth in the presence of HMF.</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSIONS: Complex gene interactions and regulatory networks as well as co-regulations exist in yeast adaptation and tolerance to the lignocellulose derived inhibitor HMF.</Gene>

<Gene>Both induced and repressed genes involving diversified functional categories are accountable for adaptation and energy rebalancing in yeast to survive and adapt the HMF stress during the lag phase of growth.</Gene>
<Gene>Transcription factor genes YAP1, PDR1, PDR3, RPN4, and HSF1 appeared to play key regulatory rules for global adaptation in the yeast S. cerevisiae.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Localization of a guanylyl cyclase to chemosensory cilia requires the novel ciliary MYND domain protein DAF-25.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In harsh conditions, Caenorhabditis elegans arrests development to enter a non-aging, resistant diapause state called the dauer larva.</Gene>
<Gene>Olfactory sensation modulates the TGF-beta and insulin signaling pathways to control this developmental decision.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Four mutant alleles of daf-25 (abnormal DAuer Formation) were isolated from screens for mutants exhibiting constitutive dauer formation and found to be defective in olfaction.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The daf-25 dauer phenotype is suppressed by daf-10/IFT122 mutations (which disrupt ciliogenesis), but not by daf-6/PTCHD3 mutations (which prevent environmental exposure of sensory cilia), implying that DAF-25 functions in the cilia themselves.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>daf-25 encodes the C. elegans ortholog of mammalian Ankmy2, a MYND domain protein of unknown function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Disruption of DAF-25, which localizes to sensory cilia, produces no apparent cilia structure anomalies, as determined by light and electron microscopy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hinting at its potential function, the dauer phenotype, epistatic order, and expression profile of daf-25 are similar to daf-11, which encodes a cilium-localized guanylyl cyclase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Indeed, we demonstrate that DAF-25 is required for proper DAF-11 ciliary localization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, the functional interaction is evolutionarily conserved, as mouse Ankmy2 interacts with guanylyl cyclase GC1 from ciliary photoreceptors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The interaction may be specific because daf-25 mutants have normally-localized OSM-9/TRPV4, TAX-4/CNGA1, CHE-2/IFT80, CHE-11/IFT140, CHE-13/IFT57, BBS-8, OSM-5/IFT88, and XBX-1/D2LIC in the cilia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intraflagellar transport (IFT) (required to build cilia) is not defective in daf-25 mutants, although the ciliary localization of DAF-25 itself is influenced in che-11 mutants, which are defective in retrograde IFT.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In summary, we have discovered a novel ciliary protein that plays an important role in cGMP signaling by localizing a guanylyl cyclase to the sensory organelle.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Bone morphogenetic protein 4 (BMP4) signaling in retinoblastoma cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Bone morphogenetic proteins (BMPs) - expressed in the developing retina - are known to be involved in the regulation of cell proliferation and apoptosis in several tumor entities.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The objective of this study was to determine the role of the BMP4 pathway in retinoblastoma cells, which are absent in a functional retinoblastoma (RB1) gene.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BMP receptors were detected in all retinoblastoma cell lines investigated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>A correct transmission of BMP signaling via the Smad1/5/8 pathway could be demonstrated in WERI-Rb1 retinoblastoma cells and application of recombinant human BMP4 resulted in an increase in apoptosis, which to a large extend is caspase independent.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cell proliferation was not affected by BMP4 signaling, although the pRb-related proteins p107 and p130, contributing to the regulation of the same genes, are still expressed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>WERI-Rb1 cells exhibit elevated endogenous levels of p21(CIP1) and p53, but we did not detect any increase in p53, p21(CIP1)or p27(KIP1) expression levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Id proteins became, however, strongly up-regulated upon exogenous BMP4 treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, RB1 loss in WERI-Rb1 cells is obviously not compensated for by pRb-independent (e.g. p53-dependent) cell cycle control mechanisms, preventing an anti-proliferative response to BMP4, which normally induces cell cycle arrest.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>COX-2 gene expression in colon cancer tissue related to regulating factors and promoter methylation status.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Increased cyclooxygenase activity promotes progression of colorectal cancer, but the mechanisms behind COX-2 induction remain elusive.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study was therefore aimed to define external cell signaling and transcription factors relating to high COX-2 expression in colon cancer tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHOD:</Gene>
<Gene>Tumor and normal colon tissue were collected at primary curative operation in 48 unselected patients.</Gene>
<Gene>COX-2 expression in tumor and normal colon tissue was quantified including microarray analyses on tumor mRNA accounting for high and low tumor COX-2 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Cross hybridization was performed between tumor and normal colon tissue.</Gene>
<Gene>Methylation status of up-stream COX-2 promoter region was evaluated.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Tumors with high COX-2 expression displayed large differences in gene expression compared to normal colon.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Numerous genes with altered expression appeared in tumors of high COX-2 expression compared to tumors of low COX-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>COX-2 expression in normal colon was increased in patients with tumors of high COX-2 compared to normal colon from patients with tumors of low COX-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IL1beta, IL6 and iNOS transcripts were up-regulated among external cell signaling factors; nine transcription factors (ATF3, C/EBP, c-Fos, Fos-B, JDP2, JunB, c-Maf, NF-kappaB, TCF4) showed increased expression and 5 (AP-2, CBP, Elk-1, p53, PEA3) were decreased in tumors with high COX-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The promoter region of COX-2 gene did not show consistent methylation in tumor or normal colon tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>Transcription and external cell signaling factors are altered as covariates to COX-2 expression in colon cancer tissue, but DNA methylation of the COX-2 promoter region was not a significant factor behind COX-2 expression in tumor and normal colon tissue.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Notch, IL-1 and leptin crosstalk outcome (NILCO) is critical for leptin-induced proliferation, migration and VEGF/VEGFR-2 expression in breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>High levels of pro-angiogenic factors, leptin, IL-1, Notch and VEGF (ligands and receptors), are found in breast cancer, which is commonly correlated with metastasis and lower survival of patients.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have previously reported that leptin induces the growth of breast cancer and the expression of VEGF/VEGFR-2 and IL-1 system.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We hypothesized that Notch, IL-1 and leptin crosstalk outcome (NILCO) plays an essential role in the regulation of leptin-mediated induction of proliferation/migration and expression of pro-angiogenic molecules in breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To test this hypothesis, leptin's effects on the expression and activation of Notch signaling pathway and VEGF/VEGFR-2/IL-1 were determined in mouse (4T1, EMT6 and MMT) breast cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Remarkably, leptin up-regulated Notch1-4/JAG1/Dll-4, Notch target genes: Hey2 and survivin, together with IL-1 and VEGF/VEGFR-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RNA knockdown and pharmacological inhibitors of leptin signaling significantly abrogated activity of reporter gene-luciferase CSL (RBP-Jk) promoter, showing that it was linked to leptin-activated JAK2/STAT3, MAPK, PI-3K/mTOR, p38 and JNK signaling pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, leptin upregulatory effects on cell proliferation/migration and pro-angiogenic factors Notch, IL-1 and VEGF/VEGFR-2 were abrogated by a gamma-secretase inhibitor, DAPT, as well as siRNA against CSL.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, blockade of IL-1R tI inhibited leptin-induced Notch, Hey2 and survivin as well as VEGF/VEGFR-2 expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest leptin is an inducer of Notch (expression/activation) and IL-1 signaling modulates leptin effects on Notch and VEGF/VEGFR-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We show for the first time that a novel unveiled crosstalk between Notch, IL-1 and leptin (NILCO) occurs in breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Leptin induction of proliferation/migration and upregulation of VEGF/VEGFR-2 in breast cancer cells were related to an intact Notch signaling axis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NILCO could represent the integration of developmental, pro-inflammatory and pro-angiogenic signals critical for leptin-induced cell proliferation/migration and regulation of VEGF/VEGFR-2 in breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Targeting NILCO might help to design new pharmacological strategies aimed at controlling breast cancer growth and angiogenesis.</Gene>
<Gene>Serum leptin levels in relation to circulating cytokines, chemokines, adhesion molecules and angiogenic factors in normal pregnancy and preeclampsia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>OBJECTIVE:</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, we determined circulating levels of C-reactive protein, several cytokines, chemokines, adhesion molecules and angiogenic factors along with those of leptin in healthy non-pregnant and pregnant women and preeclamptic patients, and investigated whether serum leptin levels were related to the clinical characteristics and measured laboratory parameters of the study participants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS: Sixty preeclamptic patients, 60 healthy pregnant women and 59 healthy non-pregnant women were involved in this case-control study.</Gene>
<Gene>Levels of leptin and transforming growth factor (TGF)-beta1 in maternal sera were assessed by ELISA.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Serum levels of interleukin (IL)-1beta, IL-1 receptor antagonist (IL-1ra), IL-2, IL-4, IL-6, IL-8, IL-10, IL-12p40, IL-12p70, IL-18, interferon (IFN)-gamma, tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha, interferon-gamma-inducible protein (IP)-10, monocyte chemotactic protein (MCP)-1, intercellular adhesion molecule (ICAM)-1 and vascular cell adhesion molecule (VCAM)-1 were determined by multiplex suspension array.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Serum C-reactive protein (CRP) concentrations were measured by an autoanalyzer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Serum total soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase-1 (sFlt-1) and biologically active placental growth factor (PlGF) levels were determined by electrochemiluminescence immunoassay.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>For statistical analyses, non-parametric methods were applied.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>There were significant differences in most of the measured laboratory parameters among the three study groups except for serum IL-1beta and TGF-beta1 levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Serum leptin levels were significantly higher in preeclamptic patients and healthy pregnant women than in healthy non-pregnant women.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Additionally, preeclamptic patients had significantly higher leptin levels as compared to healthy pregnant women.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Serum leptin levels were independently associated with BMI in healthy non-pregnant women.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In healthy pregnant women, both BMI and serum CRP concentrations showed significant positive linear association with leptin levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>There were significant positive correlations between serum leptin concentrations of healthy pregnant women and systolic blood pressure, as well as serum levels of IP-10, while their serum leptin levels correlated inversely with fetal birth weight.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In preeclamptic patients, a significant positive correlation was observed between serum concentrations of leptin and IP-10.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, elevated serum leptin level and sFlt-1/PlGF ratio had an additive (joint) effect in the risk of preeclampsia, as shown by the substantially higher odds ratios of their combination than of either alone.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>Simultaneous measurement of leptin with several inflammatory molecules and angiogenic factors in this study enabled us to investigate their relationship, which can help to understand the role of circulating leptin in normal pregnancy and preeclampsia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Release of Ku and MRN from DNA ends by Mre11 nuclease activity and Ctp1 is required for homologous recombination repair of double-strand breaks.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The multifunctional Mre11-Rad50-Nbs1 (MRN) protein complex recruits ATM/Tel1 checkpoint kinase and CtIP/Ctp1 homologous recombination (HR) repair factor to double-strand breaks (DSBs).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>HR repair commences with the 5'-to-3' resection of DNA ends, generating 3' single-strand DNA (ssDNA) overhangs that bind Replication Protein A (RPA) complex, followed by Rad51 recombinase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the Mre11-Rad50-Xrs2 (MRX) complex is critical for DSB resection, although the enigmatic ssDNA endonuclease activity of Mre11 and the DNA-end processing factor Sae2 (CtIP/Ctp1 ortholog) are largely unnecessary unless the resection activities of Exo1 and Sgs1-Dna2 are also eliminated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mre11 nuclease activity and Ctp1/CtIP are essential for DSB repair in Schizosaccharomyces pombe and mammals.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To investigate DNA end resection in Schizo.</Gene>
<Gene>pombe, we adapted an assay that directly measures ssDNA formation at a defined DSB.</Gene>
<Gene>We found that Mre11 and Ctp1 are essential for the efficient initiation of resection, consistent with their equally crucial roles in DSB repair.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Exo1 is largely responsible for extended resection up to 3.1 kb from a DSB, with an activity dependent on Rqh1 (Sgs1) DNA helicase having a minor role.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Despite its critical function in DSB repair, Mre11 nuclease activity is not required for resection in fission yeast.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, Mre11 nuclease and Ctp1 are required to disassociate the MRN complex and the Ku70-Ku80 nonhomologous end-joining (NHEJ) complex from DSBs, which is required for efficient RPA localization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Eliminating Ku makes Mre11 nuclease activity dispensable for MRN disassociation and RPA localization, while improving repair of a one-ended DSB formed by replication fork collapse.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>From these data we propose that release of the MRN complex and Ku from DNA ends by Mre11 nuclease activity and Ctp1 is a critical step required to expose ssDNA for RPA localization and ensuing HR repair.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ankyrin repeat and SOCS box containing protein 4 (Asb-4) colocalizes with insulin receptor substrate 4 (IRS4) in the hypothalamic neurons and mediates IRS4 degradation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>The arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus regulates food intake.</Gene>

<Gene>Ankyrin repeat and SOCS box containing protein 4 (Asb-4) is expressed in neuropeptide Y and proopiomelanocortin (POMC) neurons in the arcuate nucleus, target neurons in the regulation of food intake and metabolism by insulin and leptin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the target protein(s) of Asb-4 in these neurons remains unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Insulin receptor substrate 4 (IRS4) is an adaptor molecule involved in the signal transduction by both insulin and leptin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the present study we examined the colocalization and interaction of Asb-4 with IRS4 and the involvement of Asb-4 in insulin signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>In situ hybridization showed that the expression pattern of Asb-4 was consistent with that of IRS4 in the rat brain.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Double in situ hybridization showed that IRS4 colocalized with Asb-4, and both Asb-4 and IRS4 mRNA were expressed in proopiomelanocortin (POMC) and neuropeptide Y (NPY) neurons within the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In HEK293 cells co-transfected with Myc-tagged Asb-4 and Flag-tagged IRS4, Asb-4 co-immunoprecipitated with IRS4; In these cells endogenous IRS4 also co-immunoprecipitated with transfected Myc-Asb-4; Furthermore, Asb-4 co-immunoprecipitated with IRS4 in rat hypothalamic extracts.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In HEK293 cells over expression of Asb-4 decreased IRS4 protein levels and deletion of the SOCS box abolished this effect.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Asb-4 increased the ubiquitination of IRS4; Deletion of SOCS box abolished this effect.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression of Asb-4 decreased both basal and insulin-stimulated phosphorylation of AKT at Thr308.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>These data demonstrated that Asb-4 co-localizes and interacts with IRS4 in hypothalamic neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The interaction of Asb-4 with IRS4 in cell lines mediates the degradation of IRS4 and decreases insulin signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interferon regulatory factor 3 plays an anti-inflammatory role in microglia by activating the PI3K/Akt pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>Microglia are the principal cells involved in the innate immune response in the CNS.</Gene>

<Gene>Activated microglia produce a number of proinflammatory cytokines implicated in neurotoxicity but they also are a major source of anti-inflammatory cytokines, antiviral proteins and growth factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, an immune therapy aiming at suppressing the proinflammatory phenotype while enhancing the anti-inflammatory, growth promoting phenotype would be of great benefit.</Gene>

<Gene>In the current study, we tested the hypothesis that interferon regulatory factor 3 (IRF3), a transcription factor required for the induction of IFNbeta following TLR3 or TLR4 activation, is critical to the microglial phenotype change from proinflammatory to anti-inflammatory, and that this phenotype change can be greatly facilitated by IRF3 gene transfer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>Cultures of primary human fetal microglia were transduced with IRF3 using recombinant adenovirus (Ad-IRF3) and subjected to microarray analysis, real-time PCR, immunoblotting and ELISA to determine inflammatory gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Two different types of immune stimuli were tested, the TLR ligands, poly IC (PIC) and LPS, and the proinflammatory cytokines, IL-1/IFNgamma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the role of the PI3K/Akt pathway was examined by use of a pharmacological inhibitor, LY294002. RESULTS:</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results show that Ad-IRF3 suppressed proinflammatory genes (IL-1alpha, IL-1beta, TNFalpha, IL-6, IL-8 and CXCL1) and enhanced anti-inflammatory genes (IL-1 receptor antagonist, IL-10 and IFNbeta) in microglia, regardless of the cell stimuli applied.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, Ad-IRF3 activated Akt, and LY294002 reversed the effects of Ad-IRF3 on microglial inflammatory gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>pAkt was critical in LPS- or PIC-induced production of IL-10 and IL-1ra.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Significantly, microglial IFNbeta protein production was also dependent on pAkt and required both Ad-IRF3 and immunological stimuli (PIC    > IL-1/IFNgamma).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>pAkt played much less prominent and variable roles in microglial proinflammatory gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This anti-inflammatory promoting role of PI3K/Akt appeared to be specific to microglia, since astrocyte proinflammatory gene expression (as well as IFNbeta expression) required PI3K/Akt. CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results show a novel anti-inflammatory role for the PI3K/Akt signaling pathway in microglia.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>They further suggest that IRF3 gene therapy could facilitate the microglial phenotype switch from proinflammatory ("M1-like") to anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory ("M2-like"), in part, by augmenting the level of pAkt.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Reciprocal effects of NNK and SLURP-1 on oncogene expression in target epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>AIMS:</Gene>

<Gene>To elucidate how the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors expressed on bronchial and oral epithelial cells targeted by the tobacco nitrosamine (4-(methylnitrosamino)-1-(3-pyridyl)-1-butanone) (NNK) facilitate carcinogenic transformation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>MAIN METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>Since NNK-dependent transformation can be abolished by the nicotinergic secreted mammalian Ly-6/urokinase plasminogen activator receptor related protein-1 (SLURP-1), we compared effects of NNK and recombinant (r)SLURP-1 on the expression of genes related to tumorigenesis in human immortalized bronchial and oral epithelial cell lines BEP2D and Het-1A, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>KEY FINDINGS:</Gene>

<Gene>NNK stimulated expression of oncogenic genes, including MYB and PIK3CA in BEP2D, ETS1, NRAS and SRC in Het-1A, and AKT1, KIT and RB1 in both cell types, which could be abolished in the presence of rSLURP-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Other cancer-related genes whose upregulation by NNK was abolishable by rSLURP-1 were the growth factors EGF in BEP2D cells and HGF in Het-1A cells, and the transcription factors CDKN2A and STAT3 (Het-1A only).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NNK also upregulated the anti-apoptotic BCL2 (Het-1A) and downregulated the pro-apoptotic TNF (Het-1A), BAX and CASP8 (BEP2D), all of which could be abolished, in part, by rSLURP-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>NNK decreased expression of the CTNNB1 gene encoding the intercellular adhesion molecule beta-catenin (BEP2D), as well as tumor suppressors CDKN3 and FOXD3 in BEP2D cells and SERPINB5 in Het-1A cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These pro-oncogenic effects of NNK were abolished by rSLURP-1 that also upregulated RUNX3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SIGNIFICANCE:</Gene>

<Gene>The obtained results identified target genes for both NNK and SLURP-1 and shed light on the molecular mechanism of their reciprocal effects on tumorigenic transformation of bronchial and oral epithelial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>TNFR-associated factor 2 deficiency in B lymphocytes predisposes to chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma in mice.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We have previously shown that transgenic (tg) mice expressing in B lymphocytes both BCL-2 and a TNFR-associated factor 2 (TRAF2) mutant lacking the really interesting new gene and zinc finger domains (TRAF2DN) develop small lymphocytic lymphoma and chronic lymphocytic leukemia with high incidence (Zapata et al. 2004.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Proc. Nat. Acad.</Gene>
<Gene>Sci.</Gene>

<Gene>Further analysis of the expression of TRAF2 and TRAF2DN in purified B cells demonstrated that expression of both endogenous TRAF2 and tg TRAF2DN was negligible in Traf2DN-tg B cells compared with wild-type mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This was the result of proteasome-dependent degradation, and rendered TRAF2DN B cells as bona fide TRAF2-deficient B cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Similar to B cells with targeted Traf2 deletion, Traf2DN-tg mice show expanded marginal zone B cell population and have constitutive p100 NF-kappaB2 processing.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Also, TRAF3, X-linked inhibitor of apoptosis, and Bcl-X(L) expression levels were increased, whereas cellular inhibitors of apoptosis 1 and 2 levels were drastically reduced compared with those found in wild-type B cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, consistent with previous results, we also show that TRAF2 was required for efficient JNK and ERK activation in response to CD40 engagement.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, TRAF2 was deleterious for BCR-mediated activation of these kinases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, TRAF2 deficiency had no effect on CD40-mediated p38 MAPK activation but significantly reduced BCR-mediated p38 activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, we further confirm that TRAF2 was required for CD40-mediated proliferation, but its absence relieved B cells of the need for B cell activating factor for survival.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Altogether, our results suggest that TRAF2 deficiency cooperates with BCL-2 in promoting chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma in mice, possibly by specifically enforcing marginal zone B cell accumulation, increasing X-linked inhibitor of apoptosis expression, and rendering B cells independent of B cell activating factor for survival.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Defining an EPOR- regulated transcriptome for primary progenitors, including Tnfr-sf13c as a novel mediator of EPO- dependent erythroblast formation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Certain concepts concerning EPO/EPOR action modes have been challenged by in vivo studies: Bcl-x levels are elevated in maturing erythroblasts, but not in their progenitors; truncated EPOR alleles that lack a major p85/PI3K recruitment site nonetheless promote polycythemia; and Erk1 disruption unexpectedly bolsters erythropoiesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To discover novel EPO/EPOR action routes, global transcriptome analyses presently are applied to interrogate EPO/EPOR effects on primary bone marrow-derived CFUe-like progenitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Overall, 160 EPO/EPOR target transcripts were significantly modulated 2-to 21.8-fold.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A unique set of EPO-regulated survival factors included Lyl1, Gas5, Pim3, Pim1, Bim, Trib3 and Serpina 3g. EPO/EPOR-modulated cell cycle mediators included Cdc25a, Btg3, Cyclin-d2, p27-kip1, Cyclin-g2 and CyclinB1-IP-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>EPO regulation of signal transduction factors was also interestingly complex.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>For example, not only Socs3 plus Socs2 but also Spred2, Spred1 and Eaf1 were EPO-induced as negative-feedback components.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Socs2, plus five additional targets, further proved to comprise new EPOR/Jak2/Stat5 response genes (which are important for erythropoiesis during anemia).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Among receptors, an atypical TNF-receptor Tnfr-sf13c was up-modulated    >5-fold by EPO.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Functionally, Tnfr-sf13c ligation proved to both promote proerythroblast survival, and substantially enhance erythroblast formation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The EPOR therefore engages a sophisticated set of transcriptome response circuits, with Tnfr-sf13c deployed as one novel positive regulator of proerythroblast formation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Variation in IL10 and other genes involved in the immune response and in oxidation and prostate cancer recurrence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: To evaluate the association of variation in genes involved in immune response, including IL10, production and detoxification of reactive oxygen species, and repair of oxidative DNA damage with risk of recurrence after surgery for localized prostate cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>We conducted a nested case-control study of men who had a radical prostatectomy in 1993 to 2001.</Gene>
<Gene>A total of 484 recurrence cases and 484 controls were matched on age, race, and pathologic stage and grade.</Gene>
<Gene>Germline DNA was extracted from paraffin-embedded unaffected lymph nodes.</Gene>

<Gene>We genotyped candidate single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) in IL10, CRP, GPX1, GSR, GSTP1, hOGG1, IL1B, IL1RN, IL6, IL8, MPO, NOS2, NOS3, SOD1, SOD2, SOD3, TLR4, and TNF and tagging SNPs in IL10, CRP, GSR, IL1RN, IL6, NOS2, and NOS3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We used conditional logistic regression to estimate OR and 95% confidence intervals (CI).</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>The minor allele (A) in IL10 rs1800872, known to produce less interleukin-10 (IL-10), was associated with a higher risk of recurrence (OR = 1.76, 95% CI: 1.00-3.10), and the minor allele (G) in rs1800896, known to produce more IL-10, was associated with a lower risk of recurrence (OR = 0.66, 95% CI: 0.48-0.91).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We also observed associations for candidate SNPs in CRP, GSTP1, and IL1B. A common IL10 haplotype and 2 common NOS2 haplotypes were associated with recurrence.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION: Variation in IL10, CRP, GSTP1, IL1B, and NOS2 was associated with prostate cancer recurrence independent of pathologic prognostic factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IMPACT:</Gene>

<Gene>This study supports that genetic variation in immune response and oxidation influence prostate cancer recurrence risk and suggests genetic variation in these pathways may inform prognosis.</Gene>
<Gene>Minibrain/Dyrk1a regulates food intake through the Sir2-FOXO-sNPF/NPY pathway in Drosophila and mammals.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Feeding behavior is one of the most essential activities in animals, which is tightly regulated by neuroendocrine factors.</Gene>
<Gene>Drosophila melanogaster short neuropeptide F (sNPF) and the mammalian functional homolog neuropeptide Y (NPY) regulate food intake.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Understanding the molecular mechanism of sNPF and NPY signaling is critical to elucidate feeding regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we found that minibrain (mnb) and the mammalian ortholog Dyrk1a, target genes of sNPF and NPY signaling, [corrected] regulate food intake in Drosophila melanogaster and mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In Drosophila melanogaster neuronal cells and mouse hypothalamic cells, sNPF and NPY modulated the mnb and Dyrk1a expression through the PKA-CREB pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Increased Dyrk1a activated Sirt1 to regulate the deacetylation of FOXO, which potentiated FOXO-induced sNPF/NPY expression and in turn promoted food intake.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, AKT-mediated insulin signaling suppressed FOXO-mediated sNPF/NPY expression, which resulted in decreasing food intake.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, human Dyrk1a transgenic mice exhibited decreased FOXO acetylation and increased NPY expression in the hypothalamus, and [corrected] increased food intake.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings demonstrate that Mnb/Dyrk1a regulates food intake through the evolutionary conserved Sir2-FOXO-sNPF/NPY pathway in Drosophila melanogaster and mammals.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SOCS3 deficiency promotes M1 macrophage polarization and inflammation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Macrophages participate in both the amplification of inflammation at the time of injury and downregulation of the inflammatory response to avoid excess tissue damage.</Gene>
<Gene>These divergent functions of macrophages are dictated by their microenvironment, especially cytokines, which promote a spectrum of macrophage phenotypes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The M1 proinflammatory phenotype is induced by LPS, IFN-gamma, and GM-CSF, and IL-4, IL-13, and M-CSF induce anti-inflammatory M2 macrophages.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Suppressors of cytokine signaling (SOCS) proteins function as feedback inhibitors of the JAK/STAT signaling pathway, and they can terminate innate and adaptive immune responses.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we have evaluated the influence of SOCS3 on macrophage polarization and function.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Macrophages obtained from LysMCre-SOCS3(fl/fl) mice, which lack SOCS3 in myeloid lineage cells, exhibit enhanced and prolonged activation of the JAK/STAT pathway compared with macrophages from SOCS3(fl/fl) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, SOCS3-deficient macrophages have higher levels of the M1 genes IL-1beta, IL-6, IL-12, IL-23, and inducible NO synthase owing to enhanced transcriptional activation and chromatin modifications.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>SOCS3-deficient M1 macrophages also have a stronger capacity to induce Th1 and Th17 cell differentiation than M1 macrophages from SOCS3(fl/fl) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lastly, LPS-induced sepsis is exacerbated in LysMCre-SOCS3(fl/fl) mice and is associated with enhanced STAT1/3 activation and increased plasma levels of M1 cytokines/chemokines such as IL-1beta, TNF-alpha, IL-6, CCL3, CCL4, and CXCL11.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings collectively indicate that SOCS3 is involved in repressing the M1 proinflammatory phenotype, thereby deactivating inflammatory responses in macrophages.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Nrf2 is controlled by two distinct beta-TrCP recognition motifs in its Neh6 domain, one of which can be modulated by GSK-3 activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Identification of regulatable mechanisms by which transcription factor NF-E2 p45-related factor 2 (Nrf2) is repressed will allow strategies to be designed that counter drug resistance associated with its upregulation in tumours that harbour somatic mutations in Kelch-like ECH-associated protein-1 (Keap1), a gene that encodes a joint adaptor and substrate receptor for the Cul3-Rbx1/Roc1 ubiquitin ligase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We now show that mouse Nrf2 contains two binding sites for beta-transducin repeat-containing protein (beta-TrCP), which acts as a substrate receptor for the Skp1-Cul1-Rbx1/Roc1 ubiquitin ligase complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Deletion of either binding site in Nrf2 decreased beta-TrCP-mediated ubiquitylation of the transcription factor.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The ability of one of the two beta-TrCP-binding sites to serve as a degron could be both increased and decreased by manipulation of glycogen synthase kinase-3 (GSK-3) activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Biotinylated-peptide pull-down assays identified DSGIS(338) and DSAPGS(378) as the two beta-TrCP-binding motifs in Nrf2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Significantly, our pull-down assays indicated that beta-TrCP binds a phosphorylated version of DSGIS more tightly than its non-phosphorylated counterpart, whereas this was not the case for DSAPGS.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These data suggest that DSGIS, but not DSAPGS, contains a functional GSK-3 phosphorylation site.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Activation of GSK-3 in Keap1-null mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs), or in human lung A549 cells that contain mutant Keap1, by inhibition of the phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)-protein kinase B (PKB)/Akt pathway markedly reduced endogenous Nrf2 protein and decreased to 10-50% of normal the levels of mRNA for prototypic Nrf2-regulated enzymes, including the glutamate-cysteine ligase catalytic and modifier subunits, glutathione S-transferases Alpha-1 and Mu-1, haem oxygenase-1 and NAD(P)H:quinone oxidoreductase-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Pre-treatment of Keap1(-/-) MEFs or A549 cells with the LY294002 PI3K inhibitor or the MK-2206 PKB/Akt inhibitor increased their sensitivity to acrolein, chlorambucil and cisplatin between 1.9-fold and 3.1-fold, and this was substantially attenuated by simultaneous pre-treatment with the GSK-3 inhibitor CT99021.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Context- and cell-dependent effects of Delta-like 4 targeting in the bone marrow microenvironment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Delta-like 4 (Dll4) is a ligand of the Notch pathway family which has been widely studied in the context of tumor angiogenesis, its blockade shown to result in non-productive angiogenesis and halted tumor growth.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>As Dll4 inhibitors enter the clinic, there is an emerging need to understand their side effects, namely the systemic consequences of Dll4:Notch blockade in tissues other than tumors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The present study focused on the effects of systemic anti-Dll4 targeting in the bone marrow (BM) microenvironment.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here we show that Dll4 blockade with monoclonal antibodies perturbs the BM vascular niche of sub-lethally irradiated mice, resulting in increased CD31(+), VE-Cadherin(+) and c-kit(+) vessel density, and also increased megakaryocytes, whereas CD105(+), VEGFR3(+), SMA(+) and lectin(+) vessel density remained unaltered.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
