text: <Gene>We investigated also the expression of angiocrine genes upon Dll4 treatment in vivo, and demonstrate that IGFbp2, IGFbp3, Angpt2, Dll4, DHH and VEGF-A are upregulated, while FGF1 and CSF2 are reduced.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro treatment of endothelial cells with anti-Dll4 reduced Akt phosphorylation while maintaining similar levels of Erk 1/2 phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Besides its effects in the BM vascular niche, anti-Dll4 treatment perturbed hematopoiesis, as evidenced by increased myeloid (CD11b(+)), decreased B (B220(+)) and T (CD3(+)) lymphoid BM content of treated mice, with a corresponding increase in myeloid circulating cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, anti-Dll4 treatment also increased the number of CFU-M and -G colonies in methylcellulose assays, independently of Notch1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, anti-Dll4 treatment of donor BM improved the hematopoietic recovery of lethally irradiated recipients in a transplant setting.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Together, our data reveals the hematopoietic (BM) effects of systemic anti-Dll4 treatment result from qualitative vascular changes and also direct hematopoietic cell modulation, which may be favorable in a transplant setting.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Keratinocyte overexpression of IL-17C promotes psoriasiform skin inflammation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>IL-17C is a functionally distinct member of the IL-17 family that binds IL-17 receptor E/A to promote innate defense in epithelial cells and regulate Th17 cell differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We demonstrate that IL-17C (not IL-17A) is the most abundant IL-17 isoform in lesional psoriasis skin (1058 versus 8 pg/ml; p    < 0.006) and localizes to keratinocytes (KCs), endothelial cells (ECs), and leukocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ECs stimulated with IL-17C produce increased TNF-alpha and KCs stimulated with IL-17C/TNF-alpha produce similar inflammatory gene response patterns as those elicited by IL-17A/TNF-alpha, including increases in IL-17C, TNF-alpha, IL-8, IL-1alpha/beta, IL-1F5, IL-1F9, IL-6, IL-19, CCL20, S100A7/A8/A9, DEFB4, lipocalin 2, and peptidase inhibitor 3 (p    < 0.05), indicating a positive proinflammatory feedback loop between the epidermis and ECs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Psoriasis patients treated with etanercept rapidly decrease cutaneous IL-17C levels, suggesting IL-17C/TNF-alpha-mediated inflammatory signaling is critical for psoriasis pathogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mice genetically engineered to overexpress IL-17C in KCs develop well-demarcated areas of erythematous, flakey involved skin adjacent to areas of normal-appearing uninvolved skin despite increased IL-17C expression in both areas (p    < 0.05).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Uninvolved skin displays increased angiogenesis and elevated S100A8/A9 expression (p    < 0.05) but no epidermal hyperplasia, whereas involved skin exhibits robust epidermal hyperplasia, increased angiogenesis and leukocyte infiltration, and upregulated TNF-alpha, IL-1alpha/beta, IL-17A/F, IL-23p19, vascular endothelial growth factor, IL-6, and CCL20 (p    < 0.05), suggesting that IL-17C, when coupled with other proinflammatory signals, initiates the development of psoriasiform dermatitis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This skin phenotype was significantly improved following 8 wk of TNF-alpha inhibition.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These findings identify a role for IL-17C in skin inflammation and suggest a pathogenic function for the elevated IL-17C observed in lesional psoriasis skin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Chronic Akt activation attenuated lipopolysaccharide-induced cardiac dysfunction via Akt/GSK3beta-dependent inhibition of apoptosis and ER stress.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sepsis is characterized by systematic inflammation and contributes to cardiac dysfunction.</Gene>
<Gene>This study was designed to examine the effect of protein kinase B (Akt) activation on lipopolysaccharide-induced cardiac anomalies and underlying mechanism(s) involved.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mechanical and intracellular Ca2+ properties were examined in myocardium from wild-type and transgenic mice with cardiac-specific chronic Akt overexpression following LPS (4 mg/kg, i.p.) challenge.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Akt signaling cascade (Akt, phosphatase and tensin homologue deleted on chromosome ten, glycogen synthase kinase 3 beta), stress signal (extracellular-signal-regulated kinases, c-Jun N-terminal kinases, p38), apoptotic markers (Bcl-2 associated X protein, caspase-3/-9), endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress markers (glucose-regulated protein 78, growth arrest and DNA damage induced gene-153, eukaryotic initiation factor 2alpha), inflammatory markers (tumor necrosis factor alpha, interleukin-1beta, interleukin-6) and autophagic markers (Beclin-1, light chain 3B, autophagy-related gene 7 and sequestosome 1) were evaluated.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results revealed that LPS induced marked decrease in ejection fraction, fractional shortening, cardiomyocyte contractile capacity with dampened intracellular Ca2+ release and clearance, elevated reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation and decreased glutathione and glutathione disulfide (GSH/GSSG) ratio, increased ERK, JNK, p38, GRP78, Gadd153, eIF2alpha, BAX, caspase-3 and -9, downregulated B cell lymphoma 2 (Bcl-2), the effects of which were significantly attenuated or obliterated by Akt activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Akt activation itself did not affect cardiac contractile and intracellular Ca2+ properties, ROS production, oxidative stress, apoptosis and ER stress.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, LPS upregulated levels of Beclin-1, LC3B and Atg7, while suppressing p62 accumulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Akt activation did not affect Beclin-1, LC3B, Atg7 and p62 in the presence or absence of LPS.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Akt overexpression promoted phosphorylation of Akt and GSK3beta.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In vitro study using the GSK3beta inhibitor SB216763 mimicked the response elicited by chronic Akt activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, these data showed that Akt activation ameliorated LPS-induced cardiac contractile and intracellular Ca2+ anomalies through inhibition of apoptosis and ER stress, possibly involving an Akt/GSK3beta-dependent mechanism.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PI3K/mTOR inhibitor PF-04691502 antitumor activity is enhanced with induction of wild-type TP53 in human xenograft and murine knockout models of head and neck cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PURPOSE:</Gene>

<Gene>Phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K)/mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway activation is often associated with altered expression or mutations of PIK3CA, TP53/p73, PTEN, and TGF-beta receptors (TGFBR) in head and neck squamous cell carcinomas (HNSCC).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, little is known about how these alterations affect response to PI3K/mTOR-targeted agents.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN:</Gene>
<Gene>In this preclinical study, PI3K/Akt/mTOR signaling was characterized in nine HNSCC (UM-SCC) cell lines and human oral keratinocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We investigated the molecular and anticancer effects of dual PI3K/mTOR inhibitor PF-04691502(PF-502) in UM-SCC expressing PIK3CA with decreased wild-type TP53, mutant TP53-/+ mutantTGFBR2, and in HNSCC of a conditional Pten/Tgfbr1 double knockout mouse model displaying PI3K/Akt/mTOR activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>UM-SCC showed increased PIK3CA expression and Akt/mTOR activation, and PF-502 inhibited PI3K/mTORC1/2 targets.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In human HNSCC expressing PIK3CA and decreased wtTP53 and p73, PF-502 reciprocally enhanced TP53/p73 expression and growth inhibition, which was partially reversible by p53 inhibitor pifithrin-alpha.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Most UM-SCC with wtTP53 exhibited a lower IC50 than those with mtTP53 status.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PF-502 blocked growth in G0-G1 and increased apoptotic sub-G0 DNA.</Gene>
<Gene>PF-502 suppressed tumorigenesis and showed combinatorial activity with radiation in a wild-type TP53 UM-SCC xenograft model.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PF-502 also significantly delayed HNSCC tumorigenesis and prolonged survival of Pten/Tgfbr1-deficient mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Significant inhibition of p-Akt, p-4EBP1, p-S6, and Ki67, as well as increased p53 and TUNEL were observed in tumor specimens.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>PI3K-mTOR inhibition can enhance TP53/p73 expression and significantly inhibit tumor growth alone or when combined with radiation in HNSCC with wild-type TP53.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PIK3CA, TP53/p73, PTEN, and TGF-beta alterations are potential modifiers of response and merit investigation in future clinical trials with PI3K-mTOR inhibitors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Upregulation of T-cell factor-4 isoform-responsive target genes in hepatocellular carcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>

<Gene>The Wnt/beta-catenin signalling pathway regulates genes involved in cell proliferation, survival, migration and invasion through regulation by T-cell factor (TCF)-4 transcription factor proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the role of TCF-4 isoforms generated by alternative splicing events in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is unknown.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>AIM:</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we investigated TCF-4 isoforms (TCF-4J and K)-responsive target genes that are important in hepatic oncogenesis and tumour development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>Gene expression microarray was performed on HCC cells overexpressing TCF-4J and K isoforms.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Expression level of selected target genes was evaluated and correlations were made between their expression level and that of TCF-4 isoform in 47 pairs of human HCC tumours.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Comparison by gene expression microarray revealed that 447 genes were upregulated and 343 downregulated more than 2.0-fold in TCF-4J compared with TCF-4K expressing cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We validated expression of 18 selected target genes involved in Wnt/beta-catenin, insulin/IGF-1/IRS1 and Notch signalling pathways in 47 pairs of human HCCs and adjacent uninvolved liver tissues.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It was observed that 13 genes (CLDN2, STK17B, SPP1, AXIN2, WISP2, MMP7, IRS1, ANXA1, CAMK2N1, ASPH, GPR56, CD24 and JAG1) activated by TCF-4J isoform in HCC cells, were also upregulated in HCC tumours compared with adjacent peritumour tissue; more importantly, 10 genes exhibited a significant correlation with the TCF-4J expression level in tumour.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION: TCF-4 isoforms (TCF-4J and K) activated different downstream target genes in HCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The biological consequence of TCF-4J isoform expression was upregulation of genes associated with tripartite Wnt/beta-catenin, insulin/IGF-1/IRS1 and Notch signal transduction pathway activation, which contribute to the pathogenesis of HCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The eta7/csn3-3 auxin response mutant of Arabidopsis defines a novel function for the CSN3 subunit of the COP9 signalosome.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The COP9 signalosome (CSN) is an eight subunit protein complex conserved in all higher eukaryotes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In Arabidopsis thaliana, the CSN regulates auxin response by removing the ubiquitin-like protein NEDD8/RUB1 from the CUL1 subunit of the SCF(TIR1/AFB) ubiquitin-ligase (deneddylation).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Previously described null mutations in any CSN subunit result in the pleiotropic cop/det/fus phenotype and cause seedling lethality, hampering the study of CSN functions in plant development.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In a genetic screen to identify enhancers of the auxin response defects conferred by the tir1-1 mutation, we identified a viable csn mutant of subunit 3 (CSN3), designated eta7/csn3-3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition to enhancing tir1-1 mutant phenotypes, the csn3-3 mutation alone confers several phenotypes indicative of impaired auxin signaling including auxin resistant root growth and diminished auxin responsive gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Unexpectedly however, csn3-3 plants are not defective in either the CSN-mediated deneddylation of CUL1 or in SCF(TIR1)-mediated degradation of Aux/IAA proteins.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings suggest that csn3-3 is an atypical csn mutant that defines a novel CSN or CSN3-specific function.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consistent with this possibility, we observe dramatic differences in double mutant interactions between csn3-3 and other auxin signaling mutants compared to another weak csn mutant, csn1-10.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Lastly, unlike other csn mutants, assembly of the CSN holocomplex is unaffected in csn3-3 plants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, we detected a small CSN3-containing protein complex that is altered in csn3-3 plants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We hypothesize that in addition to its role in the CSN as a cullin deneddylase, CSN3 functions in a distinct protein complex that is required for proper auxin signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Downregulation of steroid receptor coactivator-2 modulates estrogen-responsive genes and stimulates proliferation of mcf-7 breast cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The p160/Steroid Receptor Coactivators SRC-1, SRC-2/GRIP1, and SRC-3/AIB1 are important regulators of Estrogen Receptor alpha (ERalpha) activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, whereas the functions of SRC-1 and SRC-3 in breast tumourigenesis have been extensively studied, little is known about the role of SRC-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Previously, we reported that activation of the cAMP-dependent protein kinase, PKA, facilitates ubiquitination and proteasomal degradation of SRC-2 which in turn leads to inhibition of SRC-2-coactivation of ERalpha and changed expression of the ERalpha target gene, pS2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we have characterized the global program of transcription in SRC-2-depleted MCF-7 breast cancer cells using short-hairpin RNA technology, and in MCF-7 cells exposed to PKA activating agents.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In order to identify genes that may be regulated through PKA-induced downregulation of SRC-2, overlapping transcriptional targets in response to the respective treatments were characterized.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, we observed decreased expression of several breast cancer tumour suppressor genes (e.g., TAGLN, EGR1, BCL11b, CAV1) in response to both SRC-2 knockdown and PKA activation, whereas the expression of a number of other genes implicated in cancer progression (e.g., RET, BCAS1, TFF3, CXCR4, ADM) was increased.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In line with this, knockdown of SRC-2 also stimulated proliferation of MCF-7 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Together, these results suggest that SRC-2 may have an antiproliferative function in breast cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Mammary carcinoma cell derived cyclooxygenase 2 suppresses tumor immune surveillance by enhancing intratumoral immune checkpoint activity.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>INTRODUCTION: Systemic inhibition of the inflammatory enzyme cyclooxygenase (COX) 2 decreases the risk of breast cancer and its recurrence.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, the biology of COX-2 in the multicellular tumor microenvironment is poorly defined.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>Mammary tumor onset and multiplicity were examined in ErbB2 transgenic mice that were deficient in mammary epithelial cell COX-2 (COX-2(MEC)KO) compared to wild type (WT) mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tumors were analyzed, by real time PCR, immune-staining and flow cytometry, for proliferation, apoptosis, angiogenesis and immune microenvironment.</Gene>

<Gene>Lentiviral shRNA delivery was used to knock down (KD) COX-2 in ErbB2-transformed mouse breast cancer cells (COX-2KD), and growth as orthotopic tumors was examined in syngenic recipient mice, with or without depletion of CD8+ immune cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Mammary tumor onset was delayed, and multiplicity halved, in COX-2(MEC)KO mice compared to WT.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>COX-2(MEC)KO tumors showed decreased expression of Ki67, a proliferation marker, as well as reduced VEGFA, its receptor VEGFR2, endothelial NOS and the vascular endothelial marker CD31, indicating reduced tumor vascularization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>COX-2(MEC)KO tumors contained more CD4+ T helper (Th) cells and CD8+ cytotoxic immune cells (CTL) consistent with increased immune surveillance.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The ratio of Th markers Tbet (Th1) to GATA3 (Th2) was higher, and levels of Retnla, a M2 macrophage marker, lower, in COX-2(MEC)KO tumor infiltrating leukocytes compared to WT, suggesting a prevalence of pro-immune Th1 over immune suppressive Th2 lymphocytes, and reduced macrophage polarization to the immune suppressive M2 phenotype.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Enhanced immune surveillance in COX-2(MEC)KO tumors was coincident with increased intratumoral CXCL9, a T cell chemoattractant, and decreased expression of T lymphocyte co-inhibitory receptors CTLA4 and PD-1, as well as PD-L1, the ligand for PD-1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PD-L1 was also decreased in IFNgamma-treated COX-2KD mouse mammary cancer cells in vitro and, compared to control cells, growth of COX-2KD cells as orthotopic tumors in immune competent mice was markedly suppressed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, robust growth of COX-2KD tumor cells was evident when recipients were depleted of CD8+ cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>The data strongly support that, in addition to its angiogenic function, tumor cell COX-2 suppresses intratumoral cytotoxic CD8+ immune cell function, possibly through upregulation of immune checkpoints, thereby contributing to tumor immune escape.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>COX-2 inhibition may be clinically useful to augment breast cancer immunotherapy.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Identification and characterization of FGF2-dependent mRNA: microRNA networks during lens fiber cell differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MicroRNAs (miRNAs) and fibroblast growth factor (FGF) signaling regulate a wide range of cellular functions, including cell specification, proliferation, migration, differentiation, and survival.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In lens, both these systems control lens fiber cell differentiation; however, a possible link between these processes remains to be examined.</Gene>
<Gene>Herein, the functional requirement for miRNAs in differentiating lens fiber cells was demonstrated via conditional inactivation of Dicer1 in mouse (Mus musculus) lens.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To dissect the miRNA-dependent pathways during lens differentiation, we used a rat (Rattus norvegicus) lens epithelial explant system, induced by FGF2 to differentiate, followed by mRNA and miRNA expression profiling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Transcriptome and miRNome analysis identified extensive FGF2-regulated cellular responses that were both independent and dependent on miRNAs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We identified 131 FGF2-regulated miRNAs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Seventy-six of these miRNAs had at least two in silico predicted and inversely regulated target mRNAs.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Genes modulated by the greatest number of FGF-regulated miRNAs include DNA-binding transcription factors</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nfib, Nfat5/OREBP, c-Maf, Ets1, and N-Myc.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Activated FGF signaling influenced bone morphogenetic factor/transforming growth factor-beta, Notch, and Wnt signaling cascades implicated earlier in lens differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Specific miRNA:mRNA interaction networks were predicted for c-Maf, N-Myc, and Nfib (DNA-binding transcription factors); Cnot6, Cpsf6, Dicer1, and Tnrc6b (RNA to miRNA processing); and Ash1l, Med1/PBP, and Kdm5b/Jarid1b/Plu1 (chromatin remodeling).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Three miRNAs, including miR-143, miR-155, and miR-301a, down-regulated expression of c-Maf in the 3'-UTR luciferase reporter assays.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These present studies demonstrate for the first time global impact of activated FGF signaling in lens cell culture system and predicted novel gene regulatory networks connected by multiple miRNAs that regulate lens differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>STAT3 regulates proliferation and survival of CD8+ T cells: enhances effector responses to HSV-1 infection, and inhibits IL-10+ regulatory CD8+ T cells in autoimmune uveitis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>STAT3 regulates CD4+ T cell survival and differentiation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, its effects on CD8+ T cells are not well understood.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we show that in comparison to WT CD8+ T cells, STAT3-deficient CD8+ T cells exhibit a preactivated memory-like phenotype, produce more IL-2, proliferate faster, and are more sensitive to activation-induced cell death (AICD).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The enhanced proliferation and sensitivity to AICD correlated with downregulation of class-O forkhead transcription factors (FoxO1, FoxO3A), p21(waf1), p27(KIP1), Bcl-2, OX-40, and upregulation of FasL, Bax, and Bad.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We examined whether STAT3-deficient CD8+ T cells can mount effective response during herpes simplex virus (HSV-1) infection and experimental autoimmune uveitis (EAU).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Compared to WT mice, HSV-1-infected STAT3-deficient mice (STAT3KO) produced less IFN-gamma and virus-specific KLRG-1+</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD8+ T cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>STAT3KO mice are also resistant to EAU and produced less IL-17-producing Tc17 cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Resistance of STAT3KO to EAU correlated with marked expansion of IL-10-producing regulatory CD8+ T cells (CD8-Treg) implicated in recovery from autoimmune encephalomyelitis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Thus, increases of IL-6-induced STAT3 activation observed during inflammation may inhibit expansion of CD8-Tregs, thereby impeding recovery from uveitis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results suggest that STAT3 is a potential therapeutic target for upregulating CD8+ T cell-mediated responses to viruses and suggest the successful therapeutic targeting of STAT3 as treatment for uveitis, derived, in part, from promoting CD8-Treg expansion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Human hepatic progenitor cells express hematopoietic cell markers CD45 and CD109.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>OBJECTIVE: To clarify the precise characteristics of human hepatic progenitor cells (HPCs) for future cytotherapy in liver diseases.</Gene>

<Gene>METHODS: Hepatic progenitor-like cells were isolated and cultured from the livers of patients who had undergone partial hepatectomy for various pathologies but displayed no sign of hepatic dysfunction.</Gene>
<Gene>These cells were characterized by transcriptomic profiling, quantitative real-time PCR and immunocyto/histochemistry.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS: Cultured HPCs contained polygonal, high nucleus/cytoplasm ratio and exhibited a global gene expression profile similar (67.8%) to that of primary hepatocytes.</Gene>

<Gene>Among the genes with more than 20-fold higher expression in HPCs were a progenitor marker (CD90), a pentraxin-related gene (PTX3), collagen proteins (COL5A2, COL1A1 and COL4A2), cytokines (EGF and PDGFD), metabolic enzymes (CYBRD1, BCAT1, TIMP2 and PAM), a secreted protein (SPARC) and an endothelial protein C receptor (PROCR).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, eight markers (ALB, AFP, CK8, CK18, CK19, CD90, CD117 and Oval-6) previously described as HPC markers were validated by qRT-PCR and/or immunocyto/histochemistry.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, human HPCs were also positive for the hematopoietic cell markers CD45 and CD109.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, we characterized the localization of HPCs in the canals of Hering and periportal areas with six previously described markers (Oval-6, CK8, CK18, CK19, CD90 and CD117) and two potential markers (CD45 and CD109).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>The human HPCs are highly similar to primary hepatocytes in their transcriptional profiles.</Gene>
<Gene>The CD45 and CD109 markers could potentially be utilized to identify and isolate HPCs for further cytotherapy of liver diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Copy number analysis of 24 oncogenes: MDM4 identified as a putative marker for low recurrence risk in non muscle invasive bladder cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Patients with non-muscle invasive bladder cancer (NMIBC) generally have a high risk of relapsing locally after primary tumor resection.</Gene>
<Gene>The search for new predictive markers of local recurrence thus represents an important goal for the management of this disease.</Gene>

<Gene>We studied the copy number variations (CNVs) of 24 oncogenes (MDM4, MYCN, ALK, PDGFRA, KIT, KDR, DHFR, EGFR, MET, SMO, FGFR1, MYC, ABL1, RET, CCND1, CCND2, CDK4, MDM2, AURKB, ERBB2, TOP2A, AURKA, AR and BRAF) using multiplex ligation probe amplification technique to verify their role as predictive markers of recurrence.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissue samples from 43 patients who underwent transurethral resection of the bladder (TURB) were used; 23 patients had relapsed and 20 were disease-free after 5 years.</Gene>

<Gene>Amplification frequencies were analyzed for all genes and MDM4 was the only gene that showed significantly higher amplification in non recurrent patients than in recurrent ones (0.65 vs. 0.3; Fisher's test p=0.023).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Recurrence-free survival analysis confirmed the predictive role of MDM4 (log-rank test p=0.041).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Our preliminary results indicate a putative role for the MDM4 gene in predicting local recurrence of bladder cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Confirmation of this hypothesis is needed in a larger cohort of NMIBC patients.</Gene>
<Gene>Cadmium-induced ethylene production and responses in Arabidopsis thaliana rely on ACS2 and ACS6 gene expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Anthropogenic activities cause metal pollution worldwide.</Gene>
<Gene>Plants can absorb and accumulate these metals through their root system, inducing stress as a result of excess metal concentrations inside the plant.</Gene>
<Gene>Ethylene is a regulator of multiple plant processes, and is affected by many biotic and abiotic stresses.</Gene>
<Gene>Increased ethylene levels have been observed after exposure to excess metals but it remains unclear how the increased ethylene levels are achieved at the molecular level.</Gene>

<Gene>In this study, the effects of cadmium (Cd) exposure on the production of ethylene and its precursor 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylic acid (ACC), and on the expression of the ACC Synthase (ACS) and ACC Oxidase (ACO) multigene families were investigated in Arabidopsis thaliana.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>Increased ethylene release after Cd exposure was directly measurable in a system using rockwool-cultivated plants; enhanced levels of the ethylene precursor ACC together with higher mRNA levels of ethylene responsive genes: ACO2, ETR2 and ERF1 also indicated increased ethylene production in hydroponic culture.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Regarding underlying mechanisms, it was found that the transcript levels of ACO2 and ACO4, the most abundantly expressed members of the ACO multigene family, were increased upon Cd exposure.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>ACC synthesis is the rate-limiting step in ethylene biosynthesis, and transcript levels of both ACS2 and ACS6 showed the highest increase and became the most abundant isoforms after Cd exposure, suggesting their importance in the Cd-induced increase of ethylene production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>Cadmium induced the biosynthesis of ACC and ethylene in Arabidopsis thaliana plants mainly via the increased expression of ACS2 and ACS6.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This was confirmed in the acs2-1acs6-1 double knockout mutants, which showed a decreased ethylene production, positively affecting leaf biomass and resulting in a delayed induction of ethylene responsive gene expressions without significant differences in Cd contents between wild-type and mutant plants.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sepsis-induced changes in amino acid transporters and leucine signaling via mTOR in skeletal muscle.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The present study tested the hypothesis that sepsis-induced leucine (Leu) resistance in skeletal muscle is associated with a down-regulation of amino acid transporters important in regulating Leu flux or an impairment in the formation of the Leu-sensitive mTOR-Ragulator complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sepsis in adult male rats decreased basal protein synthesis in gastrocnemius, associated with a reduction in mTOR activation as indicated by decreased 4E-BP1 and S6K1 phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The ability of oral Leu to increase protein synthesis and mTOR kinase after 1 h was largely prevented in sepsis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sepsis increased CAT1, LAT2 and SNAT2 mRNA content two- to fourfold, but only the protein content for CAT1 (20 % decrease) differed significantly.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conversely, sepsis decreased the proton-assisted amino acid transporter (PAT)-2 mRNA by 60 %, but without a coordinate change in PAT2 protein.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>There was no sepsis or Leu effect on the protein content for RagA-D, LAMTOR-1 and -2, raptor, Rheb or mTOR in muscle.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The binding of mTOR, PRAS40 and RagC to raptor did not differ for control and septic muscle in the basal condition; however, the Leu-induced decrease in PRAS40 raptor and increase in RagC raptor seen in control muscle was absent in sepsis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The intracellular Leu concentration was increased in septic muscle, compared to basal control conditions, and oral Leu further increased the intracellular Leu concentration similarly in both control and septic rats.</Gene>

<Gene>Hence, while alterations in select amino acid transporters are not associated with development of sepsis-induced Leu resistance, the Leu-stimulated binding of raptor with RagC and the recruitment of mTOR/raptor to the endosome-lysosomal compartment may partially explain the inability of Leu to fully activate mTOR and muscle protein synthesis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD25(+) Bcl6(low) T follicular helper cells provide help to maturing B cells in germinal centers of human tonsil.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The majority of CXCR5(+) PD1(+) CD4(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>T follicular helper (Tfh) cells (   >90%) are CD25(-) Bcl6(hi) , while a small subpopulation (   <10%) are CD25(+) Bcl6(low) but do not express FoxP3 and are not T regulatory cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We purified T:B-cell conjugates from tonsils and found they were enriched for the CD25(+) Bcl6(low)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tfh-cell subpopulation.</Gene>
<Gene>In response to IL-2, these CD25(+)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tfh cells increased expression of costimulatory molecules ICOS or OX40, upregulated transcription factor cMaf, produced cytokines IL-21, IL-17, and IL-10, and raised the levels of antiapoptotic protein Bcl2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Conjugates formed with CD25(+) BCl6(low)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Tfh cells included B cells expressing higher levels of activation-induced cytidine deaminase (AID), memory marker CD45RO, surface IgG or IgA, and MHC class II compared to B-cell conjugates including CD25(-) Bcl6(hi) Tfh cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While IL-2 suppresses early Tfh-cell differentiation, Tfh-cell recognition of antigen-presenting B cells and signaling through the T-cell receptor likely triggers expression of the high-affinity IL-2 receptor and responses to IL-2 including downregulation of Bcl6.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CD25 expression on Tfh cells and local production of IL-2 in tonsil or lymph node may support B helper T-cell function during later stages of B-cell maturation and the development of immune memory.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>VPAC2 (vasoactive intestinal peptide receptor type 2) receptor deficient mice develop exacerbated experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis with increased Th1/Th17 and reduced Th2/Treg responses.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) and pituitary adenylyl cyclase-activating polypeptide (PACAP) are two structurally-related neuropeptides with widespread expression in the central and peripheral nervous systems.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Although these peptides have been repeatedly shown to exert potent anti-inflammatory actions when administered in animal models of inflammatory disease, mice deficient in VIP and PACAP were recently shown to exhibit different phenotypes (ameliorated and exacerbated, respectively) in response to experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, elucidating what are the specific immunoregulatory roles played by each of their receptor subtypes (VPAC1, VPAC2, and PAC1) is critical.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, we found that mice with a genetic deletion of VIPR2, encoding the VPAC2 receptor, exhibited exacerbated (MOG35-55)-induced EAE compared to wild type mice, characterized by enhanced clinical and histopathological features, increased proinflammatory cytokines (TNF-alpha, IL-6, IFN-gamma (Th1), and IL-17 (Th17)) and reduced anti-inflammatory cytokines (IL-10, TGFbeta, and IL-4 (Th2)) in the CNS and lymph nodes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, the abundance and proliferative index of lymph node, thymus and CNS CD4(+)CD25(+)FoxP3(+) Tregs were strikingly reduced in VPAC2-deficient mice with EAE.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, the in vitro suppressive activity of lymph node and splenic Tregs from VPAC2-deficient mice was impaired.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Overall, our results demonstrate critical protective roles for PACAP and the VPAC2 receptor against autoimmunity, promoting the expansion and maintenance of the Treg pool.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interruption of macrophage-derived IL-27(p28) production by IL-10 during sepsis requires STAT3 but not SOCS3.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Severe sepsis and septic shock are leading causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide.</Gene>
<Gene>Infection-associated inflammation promotes the development and progression of adverse outcomes in sepsis.</Gene>

<Gene>The effects of heterodimeric IL-27 (p28/EBI3) have been implicated in the natural course of sepsis, whereas the molecular mechanisms underlying the regulation of gene expression and release of IL-27 in sepsis are poorly understood.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We studied the events regulating the p28 subunit of IL-27 in endotoxic shock and polymicrobial sepsis following cecal ligation and puncture.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Neutralizing Abs to IL-27(p28) improved survival rates, restricted cytokine release, and reduced bacterial burden in C57BL/6 mice during sepsis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genetic disruption of IL-27 signaling enhanced the respiratory burst of macrophages.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Experiments using splenectomized mice or treatment with clodronate liposomes suggested that macrophages in the spleen may be a significant source of IL-27(p28) during sepsis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In cultures of TLR4-activated macrophages, the frequency of F4/80(+)CD11b(+)IL-27(p28)(+) cells was reduced by the addition of IL-10.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IL-10 antagonized both MyD88-dependent and TRIF-dependent release of IL-27(p28).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Genetic deletion of STAT3 in Tie2-Cre/STAT3flox macrophages completely interrupted the inhibition of IL-27(p28) by IL-10 after TLR4 activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast, IL-10 remained fully active to suppress IL-27(p28) with deletion of SOCS3 in Tie2-Cre/SOCS3flox macrophages.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Blockade of IL-10R by Ab or genetic deficiency of IL-10 resulted in 3-5-fold higher concentrations of IL-27(p28) in endotoxic shock and polymicrobial sepsis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our studies identify IL-10 as a critical suppressing factor for IL-27(p28) production during infection-associated inflammation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings may be helpful for a beneficial manipulation of adverse IL-27(p28) release during sepsis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MIG-7 and phosphorylated prohibitin coordinately regulate lung cancer invasion/metastasis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Growth factors and COX-2/PGE2 enhance lung cancer invasion/metastasis via PI3K/Akt and RAS/Raf.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, we explored their mechanism of action further.</Gene>

<Gene>We found first that higher levels of migration inducting gene-7 protein (MIG-7) and PHB phosphorylated at threonine 258 (phospho-PHBT258) are positively correlated with advanced stages of human lung cancer in tissue microarray.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>PGE2 or growth factors such as EGF, HGF and IGF-1 increased complex formation of phospho-PHBT258 with Ras, phospho-AktS473, phospho-Raf-1S338, MEKK1 and IKKalpha/betaS176/180 in the raft domain transiently within 1 hour and MIG-7 in the cytosol 12-24 hours later.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Association of phospho-PHBT258 with MEKK1 but not MEKK3 activates IKK/IkappaB/NF-kappaB and MEK/ERK to increase cellular COX-2/PGE2 and an E-cadherin suppressor Snail leading to enhancement of epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and lung cancer migration/invasion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MIG-7, on the other hand, was induced by growth factors and PGE2 via Akt/GSK-3beta in a phospho-PHBT258 independent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MIG-7 increased two E-cadherin suppressors ZEB-1 and Twist to enhance EMT and cancer migration/invasion.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Downregulating phospho-PHBT258 and MIG-7 had an additive effect on attenuating lung cancer invasion/metastasis and prolonging the survival of xenograft mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Phospho-PHBT258 and MIG-7 may thus play complementary roles in the initiation and sustainment of the effects of growth factors and COX-2/PGE2 on cancer invasion/metastasis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Pharmacogenetic Analysis of INT 0144 Trial: Association of Polymorphisms with Survival and Toxicity in Rectal Cancer Patients Treated with 5-FU and Radiation.</Gene>
<Gene>PURPOSE:</Gene>

<Gene>We tested whether 18 polymorphisms in 16 genes (GSTP1, COX2, IL10, EGFR, EGF, FGFR4, CCDN1, VEGFR2, VEGF, CXCR2, IL8, MMP3, ICAM1, ERCC1, RAD51, and XRCC3) would predict disease-free survival (DFS), overall survival (OS), and toxicity in the INT0144 trial, which was designed to investigate different postoperative regimens of 5-fluorouracil (5-FU)-based chemoradiation (CRT) in locally advanced rectal cancers: Arm 1 consisted of bolus 5-FU followed by 5-FU protracted venous infusion (PVI) with radiotherapy; arm 2 was induction and concomitant PVI 5-FU with radiotherapy and arm 3 was induction and concomitant bolus 5-FU with radiotherapy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN:</Gene>
<Gene>DNA from 746 stage II/III rectal patients enrolled in the Southwest Oncology Group (SWOG) S9304 phase III trial was analyzed.</Gene>
<Gene>Genomic DNA was extracted from formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded (FFPE) tumor tissue.</Gene>
<Gene>The polymorphisms were analyzed using direct DNA-sequencing or polymerase chain reaction-restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP).</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>GSTP1-Ile105Val (rs1695) was significantly associated with DFS and OS and its effect did not vary by treatment arm.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The five-year DFS and OS were 53% and 58%, respectively, for G/G, 66% and 72% for G/A, and 57% and 66% for A/A patients.</Gene>
<Gene>In arm 2, IL8-251A/A genotype (rs4073) was associated with a lower risk of toxicities (P = 0.04).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The VEGFR2 H472Q Q/Q genotype (rs1870377) was associated with a higher risk of grade 3-5 proximal upper gastrointestinal tract (PUGIT) mucositis (P = 0.04) in arm 2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, in arm 1, this genotype was associated with a lower risk of PUGIT mucositis (P = 0.004).</Gene>
<Gene>CONCLUSION:</Gene>
<Gene>rs1695 may be prognostic in patients with rectal cancer treated with adjuvant CRT.</Gene>
<Gene>rs4073 and rs1870377 may exhibit different associations with toxicity, according to the 5-FU schedule.</Gene>

<Gene>Expression of the potential therapeutic target CXXC5 in primary acute myeloid leukemia cells - high expression is associated with adverse prognosis as well as altered intracellular signaling and transcriptional regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The CXXC5 gene encodes a transcriptional activator with a zinc-finger domain, and high expression in human acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells is associated with adverse prognosis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We now characterized the biological context of CXXC5 expression in primary human AML cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The global gene expression profile of AML cells derived from 48 consecutive patients was analyzed; cells with high and low CXXC5 expression then showed major differences with regard to extracellular communication and intracellular signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We observed significant differences in the phosphorylation status of several intracellular signaling mediators (CREB, PDK1, SRC, STAT1, p38, STAT3, rpS6) that are important for PI3K-Akt-mTOR signaling and/or transcriptional regulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>High CXXC5 expression was also associated with high mRNA expression of several stem cell-associated transcriptional regulators, the strongest associations being with WT1, GATA2, RUNX1, LYL1, DNMT3, SPI1, and MYB.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, CXXC5 knockdown in human AML cell lines caused significantly increased expression of the potential tumor suppressor gene TSC22 and genes encoding the growth factor receptor KIT, the cytokine Angiopoietin 1 and the selenium-containing glycoprotein</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Selenoprotein P. Thus, high CXXC5 expression seems to affect several steps in human leukemogenesis, including intracellular events as well as extracellular communication.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inactivation of Sag/Rbx2/Roc2 e3 ubiquitin ligase triggers senescence and inhibits kras-induced immortalization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our recent study showed that SAG/RBX2 E3 ubiquitin ligase regulates apoptosis and vasculogenesis by promoting degradation of NOXA and NF1, and co-operates with Kras to promote lung tumorigenesis by activating NFkappaB and mTOR pathways via targeted degradation of tumor suppressive substrates including IkappaB, DEPTOR, p21 and p27.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we investigated the role of Sag/Rbx2 E3 ligase in cellular senescence and immortalization of mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs) and report that Sag is required for proper cell proliferation and Kras(G12D)-induced immortalization.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Sag inactivation by genetic deletion remarkably suppresses cell proliferation by inducing senescence, which is associated with accumulation of p16, but not p53.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Mechanistically, Sag deletion caused accumulation of Jun-B, a substrate of Sag-Fbxw7 E3 ligase and a transcription factor that drives p16 transcription.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, senescence triggered by Sag deletion can be largely rescued by simultaneous deletion of Cdkn2a, the p16 encoding gene, indicating its causal role.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, Kras(G12D)-induced immortalization can also be abrogated by Sag deletion via senescence induction, which is again rescued by simultaneous deletion of Cdkn2a.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, we found that Sag deletion inactivates Kras(G12D) activity and block the MAPK signaling pathway, together with accumulated p16, to induce senescence.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, our results demonstrated that Sag is a Kras(G12D)-cooperating oncogene required for Kras(G12D)-induced immortalization and transformation, and targeting SAG-SCF E3 ligase may, therefore, have therapeutic value for senescence-based cancer treatment.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nitrogen regulates AMPK to control TORC1 signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Cell growth and cell-cycle progression are tightly coordinated to enable cells to adjust their size (timing of division) to the demands of proliferation in varying nutritional environments.</Gene>
<Gene>In fission yeast, nitrogen stress results in sustained proliferation at a reduced size.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Here, we show that cells can sense nitrogen stress to reduce target of rapamycin complex-1 (TORC1) activity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nitrogen-stress-induced TORC1 inhibition differs from amino-acid-dependent control of TORC1 and requires the Ssp2 (AMPKalpha) kinase, the Tsc1/2 complex, and Rhb1 GTPase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, the beta and gamma regulatory subunits of AMPK are not required to control cell division in response to nitrogen stress, providing evidence for a nitrogen-sensing mechanism that is independent of changes in intracellular ATP/AMP levels.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The CaMKK homolog Ssp1 is constitutively required for phosphorylation of the AMPKalpha(Ssp2) T loop.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, we find that a second homolog CaMKK(Ppk34) is specifically required to stimulate AMPKalpha(Ssp2) activation in response to nitrogen stress.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, ammonia also controls mTORC1 activity in human cells; mTORC1 is activated upon the addition of ammonium to glutamine-starved Hep3B cancer cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>The alternative nitrogen source ammonia can simulate TORC1 activity to support growth and division under challenging nutrient settings, a situation often seen in cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Sex-differences in renal expression of selected transporters and transcription factors in lean and obese Zucker spontaneously hypertensive fatty rats.</Gene>

<Gene>The aim of this study was to identify sex-dependent expression of renal transporter mRNA in lean and obese Zucker spontaneously hypertensive fatty (ZSF1) rats and to investigate the interaction of the most altered transporter, organic anion transporter 2 (Oat2), with diabetes-relevant metabolites and drugs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Higher incidence of glomerulosclerosis, tubulointerstitial fibrosis, and protein casts in Bowman's space and tubular lumen was detected by PAS staining in obese male compared to female ZSF1 rats.</Gene>
<Gene>Real-time PCR on RNA isolated from kidney cortex revealed that Sglt1-2, Oat1-3, and Oct1 were higher expressed in kidneys of lean females.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Oct2 and Mrp2 were higher expressed in obese males.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Renal mRNA levels of transporters were reduced with diabetic nephropathy in females and the expression of transcription factors Hnf1beta and Hnf4alpha in both sexes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The highest difference between lean and obese ZSF1 rats was found for Oat2.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, we have tested the interaction of human OAT2 with various substances using tritium-labeled cGMP.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human OAT2 showed no interaction with diabetes-related metabolites, diabetic drugs, and ACE-inhibitors.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, OAT2-dependent uptake of cGMP was inhibited by furosemide.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The strongly decreased expression of Oat2 and other transporters in female diabetic ZSF1 rats could possibly impair renal drug excretion, for example, of furosemide.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>mTORC2 Deficiency in Myeloid Dendritic Cells Enhances Their Allogeneic Th1 and Th17 Stimulatory Ability after TLR4 Ligation In Vitro and In Vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The mammalian/mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) is a key integrative kinase that functions in two independent complexes, mTOR complex (mTORC) 1 and mTORC2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In contrast to the well-defined role of mTORC1 in dendritic cells (DC), little is known about the function of mTORC2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study, to our knowledge, we demonstrate for the first time an enhanced ability of mTORC2-deficient myeloid DC to stimulate and polarize allogeneic T cells.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We show that activated bone marrow-derived DC from conditional Rictor(-/-) mice exhibit lower coinhibitory B7-H1 molecule expression independently of the stimulus and enhanced IL-6, TNF-alpha, IL-12p70, and IL-23 production following TLR4 ligation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Accordingly, TLR4-activated Rictor(-/-)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DC display augmented allogeneic T cell stimulatory ability, expanding IFN-gamma(+) and IL-17(+), but not IL-10(+) or CD4(+)Foxp3(+) regulatory T cells in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A similar DC profile was obtained by stimulating Dectin-1 (C-type lectin family member) on Rictor(-/-) DC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Using novel CD11c-specific Rictor(-/-) mice, we confirm the alloreactive Th1 and Th17 cell-polarizing ability of endogenous mTORC2-deficient DC after TLR4 ligation in vivo.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, we demonstrate that proinflammatory cytokines produced by Rictor(-/-)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>DC after LPS stimulation are key in promoting Th1/Th17 responses.</Gene>
<Gene>These data establish that mTORC2 activity restrains conventional DC proinflammatory capacity and their ability to polarize T cells following TLR and non-TLR stimulation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our findings provide new insight into the role of mTORC2 in regulating DC function and may have implications for emerging therapeutic strategies that target mTOR in cancer, infectious diseases, and transplantation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Neuroprotective effect of neuroserpin in oxygen-glucose deprivation- and reoxygenation-treated rat astrocytes in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Neuroserpin (NSP) reportedly exerts neuroprotective effects in cerebral ischemic animal models and patients; however, the mechanism of protection is poorly understood.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We thus attempted to confirm neuroprotective effects of NSP on astrocytes in the ischemic state and then explored the relative mechanisms.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Astrocytes from neonatal rats were treated with oxygen-glucose deprivation (OGD) followed by reoxygenation (OGD/R).</Gene>

<Gene>To confirm the neuroprotective effects of NSP, we measured the cell survival rate, relative lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) release; we also performed morphological methods, namely Hoechst 33342 staining and Annexin V assay.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To explore the potential mechanisms of NSP, the release of nitric oxide (NO) and TNF-alpha related to NSP administration were measured by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The proteins related to the NF-kappaB, ERK1/2, and PI3K/Akt pathways were investigated by Western blotting.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To verify the cause-and-effect relationship between neuroprotection and the NF-kappaB pathway, a NF-kappaB pathway inhibitor sc3060 was employed to observe the effects of NSP-induced neuroprotection.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found that NSP significantly increased the cell survival rate and reduced LDH release in OGD/R-treated astrocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It also reduced NO/TNF-alpha release.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Western blotting showed that the protein levels of p-IKKBalpha/beta and P65 were upregulated by the OGD/R treatment and such effects were significantly inhibited by NSP administration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The NSP-induced inhibition could be significantly reversed by administration of the NF-kappaB pathway inhibitor sc3060, whereas, expressions of p-ERK1, p-ERK2, and p-AKT were upregulated by the OGD/R treatment; however, their levels were unchanged by NSP administration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results thus verified the neuroprotective effects of NSP in ischemic astrocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The potential mechanisms include inhibition of the release of NO/TNF-alpha and repression of the NF-kappaB signaling pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our data also indicated that NSP has little influence on the MAPK and PI3K/Akt pathways.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Gastrointestinal hormones/neurotransmitters and growth factors can activate P21 activated kinase 2 in pancreatic acinar cells by novel mechanisms.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>P-21-activated kinases (PAKs) are serine/threonine kinases comprising six isoforms divided in two groups, group-I (PAK1-3)/group-II (PAK4-6) which play important roles in cell cytoskeletal dynamics, survival, secretion and proliferation and are activated by diverse stimuli.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, little is known about PAKs ability to be activated by gastrointestinal (GI) hormones/neurotransmitters/growth-factors.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We used rat pancreatic acini to explore the ability of GI-hormones/neurotransmitters/growth-factors to activate Group-I-PAKs and the signaling cascades involved.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Only PAK2 was present in acini.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>PAK2 was activated by some pancreatic growth-factors [EGF, PDGF, bFGF], by secretagogues activating phospholipase-C (PLC)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>[CCK, carbachol, bombesin] and by post-receptor stimulants activating PKC</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>[TPA], but not agents only mobilizing cellular calcium or increasing cyclic AMP.</Gene>
<Gene>CCK-activation of PAK2 required both high- and low-affinity-CCK1-receptor-state activation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>It was partially reduced by PKC- or Src-inhibition, but not with PI3K-inhibitors (wortmannin, LY294002) or thapsigargin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IPA-3, which prevents PAK2 binding to small-GTPases partially inhibited PAK2-activation, as well as reduced CCK-induced ERK1/2 activation and amylase release induced by CCK or bombesin.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This study demonstrates pancreatic acini, possess only one Group-I-PAK, PAK2. CCK and other GI-hormones/neurotransmitters/growth-factors activate PAK2 via small GTPases (CDC42/Rac1), PKC and SFK but not cytosolic calcium or PI3K. CCK-activation of PAK2 showed several novel features being dependent on both receptor-activation states, having PLC- and PKC-dependent/independent components and small-GTPase-dependent/independent components.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These results show that PAK2 is important in signaling cascades activated by numerous pancreatic stimuli which mediate their various physiological/pathophysiological responses and thus could be a promising target for the development of therapies in some pancreatic disorders such as pancreatitis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The Arabidopsis thaliana elongator complex subunit 2 epigenetically affects root development.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The elongator complex subunit 2 (ELP2) protein, one subunit of an evolutionarily conserved histone acetyltransferase complex, has been shown to participate in leaf patterning, plant immune and abiotic stress responses in Arabidopsis thaliana.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here, its role in root development was explored.</Gene>
<Gene>Compared to the wild type, the elp2 mutant exhibited an accelerated differentiation of its root stem cells and cell division was more active in its quiescent centre (QC).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The key transcription factors responsible for maintaining root stem cell and QC identity, such as AP2 transcription factors PLT1 (PLETHORA1) and PLT2 (PLETHORA2), GRAS transcription factors such as SCR (SCARECROW) and SHR (SHORT ROOT) and WUSCHEL-RELATED HOMEOBOX5 transcription factor WOX5, were all strongly down-regulated in the mutant.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>On the other hand, expression of the G2/M transition activator CYCB1 was substantially induced in elp2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The auxin efflux transporters PIN1 and PIN2 showed decreased protein levels and PIN1 also displayed mild polarity alterations in elp2, which resulted in a reduced auxin content in the root tip.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Either the acetylation or methylation level of each of these genes differed between the mutant and the wild type, suggesting that the ELP2 regulation of root development involves the epigenetic modification of a range of transcription factors and other developmental regulators.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Transmembrane-Bound IL-15-Promoted Epithelial-Mesenchymal Transition in Renal Cancer Cells Requires the Src-Dependent Akt/GSK-3beta/beta-Catenin Pathway.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Intrarenal interleukin-15 (IL-15) plays a major role controlling epithelial survival and polarization both in physiological and pathologic conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Herein, we confirmed that human renal cell carcinomas (RCCs) express a membrane-bound IL-15 isoform displaying an unusual molecular weight of 27 kDa.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Its stimulation with soluble IL-15 receptor alpha chain (s-IL-15Ralpha) triggers epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) process as shown by the down-regulation of E-cadherin and zona occludens 1 and the up-regulation of vimentin and N-cadherin and promotes the migratory and invasive properties of RCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>S-IL-15Ralpha treatment triggered the Src/PI3K/Akt/GSK-3beta pathway and promoted beta-catenin nuclei translocation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Deactivation of this pathway by using Src-specific inhibitor PP2, PI3K inhibitor LY294002, and AKT inhibitor MK2206 hampered beta-catenin nuclei translocation and suppressed EMT, migration, and invasion of RCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>S-IL-15Ralpha treatment also enhanced Src-dependent phosphorylation of focal adhesion kinase (FAK) and extracellular signal-regulated kinase (Erk1/2).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>FAK knockdown significantly decreased the migration and invasion of RCC, which suggest that Src-FAK signaling was involved in s-IL-15Ralpha-favored migration and invasion of RCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>At the same time, inhibitors of Erk1/2 also significantly decreased the migration and invasion of RCC but could not reverse s-IL-15Ralpha-induced EMT.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, our results reveal that Src-dependent PI3K/Akt/GSK3b/beta-catenin pathway is required for s-IL-15Ra-dependent induction of EMT in RCC, while Src-FAK and Src-Erk1/2 signaling were involved in s-IL-15Ralpha-promoted migration and invasion properties of RCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our study provides a better understanding of IL-15 signaling in RCC tumor progression, which may lead to novel targeted therapies and provide some suggestions when using IL-15 in clinic.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The autotaxin-LPA2 GPCR axis is modulated by gamma-irradiation and facilitates DNA damage repair.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In this study we characterized the effects of radiation injury on the expression and function of the autotaxin (ATX)-LPA2 GPCR axis.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In IEC-6 crypt cells and jejunum enteroids quantitative RT-PCR showed a time- and dose-dependent upregulation of lpa2 in response to gamma-irradiation that was abolished by mutation of the NF-kappaB site in the lpa2 promoter or by inhibition of ATM/ATR kinases with CGK-733, suggesting that lpa2 is a DNA damage response gene upregulated by ATM via NF-kappaB.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The resolution kinetics of the DNA damage marker gamma-H2AX in LPA-treated IEC-6 cells exposed to gamma-irradiation was accelerated compared to vehicle, whereas pharmacological inhibition of LPA2 delayed the resolution of gamma-H2AX.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In LPA2-reconstituted MEF cells lacking LPA1    '3 the levels of gamma-H2AX decreased rapidly, whereas in Vector MEF were high and remained sustained.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Inhibition of ERK1    '2 or PI3K/AKT signaling axis by pertussis toxin or the C311A/C314A/L351A mutation in the C-terminus of LPA2 abrogated the effect of LPA on DNA repair.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>LPA2 transcripts in Lin(-)Sca-1(+)c-Kit(+) enriched for bone marrow stem cells were 27- and 5-fold higher than in common myeloid or lymphoid progenitors, respectively.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, after irradiation higher residual gamma-H2AX levels were detected in the bone marrow or jejunum of irradiated LPA2-KO mice compared to WT mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We found that gamma-irradiation increases plasma ATX activity and LPA level that is in part due to the previously established radiation-induced upregulation of TNFalpha.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings identify ATX and LPA2 as radiation-regulated genes that appear to play a physiological role in DNA repair.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MAPK signaling downstream to TLR4 contributes to paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) has been implicated as a locus for initiation of paclitaxel related chemotherapy induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This project explores the involvement of the immediate down-stream signal molecules in inducing paclitaxel CIPN.</Gene>

<Gene>Mitogen-activated protein kinases (MAPKs) and nuclear factor-kappaB (NFkappaB) were measured in dorsal root ganglia (DRG) and the spinal cord over time using Western blot and immunohistochemistry in a rat model of paclitaxel CIPN.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The effects of MAPK inhibitors in preventing and reversing behavioral signs of CIPN were also measured (group sizes 4-9).</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Extracellular signal related kinase (ERK1/2) and P38 but not c-Jun N terminal kinase (JNK) or PI3K-Akt signaling expression was increased in DRG.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Phospho-ERK1/2 staining was co-localized to small CGRP-positive DRG neurons in cell profiles surrounding large DRG neurons consistent with satellite glial cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The expression of phospho-P38 was co-localized to small IB4-positive and CGRP-positive DRG neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The TLR4 antagonist LPS derived from Rhodobacter sphaeroides (LPS-RS) inhibited paclitaxel-induced phosphorylation of ERK1/2 and P38.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The MAPK inhibitors PD98059 (MEK1/2), U0126 (MEK1/2) and SB203580 (P38) prevented but did not reverse paclitaxel-induced behavioral hypersensitivity.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Paclitaxel treatment resulted in phosphorylation of Inhibitor alpha of NFkappaB (IkappaBalpha) in DRG resulting in an apparent release of NFkappaB from the IkappaBalpha-NFkappaB complex as increased expression of nuclear NFkappaB was also observed.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>LPS-RS inhibited paclitaxel-induced translocation of NFkappaB in DRG.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>No change was observed in spinal NFkappaB.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>These results implicate TLR4 signaling via MAP kinases and NFkappaB in the induction and maintenance of paclitaxel-related CIPN.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Nitric oxide stress and activation of AMP-activated protein kinase impair beta-cell sarcoendoplasmic reticulum calcium ATPase 2b activity and protein stability.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The sarcoendoplasmic reticulum Ca(2+)</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>ATPase 2b (SERCA2b) pump maintains a steep Ca(2+) concentration gradient between the cytosol and ER lumen in the pancreatic beta-cell, and the integrity of this gradient has a central role in regulated insulin production and secretion, maintenance of ER function and beta-cell survival.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We have previously demonstrated loss of beta-cell SERCA2b expression under diabetic conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>To define the mechanisms underlying this, INS-1 cells and rat islets were treated with the proinflammatory cytokine interleukin-1beta (IL-1beta) combined with or without cycloheximide or actinomycin D. IL-1beta treatment led to increased inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) gene and protein expression, which occurred concurrently with the activation of AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>IL-1beta led to decreased SERCA2b mRNA and protein expression, whereas time-course experiments revealed a reduction in protein half-life with no change in mRNA stability.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, SERCA2b protein but not mRNA levels were rescued by treatment with the NOS inhibitor l-NMMA (NG-monomethyl L-arginine), whereas the NO donor SNAP (S-nitroso-N-acetyl-D,L-penicillamine) and the AMPK activator AICAR (5-aminoimidazole-4-carboxamide ribonucleotide) recapitulated the effects of IL-1beta on SERCA2b protein stability.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Similarly, IL-1beta-induced reductions in SERCA2b expression were rescued by pharmacological inhibition of AMPK with compound C or by transduction of a dominant-negative form of AMPK, whereas beta-cell death was prevented in parallel.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Finally, to determine a functional relationship between NO and AMPK signaling and SERCA2b activity, fura-2/AM (fura-2-acetoxymethylester)</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ca(2+) imaging experiments were performed in INS-1 cells.</Gene>

<Gene>Consistent with observed changes in SERCA2b expression, IL-1beta, SNAP and AICAR increased cytosolic Ca(2+) and decreased ER Ca(2+) levels, suggesting congruent modulation of SERCA activity under these conditions.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In aggregate, these results show that SERCA2b protein stability is decreased under inflammatory conditions through NO- and AMPK-dependent pathways and provide novel insight into pathways leading to altered beta-cell calcium homeostasis and reduced beta-cell survival in diabetes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Two Distinct Cdc2 Pools Regulate Cell Cycle Progression and the DNA Damage Response in the Fission Yeast S.pombe.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The activity of Cdc2 (CDK1) kinase, which coordinates cell cycle progression and DNA break repair, is blocked upon its phosphorylation at tyrosine 15 (Y15) by Wee1 kinase in the presence of DNA damage.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>How Cdc2 can support DNA repair whilst being inactivated by the DNA damage checkpoint remains to be explained.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Human CDK1 is phosphorylated by Myt1 kinase at threonine 14 (T14) close to its ATP binding site before being modified at threonine 161 (T167Sp) in its T-loop by the CDK-activating kinase (CAK).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>While modification of T161 promotes association with the cyclin partner, phosphorylation of T14 inhibits the CDK1-cyclin complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This inhibition is further enforced by the modification of Y15 by Wee1 in the presence of DNA lesions.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In S.pombe, the dominant inhibition of Cdc2 is provided by the phosphorylation of Y15 and only a small amount of Cdc2 is modified at T14 when cells are in S phase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Unlike human cells, both inhibitory modifications are executed by Wee1.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Using the novel IEFPT technology, which combines isoelectric focusing (IEF) with Phos-tag SDS electrophoresis (PT), we report here that S.pombe Cdc2 kinase exists in seven forms.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>While five forms are phosphorylated, two species are not.</Gene>
<Gene>Four phospho-forms associate with cyclin B (Cdc13) of which only two are modified at Y15 by Wee1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, only one Y15-modified species carries also the T14 modification.</Gene>
<Gene>The fifth phospho-form has a low affinity for cyclin B and is neither Y15 nor T14 modified.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The two unphosphorylated forms may contribute directly to the DNA damage response as only they associate with the DNA damage checkpoint kinase Chk1.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Interestingly, cyclin B is also present in the unphosphorylated pool.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We also show that the G146D mutation in Cdc2.1w, which renders Cdc2 insensitive to Wee1 inhibition, is aberrantly modified in a Wee1-dependent manner.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In conclusion, our work adds support to the idea that two distinct Cdc2 pools regulate cell cycle progression and the response to DNA damage.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Serum levels of chemokines CCL4 and CCL5 in cirrhotic patients indicate the presence of hepatocellular carcinoma.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND: Most hepatocellular carcinomas (HCCs) are diagnosed at an advanced stage.</Gene>
<Gene>The prognostic value of serum tumour markers alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and des-gamma-carboxy prothrombin (DCP) is limited.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The aim of our study is to evaluate the diagnostic value of serum growth factors, apoptotic and inflammatory mediators of cirrhotic patients with and without HCC.</Gene>
<Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>Serum samples were collected from cirrhotic potential liver transplant patients (LTx) with (n=61) and without HCC (n=78) as well as from healthy controls (HCs; n=39).</Gene>

<Gene>Serum concentrations of CRP, neopterin and IL-6 as markers of inflammation and thrombopoietin (TPO), GCSF, FGF basic and VEGF, HMGB1, CK-18 (M65) and CK18 fragment (M30) and a panel of proinflammatory chemokines (CCL2, CCL3, CCL4, CCL5, CXCL5 and IL-8) were measured.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Chi square, Fisher exact, Mann-Whitney U-tests, ROC curve analysis and forward stepwise logistic regression analyses were applied.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>
<Gene>Patients with HCC had higher serum TPO and chemokines (P   <0.001 for TPO, CCL4, CCL5 and CXCL5) and lower CCL2 (P=0.008) levels than cirrhotic patients without HCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Multivariate forward stepwise regression analysis for significant parameters showed that among the studied parameters CCL4 and CCL5 (P=0.001) are diagnostic markers of HCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Serum levels of TPO and chemokines were lower, whereas M30 was significantly higher in cirrhotic patients than in HCs.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS: High serum levels of inflammatory chemokines such as CCL4 and CCL5 in the serum of cirrhotic patients indicate the presence of HCC.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hedgehog signaling mediates woven bone formation and vascularization during stress fracture healing.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hedgehog (Hh) signaling is critical in developmental osteogenesis, and recent studies suggest it may also play a role in regulating osteogenic gene expression in the post-natal setting.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, there is a void of studies directly assessing the effect of Hh inhibition on post-natal osteogenesis.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>This study utilized a cyclic loading-induced ulnar stress fracture model to evaluate the hypothesis that Hh signaling contributes to osteogenesis and angiogenesis during stress fracture healing.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Immediately prior to loading, adult rats were given GDC-0449 (Vismodegib - a selective Hh pathway inhibitor; 50mg/kg orally twice daily), or vehicle.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Hh signaling was upregulated in response to stress fracture at 3 days (Ptch1, Gli1 expression), and was markedly inhibited by GDC-0449 at 1 day and 3 days in the loaded and non-loaded ulnae.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>GDC-0449 did not affect Hh ligand expression (Shh, Ihh, Dhh) at 1 day, but decreased Shh expression by 37% at 3 days.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>GDC-0449 decreased woven bone volume (-37%) and mineral density (-17%) at 7 days.</Gene>
<Gene>Dynamic histomorphometry revealed that the 7 day callus was composed predominantly of woven bone in both groups.</Gene>

<Gene>The observed reduction in woven bone occurred concomitantly with decreased expression of Alpl and Ibsp, but was not associated with differences in early cellular proliferation (as determined by callus PCNA staining at 3 days), osteoblastic differentiation (Osx expression at 1 day and 3 days), chondrogenic gene expression (Acan, Sox9, and Col2alpha1 expression at 1 day and 3 days), or bone resorption metrics (callus TRAP staining at 3 days, Rankl and Opg expression at 1 day and 3 days).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To evaluate angiogenesis, vWF immunohistochemistry showed that GDC-0449 reduced fracture callus blood vessel density by 55% at 3 days, which was associated with increased Hif1alpha gene expression (+30%).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Dynamic histomorphometric analysis demonstrated that GDC-0449 also inhibited lamellar bone formation.</Gene>
