text: <Gene>In this study, we therefore investigated the actions of LPS prepared from different strains of Escherichia coli on platelet function, the underlying signalling mechanisms, and the potential role of TLR4 in orchestrating these.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>We report that LPS increased the aggregation of washed platelets stimulated by thromboxane (U46619) or GPVI collagen receptor agonists, effects that were prevented by a TLR4 antagonist.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Associated with this, LPS enhanced fibrinogen binding, P-selectin exposure and reactive oxygen species (ROS) release.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Increase of ROS was found to be important for the actions of LPS on platelets, since these were inhibited in the presence of superoxide dismutase or catalase.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The effects of LPS were associated with phosphorylation of Akt, ERK1/2 and PLA2 in stimulated platelets, and inhibitors of PI3-kinase, Akt and ERK1/2 reduced significantly LPS enhanced platelet function and associated ROS production.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Furthermore, inhibition of platelet cyclooxygenase or the thromboxane receptor, revealed an important role for thromboxane A2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We therefore conclude that LPS increases human platelet activation through a TLR4-PI3K-Akt-ERK1/2-PLA2 -dependent pathway that is dependent on ROS and TXA2 formation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Regulation of TLR4 expression mediates the attenuating effect of erythropoietin on inflammation and myocardial fibrosis in rat heart.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The mechanism underlying the anti-inflammatory or antifibrotic activity of erythropoietin (EPO) in myocardial fibrosis (MF) remains elusive.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In the current study, abdominal aortic constriction (AAC) was performed on rats and EPO and/or Toll-like receptor (TLR)4 were overexpressed in rat hearts through intramyocardial administration of lentivirus expressing the EPO and TLR4 genes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Hematoxylin and eosin staining and Masson's trichrome staining were performed on tissue sections from rat hearts for histopathological examination.</Gene>
<Gene>ELISA was used to determine the levels of inflammatory mediators in serum.</Gene>

<Gene>Gene expression levels were determined by quantitative polymerase chain reaction analysis and protein expression levels were determined by western blot analysis and immunofluorescence staining.</Gene>

<Gene>The results indicated that EPO overexpression improved MF in rat hearts, by inhibiting the release of transforming growth factor (TGF)-beta1, tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha, interleukin (IL)-6, IL-1beta, IL-17A, matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-9 and MMP-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, EPO overexpression suppressed the expression of TLR4, while promoting phosphoinositide 3-kinase (PI3K) and phosphorylated AKT serine/threonine kinase 1 (Akt) expression levels.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, the beneficial effects of EPO were attenuated by overexpression of TLR4.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, inhibition of PI3K/Akt signaling activity by treatment with LY294002 markedly reversed the protective effect of EPO on the AAC-induced MF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Taken together, the present study demonstrated that EPO may have a critical role against MF by activating PI3K/Akt signaling and by downregulating TLR4 expression, thereby inhibiting the release of TGF-beta1, TNF-alpha, IL-6, IL-1beta, IL-17A, MMP-9 and MMP-2.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>These findings suggest that the PI3K/Akt/TLR4 signaling pathway is associated with the anti-inflammatory effects of EPO and may play a role in attenuating AAC-induced MF.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Ca2+-dependent endoplasmic reticulum stress correlation with astrogliosis involves upregulation of KCa3.1 and inhibition of AKT/mTOR signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>The intermediate-conductance Ca2+-activated K+ channel KCa3.1 was recently shown to control the phenotype switch of reactive astrogliosis (RA) in Alzheimer's disease (AD).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>
<Gene>KCa3.1 channels expression and cell localization in the brains of AD patients and APP/PS1 mice model were measured by immunoblotting and immunostaining.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>APP/PS1 mice and KCa3.1-/-/APP/PS1 mice were subjected to Morris water maze test to evaluate the spatial memory deficits.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Glia activation and neuron loss was measured by immunostaining.</Gene>
<Gene>Fluo-4AM was used to measure cytosolic Ca2+</Gene>
<Gene>level in beta-amyloid (Abeta) induced reactive astrocytes in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>KCa3.1 expression was markedly associated with endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress and unfolded protein response (UPR) in both Abeta-stimulated primary astrocytes and brain lysates of AD patients and APP/PS1 AD mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>The KCa3.1 channel was shown to regulate store-operated Ca2+ entry (SOCE) through an interaction with the Ca2+ channel Orai1 in primary astrocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Gene deletion or pharmacological blockade of KCa3.1 protected against SOCE-induced Ca2+ overload and ER stress via the protein kinase B (AKT) signaling pathway in astrocytes.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Importantly, gene deletion or blockade of KCa3.1 restored AKT/mechanistic target of rapamycin signaling both in vivo and in vitro.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Consistent with these in vitro data, expression levels of the ER stress markers 78-kDa glucose-regulated protein and CCAAT/enhancer-binding protein homologous protein, as well as that of the RA marker glial fibrillary acidic protein were increased in APP/PS1 AD mouse model.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Elimination of KCa3.1 in KCa3.1-/-/APP/PS1 mice corrected these abnormal responses.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Moreover, glial activation and neuroinflammation were attenuated in the hippocampi of KCa3.1-/-/APP/PS1 mice, as compared with APP/PS1 mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, memory deficits and neuronal loss in APP/PS1 mice were reversed in KCa3.1-/-/APP/PS1 mice.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>

<Gene>Overall, these results suggest that KCa3.1 is involved in the regulation of Ca2+ homeostasis in astrocytes and attenuation of the UPR and ER stress, thus contributing to memory deficits and neuronal loss.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Galangin Inhibits Thrombin-Induced MMP-9 Expression in SK-N-SH Cells via Protein Kinase-Dependent NF-kappaB Phosphorylation.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Galangin, a member of the flavonol compounds of the flavonoids, could exert anti-inflammatory effects in various cell types.</Gene>
<Gene>It has been used for the treatment of arthritis, airway inflammation, stroke, and cognitive impairment.</Gene>

<Gene>Thrombin, one of the regulators of matrix metalloproteinase (MMPs), has been known as a vital factor of physiological and pathological processes, including cell migration, the blood-brain barrier breakdown, brain edema formation, neuroinflammation, and neuronal death.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>MMP-9 especially may contribute to neurodegenerative diseases.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>However, the effect of galangin in combating thrombin-induced MMP-9 expression is not well understood in neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, we attempted to explore the molecular mechanisms by which galangin inhibited MMP-9 expression and cell migration induced by thrombin in SK-N-SH cells (a human neuroblastoma cell line).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Gelatin zymography, western blot, real-time PCR, and cell migration assay were used to elucidate the inhibitory effects of galangin on the thrmbin-mediated responses.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>The results showed that galangin markedly attenuated the thrombin-stimulated phosphorylation of proto-oncogene tyrosine-protein kinase (c-Src), proline-rich tyrosine kinase 2 (Pyk2), protein kinase C (PKC)alpha/beta/delta, protein kinase B (Akt), mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR), p42/p44 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK), Jun amino-terminal kinases (JNK)1/2, p38 MAPK, forkhead box protein O1 (FoxO1), p65, and c-Jun and suppressed MMP-9 expression and cell migration in SK-N-SH cells.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Our results concluded that galangin blocked the thrombin-induced MMP-9 expression in SK-N-SH cells via inhibiting c-Src, Pyk2, PKCalpha/betaII/delta, Akt, mTOR, p42/p44 MAPK, JNK1/2, p38 MAPK, FoxO1, c-Jun, and p65 phosphorylation and ultimately attenuated cell migration.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Therefore, galangin may be a potential candidate for the management of brain inflammatory diseases.</Gene>
<Gene>Model based on GA and DNN for prediction of mRNA-Smad7 expression regulated by miRNAs in breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>BACKGROUND:</Gene>
<Gene>The Smad7 protein is negative regulator of the TGF-beta signaling pathway, which is upregulated in patients with breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>miRNAs regulate proteins expressions by arresting or degrading the mRNAs.</Gene>

<Gene>The purpose of this work is to identify a miRNAs profile that regulates the expression of the mRNA coding for Smad7 in breast cancer using the data from patients with breast cancer obtained from the Cancer Genome Atlas Project.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>METHODS:</Gene>

<Gene>We develop an automatic search method based on genetic algorithms to find a predictive model based on deep neural networks (DNN) which fit the set of biological data and apply the Olden algorithm to identify the relative importance of each miRNAs.</Gene>
<Gene>RESULTS:</Gene>

<Gene>A computational model of non-linear regression is shown, based on deep neural networks that predict the regulation given by the miRNA target transcripts mRNA coding for Smad7 protein in patients with breast cancer, with R2 of 0.99 is shown and MSE of 0.00001.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, the model is validated with the results in vivo and in vitro experiments reported in the literature.</Gene>

<Gene>The set of miRNAs hsa-mir-146a, hsa-mir-93, hsa-mir-375, hsa-mir-205, hsa-mir-15a, hsa-mir-21, hsa-mir-20a, hsa-mir-503, hsa-mir-29c, hsa-mir-497, hsa-mir-107, hsa-mir-125a, hsa-mir-200c, hsa-mir-212, hsa-mir-429, hsa-mir-34a, hsa-let-7c, hsa-mir-92b, hsa-mir-33a, hsa-mir-15b, hsa-mir-224, hsa-mir-185 and hsa-mir-10b integrate a profile that critically regulates the expression of the mRNA coding for Smad7 in breast cancer.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>CONCLUSIONS:</Gene>
<Gene>We developed a genetic algorithm to select best features as DNN inputs (miRNAs).</Gene>
<Gene>The genetic algorithm also builds the best DNN architecture by optimizing the parameters.</Gene>

<Gene>Although the confirmation of the results by laboratory experiments has not occurred, the results allow suggesting that miRNAs profile could be used as biomarkers or targets in targeted therapies.</Gene>
<Gene>The Drosophila fussel gene is required for bitter gustatory neuron differentiation acting within an Rpd3 dependent chromatin modifying complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Members of the Ski/Sno protein family are classified as proto-oncogenes and act as negative regulators of the TGF-ss/BMP-pathways in vertebrates and invertebrates.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>A newly identified member of this protein family is fussel (fuss), the Drosophila homologue of the human functional Smad suppressing elements (fussel-15 and fussel-18).</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We and others have shown that Fuss interacts with SMAD4 and that overexpression leads to a strong inhibition of Dpp signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>However, to be able to characterize the endogenous Fuss function in Drosophila melanogaster, we have generated a number of state of the art tools including anti-Fuss antibodies, specific fuss-Gal4 lines and fuss mutant fly lines via the CRISPR/Cas9 system.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Fuss is a predominantly nuclear, postmitotic protein, mainly expressed in interneurons and fuss mutants are fully viable without any obvious developmental phenotype.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>To identify potential target genes or cells affected in fuss mutants, we conducted targeted DamID experiments in adult flies, which revealed the function of fuss in bitter gustatory neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>We fully characterized fuss expression in the adult proboscis and by using food choice assays we were able to show that fuss mutants display defects in detecting bitter compounds.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>This correlated with a reduction of gustatory receptor gene expression (Gr33a, Gr66a, Gr93a) providing a molecular link to the behavioral phenotype.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>In addition, Fuss interacts with Rpd3, and downregulation of rpd3 in gustatory neurons phenocopies the loss of Fuss expression.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Surprisingly, there is no colocalization of Fuss with phosphorylated Mad in the larval central nervous system, excluding a direct involvement of Fuss in Dpp/BMP signaling.</Gene>
label: Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene
Gene

text: <Gene>Here we provide a first and exciting link of Fuss function in gustatory bitter neurons.</Gene>
label: Gene

text: <Gene>Although gustatory receptors have been well characterized, little is known regarding the differentiation and maturation of gustatory neurons.</Gene>
<Gene>This work therefore reveals Fuss as a pivotal element for the proper differentiation of bitter gustatory neurons acting within a chromatin modifying complex.</Gene>
label: Gene
